All,
Please be advised that IIT will be performing a planned network maintenance on the following date and time:

Tuesday November 13th 2018 from 6:00pm to 11:59pm

This maintenance is necessary to perform upgrades to our network infrastructure. We anticipate this scheduled outage will take approximately 4 to 6 hrs. to complete. During this maintenance window you may experience brief outages where servers, business applications, and or files may not be accessible both internally and externally. To ensure uptime and stability of our platform, we are performing this upgrade shortly after close of business so we can maximize our efforts to ensure business operations will not be impacted when we open the next day.

If you have any questions or concerns please contact the Service Desk team at x0130.

We thank you in advance for your attention and understanding.

Using Microsoft Outlook Calendar for Appointments

Outlook Calendar is the tool used by all MOS staff to schedule appointments and any other Museum business that requires your guest to check in at the Information Desk. When scheduling an appointment or meeting, be sure to always invite the Information Desk so that we know to expect your guests when they arrive.


Directions to follow when notifying the Information Desk of an appointment.
1. In Outlook Calendar, select New Meeting
2. In the [To] field, select Shared_Infodesk from the address book (NOT infodesk@mos.org)
3. In the [Subject] field, enter your guest's name and who they are here to see
4. In the [Location] field, enter where the appointment/meeting will take place
5. REQUIRED: In the notes field, enter instructions for the Information Desk staff/volunteer: who to call (with extension) when your guest arrives, parking validation, and any other relevant information.
6. Send

PLEASE NOTE: THE INFORMATION DESK CALENDAR IS FOR APPOINTMENTS AND MEETINGS ONLY. IF YOU HAVE FRIENDS OR FAMILY VISITING THE MUSEUM, PLEASE ARRANGE TO MEET THEM IN THE LOBBY.

You have several options for granting your guests access into the Museum once you meet them in the lobby:
•Use your MOS Membership card at the main lobby entrance (you must be present)
•Use your HR-issued paper passes at the main lobby entrance.

If you know that you will not be in the building when your guests arrive:
•Use your MOS membership electronic passes – either online (using an email confirmation) or in person at the box office in advance of their visit. Please reach out if you need guidance on how this process works.
•Leave your HR-issued paper passes at will call, located at the box office, clearly marked with your guest’s name and the date of their visit.

PLEASE NOTE: INFORMATION DESK STAFF CANNOT AUTHORIZE FREE EXHIBIT HALLS ADMISSION FOR FRIENDS OR FAMILY.

If you have any questions, contact Erika Di Sciascio, Assistant Manager of Science Central and the Information Desk: edsciascio@mos.org or x0126
docs.messageSubject: Using Microsoft Outlook Calendar for Appointments

Tomorrow, Friday 11/9, is the premier of our newest IMAX Film - Volcanoes: The Fire of Creation. The star of the film, photographer Carsten Peter, will be at the Museum tomorrow. He will be speaking at the Current Science & Technology Stage at 12:30 - stop by and check it out!

About the film:
Volcanoes: The Fires of Creation is a tale of science, culture, and thrilling adventure! Earth is a planet born of fire. For billions of years, volcanoes have helped create the world we know. From the continents to the air we breathe and even life itself, all have their origins in fire. With over 500 active volcanoes, Earth is bursting at the seams with these forces of mass construction. The story of volcanoes is the story of the planet’s creation, and the story of us.

With intrepid explorer Carsten Peter as your guide, dodge boulders at the edge of an active volcano in Indonesia, descend to a lava lake in Vanuatu, and visit the incredible mineral deposit fields in Ethiopia. Travel across the globe to see the archaeological ghost town of Pompeii and witness the devastating effects of the recent Kilauea eruption in Hawaii. You'll be on the edge of your seat as you discover molten worlds and exploding craters in this adrenaline-filled, immersive experience that only IMAX®/Giant Screen films can provide!

HOLIDAY GIFT WRAPPING TO BENEFIT LOW INCOME FAMILIES

Come and Wrap presents this Holiday season at CambridgeSide Galleria to benefit A Bed For Every Child Program. All funds raised by this wonderful volunteer activity will be used to purchase brand new twin beds for unprivileged kids throughout Massachusetts.

The money raised at the giftwrap booth will go directly to A Bed for Every Child Initiative. This initiative provides beds to low income families through Massachusetts. Last year, we were able to raise $10,265.50 enough to purchase 41 beds.

With your help we will make this possible again!

If you are ready to select a volunteer date, please visit:
http://signup.com/go/TPExOmn

If you have any questions, please reach out to Melissa Rousselle at mrousselle@mos.org

Thank you!
Melissa

docs.messageBody:
Internal Job Postings



Paid staff positions will be posted internally for five (5) business days to give internal applicants priority during the recruitment process, in support of the Museum’s Affirmative Action Plan. All positions accepting internal applications can be found on our Internal Employment Opportunities page.

To apply, simply click on the position title below and complete the online application. If internal staff apply after the position is posted externally, they will not be considered as a candidate because they did not apply during the internal posting period.

At this time, the below listings are actively accepting internal applications:

Director, Relationship Development


The Director, Relationship Development will be responsible for managing special volunteer leadership initiatives, and together with senior Advancement leadership and fundraising teams, set annual Advancement board development goals up to and including collaborative creation, execution, and follow-up on donor engagement and recruitment initiatives. This position will work closely with the SVP to advance the volunteer engagement agenda by developing and implementing a strategic engagement plan that serves fundraising goals across the Museum. The primary functions will be management of special board initiatives, with a focus on cross-Division advancement projects and volunteer leadership management. The Director will meet individually and collectively with leading donors to deepen their involvement with the Museum. The Director will partner with the President's Senior Management Team and the President's Office to strategically shape the agendas, materials and presentations volunteer leadership meetings. Together with the President's Office, specifically engage in the board nomination strategy process. This role will provide administrative support for select Committees and Task Forces, as needed.


Deadline for Internal Applicants: Thursday, November 1, 2018

This position is full-time, 40 hours/week, Monday-Friday, with some weekend, evening and travel required.
docs.messageSubject: Internal Job Listing - Director, Relationship Deve

Effective December 1, 2018, the Museum will no longer be able to provide staff with a pre-tax MBTA or commuter rail pass. The new Internal Revenue Code, Section 512(a)(7) has eliminated the pre-tax offering that companies can make.

If you were thinking of ordering a pass you can do so online here: https://commerce.mbta.com/Passes/
If you choose to order your pass online, please be aware that the MBTA ships out passes 7-10 business days before the pass is activated on the first of the month. You can also sign up for the MBTA mobile app. Additional information can be found here: https://www.mbta.com/fares/commuter-rail-fares#how-to-pay

We are truly sorry for the inconvenience.

In April 2017, the Museum installed four Level 2 EV Charging Stations on the fourth floor of the garage to accommodate Museum guests and staff who drive EV vehicles. Due to the high demand, an additional Level 1 EV parking spots were installed to help accommodate Museum staff and guests who will be parking in the garage during the day.

We ask the Museum Staff and Volunteers make an effort to park in one of the Level 1 EV parking spots, which vehicles can be left in all day. Should you park in a Level 2 EV parking spot, we ask that your vehicle be moved upon completion of charging. This will help maximize usage of the EV charging stations and ensure availability for both Museum staff and guests.

Please contact Mike Sullivan at x4495 if you have any questions.
docs.messageSubject: EV Charging on the 4th Floor of the Garage

Hi Everyone,

We are thrilled to announce the headliner for our upcoming Winter/Spring 2019 SubSpace season of adult programming! Jonathan Van Ness, Emmy-winning star of Netflix’s “Queer Eye”, will come to the Museum for one night only with his popular podcast, Getting Curious with Jonathan Van Ness, on Wednesday, February 27th, 2019. This will be a live recording which will become a future episode of the podcast, and feature Jonathan exploring a science or health related topic with a special guest expert. The show will take place in the Blue Wing, with seating on the terrace level, and standing room on level 1 and 2.

The show is being announced and tickets go live today, Wednesday, 9/19 at 9:00AM, and we will begin rolling out to the public and press that hour, with JVN making the exciting announcement shortly after.

We wanted to share this exciting news with staff ahead of time. Tickets are limited and we are unable to hold or comp any tickets, so we urge interested folks to purchase sooner than later! GSE's will be made available shortly as well for those interested.

Once again, we are thrilled to be bringing this important voice of today's culture to the Museum, and hope you all share that excitement!

-James

A RENO FAMILY FOUNDATION SYMPOSIUM—
Getting Curious with Jonathan Van Ness
Wednesday, February 27, 2019; 7:30pm
Blue Wing
Tickets: Seated- $35; Standing-$25; On sale Wednesday, September 19th at 9:00AM EST

Television personality, Emmy winner, and hairstylist to the stars, Jonathan Van Ness comes to the Museum of Science for one night only! Enjoy a live taping of his popular podcast Getting Curious with Jonathan Van Ness.

Growing up, Jonathan had a ravenous curiosity for learning new stuff (like his obsession with Finland) that defied the more common pursuits of midwestern boys. In Getting Curious: The Podcast, Jonathan’s curiosity marches on, exploring topics like the Armenian Genocide, Gravitational waves and the Romanovs to lighter fare featuring Margaret Cho or Denise Bidot on what it’s like being a model in fashion today. Each episode focuses on a different topic of interest, welcoming an expert in that particular field to satiate everyone’s curiosity. Jonathan has been turning out episodes since 2015, you will find Getting Curious on Earwolf, Libsyn or the Apple Podcast Store.

Funding provided by the Reno Family Foundation Fund.

Seating and standing room is general admission, so we encourage you to arrive early to guarantee your party is seated together. Doors to the show will open at 7:00 pm.
docs.messageSubject: Jonathan Van Ness- Live at MOS!

docs.messageBody:
This policy applies to all staff at the Museum, whether working on the Museum property or conducting off-site Museum business as it relates to the use of chemicals. This includes all chemicals, including cleaning and maintenance supplies as well as chemicals used for educational purposes.  A Chemical Safety Tip Sheet has been posted on the EH&S  Hub to help summarize the program.


This Chemical Safety Program addresses minimum requirements and guidelines for safe handling of chemicals while addressing regulatory and best practices for chemical purchases, usage, labeling, transporting, storage and waste disposal.


The Chemical Safety Program is located on the EH&S Hub in the category “Program” or follow this direct link: https://bmos.sharepoint.com/EHSDocs/Chemical%20Safety%20Program.pdf


Please don’t hesitate to contact me with your safety questions. And thank you for your continued dedication to making the Museum even safer!


Best regards,


Christina


Christina Dillard | Environmental Health & Safety (EHS) Program Manager X4249 | cdillard@mos.org
docs.messageSubject: Did you see the *new* Chemical Safety Policy?

docs.messageBody:
The 5th floor of the garage will not be available for parking Thursday and Friday (9/13 & 9/14), will be available for parking this weekend, and then shut down again for the next few weeks starting Monday (9/17).

During this time, Museum staff and contract parkers will be asked to park on the 3rd and 4th floors; similar to how we manage large snow events.

But….”There’s no snow (yet?)” you might say – very observant! This is for our “Phase 1” of Garage Repair Projects being executed throughout this fall and next spring.

Over the course of the next months, Contracting Specialists Inc (CSI) will be systematically performing repairs with several crews throughout our garage and exterior facade on a variety of prioritized items to maintain and extend the useful life of the Garage. When the work has to affect parking or garage traffic, like their first phase on the 5th floor which includes concrete repairs and recoating the entire surface in a multi-step process, we will be posting messages like this one. Additional areas will be coned off for the required work locations, staging, and safety requirements where needed, so please obey them. Should you have any questions or concerns, please let me know.
Thanks!
-Jena Boehm x.0145

Mobile Mini Golf
September 13th 11:00am - 3:00pm
Skyline


The Wellness Team is hosting a day of mini golf! Nine holes mini golf will be set up at the Museum! These colorful holes are designed to challenge teams with hills, jumps, bumps, and loops! Take some time out of your day to de-stress, move around, and have fun with your colleagues.

You will receive all materials needed at the event, including score cards. A leader board will be kept so that you can see how your team is doing throughout the day.

Teams have the opportunity to earn BONUS POINTS that deduct from your final team score by:



  • Create a fun team name

  • Having multi-department teammates

  • Having themed or matching outfits


Important notes: You will sign up for a tee time in groups of 5 (can be less, but no more than 5). A 9 hole circuit will take about 40-45 minutes for a team of 5. The tee times only allow for 1 team per slot, if you do not see a time slot it is because it has been taken.



TO SIGN UP CLICK HERE!

Please plan accordingly and do not use the door on the Cambridgeside/Riverside except for emergency egress only. Signs will be posted on the garage stairwells and on the exit door.

Comment Card Report 7/1/18-7/31/18 Part 1

“Disappointed that the Dora exhibit is ending soon! So many of the sections are a favorite with my 2.5 year old and when we say we are going to MOS, something in that room is what she says she'd like to do, the slide, planting the flowers, playing with the balls or checking the animals. The variety of little kid sized activities in there is awesome. Some sections don't have much at eye level for the toddler/pre-K set, though we do love many of the other areas of the MOS which have little kid oriented elements, like the ""sewer"" she can crawl in under the exhibit down on the bottom floor. The baby chicks are a great level for littles and others and the height chart with magnets nearby it is good access for shorties and grownups too. Would very much appreciate some more permanent or visiting areas which have interactive spaces workable for toddlers/pre-K.”

“Hi! Just wanted to inform you of a bug on your webpage. On at least (assuming you recycle your javascipt) your ""Exhibits"" page (Home>Explore>Exhibits), your dialogue boxes, upon hovering, go full blown Tigger and keep bouncing. This is on Safari for MacOS Vs. 11.1. Thanks!”

“Today we had the pleasure of going to the Discovery Center and working with the wonderful staff there. In particular, Elizabeth worked with our 4 year old son to put together an ostrich skeleton. We were extremely impressed with how she managed the different kids that came and left while our son stayed put. He can be very shy and is petite so he can easily be overshadowed by other children. She was very careful to include him in everything and listened to everything he said, no matter how quiet. He will have many great memories thanks to her!”

“So sad to see the Dora exhibit closing, we LOVE IT! Please ass more younger kid playspaces, it's a nice change to Discovery Center & especially useful for stay at home families with kids who don't go to school yet to do in the week. We have come more to MOS because of it.”

“Came down for Night of Sky at Planetarium due to website looked like you were shown a lot of animals and person shaped in sky and presenter just showed 3 things in 45 minutes as a member I was upset.”

“Please please please
1) Bring back the Dora exhibit (we know it leaves July 4th)
2) More exhibits like it for younger kids”

“Love Dora room. Kiddo is only 20 mo. so we don't actually care about Dora. But a place for a toddler to climb and adventure! Yes!”
“More exhibits like the Dora exhibit”

“Bye bye Dora please bring the exhibit back again. Soon.”

“I visited the museum with my son this morning. I tried 5 different hand sanitizer stations and they were all empty. This was between 10 and 10:30 am so there is no way they had all been used up that morning. If you are going to have them out, please keep them filled.”

“We visited the Hayden planetarium today and I had not been there for a number of years”

"Please explain why you're giving the stage of a kid/family museum to this event. https://www.mos.org/public-events/summer-thursdays/drag”

"I was very disappointed to hear about the so called 'Drag Thursdays' now scheduled at your once fine publicly supported institution. Entirely inappropriate and offensive. I will no longer support the MOS.”

"Hello! I recently visited the museum for the first time. It was a great experience. I learned a lot, but left wondering... what becomes of the chicks hatched in the Hall of Human Life's hatchery after their tenure in the exhibit? Thank you”

"Great visit, as usual. A suggestion: Many (not all) exhibits have only US measure units in their explanation text. Consider adding metric equvalents to all museum exhibits."

“My charge (age 5) had an idea for an exhibit while eating lunch: the science and stickiness of grilled cheese!”

“Koby was great! The food court was clean, quick and inviting.
Love this.”

“Hi - I have been a member for several years and, having guests this past week, pulled out my Omni passes to use on our visit. I discovered expiration dates such that it seems that none of these passes are any longer valid. What a disappointment. Retail stores can no longer invalidate gift cards for it was declared a deceptive practice. I ask that you reconsider this practice for the same reason. Such a practice leads me to reconsider my support for MOS. Thanks for considering.”

“Can you please have someone clean the Flying Over The Atomic Landscape exhibit? It is filled with grime in the holes that you’re supposed to put the red/blue/green pegs in to.”

“Math exhibit needs more acknowledgment of African culture and people. All science was stolen from African genius culture that white scientists profit from. That wall of scientists is ALL white people! White scientists owe reparations to African people."

“Been to many museums worldwide. This one was the best! Thanks."

“I've ended our membership with the museum. Our family had been members for about 10 years. I don't believe that drag performances align to the charter of the museum. As such, I will contribute to other entities”

“Toilet in basement men's room won't flush.”

“Hello, I purchased two memberships today during my first visit. I was very disappointed to find that only one of the hand sanitizer dispensers in the entire indoor premises (the one near the stairwell to the Live Animal Center) was working. This was very disappointing, as there are a lot of germs being spread around and one of the exhibits in the Journey to Space event involves putting your hand in a glove. Please fix this going forward.”

“Most staff was very kind and helpful. The conditions of the women's bathroom in the blue wing (2nd and 3rd floor) was disgusting! I was surprised and completely grossed out by the mess and smell in both bathrooms. The cafe needs to be better organized. It was REALLY busy today (due to the rainy weather) and the cafe was chaotic. I have never visited a place and felt so frustrated as I did today. I will NEVER visit the MOS on a rainy weekend again!! I was thinking about becoming a member but I changed my mind today.”
docs.messageSubject: A New Comment Card Report Part 1

docs.messageBody:
Internal Job Postings



Paid staff positions will be posted internally for five (5) business days to give internal applicants priority during the recruitment process, in support of the Museum’s Affirmative Action Plan. All positions accepting internal applications can be found on our Internal Employment Opportunities page.

To apply, simply click on the position title below and complete the online application. If internal staff apply after the position is posted externally, they will not be considered as a candidate because they did not apply during the internal posting period.

At this time, the below listings are actively accepting internal applications:

Manager, Living Collections


The Senior Curator/Manager of the Living Collections Department is responsible for the overall management of the Live Animal Care Center and the Butterfly Garden composed of approximately 140 vertebrate animals and 60 individuals or colonies of invertebrates. The Manager must ensure that all Museum standards, governmental regulations and AZA accreditation standards for live animals and plants are being met or surpassed. The Manager has the final approval of all animals and plants used in programs and exhibits. Working with a full-time staff of nine and part-time staff of six, the Manager must ensure that the living collection is relevant to the Museum mission, species are appropriate for exhibits or programs, that acquisitions and transfers meet all permit requirements and that there are sufficient resources to support the collection. Every five years the Manager must also lead the AZA accreditation process.


Deadline for Internal Applicants: Wednesday, August 8

This position is full-time, 40 hours/week, Tuesday-Saturday and must be available for emergencies
docs.messageSubject: Internal Job Listing - Manager, Living Collections

docs.messageBody:
Comment Card report 7/1/18-7/31/18 Part 3

"I'm a diehard fan of the remnants of the Boston Community Solar System and would love to see it reinstated to its former glory. What would be involved in restoring the planets throughout the city? Please!”

“I went to your website to plan a trip for my visiting grandchildren. I came across your Drag Queen events on Thursdays in the Planetarium. First of all what in heavens names does this have to do with science and secondly what kind of education are you trying to provide to young minds? Sure I cannot bring my grandchildren to the Museum in Thursday’s and avoid this exposure. But if this is where you are investing your dollars and programming, then I will not give one dollar of my money to the museum any day of the week. We have enjoyed bringing our kids and grandkids to the museum over the years. No more!”

“When I bought my membership, I got a temporary card that’s valid for 14 days. However, wouldn’t it be better for it to be 21 days to cover the 3-4 week wait time for the actual card? I understand that we could just go to the box office to receive a temporary 1 day, but what if I didn’t receive the card until the end of the 4th week and went multiple times?”

“Hi what T area are you closest too? Thx”

“I was beyond impressed with a young gentleman who helped us when we were seeing ""dream big"" at 3 PM. He was so accommodating and helped my 4 year old be comfortable in the theater. He is incredibly kind and patient and has excellent skills with children. i am a child psychiatrist so really impressed. Thank you! Please make sure he is recognized. An outstanding employee I apologize I can't recall his name! thank you!”

“mrn was fantastic! We learned so much about Boston from her as opposed to everyone else we have met, despite tours. Absolutely great, glad we came!”

“My family visited the museum. Upon going through the gates at the exhibit hall we had an instance that I need to share with you which was very unpleasant. My 8 year old daughter was standing on the side of me while I was pushing a baby stroller and my husband and son were ahead of us. The employee letting us through did not realize my daughter standing next to me was with us (not sure how because we were all standing together) and they screamed very loudly at my daughter and scared her immensely. I did not think this was necessary at all. I told the employee she was our daughter and while my 8 yo started crying they did not even apologize or say anything at all. Needless to say this ruined our experience and honestly upset my daughter to the point that she was upset about this for days. It really made an impact on her. I am not trying to sound dramatic but I feel this was very unnecessary what happened. I wanted to pass this information on to you. Thank you for your time.”

“Member feedback on frustration at MOS. First on more than one occasion, I have checked out at parking and entered the info and charge card before entering member card and therefore did not get 2 hr free parking. this is because I am an English reader and read top to bottom left to right. the last thing at station is member card at bottom right. could you place a reminder for members to enter member card first? second I have emailed the member email about this after a frustrating experience and did not receive a response. third I was there ayt April vacation in a long line waiting to purchase tics for a long time until a volunteer asked if there were members in line because there was a special short line for members to purchase or pick up tics. A sign would have saved a half hour waiting with young children.”

Hey all, I've got a broken PlayStation 2 on my hands that I have no use for. Not sure what's wrong with it, but it doesn't power on, so it might just be the power supply. If you want to try and fix it, or just use it for parts, it's yours for $15 OBO! Email me @ kkane@mos.org if you're interested in getting your tinker on!
Just a reminder that Summer Courses still needs 2 liter soda bottles. Please call X0435 and we will come and get them, thanks.

The students in my Jr Museum Guides summer course have spent this week learning about all the types of education that happen in our museum and today they are ready to share what they have learned!

We will be having our Activity Fair in the Blue Wing Well from 3-3:45pm this afternoon and everyone is invited to come see the students in action, sharing hands on activities with our visitors. Please join us if you'd like to see the results of the hard work they've been doing this week!

Virtual Walk/Run/Bike


2018 Summer Series Continues!


July 28 – 29


3 mile walk/run & 12 mile bike


 


Our summer series continues with a 3 mile walk/run and a 12 mile bike ride! We hope you enjoyed our June virtual race and are displaying (or wearing) your medals proudly. Our second event in the series pushes you a little bit further. Don’t forget if you’re not able to do this in one fell swoop, you can do this over the course of two days.


 


As a reminder, a virtual race is a race in which you can do on your own time, at your own pace, anywhere you would like.


 


Participants will receive a personalized printable bib to wear while walking, running, or biking and a medal!


 


To participate in our second virtual race all you have to do is:



  1. Sign up HERE by July 26, 2018

  2. Complete 1 mile the weekend of June 28 - 29

  3. Send proof of your distance to wellness@mos.org


How can you send us proof?



  • Screenshot your Heath App (iPhone)

  • Screenshot any other fitness tracking apps you may have (iPhone or otherwise)

  • Take a picture of your FitBit/Garmin/wearable device

  • Take a picture of your treadmill dashboard data


Send those screenshots and any pictures you take of your race to wellness@mos.org!


 


CLICK HERE TO SIGN UP!

All,

Please be advised that IIT will be performing a planned out of band network maintenance on the following date and time:

Tuesday July 10th, 2018 from 8:00pm to 11:59pm

This maintenance is necessary to perform upgrades to our network infrastructure. We anticipate this scheduled outage will take approximately 4 to 6 hrs. to complete. During this maintenance window you may experience brief outages where servers, business applications, and or files may not be accessible both internally and externally. To ensure uptime and stability of our platform, we are performing this upgrade shortly after close of business so we can maximize our efforts to ensure business operations will not be impacted when we open the next day.

If you have any questions or concerns please contact the Service Desk team at x0130.
We thank you in advance for your attention and understanding.

After 2.5 years at the Museum, please join me in wishing Mike Sullivan a fond farewell and the best of luck in his new endeavors! Mike will be using her considerable security experience and talent in his new position as the Industrial Specialist for the Defense Contract Management Agency based in Andover Massachusetts. Over the years, Mike has impacted the Museum in many ways, he has received several Moscar recognitions for exemplary service and has enhanced our departments efforts in countless way! Please join me in wishing Mike all the best in this exciting opportunity.  Mike last day of work will be Tuesday November 20th!

We generated a new Comment Card Report-June 6, 2018-June 30, 2018

“Why did you discontinue the Let's Celebrate 4th of July! Member event? So disappointing!”

“ The museum was fun for myself, my husband and 3 young nieces. However, in your In The Kitchen exhibit, my 5 year old niece unfortunately infested some of the water that was part of the exhibit. She became very ill with diarrhea and dehydration the very next day. I do not think it is wise to have a hands on exhibit that would invite young children to drink the liquids that have been exposed to bacteria and harmful microorganisms from every person that comes into contact with it. These are very young children who will impulsively drink from a paper cup that they often drink from. It’s a very unsafe exhibit which caused my niece to become terribly ill. It should be enclosed so that others do not have the same unfortunate incident.”

"Sometimes the lines to purchase items in the museum gift shop are prohibitively long. Perhaps you might consider adding a temporary cash register station during the times when there are school field trips (end of the school year). Other than that, the museum caters so well to the student population during the crush of end-of-the-year field trips. Thank you so much!”

“Trying to register to give a gift membership. The web page keeps telling me my address is invalid. Help!”

“Just an idea: maybe start an urban garden here at the museum which could be used for education as well as for the cafe/education (https://greencitygrowers.com). Also maybe start composting to use in the garden.”

"As a longtime Museum of Science member and former freelance employee, I object to the policy of having unused passes expire at the end of the membership year. I have paid for them and should have the use of them for as long as my membership is current. This was your policy with paper passes but apparently changed with the introduction of electronic passes. I think the expiration of passes is a disservice to loyal members like me!”

“ James Otis Students really enjoyed the scholarship that allowed them to visit the Museum on June 6th. They learned a lot and had a great time.THANKS!”

“I would like to see an OMNI film on the Northern Lights. Thank you”

“Kobie Garcia, the Cafe Manager in the Museum of Science was so wonderful! We were on a visit with 45 students and our tour company neglected to make lunch reservations to ensure we’d have somewhere to sit together. Kobie arranged for us to have a spot in the reserved area anyway and with a waterfront view to boot!! So accommodating and kind!”

“Please label the cats in the natural Wonder Exhibit.”

“It takes too long to knock them down."

“Please don't have live animals in your exhibits. This is cruel and unnecessary.”

“ Just wanted to say that I live in Joliet Illinois and the lightning bugs have massively increased in the last 2 years in my area.”

“I have a couple of ideas for exhibits. Do you take suggestions of this kind? If so, who should I contact?”

“Hi, we were visting the museum this week and, while in the Red Wing discovering our universe, we noticed a slight typo. There's a place describing radio waves and how they're measured and recorded. On it it mentions the ALMA device located in Atacama, Chile. However, you have it spelled as ALTACAMA, with an L. Probably a slight oversight, but I figured I'd point it out to you.”

"Linda at Omni brought my daughter's lost hat and brought it up to us in the theater. She was so sweet to do that.”

“Loved everything! Except for the live animal exhibits. It's inhumane. All else great!”

“The Space exhibit is fantastic. And I think The Museum of Science should have lots of stuff like it as permanent exhibits. Space content is woefully underrepresented in The Museum and this exhibit not only highlighted that fact but also showed how well it can be done. The rotating simulator wouldn't be necessary, of course, but any of the smaller parts of the exhibit would be great additions.”

“We have SO enjoyed the Dora kid play space! My kids could spend hours in there. Our family would love to see more of those types of things for the younger kiddos at the museum.”

“Please can you put the taco stand back. It makes no sense that there are two stands with burgers and hot dogs. So can you please bring the taco stand back.”

“Roof top garden outside the bee exhibit!”

“More toddler spaces like the Dora exhibit or water area like at the children’s museum.”

Hi friends! We are looking for extra help in the Discovery Center over the next 2 weeks. Sign up for a GSE to come facilitate hands-on activities with children and families. GSEs are available November 6th-15th.

Thanks!
Janna
x0427

Just wanted to let everyone know about some of the newest additions in the Charles River Gallery exhibit. This past week 2 Brown Bullhead catfish, 3 Red-breasted sunfish, and 1 Bluegill were added to the tank. There are also some new pieces of driftwood that provide new territories and hiding places. The fish are now establishing new territories so there's been some interesting behavior to observe!

-Christa
docs.messageSubject: New additions in Charles River Gallery

docs.messageBody:
As of today the 5th floor renovation has been concluded and the 5th floor is again open for staff and guests.

As always, parking on levels 2 and 3 are reserved for our guests.

Now that the 5th floor is open again, staff and volunteers are expected to park on the 4th and 5th floors.

Thank you for your cooperation as we deal with the impact of the garage renovation project.

Now closed- Starting Wednesday morning 10/17 at 8:30am, IIT will be having a yard sale of retired computers. It is mostly PC laptops at this time but we do have a few older 21" iMacs.

The price range is $50 to $125. Everything is first come, first served. There are NO keyboards or mice to go with the iMacs. All of the machines will have a clean install of the OS as if it were a new machine. All of the equipment is older but working and is sold as is. Please keep in mind that these are used machines and will show some wear and tear. Battery life is also something we cannot guarantee.

All sales are final and must leave the museum property after being purchased. You will need to pay by cash or check at the time of the purchase and we cannot hold machines.

So please stop by the 3rd floor on Wednesday after 8:30am and see me. Please email if you have any question prior to the sale.

Thank you!
Allie

The Museum has signed on to Freedom Massachusetts’ efforts to support Yes on 3. As a place of public accommodation, we believe in being inclusive and welcoming to all, and to treat our employees, customers and visitors with dignity and respect. Please see below for a link to their website and our statement of support. If you receive any inquiries regarding this, please direct them to tsperry@mos.org.

https://www.freedommassachusetts.org/nonprofit/

"The Museum of Science endorses Yes on 3 because everyone should have basic protections. As a place of public accommodation, we believe in being inclusive and welcoming to all, and to treat our employees, customers and visitors with dignity and respect. No one should be worried about discrimination or harassment at a restaurant, store, museum or anywhere else. Voting Yes on 3 keeps Massachusetts fair and safe for all.”

The Wellness Team is looking to add some variety and expand our offerings. We want to learn about your interests in wellness and health-related activities. Using this information, we hope to provide wellness offerings that are exciting and relevant to you!


Please take a few minutes to complete this anonymous, voluntary survey.


Information about your participation:



  • This survey should take approximately 10 minutes to complete

  • The survey is optional, and you may skip any questions or stop at any time.

  • Your responses will be anonymous.

  • You must be 18 years older to participate


As a thank you for your time, all participants who submit a survey by the end of the day November 13th  will have the choice to enter a drawing for one of three $50 AMEX gift cards.


 


Please CLICK HERE to access the survey.


 


Thank you in advance for your feedback!


 


If you have any questions about the survey, please contact Lorah Broderick at lbroderick@mos.org. If you have any questions about the Wellness Program in general please contact wellness@mos.org.

We just generated a new comment card report for Sept. 1-Sept. 30, 2018

Comment Card Report 9/1/18-9/30/18--Part 2

"Bring back Mac and cheese in the pasta section my children and now grandchildren and everyone I bring loved the famous science museum cheese its a Museum classic"

"We have been circling your parking garage for 40 minutes with about 30 other cars. One whole level is blocked off for construction, which is understandable. However, there should be a limit on how many cars are allowed in when there are no spaces. Specially when there are frustrated drivers going through a parking garage with kids."

"The whole grain salads on today's salad bar were all awesome! Please have them more often."

"Lots of people eating in the exhibit halls - tons of food in space ship
*unsafe for allergies!"

"I got your email about membership appreciation day this Sunday. Immediately tried to sign up and couldn't and eventually called and was advised it was sold out within 5 minutes of opening--The items I wanted are not available. I feel more like the victim of a bait and switch than an appreciated member. Please don't send anymore emails."

"Hi: I have been a member of your place probably more than 10 years with my kids and previously other years when I was single. I have to say that i enjoyed the musuem a lot ... and now with kids even more. However I want to say how disappointing is your membership appreciation night. I have been trying the complimentary tickets online. The opening was at 11 am . It is 11:05 and there were gone. I understand that is first come first serve, however it sounds unfair for all your members. I am sure that a lot of them are disappointed at this time. Is there any other way that you can give the free tickets, maybe as a lottery ? or Maybe don’t do it at all... I do not like to see after 5 min of the offer: We were unable to add the seats to your cart. There may be insufficient availability Thank you for your consideration.”

“Hello, I went to go see the Beyonce Experience last night, 9/22/2018, and I was extremely disappointed. The word I would use would be bizarre. I had to leave early as it truly made no sense. I was not the only one.”

"I recently attented a showing of Pink Floyd's Dark Side of the Moon laser show at the Charles Hayden Planetarium. Although I overall enjoyed the show, I was particularly impressed by the background projections that take you through mountainscapes, space, and other psychedelic worlds. Out of all the people who went with me to the laser show and that I spoke with after, all agreed that the laser projection itself was kind of cheesy and distracting from the beautiful projections that were going on behind the laser. Laser light showings like this have been around since the 70's and although it was considered impressive then to see a laser show playing with your favorite album, the technology portrayed behind the scenes at the Hayden planetarium far surpasses the technology of the laser itself and makes it look like a screen saver from Windows 95'. I just wanted to give my feedback that I think all who attend the musicly inspired laser shows at the planetarium would like to see the technology of the planetarium itself fully utilized to create vast moving images that give the viewer an almost unlimited view of projection. The laser itself only fills the top middle portion of the theater, while the background imagery filled the entire screen."

"I am from Chester County Pennsylvania and I am still seeing firflies at dusk here in my yard - September 28 th. I have never seen them previously that late in the year."

"Hello. I am currently living Maine . I grew up in Cambridge. I took my daughter here when we were in town for another reason which we are every couple months. We had a late entry but we were told at the desk that she stamped our tickets and we could come back anytime within the next 6 months. Well when i put the tickets in my pocket the stamp smeared and it just looks like two ink smudges on our tickets. I was very disappointed when I saw this . I went to your museum a lot as a kid, I loved it. Field trips as well. It was a huge part of my childhood . To take my daughter back here and explore it with her and just see the same glimmer in her eyes was amazing. Unfortunately we arrived too late for a lot of the shows , the butterfly room or anything and did not get to see all the exhibits but We still payed full price. I would love to bring my daughter back here and explore the museum fully and really make another trip out of it . Was wondering if these tickets were still good to get us back in even though its smudged. I can send you pictures of the tickets if that helps. It was a Child and an Adult Ticket. Thank You for years and years of happiness and memories and look forward to being back there again with my family . Thank You"

“Please consider an exhibit dedicated to the science of human nutrition.”

Last Call for MOScar submissions!


 


The 2017-2018 “MOScars Season” officially ends on September 30th!


What does this mean?


Any MOScar submitted through September 30 is eligible to be nominated for a 2018 trophy! Don't miss the chance to recognize your fellow colleagues for their excellence!


 


What do we need from YOU?


Say thank you to a colleague, volunteer, or intern by September 30th by clicking HERE. Remember, we love thank you’s big and small, now’s your chance to make someone’s day!


 


YOU DID THAT! We have broken our all-time MOScar record! 617 Thank You’s have been given this year with a MOScar. We look forward to celebrating every single one of you at our MOScar award ceremony in early 2019!

Comment Card Report 8/1/18 through 8/31/18-Part 1

"First/basement bathroom is not clean!"

"‘Engineering in a River System’ is a very well designed interactive exhibit. As is the entire Charles River section. Well done. I would be curious about the experience designers.”

“We brought our 13 and 15 year old Finnish grandsons to the Museum. They and I were disappointed in the number of parents who let their smaller children loose to just bang on all the buttons ( since they couldn’t read yet) and take up the time older kids needed to try out the different exhibits. I wish the staff would patrol or post the need for parents to keep track of toddlers and kids who shouldn’t be abusing the exhibit controls. My grandchildren are from Finland and were really astounded by this behavior.”

"Hello! I visited the museum last weekend - it is fantastic!! I just wanted to point out that in the natural science areas, there's a tree leaf matching game... some of the leaves aren't labeled correctly (ex: a red ginko leaf is labeled as an English Hawthorne). Just wanted to let you know so as to make your museum as great as possible!"

"Plaque explaining how often the pendulum knocks over pieces. We wanted to watch it hit a piece but with no info on how it works that couldn't happen."

"Have better postcards. Only two specific to the museum is depressing."

"The guest spoke to a friend whose father suffers from macular degeneration. She brought her father to an Omni show, and perhaps due to the size of the screen and/or the curved surface, he was able to see the film as if he had no visual impairment. He was deeply moved to have such an opportunity. The guest suggested this was something we could promote and hopefully reach more people with this condition."

"While in the dinosaur room, I noticed how none of the exhibits mentioned how these beautiful creatures once possessed feathers. We now know they did, so the exhibit overall lacked a bit of an update."

"Went to the lightning show with my nieces and nephew. People were continuously standing on the red carpet although it was announced multiple times people still stood blocking the children's view. DO NOT PLAN ON COMING BACK."

“While eating in the cafe, the guest saw dirigibles further down the river. He thought it would be a good idea to get dirigibles to fly close to the Museum - for advertising, perhaps, and also to get kids to think about science.”

"On the third floor, in the Weems sculpture exhibit, I believe one of the sculptures is mislabeled. It is labeled ‘Clydesdale Stallion,’ but I'm pretty sure the title is mixed up with the neighboring one. The rest of the info does appear correct."

"Went to the ‘Lightning’ show - disaster! No staff directing crowds, staff person running the show had to continually stop show to ask people to move to designed areas. Worst live show experience, should have more staff to control crowd flow."

"Good day:
My grandson is in one of the Summer programs. I happened to be in the Charles River exhibit by myself when the students arrived. I observed the tutors in charges of the group. They were sitting looking at the children as they ran from exhibit to exhibit with no orientation or direction. As an ex-teacher and principal of an elementary school I recommend the following:
The tutors need to be trained on how to _engage_ the students. They need to be actively involved in provoking questions and structuring an overview of the exhibit.
As to the exhibit itself, it needs some monitoring. For example, the Turbidity exhibit has three tubes for observation, algae, clear water, and one more. The most turbid was the clear water due to the interior condensation leading to an erroneous conclusion that clear water is the most turbid because the Secchi disk is barely visible.
Charles River
-Aquatic insects audio guide not working
-Monitoring the Charles River EPA data is over a year old and some indicators register nothing.”

“Our experience at the museum today is a good example of why we did not renew our membership last year, and why we have stopped recommending the museum as a ‘can't miss’ attraction to our friends who visit the area. As great as the museum is, it seems there is always something that ruins the experience. A special thank you to the custodian in the food court, who was in such a rush to sweep under our table that he literally swept our legs and feet, and then continued to do so EVEN HARDER after we asked them very politely to stop. And another special thank you to the staff at the Information desk who wouldn't take a complaint and said ‘they're separate; go back and complain to them’). We will not be returning to the museum anymore.”

"Why would you spend all the time and money for a museum and have such a poor, unclear website and then have no one to talk to when a call is placed. I planned on visiting and will not longer.Lots to do but not able to plan a day, lack of info due to poor management. I was trying to coordinate a day for a small group but cannot develop any type of syllabus"

“Just want to say that Mia in the little kids Discovery Center was awesome! She went above and beyond all expectations. My kids love her!!!”

“We arrived at the virtual reality ride for our scheduled time, but my daughter started to not feel well due to low blood sugar (she is 10 and type 1 diabetic). Sam was so kind and helpful in allowing us to reschedule and wait until our daughter's blood glucose level was in a safe range after a snack. Thank you!!"

“I want to thank George from security. He helped to find my phone. He was awesome and really helpful. Thank you, George!! You are the best!”

“Please increase the cleaning times in cafe men + women's bathrooms. 4 toilets out of 5 were disgusting when I opened women's stalls. Feces over filled with T/P. Gross. Please increase cleaning to adjust for peak times.”
After an additional week of work and repairs, BOTH ISS Destiny Lab modules are rotating and running normally in the Space exhibit again.
docs.messageSubject: Space Rotating Labs Both Rotating Again

docs.messageBody: ...or know someone who does and is passionate about it? My Mom was, as well, and she assembled a box-full of resource materials that I'd like to find a good home for: from books on basic grammar, to phonics,to simple conversational tools, and everything in-between. I know supporting this cause can be costly (books are expensive!), so I'd like to find a good home for these materials. Mom taught ESL to Polish immigrants, but the books can be applied to any learner of any speaking background and age. Please let me know if you're interested - I'd be thrilled to find someone who could put these resources to good use! - Barbara (bwroblewski@mos.org, x0192)

Virtual Walk/Run/Bike


2018 Summer Series Coming to an end!


August 25 – 26


5 mile walk/run & 20 mile bike


 


Our summer series ends with a 5 mile walk/run and a 20 mile bike ride! Challenge yourself to complete the series, you know you want all three medals to display proudly in your office :). Don’t forget if you’re not able to do this in one fell swoop, you can do this over the course of two days.


 


As a reminder, a virtual race is a race in which you can do on your own time, at your own pace, anywhere you would like.


 


Participants will receive a personalized printable bib to wear while walking, running, or biking and a medal!


 


To participate in our second virtual race all you have to do is:



  1. Sign up HERE by August 23, 2018

  2. Complete distance the weekend of August 25-26

  3. Send proof of your distance to wellness@mos.org


How can you send us proof?



  • Screenshot your Heath App (iPhone)

  • Screenshot any other fitness tracking apps you may have (iPhone or otherwise)

  • Take a picture of your FitBit/Garmin/wearable device

  • Take a picture of your treadmill dashboard data


Send those screenshots and any pictures you take of your race to wellness@mos.org!

docs.messageBody:
**Reminder**
The Blue Wing Escalator Project will start this Sunday night, August 19th, with the set up of the construction barriers, and be out of service through mid-December as part of our efforts to improve the vertical transportation throughout the Museum.

As many of you know our existing Blue Wing escalators utilize outmoded mechanics and technology that require expensive repairs, cause an increase in downtime during peak periods, exhibit higher energy consumption, and are not equipped with modern safety devices.

After an extensive design and bid process, we have partnered with KONE to implement their EcoMod system. With the EcoMod system, we can undertake a complete modernization, replacing all existing components within the surrounding structure and truss with brand new technology, therefore minimizing downtime and visitor impact. The EcoMod system will also eliminate the need for structural modifications to the Blue Wing’s Lower Level and First Floor as a traditional replacement would have required.

Additional EcoMod features include:
•Improved ride and passenger safety through fully synchronized step and handrail movement
•Ensures smooth, constant deceleration improving passenger safety
•Constantly monitors speed, direction, safety status, and other operating parameters to enhance safety and maintenance diagnostics
•Modifications that reduce handrail drag, reducing maintenance downtime

How Will This Impact Museum Day to Day Operations?
•All four escalators will be completed simultaneously in order to minimize disruption to the Visitor Experience.
•The total project will take 16 weeks, spanning from mid to late August to early December. (We currently are targeting Sunday night August 19th thru December 18th)
•Eight foot high barriers will surround the construction areas. (These barriers will affect the pedestrian passage between the escalators on the 1st floor, adjacent to the CS&T stage.)
•Guests will be directed to use the stairwells and elevators with the same signage we currently use during escalator breakdowns and wayfinding will be adjusted to properly direct guests.
•Construction will take place from early morning hours into mid-afternoon, during museum operating hours, and will have the similar sounds of active construction to those of the Yawkey Gallery on the Charles River, Lobby, or Concourse renovations.
•We are working closely with Kone and various Museum Departments with the Museum Wide Calendar to schedule deliveries, off hour work, and the associated impacts.

Thank you in advance for your cooperation as we work to improve the functionality of our vertical transportation within the building. We look forward to working through this construction to provide the museum safe & reliable vertical transportation for the Blue Wing guest experience.
docs.messageSubject: Blue Wing Escalators to begin week of August 19th

This past weekend I rode in the PMC with Team Kermit. Saturday Sturbridge to Bourne. Sunday Bourne to Ptown. For a total of 192miles. Team Kermit raises money for the Jared Branfman Sunflower for life fund.
http://profile.pmc.org/MF0312

In 2004 Jared was diagnosed with Jared was diagnosed with spinal/cranial tumors. In 2004 and 2005 Adam (Jared brother) and Steven (his dad) rode the Pan Mass while Ellen (Jared Mom) and Jared volunteered, Jared in a wheelchair. 2006 was going to be the year that we all rode together. Instead, Ellen, Adam, and Steven rode in Jared's honor and memory along with 15 other dear friends as Team Kermit. They established the Jared Branfman Sunflowers For Life Fund For Pediatric Brain And Spinal Cancer Research at the Jimmy Fund. All the money raised by Team Kermit goes through the PMC and into our fund. It supports research into the type of disease that Jared had and is helping to make the dream of no more cancer a reality. It is a fitting legacy to Jared's wish to help others.

This year I joined Team Kermit. What better year to do it that 2018? In Jewish culture the number 18 has special meaning and is associated with life, in Hebrew Chai (with a hard ch). Numerically, the word consists of the eighth (chet) and tenth (yud) letters of the Hebrew alphabet, adding up to eighteen the number 18.
I am asking you to donate in multiples of 18 to give a life: 18, 36, 54, 78, 90, 108 etc
Join us in our fight to rid the world of this terrible disease so that your children, grandchildren, and great grandchildren never have to hear the word cancer again. By using this link http://profile.pmc.org/MF0312

Thanks

Effective July 5, 2018, the Exhibit Halls prices will increase by $3 to $28 for adults, $24 for seniors, and $23 for children for tickets purchased on the day of visit. The Exhibit Halls combination prices will likewise increase by $3 for same day purchases. This is the first Exhibit Halls price increase in 2 years and still positions the Museum competitively with our peer institutions.

In order to increase advance purchases and provide more price conscious visitors an option, prices will remain at their current levels for those who purchase their tickets at least one day in advance of their visit. Non-school groups, who are always required to purchase their tickets in advance, will receive a $4 discount off of the new prices while school group pricing will remain flat.

Hi everyone,

After 6 years of dedicated service to the Museum of Science, Erica Panacopoulos will be starting a new adventure in her career as a classroom teacher at Kipp Academy Charter School in Lynn, where she will be teaching science to first, second, and third grade students. Her last day at the Museum will be July 12th.

Erica has had many roles at the Museum, including Intern, Fellow and Education Associate in departments such as the Discovery Center, Courses, Overnights, and School & Youth Programs. She has also been instrumental in starting and implementing programs such as BEST (Buddies Exploring Science Together), creating a positive learning environment for our 2nd graders and Volunteers of Eye Opener, and much, much more!

Please join us on Wednesday, July 11 from 2-4 pm in the Gordon Classroom to celebrate Erica’s accomplishments at the Museum and say a fond farewell.

Warmly,

The School & Youth Programs Team

Information Technology is excited to announce the formation of our new service desk team, System Support Services. This is a step towards evolving what was the IT Help Desk into a larger team of first responders to address your various computing and system needs. The team will be led by Tony Farrand, who will be joining the Museum on June 4th as a new manager.


With Tony’s arrival, Amy Gallant and Allie Curtis, both of whom have coordinated the previous Help Desk, will now transition fully to their new positions. Amy has taken on the role of IT Business Analyst, working with departments across the Museum on both process design and system needs, with a focus on Tessitura. Allie serves as our IT Operations and Project Manager, with her primary focus being project management, communications, operational documentation, and vendor and contract management.


The new System Support Services team has many familiar faces, including Norah Alqahtani, John Barbieri, Eric Workman and Jeff Lozeau. You can still reach us via the same channels! You can call x0130, email ithelp@mos.org or submit a request online.

Comment Card Report-October 1, 2018-October 31, 2018--Part 2

“My wife and I came to visit your museum on October 12th. While we were takiing a break we had some difficulty with the self serve vending machines, which your Cafe Manager, Kobie Garcia remedied with prompt and professional skill. His service was greatly appreciated. I just wanted to let you know of his excellent service and hope you know that his extroidinary service really made our day.”

“I strongly suggest you have a large display of evolution of earth and evolution of man!”

“I attended the evening event and it would have been so nice to have a coffee! Can you keep Starbucks open for evening events?”

“I found the Exhibits too elementary and not well coordinated. A person cannot develop an understanding of the subject from them.”

“My girlfriend and I recently came to the museum while in Boston as it was recommended to do so online. After spending an overpriced admission fee we began to explore the facility. We both have been to museums of science in other cities before and greatly enjoyed them but did not at your facility. Nearly everything on display was childish and insulting to anyone other than a child. If it were a children's museum the advertising and representation done by your organization is clearly off. We left after less than an hour in the facility and would definitely not recommend to anyone who is not going with a child. Thank you for a waste of time and money.”

“Hello. I am a long time premiere member and my son has celiac disease which means he can’t eat gluten. I was shocked to find out - after asking a cafeteria manager - that one have no gluten free food options. While I understand that technically the salad bar options are gluten free, they are easily cross contaminated and not sage for those with celiac. Most similar museums and amusement parks now offer gluten free buns, pizza and pasta. I strongly suggest you find a way to offer safe gluten free items to your guests”

“Yesterday was my birthday and my son and I spent the day in Boston. Being that it was so rainy and cold, I bought tickets for the museum and we decided to check it out. We arrived at 3 p.m., and were saddened to see that one of the wings closed within an hour and it appeared that a lot of exhibits were closed. We did not realize that most of the shows were early on in the day and that we would be arriving at the wrong time. I feel that I spent $56 to see a few displays and a snake. I feel it was not at all worth the money spent for less than two hours.”

“As a member, I love getting the monthly email notifications, so I can plan my visits. But I have now received spam about this damn stargazing quiz at least three times. Moreover, I can't see any way to unsubscribe from terrible spam like this without also unsubscribing from notifications of museum calendars. If I have to, I”

“I do not know who to contact about the cams on your roof, but the cam facing east has a wrong time setting, it is 1 hour earlier than it really is. DST does not start for another week. Just so you know, whoever is caring for the cams has made a mistake here. Thank you.”


“Please bring back the quesadilla station in the cafe. I love those quesadillas and I miss them very much. Have a nice day!”


“Hello there. I submitted a comment regarding a recent visit and my experience. We had a very bad experience which affected my daughter immensely due to a member of your staff. I’m very disappointed that no one has even responded with an email at all. I understand that there’s many departments but I would of expected something at least via email by now.”

“I am not finding much information on your website about which exhibits are good for toddlers. Can you tell me what exhibits/activities you have for kids around 2 years of age?”

“Dear Membership Team, Thank you so much for thinking of us and sending four free passes!! It is a very thoughtful and touching gesture!”
docs.messageSubject: A New Comment Card Report Part 2

docs.messageBody:
We just generated a new comment card report from Apr. 23, 2018 to June 5, 2018.
Comment Cards- 4/23/18-6/5/18 Part 1

“The diabetes exhibit incorrectly states that dairy (specifically CHEESE) may help prevent type two diabetes. This is blatantly false.
Secondly, the cancer exhibit neglects in ITS ENTIRETY to address prevention,reversing and curing cancer is DIET. Cancer does not fall from the sky. It is based on a person making perfecting cells. Cells can only be made through GOOD
NUTRITION, and healthy lifestyle choices. Why is this not even touched upon?
Children, in particular, should know they have choices!”

“The museum always makes me starry-eyed.”

“Like, bro, those laws of motion man... there's like... so much gravity to them.”

“I hope whoever read these cards today has a wonderful day! <3”

“The museum is wonderful and so is just about everyone who works there!”

“I still haven’t received the premium membership of 2 even after I directly paid in person for our membership and visit. Please check and send it asap.”

“Please PLEASE look into In Saturn's Rings..!”

“Looking to purchase B & W Alaska photos. Like we did in the 80's ! Is this still available ? Thank You”

“We visited the museum and the experience was awesome EXCEPT purchased 2 items at the store for the grandkids. One, the lava lamp, worked on night then quit. I don't have my receipt but do know spent $46.69 total. Is there anyway can
be reimbursed for the lamp? Lastly loved the mirror maze.. Thank you in
advance”

“While normally I have a stress free and great experience at the Museum of Science, today was different. One of the employees was rude to both me and my brother who is special needs. I do understand that there are many signs around
the butterfly garden that way that you may not touch the butterflies. However,there is not much room in the garden allowing for room to walk around. We were yelled at about touching butterflies, but had only disturbed a couple of plants by moving over for people. The other employees were so nice.

“on 5/3 can't seem to get tickets into cart”

“So you have passes for the Journey to the South Pacific IMAX showing on Sunday evening for members - these were made available at 11AM today. Here it is not even 2PM and I've been informed that they sold out by noon. Wow, thanks a lot.
So if someone is working & in meetings they're out of luck I guess. I don't think I'll be renewing it when it expires at the end of this month.”

“Please consider toilet seat covers. The flush sends a whirlwind of bacteria 10 feet in all directions. Otherwise, I love this Museum."

“I really enjoyed the whole Museum except the Mirror Maze was too small."

“We miss the Weather Exhibit in the electricity wing. Also, my boys miss the running exhibit at the playground."

“More ink in stamps. Darker skin tones hard to see."

“Hello, My family visited the museum this past Monday and had a wonderful time! I wanted to share a really exceptional interaction between my sons (2 and 4yrs) and Carol from the Discovery Room. She was so enthusiastic and answered
all of my sons’ questions showing them all kinds of amazing items. My 4yr old is obsessed with prehistoric sharks and was beyond happy to hold a Megladon tooth and see how big they would have been. When he returned to preschool yesterday he ran up to his teacher to tell her what he saw “I met this really nice lady who made the trip special...” Thank you to Carol who did in fact make our trip special!
:)”

“I recently took my 4 year old for her first trip to the Museum of Science. We had
a wonderful time, but I especially wanted to share how much we enjoyed the temporary Dora & Diego exhibit. We don't watch Dora, but the exhibit was small and perfect for kids her age. There were seats for the adults so we could sit and
observe while the kids had fun - my girl played with other kids and had a wonderful time. It is a small exhibit but we were there for at least an hour. The staff suggested I let you know how much we enjoyed it. Many thanks.”

“Just wondering if the free Omni passes that you get each year with membership ever expire?"

“We had so much fun on our visit to MoS on Friday May 18th and we wanted to say how grateful we were to Carol, one of your amazing Educators that made sure our visit with my little one was great. When we were in the Discovery Area, she reminded us about the Dora and Diego exhibit which sure was a hit with my five year old. Imagine our surprise when Carol popped up at that exhibit after we had
made a stop for lunch in your cafeteria. She was so knowledgeable about all the exhibits and the new ones that will be coming this summer, she sure made us realize it was time to get our Family Membership. See you all this Summer.”

“Years ago I saw a movie at the IMAX theater with some wonderful footage from the Space Shuttle. I believe it was ""The Dream is Alive"" from what I find on the web. Personally, this was the best IMAX movie I had ever seen mainly because it fits that theater format so perfectly. Is there any chance you will bring this back
for a new showing?”
docs.messageSubject: A New Comment Card Report Part 1

docs.messageBody:
If you have ELECTRONIC WASTE please contact me, preferably via email with an estimate of the items you need to dispose. We are collecting in-house generated E-waste only.

The next pick up will be scheduled soon. We will arrange a time for you to bring down to the collection area in the Basement level of the Parking Garage before then.



CRT Recycling, our E-waste recycling vendor, accepts any of the following:



Crt's (monitors/televisions) computers, network servers, large office computer equipment, cpu boxes, laptops, printers, fax machines, cd-roms, dvd-roms, vcr's, audio equipment, video games, disc drives, modems, cards, keyboards, computer mice, electronic wires or plugs, pc speakers, recording, surveillance or camera equipment, digital cameras, cell phones & accessories, lcd products, parts or pieces of computers as well as regulated and non-regulated appliances such as air conditioners, refrigerators, stoves, microwaves, mini-refrigerators and coolers.



We will be collecting items until the designated area becomes full.



Feel free to contact me with any questions.



Thanks,




Yessie x0158

Internal Job Postings



Paid staff positions will be posted internally for five (5) business days to give internal applicants priority during the recruitment process, in support of the Museum’s Affirmative Action Plan. All positions accepting internal applications can be found on our Internal Employment Opportunities page.

To apply, simply click on the position title below and complete the online application. If internal staff apply after the position is posted externally, they will not be considered as a candidate because they did not apply during the internal posting period.

At this time, the below listings are actively accepting internal applications:

Associate Director of Donor Relations


Under the general direction of the Director of Donor Relations, the Associate Director will assist in the development, implementation and management of an institution-wide comprehensive stewardship program that appropriately and consistently promotes interaction with and recognition of donors at all levels. This position's role is to sustain positive and mutually-rewarding relations between the Museum and its donors; partner with development directors to determine strategies for effective stewardship of donors; maintain ongoing and active networking with internal and external constituencies; coordinate recognition events for major gift donors and coordinate various activities for the Museum's leadership and planned giving donor societies. The position reports to the Director of Donor Relations and includes supervisory responsibility for the Donor Relations Officer and one intern per semester.


Deadline for Internal Applicants: Friday, September 14

This position is full-time, 40 hours/week, Monday-Friday.

docs.messageBody:
Good Afternoon,

Just a gentle reminder that we'll be performing our scheduled IT Systems\Network Maintenance work during the Museum Closure on Tuesday 09/04/2018.

What Does This Mean?

During the upgrade on 9/4/18, some Museum IT services will periodically be without connectivity during the hours of 9am and 5pm on that day. Email will continue to function, as that is hosted offsite with Microsoft. Our main website, www.mos.org, will also be up (with appropriate messaging for visitors). The main phone line will have the recording available as well.

What Can I Expect When This Takes Effect?

All internal systems (VPN, Zeus, internal phones, applications, guest wireless, DMZ, and Internet based services, etc.) will periodically be unavailable throughout the course of the day.

What Do I Need To Do?

If you are not going to be in the office on 9/3/18, please close out of all MOS applications and shared files prior to leaving the building this weekend.

As always, if you have any questions or issues, please contact our service desk, System Support Services, at ithelp@mos.org or call x0130.

Thank you,

Angela

Hi everyone,

After 10 years of dedicated service to the Museum of Science, Jay Bernal will be leaving the Museum of Science for new adventures.

Jay has had many roles at the Museum in many departments, including the Discovery Center, Courses, Design Challenges/Tech Studio, Community Outreach/Street Team, Hall of Human Life/Living Lab and School & Youth Programs. He has also been instrumental in leading and mentoring youth through our high school partnerships, Summer Youth Internship program, and much, much more! His passion for youth development, sense of humor, and overall desire to make a positive impact on his community will be sorely missed.

Please join us on Thursday, August 23 from 3:30-5 pm in the ERC to celebrate Jay’s accomplishments at the Museum and say a fond farewell. The celebration will continue at new Lingo after 5 pm!

Warmly,

The School & Youth Programs Team

Tuesday August 14th 2018 from 8:00pm to 11:59pm

This maintenance is necessary to perform upgrades to our network infrastructure. We anticipate this scheduled outage will take approximately 4 to 6 hrs. to complete. During this maintenance window you may experience brief outages where servers, business applications, and or files may not be accessible both internally and externally. To ensure uptime and stability of our platform, we are performing this upgrade shortly after close of business so we can maximize our efforts to ensure business operations will not be impacted when we open the next day.

If you have any questions or concerns please contact the Service Desk team at x0130.

We thank you in advance for your attention and understanding.

6 Week Tai Chi Series


Tuesdays July 17th – August 21st


8:30AM -9:00:00AM


Wicked Smart


Looking for a way to calm your mind, move your body and learn something new this summer? Why not try Tai Chi! Often called “meditation in motion,” this low impact exercise is a great way to stretch and strengthen your muscles and joints while quieting your mind.


Our own Lori Sartre, a member of the Marketing Communications team, has offered to teach a Tai Chi series to staff! Lori has been training in kung fu and tai chi for 25 years. She and her husband have had their own martial arts studio on the South Shore for 18 years.


This 6 part series will be held Tuesdays before the Museum opens from 8:30 - 9am in Wicked Smart. Please wear comfortable clothing and shoes you can easily move in.


Click here to sign up!



(Please note, you can join the class at any time if you are not sure if you're able to attend a future class)

We are happy extend an invitation and offer to all Museum staff and their families and friends to our final performance of Yellow Bird in Space, our theater piece we've premiered as part of our Summer Thursdays series. Join us tomorrow evening, Thursday, August 2 at 7:30pm to catch this innovative and imaginative show before it's gone!

Please email James Wetzel, jwetzel@mos.org, by 12pm tomorrow (Thursday) to reserve your tickets!

SUMMER THURSDAYS: YELLOW BIRD IN SPACE

Conceived and Directed by Jason Slavick
Written by the LAB Ensemble

A clownish maintenance crew finds a magical yellow bird, and a mad chase begins. Racing over land, across the sea, and into space – battling monsters, robots, climate change, and aliens – how far will our heroes go? Take a leap into a world of imagination, with masks, puppets, and gibberish. This adult clown adventure, adapted from the successful 2017 Liars & Believers production at the Boston Center for the Arts, is one small step for comedy; one giant step for… more comedy.

" Pure entertainment ... Utterly charming.

– The Theatre Mirror


" … a delight no matter how old (or young) you happen to be."

– WBUR The ARTery


" … the creativity and ingenuity of this theater troupe is without parallel."

– The White Rhino Report

Almost ten years ago the Museum of Science took a stand against single use plastic bags in the Museum Store based on our experience working with the Charles River Clean Up Boat, and the widespread attention the movement was just beginning to get back then. We immediately started selling Museum of Science branded reusable bags at a great price and offered free compostable bags for retail purchases as well. Fast forward ten years and we have dropped the compostable bags completely from the store(they look like plastic), converted to paper bags for retail purchases, and we will soon have new and improved reusable bags that are even better than the current ones and they reflect our latest brand. Ten years ago we were ahead of the movement, and while it was not without some challenges, we were very pleased with the outcomes.

And now I am writing to let you know we are banning single use plastic straws in the café. Single use plastic straws have been eliminated in most major aquariums and zoos for almost ten years, and now that movement is spreading everywhere else. Essentially plastic straws are the new plastic bags. The reason for this is the overwhelming negative press that all single use plastic is getting worldwide, as the materials are not able to break down naturally, it creates massive amounts of litter everywhere, it kills wildlife, and the fact that microplastics are being found throughout the world’s oceans which is literally changing the world we live in.

Effective immediately we have removed single use plastic straws from the condiment areas in the café. In order to accomplish this we have changed the lid on the fountain soda cup to ones that have an open slot, just like the Starbucks hot coffee lids we have used for years, and we will be supplying similarly designed lids for cold Starbucks drinks as well. We will individually hand out the Starbucks green compostable straws to all guests purchasing a frozen drink, and make these same straws available ,upon request, for Starbucks guests who have purchased a cold beverage where you would be accustomed to using a straw and for which the new lid does not work well. In addition, we will have these same compostable straws available at all point of sale stations (not in view) for any guests that requests a straw for any reason. Lastly, in certain cases it makes sense to have a straw for catered events, and in these scenarios we will use paper straws.

We will add some language to the www.mos.org/accessibility letting guests know they can request a straw from any member of the café staff. And we will ensure café staff are trained to provide these straws on demand if requested. I will also post something on Quark for Museum staff.

Please let me know if you have any questions at all.

Thanks,

Jonathan
docs.messageSubject: No more single use plastic straws in the cafe
