docs.messageBody:
What: Membership dues are increasing -- $5 increase for Basic 2/Premier 2, $10 increase for Basic 5/Premier 5, $20 increase for Basic 8/Premier 8

When: July 1, 2018

Why: We’ve managed to keep dues the same for the past 2 years but as operating costs increase we need to increase dues. The increase is different for different levels to stay calibrated with admission prices. Before increasing dues we looked at pricing at similar organizations, and the Museum of Science membership program is still a great value for people that are likely to visit more than once a year.

Also: Member benefits have not changed – members still get 2 or 4 each of Omni, Planetarium and Exhibit Hall passes with their annual membership, $5 tickets at the Omni, Planetarium, Butterfly Garden, 4-D theater and 360 Simulator, plus discounts in the parking garage, Museum Store and Café. Please be advised that IIT will be performing a planned network maintenance on the following date and time:

Tuesday June 12th 2018 from 6:00pm to 11:59pm

As previously communicated, the Museum, and in particular EiE, received a donation from Dell EMC for a new storage device. This has enabled the Museum to improve how we manage, store and backup much of our unstructured content.

In order to prepare for the final migration of data to the new device we ask that users close out of all shared museum file directories and personal work drives on the night of June 12th before 6pm so that IT can work with Dell EMC and maximize our final migration window. If files and folders are not closed out, IT will close them to ensure that the data is properly migrated to the new device. To avoid losing changes to files please close out of all files and folders promptly before 6pm.

This maintenance is necessary to perform upgrades to our network and system infrastructure. We anticipate this scheduled outage will take approximately 4 to 6 hrs. to complete due to the storage migration of Zeus. During this maintenance window you may experience brief outages where servers, business applications, and or files may not be accessible both internally and externally. To ensure uptime and stability of our platform, we are performing this upgrade shortly after close of business so we can maximize our efforts to ensure business operations will not be impacted when we open the next day.

If you have any questions or concerns please contact the Service Desk team at x0130.

We thank you in advance for your attention and understanding.

With profuse apologies that it has taken so long, Finance is pleased to announce the implementation of a new reporting system to replace Crystal, which, though still functional, has not had up-to-date data since we changed our main Accounting software back in November.



The new reporting tool is called Finance Reports in SSRS, and here’s the quick and dirty:



  • If you had access to Finance Reports in Crystal, you have access to Finance Reports in SSRS.
  • There’s a link to the system on the Accounting Hub page  (Under “On The Web”).
  • There’s a new “All About” on our Hub Page to help you use the system.

This project is still in its early stages.  Right now, only a couple of General Ledger reports are available.  We intend to slowly flesh out the system to reproduce all the reports you previously had in Crystal.  (In the meantime, Accounting can continue to provide those on an as-needed/upon-request basis.)



And Accounting will continue to send out those reports we e-mail to you each month.  This new system supplements the information you already get from us.



Many thanks to IT for getting this system up and running.

docs.messageBody:
Good afternoon,

As previously communicated, the Museum, and in particular EiE, received a donation from Dell EMC for a new storage device. This has enabled the Museum to improve how we manage, store and backup much of our unstructured content.

What Does This Mean?
Information Technology will use the new device to replace our existing Zeus file server. After a successful pilot over the past few months, we will finalize the migration of all Zeus shared folders and home directories on our regularly scheduled June Maintenance night on 6/12 starting at 6pm.

What Can I Expect When This Takes Effect?
Do not panic! We will be retaining all file and folder permissions and will be retaining the existing “Zeus” naming convention in order to maintain how users currently connect to shared resources.

For PC/Windows users, this will not introduce any changes to the way you connect to your Zeus shares. However, Mac users that do not currently connect to Zeus via the SMB connection (i.e CIFS) will need to be remapped on the morning of 6/13/18 in order to access the shares. Our service desk will be ready to help with this change and you should contact us immediately for assistance.

What Do I Need To Do?
In order to prepare for the final migration of data to the new device we ask that users close out of all shared museum file directories and personal work drives on the night of June 12th before 6pm so that IT can work with Dell EMC and maximize our final migration window. If files and folders are not closed out, IT will close them to ensure that the data is properly migrated to the new device. To avoid losing changes to files please close out of all files and folders promptly before 6pm.

Please note that staff should not store non-work related items (music, personal photos, videos, etc.) on Zeus shared museum file directories and home directories, in keeping with the Museum’s Technology Resource Policy. This will help us keep up with the demand for storage needs and retain a longer backup retention policy for museum related work needs. In the future, if you need additional storage capacity for your home directory, you can call the service desk or submit a request online.

As always, if you have any questions or issues, please contact our service desk, System Support Services, at ithelp@mos.org or call x0130.

Thank you,

Pat

Hi everyone,

The Summer Youth Internship Program is right around the corner, starting with Summer Youth Orientation this Friday, June 15th. We look forward to hosting 35 Interns and 11 Program Assistants across 8 different departments in the Museum. Please say hello if you spot one of our great Youth this summer!

Virtual Walk/Run/Bike


2018 Summer Series!


 


The Wellness Team has brought back this popular wellness event for a 2018 summer series! A virtual race is a race in which you can do on your own time, at your own pace, anywhere you would like. We will be building the race distance as the summer goes in hopes that it will keep you motivated to stay active this summer!


 


Participants will receive a personalized printable bib to wear while walking, running, or biking and a medal!


 


June 23 – 24; 1 mile walk/run or 5 mile bike ride


July 28 – 29; 3 mile walk/run or 12 mile bike ride


August 25 – 26; 5 mile walk/run or 20 mile bike ride


 


To participate in our first virtual race all you have to do is:



  1. Sign up HERE by June 21, 2018

  2. Complete 1 mile the weekend of June 23 - 24

  3. Send proof of your distance to wellness@mos.org


How can you send us proof?



  • Screenshot your Heath App (iPhone)

  • Screenshot any other fitness tracking apps you may have (iPhone or otherwise)

  • Take a picture of your FitBit/Garmin/wearable device

  • Take a picture of your treadmill dashboard data


Send those screenshots and any pictures you take of your race to wellness@mos.org!

This Saturday 5/26 at 11:30, we will have author Richard Munson at the CS&T Stage promoting his new book 'Tesla: Inventor of the Modern'. Come by and hear all about Nikola Telsa's life and accomplishments!

"Tesla’s inventions transformed our world, and his visions have continued to inspire great minds for generations.

Nikola Tesla invented the radio, robots, and remote control. His electric induction motors run our appliances and factories, yet he has been largely overlooked by history. In Tesla, Richard Munson presents a comprehensive portrait of this farsighted and underappreciated mastermind.

When his first breakthrough—alternating current, the basis of the electric grid—pitted him against Thomas Edison’s direct-current empire, Tesla’s superior technology prevailed. Unfortunately, he had little business sense and could not capitalize on this success. His most advanced ideas went unrecognized for decades: forty years in the case of the radio patent, longer still for his ideas on laser beam technology. Although penniless during his later years, he never stopped imagining. In the early 1900s, he designed plans for cell phones, the Internet, death-ray weapons, and interstellar communications. His ideas have lived on to shape the modern economy.

Who was this genius? Drawing on letters, technical notebooks, and other primary sources, Munson pieces together the magnificently bizarre personal life and mental habits of the enigmatic inventor. Born during a lightning storm at midnight, Tesla died alone in a New York City hotel. He was an acute germaphobe who never shook hands and required nine napkins when he sat down to dinner. Strikingly handsome and impeccably dressed, he spoke eight languages and could recite entire books from memory. Yet Tesla’s most famous inventions were not the product of fastidiousness or linear thought but of a mind fueled by both the humanities and sciences: he conceived the induction motor while walking through a park and reciting Goethe’s Faust.

Tesla worked tirelessly to offer electric power to the world, to introduce automatons that would reduce life’s drudgery, and to develop machines that might one day abolish war. His story is a reminder that technology can transcend the marketplace and that profit is not the only motivation for invention. This clear, authoritative, and highly readable biography takes account of all phases of Tesla’s remarkable life.

Hi all,

We're hosting a Forum event this Tuesday that might be of interest to many of you. The program is called "What's In Your Fish?" and deals with the tradeoffs of neurotoxins in seafood, in the context of the well-known benefits of seafood consumption for brain development in young children and expecting/recent mothers. We are co-presenting this event with the Boston University Superfund Research Program (BUSRP), for whom we are a subaward on their federal NIEHS grant. We developed the forum materials in collaboration with BUSRP partners and a board of advisors from the local EPA office, Massachusetts state regulators, and other kinds of community and scientific experts.

The 90-minute Forum event will feature two consecutive case studies, each lasting about 40 minutes. It’s taking place connected to a conference of Superfund Research Program grantees that will be happening that afternoon here at MOS. First, Kate Crawford from BU will talk about how researchers can assess and communicate risk about toxics in fish and then participants will consider and discuss a local case study about Chelsea Creek, which is part of the Mystic River and has experienced a history of environmental health challenges.

Then, Celia Chen, Professor of Environmental Health at Dartmouth College in NH, will present her research about toxics in fish to the public that can impact the particularly vulnerable populations of with young children and pregnant women/prospective moms. Participants will then discuss and design a risk advisory for how they would want to be advised of these risks as consumers and community members.

Here's the link to sign up - the program is free but pre-registration is strongly encouraged. https://www.mos.org/public-events/whats-in-your-fish. Please help us spread the word!

Thanks and please feel free to contact me with any questions.

David
docs.messageSubject: What's In Your Fish? Forum Tuesday 5/22

 Our April MOScars of the Month are….


 


CONGRATULATIONS Ellie Starr!


Best Service to Guests


Recognized by Kaylan Petrie on 04/22/2018


 “The impact of a field trip to the Museum of Science is difficult to put into words, as it changes students, chaperones, and teachers in a multitude of ways intellectually and emotionally. For many schools, even those which are geographically close to us, the opportunity to come to our Museum is out of reach because of budgetary constraints related to admission and transportation.


Thanks to the hard work of Ellie during Stars of STEM, she was able to raise enough funds to eliminate this barrier for more than 2,000 students! A big THANK YOU from all of us in Education and Enrichment Programs!!”


 


CONGRATULATIONS Jeannine Madrid, Sue Stoessel, Mark Sherwood!


Best Service to Colleagues


Recognized by Megan Litwhiler & Karine Thate on 04/03/2018


 “When The Amazing Nano Brothers Jugglers Show had to cancel both of its Saturday performances at the last minute due to a medical emergency, our wonderful colleagues Jeannine, Sue, and Mark were there to help us make all the necessary arrangements. Jeannine walked us through what to do and who to contact. Mark helped us make sure that visitors would be aware of the schedule change. And Sue took care of all the day-of arrangements, such as signs and helping us alert staff to make sure that visitors would be aware that the shows had been canceled. Thanks so much to Jeannine, Mark, and Sue!”


 


CONGRATULATIONS Jeff Mills!


Best Service to Colleagues


Recognized by Yesenia Lopez on 04/18/2018


 “Jeff noticed that a black car in the Parking garage, who he suspected it was mine but was not sure, had a flat tire and he went ahead and filled it up. Later, he stop by the office and confirms that in fact the the car was mine and tried to guide me on next steps to fix the tire since this a recurrent issue.


I want to recognize Jeff not only because he helped me with the tire situation but he didn't do it because it was me, he did it because he is thoughtful like that. Jeff is one of a kind! :D”

Please direct all inquiries to www.mos.org/marathon or have them reach out to me, Gina Crotty, Senior Fundraising Events Coordinator, at 617-589-4475 or gcrotty@mos.org.

Spaces are limited; applications will be accepted on a rolling basis through Friday, November 16th.

Go Team!

Thank you,
Gina

Comment Card Report 8/1/18 through 8/31/18--Part 2

“I'm glad the cafe has removed plastic straws. But could you please supply wood stirrers at the coffee area? Thanks!”

“The horizontal mill steam engine in the lower level of the blue wing is mislabeled. The automatic speed regulator (unlabeled) is marked as the cylinder lubricator both in the diagram stand and on the actual engine. I imagine correcting this would be a good idea.”

“Hi, I came to the museum yesterday and was in the discovery room with my 17 month old baby and a 6 month old. In the time we were there we saw 2 mice running around. I hope you can try and sort this as it is very unhygienic.”

“As a nurse and lactation consultant, I was most interested in your “human life” exhibits. I was extremely disappointed and confused as to why you show a video of egg to baby-with a baby bottle feeding? This is NOT the biological norm. Breastfeeding is. Shame on you for not normalizing breastfeeding!!”

“Is there anyway to order laser Floyd tickets? I have been trying all month but I can never add to cart! What gives?”

"I recently became a member of Museum of Science, but I have been going for a very long time, first as an international student in Boston, and now as a father. I have continually witnessed how great of an institution the MoS has become. My two boys can easily spend the whole day in there, without blinking. So, all is great, but one BIG thing: that is that the truly subpar quality of the meals offered there. I am saddened to witness time and time again how the advancements in technology, for example (as witnessed by the great exhibitions in the MoS that couldn't have been possible a few years ago), never match with should be a core for each child's life: a healthy and balanced meals. And by that I mean the whole food court at the MoS starting with subpar pizzas, clam chowder soups from the can, non-organic salads, milk of the lowest quality (Garelick, if I recall), sodas, etc.”

“I would like to express my extreme displeasure at the new "paperless vouchers" which are now being used instead of the paper passes one would get with one's membership.”

“Loved your Science Museum! BEST we've ever visited :)
Only suggestion is for the "make a/engineer a waterway" - our son (and another kid we observed) stepped off/fell off of the stools...”

“I would like to make you some suggestions about the people that are in the ticket box. They are not kind. Moreover, this museum should be an icon of the Boston's tourism, and it isn't with this kind of behavior and bad manners.
Also, you haven't complaint forms. You should have (such as most of the good museum in the USA, NYC...) special free passes for journalists to make some comments and articles about the museum and Boston, but unfortunately you don't have too.
I am looking forward to hearing from you.”

“Please bring back the tater tots to the cafe.”

“Karen who did the presentation on lightning was absolutely phenomenal! She was the highlight of my visit by far. 10/10 would watch her again.”

“I came in with my 3 Y old granddaughter and she loved it here. My only complaint is that the cafe closes before the Discovery Center. The cafe should stay open. Thank you.”

“Pink Floyd the Wall was horrible. I felt like I paid to watch a giant screen saver that made me feel sick and dizy.”

“There is a spelling mistake on the placard titled ‘Radio Waves’ in the astronomy exhibit adjacent to the entrance of the planetarium. The place name Atacama is twice misspelled as ‘Altacama.’"
Thanks! We <3 the museum!"

Internal Job Postings



Paid staff positions will be posted internally for five (5) business days to give internal applicants priority during the recruitment process, in support of the Museum’s Affirmative Action Plan. All positions accepting internal applications can be found on our Internal Employment Opportunities page.

To apply, simply click on the position title below and complete the online application. If internal staff apply after the position is posted externally, they will not be considered as a candidate because they did not apply during the internal posting period.

At this time, the below listings are actively accepting internal applications:

Welcome Representative


The Guest Welcome Representative helps Museum of Science visitors begin their visits smoothly and efficiently, greeting guests upon arrival, assisting visitors as they navigate the ticketing and admission process, supporting guests in taking advantage of self-service ticketing options, and providing visit planning and Museum information.


Deadline for Internal Applicants: 9/6/18

This position is part-time, 4 hrs/wk, Sundays:10am-2pm

Good afternoon,

The September 4th museum closure affords us a unique opportunity to upgrade legacy network equipment in our server room. This year IT will be replacing our routers beginning promptly at 9am. These new routers will provide hardware and Internet route redundancy that will allow us to better utilize our existing connections in the event of equipment failure. We will be working closely with our external solutions provider, Aqueduct, in this endeavor.

What Does This Mean?

In preparation of this upgrade, IT will be performing an out of band network maintenance on Monday, August 27th beginning at 8:30pm. This will allow us to patch our existing network equipment to ensure things go smoothly on Staff Appreciation day.

During the upgrade on 9/4/18, some Museum IT services will periodically be without connectivity during the hours of 9am and 5pm on that day. Email will continue to function, as that is hosted offsite with Microsoft. Our main website, www.mos.org, will also be up (with appropriate messaging for visitors). The main phone line will have the recording available as well.

What Can I Expect When This Takes Effect?

All internal systems (VPN, Zeus, internal phones, applications, guest wireless, DMZ, and Internet based services, etc.) will periodically be unavailable throughout the course of the day.

What Do I Need To Do?

If you are not going to be in the office on 9/3/18, please close out of all MOS applications and shared files prior to leaving the building.

As always, if you have any questions or issues, please contact our service desk, System Support Services, at ithelp@mos.org or call x0130.

In our efforts for pest prevention we need your help.






We ask that you please report pest sightings as well as any evidence of pest activity in a timely manner, always.(includes but not limited to cockroaches, mice, mice droppings, ants, fruit flies, spiders, etc.)


The Facilities department offers the following options for reporting. Choose which ever works best for you.



1. Call Facilities at ext 0150

2. Submit a W.O. with Museum's On line work order (on Quark under Get It Done) or

3. Write the information as detailed as possible in the sighting book located at the Front desk.




More helpful tips that relate to pest prevention:



• When reporting, be specific (date, type of pest seen, where, route of travel, your name & ext in case we need more information)


• Keep your space clean of clutter, food etc. Treats kept in office should be in covered containers.


• Do not change, remove or throw out pest control devices/equipment. Proper pest entrapment follow up will be done if someone in Facilities is notified.


• Keep the food disposal related items in a centralized location (we suggest the Kitchenettes areas rather than individual trash barrels)


• Abstain from eating in hallways, stairs, elevators or exhibit halls.


• Keep floor & walls clutter free (suggested clearance of 6 inches off floor and away from walls when possible)




Need some help cleaning? – Submit a work order for assistance to C&W


Need assistance with other items that could help improve your space? – Submit a work order to the Facilities Department.



If you have any questions, suggestions or concerns please let me know.



Yesenia Lopez

Facilities Department


617-589-0150/0158

docs.messageBody:
Comment Card report 7/1/18-7/31/18 Part 2

“Dear museum staff, in your hall for mathematics and statistics you mention Omar Khayam but nowhere do you mention where he’s from. Sure, I know where all those cities such as Esfahan or esphahan are, but your audience doesn’t. Earasing Iran from the origins of mathematics and medicine is a small yet significant way in which an institution can contribute to world conflict. For example the father of the theory of probability was from the Middle East and math, science, and medicine have their origins in China, India, and Iran, iraq, and Syria. We know what has already happened to Iraq and Syria, in no small part because the people in the western countries no nothing about those nations. Erase them from history and you will be part of the forces and destroy those nations and cultures. Keep them in history and people will support their governments less in war and more in peace with those nations. Choose your side and I will choose if I visit again. But as a public school teacher, I was rather appalled by yet one more example of an institution focused on science and education, keeping history Eurocentric and conveniently erasing the founders and major contributors.”
“Thank you MOS for a great time last week. Our two children (10yo and 6yo) had a blast! As a parent, the best part for me was the cafe. I say this because our oldest has a long list of allergies and it’s always hard going places (especially those far from home like the MOS) because we usually have to pack a lot of food from home. However, I called the museum ahead of time and was able to get ahold of someone in the kitchen. He assured me that there were things that met my daughter’s allergy needs. He also told me to speak directly to the Cafe Manager, Kobie Garcia. When we got to the museum, we went directly to the cafe so I could check in with Kobie and make sure that there REALLY WAS food that my daughter could eat, as it almost seemed a little too good to be true. He met me with a smile and said he was expecting me. He walked me through the options available (there was more than enough). When my husband brought the kids back to the cafe and I gave my daughter all the options. Naturally she was ELATED to feel like she fit in with everyone else, ordering off the same menu. On top of that, Kobie even told me to bring the kids back for a surprise after they finished eating. When the kids finished lunch and we found Kobie again, he had complimentary cups of Dippin Dots for them, including one of the very few flavors my daughter can actually eat and loves! Kobie was so great and accommodating, never making me feel like we were a burden. It was the first time in a long time that things felt “normal” for my daughter and I am forever grateful for that. Thank you MOS for s great day and for hiring such a fantastic crew! We WILL be back.”

“Yesterday I visited the museum but had to leave after 20 minutes because my friend who was meeting me there was turned away from a full parking structure. As I was leaving, I saw many availabile spaces and although it was too late for my family and my friends family to enjoy a visit, I assumed your staff would want to know there were plenty of spaces and they were unnecessarily turning visitors away and causing a back up of traffic. Instead, the parking attendant ignored me before shouting at me to move along, and the attendant at the information desk asked me if I wanted to leave a comment. It’s very strange to me that you would have a policy of turning visitors away, especially on a rainy Sunday.”

“Hi, I visited the museum with my son today, and have two main comments: 1) We arrived at 14:20 PM, after being stuck in a huge traffic jam for 25 minutes trying to enter the parking lot. The street was jammed with visiting cars coming from both directions. Upon entering I realized that 2 of the 3 lanes were used for exiting cars, even though almost no one was coming out. This is a waste of an entering lane. 2) the museum was super crowded today. I'm not sure about your safety procedure, or any limits. But, this is not the first time that a visit is absolutely insane. People are pushing down hallways (not to mention exhibits), the line to get a cup of coffee is more than a half an hour long, and it seems over crowded (we did notice quite a few buses, so there must have been school visits or the such, but still, as a member I would expect a reasonable experience, which we did not have.”

“This is my first time in the museum. The museum and the experience is amazing. 20/10”

“I was very disappointed about the new location of the mathematica exhibit. I had to leave and come back a few times due to the lightning shows.”

"First of all, I love the museum, and I think this is the best museum of science I have seen in my life. Howeverm minor thing, the definition of a plasma (as listed in the gift shop) is wrong. Plasma is not just hot, it is also made in a variety of ways. What distinguishes a plasma from other matters (including ionized gas) is the electrical shielding it displays (Debye shielding).”

docs.messageBody:
New Construction at Cambridge Crossing, formerly Northpoint, between the Gilmore Bridge and Lechmere Station

Overview
Cambridge Crossing is sustainability-focused, will feature over 11 acres of urban green space, will feature footpaths, and protected bike lanes. Cambridge Crossing is located a short drive from Interstates 90, 93 and 95 and Logan Airport. The first buildings at Cambridge Crossing, a 430,000-square-foot science and technology building with ground floor retail and retail structures totaling 15,000 square feet, are expected to be ready for occupancy in 2019.

Phase 1 Scope
Reconstruction, construction and modifications of:
•Six traffic Signals
•Extension of First Street to McGrath O’Brien Highway
•Sidewalk Reconstruction
•Separated Bike Lanes
•New Drainage System
•Landscaping and Street scraping

Important Information
•Work Hours Monday-Friday 7am-6pm
•Work Hours in the street Monday-Friday 10am-2pm
•Traffic Management – Lane Closures & Pedestrian
Detours
•Emergency Vehicle Access at all times
•Website: www.cxconstruction.info

Cambridge Crossing (CX) has been proactive in reaching out to us and asked us to let them know if we experience any negative impact from their work on this project. If you experience any issues please let me know so I can work with them to remedy the situation.

We just generated a new comment card report from Apr. 23, 2018 to June 5, 2018.
Comment Cards- 4/23/18-6/5/18 Part 2

“For the Foucault Pendulum, since some energy is constantly being lost to hitting the pegs and to air friction, does the pendulum energy need to have energy applied back in to the pendulum's motion?”

“The café floor and tables, especially near the windows facing the river, are always dirty with food and food and utensils lying around most times we come. Can you please have these surfaces cleaned more often? We sat down for a snack at about 10 AM this morning before most people even use the café was cleared it hadn’t been cleaned since at least the day before.”

“It would be nice to create an App for visiting.”

“Linda at Omni went 110% out of her way. We were sitting in a bottom row of the theater. She came down all those stairs before and advised us to much better seats. Thank you.”

“Omni intro: I love that you kept Leonard Nimoy's voice, but please consider replacing the car crash/police car segment. Without the original video, it's out of context and could be upsetting. Maybe use a shuttle launch or plane overflight?"

“Please play Dave Matthews Experience.”

“Question for you: Is the Annual Report recyclable? It’s a weird material, so I’m not sure. If not, even though it’s unusuab and attention-catching, it wasn’t a goodidea!”

“I just learned about a chamber music piece by Bruce Adolphe called Tyrannosaurus Sue: A Cretaceous Concerto. Apparently it has been performed around the country. sometimes in conjunction with the actual Sue on tour. Your institution seems like the perfect venue for a performance.”

“We are long time members of the museum and enjoy using our reciprocity. We are currently visiting the Orlando Science Center. They have a temporary exhibit called Hall of Heroes. My kids loved it and would love to spend more time exploring this exhibit. We think it would the exhibit. We think it would make a great addition to the MOS at some point in time. Not sure where t direct our suggestion, but hope it finds it way to the right person.”

“ My family are members of the museum. I brought my preschooler to the museum today. When we went to use the restroom, the hand dryers were so loud that my child would not go. Is there something that can be done to reduce the
noise level? I would like my child to be able to go to the museum without an accident. Thank you.”

“The earth is missing! The earth model from the Museum's Community Solar System is no longer at the Sonesta Hotel. Please replace it?”

“Me and my Mother had so much fun!”

“I have listened to Leonard Nimoy for 40 years in Omni. No one knows who he is anymore. Once he left Boston we never heard from him. Re-do with Matt Damon and Ben Affleck who love Boston and keep coming back! Mark Walberg is also
more relevant.”

“I had an incredible experience watching the particle decay patterns in the cloud chamber. Ted kept me captivated for almost an hour with his incredible knowledge of science history. Thank You!”

“In the Solar House exhibit, I think there is a wire loose inside Position A. It often comes up 0,000 but if you hit it, it will give you a reading.”

“To MOS: I just participated in the Eversource Mass Energy Workshop for educators on May 31. The program was incredible and I 100% appreciated being at such a great venue as your 6th floor conference room. The hospitality of the
staff and the food and beverages provided were great. One thing I was surprised at was that with all the plastic we generated via water bottles and other plastics,
there was no recycling available. Everything just went into the trash. Does the MOS not have the ability for recycling? Is it too costly and impractical for the numbers of people you service? Aside from that one question, I want to thank you for for hosting programs for teachers such as the one I attended.”

“I drove an hour to get the museum and arrived a mere 5 minutes late to be turned away from the Beyonce live exhibit. I was 5 minutes late because I went to the bathroom. This is one of my favorite museums but I am disappointed with the inflexible policy. This experience has left me feeling negative especially since it is
rare that I am available to drive into Boston. #disappointed”

“I recently took my class of 23 students to the museum on a field trip. The students thoroughly enjoyed the museum but all staff we encountered could have been more helpful. Everyone we encountered seemed annoyed that they were on ""field trip duty"" and things like transitioning from our lunch spot back to the museum were confusing (for storage of the coolers we brought) and when we asked, were given comments in rude tones. While I understand that managing groups of children in a museum can be difficult and not everyone's cup of tea, I do have a problem with people not modeling appropriate social conduct in front of my students--if I ask you a question and my students pick up on your rude behavior, how can I defend your actions?v This ranged from check in, to lunch, to asking the info desk questions (to which the info desk was even helpful when we asked were a certain exhibit was in the museum).”

“I was disappointed that I drove an hour to arrive a mere 5 minutes late and notable to see the Beyonce experience show. I was slightly late due to the fact that I had to use the bathrooms. I was disappointed with the inflexible policy and now I am not sure if I can make another show. This museum is one of my favorites but this experience has definitely left me feeling negative.”

"Horrified and Offended by Beyonce Experience. 80% of the music was edited but shocked by the words being played. No posting in the Museum that show was 18+.”

“Hi there - we are members and I just wanted to say how much my kids have enjoyed the Dora exhibit. It has been wonderful having an activity that toddlers can take part in - my 2 year old son asks to go every day. It would be amazing to
continue to offer something for that age group.”
docs.messageSubject: A New Comment Card Report Part 2

Internal Job Postings



Paid staff positions will be posted internally for five (5) business days to give internal applicants priority during the recruitment process, in support of the Museum’s Affirmative Action Plan. All positions accepting internal applications can be found on our Internal Employment Opportunities page.

To apply, simply click on the position title below and complete the online application. If internal staff apply after the position is posted externally, they will not be considered as a candidate because they did not apply during the internal posting period.

At this time, the below listings are actively accepting internal applications:

Group Sales & Tourism Marketing Manager


The Group Sales & Tourism Marketing Manager position serves a critical role in bringing in visitors to the Museum. The role serves as the ambassador, evangelist, and primary contact for the tourism market segment (hotel partners, group leaders, tour operators, concierges, online affiliates, and travel portals) providing exemplary service that helps grow relationships. The Marketing Manager works to identify new customers, new markets and new products that help drive incremental sales and ultimately visits to the museum. The role develops and executes marketing and sales strategies that address the needs of multiple audiences, implementing cross-channel campaigns (email, social, digital, print, etc.) that raise brand awareness, generate leads, and bookings. The Marketing Manager optimizes collateral, web site, and other sales materials and identifies new opportunities to increase exposure of the Museum. Through staying abreast of marketplace trends in travel, technologies, and vendor products, as well as through the integration of internal data and customer needs, the Program Manager creates data and customer centric solutions to help the museum achieve its goals.


Deadline for Internal Applicants: Friday, May 25

This position is full-time, 40 hours/week, Monday-Friday

A big thank you to all who helped make Red Sox Weekend a success! Visitors had a blast watching baseball-themed live presentations, interacting with educators at our drop-in activities, experiencing the Red Sox showcase items, and enjoying Fenway-inspired food in the Cafe. It was a true group effort and it certainly paid off. Go Sox!

I am happy to introduce Jason Gorman, Executive Chef; Wolfgang Puck Catering as well as Loranzo Gayle, Café Chef-Manager; Wolfgang Puck Catering. Both will be starting on Monday, May 21st.

Chef Jason is a passionate clean food advocate. His personal culinary style draws inspiration from his Italian heritage, personal experiences and classical training from some of America’s best chefs. Jason has helmed some of the region’s top kitchens; The Milwaukee Art Museum, The Art Institute of Chicago, The Iron Horse Hotel and Dream Dance Restaurant.


Loranzo, born in the Caribbean and raised in the United States has always been passionate about great food. Loranzo feels blessed with the opportunity to combine his classical culinary training with his expertise as a personal trainer to truly take care of people.

Please join me in welcoming Chef Jason and Loranzo to the Museum of Science!

docs.messageBody: In preparation for the upcoming escalator work, Design Challenges has cleaned and sorted many of our materials. Free items are up for grabs in the central area of Lower Morse outside of the Lower Morse conference room. Materials are an eclectic mix including toys, science teaching/household supplies, craft materials and building materials. Everything not claimed will be thrown away on Tuesday evening.

Here at Current Science & Technology, we keep you up to date on the latest scientific breakthroughs and advanced research methods.

In accordance with this mission, in June we will be featuring SnotBot, a drone that follows whales as they surface and collects the boogers that get blasted into the air when they blow. For science!
https://www.popsci.com/drones-science-research-whale-snot

As such, we would like to have a small drone on stage to serve as a prop. If you have an unused or even non-functioning drone of the quadcopter/hexacopter variety, we would love to borrow it for the month.

The Wellness Team is looking to add some variety and expand our offerings. We want to learn about your interests in wellness and health-related activities. Using this information, we hope to provide wellness offerings that are exciting and relevant to you!


Please take a few minutes to complete this anonymous, voluntary survey.


Information about your participation:



  • This survey should take approximately 10 minutes to complete

  • The survey is optional, and you may skip any questions or stop at any time.

  • Your responses will be anonymous.

  • You must be 18 years older to participate


As a thank you for your time, all participants who submit a survey by the end of the day November 13th will have the choice to enter a drawing for one of three $50 AMEX gift cards.



Please CLICK HERE to access the survey.



Thank you in advance for your feedback!



If you have any questions about the survey, please contact Lorah Broderick at lbroderick@mos.org. If you have any questions about the Wellness Program in general please contact wellness@mos.org.
docs.messageSubject: Wellness Survey Reminder - Chance to Win $50!

docs.messageBody:
As you have likely noticed, there is significant work taking place in the Museum garage. When the current scope of work on the 5th floor is completed, work will transition to the second phase, impacting the ramp to the 4th floor. This phase of work is expected to have an even greater impact for everyone. Here’s what you need to know:

•Phase 2 will begin when work on the 5th floor is completed. We currently project phase 2 will begin on Monday October 15th.
•The ramp leading to the 4th floor will be reduced to one lane of traffic while work is taking place on the other lane.
•Staff at the top and bottom of the ramp will be directing traffic to ensure safety and prevent gridlock.
•Traffic cones and signage will be strategically placed to ensure traffic flow entering and exiting the 4th floor is as smooth as possible.
•Please pay close attention to this new set-up and follow the directions of staff.
•The work is expected to take about 6 weeks in total. We anticipate the 4th floor ramp will be back in service by mid-November.

While this work will be disruptive, please keep in mind that the Museum garage is a valued amenity for our guests, contract parkers, staff, and volunteers as well as a source of revenue, contributing $3 million to the Museum’s budget annually and we are extremely fortunate that a generous donor contributed to support much needed garage repairs. The work this fall is just the beginning. The next phases of this project will start in the spring with precise timing depending on our New England weather. With each phase we will send out detailed information to help you know what to expect.

When this project is concluded it will greatly enhance and improve the useful life on this important Museum amenity.

Thank you advance for your patience and cooperation.

Check out this comprehensive article from Self Magazine online covering the health benefits of mindfulness meditation- what it can and cannot do for you:

https://www.self.com/story/mindfulness-meditation-health-benefits

Hi all,

We wanted to take a moment to share information about a few recent refurbishments in A Bird's World.

• The FBI van and screen kiosks have been replaced with Bird Flight, a new projection-based component, in which visitors can identify a variety of birds by observing animations of their flight patterns.

• The Bird Silhouette component has been moved to the far side of the specimen cases, away from the Science Live Stage.

• Sneak has been updated with its final software, and will have final graphic labels installed within the next few weeks.

Please stop by and check out the new components. We’d love to hear what you think!

Mobile Mini Golf
September 13th 11:00am - 3:00pm
Skyline


The Wellness Team is hosting a day of mini golf! Nine holes mini golf will be set up at the Museum! These colorful holes are designed to challenge teams with hills, jumps, bumps, and loops! Take some time out of your day to de-stress, move around, and have fun with your colleagues.

You will receive all materials needed at the event, including score cards. A leader board will be kept so that you can see how your team is doing throughout the day.

Teams have the opportunity to earn BONUS POINTS that deduct from your final team score by:



  • Create a fun team name

  • Having multi-department teammates

  • Having themed or matching outfits


Important notes: You will sign up for a tee time in groups of 5 (can be less, but no more than 5). A 9 hole circuit will take about 40-45 minutes for a team of 5. The tee times only allow for 1 team per slot, if you do not see a time slot it is because it has been taken.



TO SIGN UP CLICK HERE!

MOScars of the Month!


From the dozens of nominations we receive each week, the MOScars Team chooses a MOScar that we believe best exemplifies the spirit of the program across all categories each month.


 


Our July MOScars of the Month are….Daniel Strauss, Shubhecchha Dhaurali, and Debbie Jacob


 


3 MOScars in one month, way to go Eric!


 


CONGRATULATIONS Daniel Strauss!


Best Service of Volunteer Service & Spirit


Recognized by Aly Richardson on 07/05/2018


“Dan has voluntarily chosen to come back and spend his summer Saturdays with us after finishing his first year of college. On one of his first days back in HHL, Dan jumped right back into interpreting one of his favorite subjects: bones. As different groups of visitors came and went, one visitor in particular stayed at the Hub for a while and seemed very interested and engaged with the skeletons Dan was talking about. Eventually the visitor moved on and his chaperone came up to the Hub to thank Dan. She was bursting with appreciation for his patience, knowledge, and kindness during the interaction with her student, who she said was part of a group of teens with special learning needs. It was heartwarming and encouraging to hear a very deserving individual receive such incredibly sincere and grateful feedback for something that he enjoys doing, but also does so completely voluntarily. Thanks Dan for always sharing your positive and genuine spirit with visitors, fellow volunteers, and staff!”


 


CONGRATULATIONS Shubhecchha Dhaurali!


Best Service to Guests


Recognized by Kaylan Petrie on 07/16/2018


“Shubhecchha is amazing. A group of high profile international guests were visiting the Museum on a very busy Sunday, and due to a scheduling mix-up they had an extra hour or two to explore the exhibit halls. While visiting HHL, the group leader became very interested and excited about the exhibit and wanted to know more about what happens in HHL, what it's like to work there, and what the goals of the exhibit experience are. I quickly popped over to the briefing room to see if anyone was available to answer a few quick questions from the group, and Shubhecchha said she'd be happy to do a Q&A. Instead of just doing a brief and informal meet and greet, Shubhecchha invited the group into the briefing room and led an extremely professional and concise presentation that truly impressed me as well as our distinguished guests. Shubhecchha went way above and beyond to create a warm and welcoming experience for this group (with no time to prepare), and took extreme initiative far beyond what is normally expected from High School interns. Thank you Shubhecchha for your service and leadership!”


 


CONGRATULATIONS Debbie Jacob!


Best Service to Colleagues


Recognized by Annie Petroff on 7/27/2018


“The museum implemented a credit card updater process to coincide with our one step auto-renewal program. While preparing for our August update, we noticed that a significant number of cards were missing an attribute that was required for the process to work. This attribute needed to be added to over 400 records by the end of the day. Realizing that it was already noon, and there would be no way we could get these done by hand, it became obvious that we would either lose the opportunity to update a significant number of accounts this month, or we would have to work with a delayed schedule which would put too much pressure on DMS to get the memberships processed in time to be mailed to our members. Debbie quickly developed an efficient solution and saved the day - and most likely a significant amount of revenue for the museum.”


 


Getting a MOScar is great feeling, giving a MOScar is an even better one. It only takes a minute but can make someone’s entire day. Remember - no deed is too small!


 


CLICK HERE to recognize someone

Last Month for MOScar submissions!


 The 2017-2018 “MOScars Season” officially ends on September 30th!


What does this mean?


Any MOScar submitted through September 30 is eligible to be nominated for a 2018 trophy! Don't miss the chance to recognize your fellow colleagues for their excellence!


What do we need from YOU?


Say thank you to a colleague, volunteer, or intern by September 30th by clicking HERE. Remember, we love thank you’s big and small, now’s your chance to make someone’s day!


We are ONLY 35 nominations away from breaking our MOScar record! Let’s work together to make 2017-2018 our most thankful season.


 


The MOScar award ceremony will be held in early 2019, the official date will be coming to your inbox soon!

6 Week Tai Chi Series


Tuesdays July 17th – August 21st


8:30AM -9:00:00AM


Wicked Smart


Looking for a way to calm your mind, move your body and learn something new this summer? Why not try Tai Chi! Often called “meditation in motion,” this low impact exercise is a great way to stretch and strengthen your muscles and joints while quieting your mind.


Our own Lori Sartre, a member of the Marketing Communications team, has offered to teach a Tai Chi series to staff! Lori has been training in kung fu and tai chi for 25 years. She and her husband have had their own martial arts studio on the South Shore for 18 years.


This 6 part series will be held Tuesdays before the Museum opens from 8:30 - 9am in Wicked Smart. Please wear comfortable clothing and shoes you can easily move in.


Click here to sign up!

Virtual Walk/Run/Bike


2018 Summer Series Continues!


July 28 – 29


3 mile walk/run & 12 mile bike


Haven’t signed up? Now’s your chance!


 


Our summer series continues with a 3 mile walk/run and a 12 mile bike ride! We hope you enjoyed our June virtual race and are displaying (or wearing) your medals proudly. Our second event in the series pushes you a little bit further. Don’t forget if you’re not able to do this in one fell swoop, you can do this over the course of two days.


 


As a reminder, a virtual race is a race in which you can do on your own time, at your own pace, anywhere you would like.


 


Participants will receive a personalized printable bib to wear while walking, running, or biking and a medal!

  • Take a picture of your treadmill dashboard data

Comment Card Report- October 1, 2018-October 31, 2018--Part 1

"I hope that your program tonight funded by the Reno Foundation somehow gives this more responsible perspective: FDA alerts public about fraudulent claims that marijuana products can treat, cure cancer, https://www.google.com/amp/s/medicalxpress.com/news/2017-11-fda-fraudulent-marijuana-products-cancer.amp"

"To Whom It May Concern: We recently enjoyed a stimulating and rewarding day at the Museum with our 13 year old grandson who was visiting [us]. While exploring The Human Body, I was compelled to pay particular attention to the capsule exhibit that focused on depression, a condition unfortunately and regularly apparent in my genealogy. My son, one of my daughters, my brother and I fall into the category and all of us are currently under long-term treatment for this condition. My mother was a long-term patient in the late 60s under treatment for depression. While I appreciate your recognition of this particular aspect of mental illness, I was disappointed and frankly annoyed by the use of a female model to demonstrate new technologies being developed for the treatment of depression. Having taken note of the three accompanying video testimonies of two women and one gentleman who candidly relate their personal experiences, it's abundantly clear that women dominate the overall picture, thereby perpetuating the notion that depression is a condition largely associated with females. Perhaps the Museum should consider a second look at the promotion of the supposition that women are indeed the weaker sex. Thank you for your consideration. I look forward to hearing from you."

"https://www.mos.org/drop-in-activities/astronomy-after-hours says 'LOCATION: Gilliland Observatory. Find on map'. But when I click 'Find on map', I don't actually see an observatory anywhere."

"Hello! I just wanted to say the presenter on Sunday's Explore the Universe show was amazing. They were very knowledgeable, engaging, and made the day special for my little one. Hope to see another one of their shows soon!"

"It is outrageous that you would schedule such a misleading program at the Museum of Science, particularly since it is a respected institution attended by many children and adolescents: https://www.mos.org/public-events/killing-cancer-with-cannabis"

"Hello, I am teacher and visited the museum today with some friends as part of an assignment for me masters in elementary education at Merrimack College. I had asked a group of employees at the information area if I could have access to the teacher resource area and they told me that it is not open on Saturdays. I just checked online and it says that it is open on Saturdays from 1-4, we were there from 11:30-3:30. I am unable to come back to complete the assignment but I would like to know why I was lied to about it being open or if the online hours are incorrect? Thank you."

"Went to renew our membership as per instructions in the letter received: http://mos.org/membership The problem is, there is no evident way to /renew/. If you cllick on one of the boxes listing membership levels (and you log in as a current member), it says 'you are already a member' and won't put anything in your cart! Renewal deserves its own button."

"Very hard to see what shows are playing at the Planetarium!"

"I had an amazing time in your Museum. The interactive exhibits were stimulating and prompted the use of logic, reasoning, and questions.Initially I felt that the exhibits looked dated but after walk through the human body section"

"Recycling is important. Please have more options for recycling paper and utensils. Compostable utensils and a composte bin would be an important addition for MOS."

"Your 2nd grade Eye Opener Program is the absolute best! It's the only field trip I'd every take my class on in October. Thank you for expanding the minds of Boston's second graders! (no follow up needed)"

"Very disappointed with the lack of recycling. Whole Foods and most other locations have more comprehensive recycling. And this is the museum of science. Missed opportunity w/composting and incentivizing to keep things sustainable."

"I was at your food court recently. Your serve ware should all be compostable and the recycle program/instructions should be more visible. Thanks"

"I was surprised that the section on Alexander Graham Bell makes no mention of Antonio Meucci, whose designs he STOLE. He played a significant role, but much of it, and his credit, is due to Meucci."

“ Yesterday I attended a show at your planetarium called explore the universe. I just wanted to say how fabulous the presenter was. If I recall correctly, her name was Charity, I may be wrong though. She was so funny and witty, but most importantly engaging. I felt like I was having fun while also learning about space. It was nice to hear about more than our own solar system. Charity had such a unique and relatable perspective. I hope to come back and see her do a show again.”

“I was hoping that you can kindly send me a teacher member card. I have misplaced my card. I have been a member for years.”

“Signed up with two different emails yet I cannot login in?? I am trying to buy a membership and the process of your website is making it impossible.”

“I submitted an email already with no response. I am trying to buy a membership online but when ever i click add to cart it reads cart is empty and my correct account and password does not let me gain access. Please advice.”

“I was at the museum on Friday for your teacher partner event. I just wanted to email and say how great of a time myself and my teacher friends had! The activities were so much fun, the museum had some great exhibits, and the space exhibit was amazing! We really had a great time! Thank you!!”

“Please bring back the lightning hand stamp. It was our favorite.”

“I brought my grandchildren to the museum on Sunday (10/21). I've been several times in the past 30 years and have always been very happy with what you present. Yesterday's visit was excellent too except for the Mars film in the Omni Theater. It is poorly done and contains far to many corporate references for my liking. The children were bored as was my daughter, wife, and I. The technology is wonderful. It seems as though the Museum of Science could do much better than this. Thank you.”

Internal Job Postings



Paid staff positions will be posted internally for five (5) business days to give internal applicants priority during the recruitment process, in support of the Museum’s Affirmative Action Plan. All positions accepting internal applications can be found on our Internal Employment Opportunities page.

To apply, simply click on the position title below and complete the online application. If internal staff apply after the position is posted externally, they will not be considered as a candidate because they did not apply during the internal posting period.

At this time, the below listings are actively accepting internal applications:

Human Resources Assistant


The Human Resources Assistant proactively provides administrative assistance to Human Resources division to ensure a smooth functioning office and serve as a positive, welcoming Museum representative for all staff, volunteers and interns. This role administers and supports the youth volunteer and intern recruitment, and on occasion staff, on-boarding processes by utilizing the online applicant tracking system and other various databases. This role also supports the Wellness program to ensure staff are fully engaged in the Museum community.


Deadline for Internal Applicants: Thursday, October 17, 2018

This position is full-time, 40 hours/week, Monday-Friday 8:30am-5:00pm. This role also works one Saturday per month.


Talent Acquisition Coordinator


The Talent Acquisition Coordinator assists the Museum's staff recruitment efforts by processing requisition requests, posting positions, reviewing and selecting resumes, phone-screening candidates, scheduling and conducting interviews, updating and maintaining records, and other recruitment activities. The position is also responsible for maintaining our applicant tracking system database, paper requisition files, and assisting the Manager, Talent Acquisition & Development with bi-annual Affirmative Action reports in accordance with state and federal guidelines. The Talent Acquisition Coordinator will also support the Manager and the Museum's outreach efforts by researching and liaising with local colleges, job fairs, and/or community organizations to promote the Museum and its opportunities.


Deadline for Internal Applicants: Thursday, October 17, 2018

This position is full-time, 40 hours/week, Monday-Friday.

We just generated a new comment card report from Sept. 1 to Sept. 30, 2018

Comment Card Report 9/1/18-9/30/18

“I was really disappointed to discover that the MOS has become another institution to remove straws from their cafeteria - an ableist ethos to say the least. While the plastic straw ban has been gaining steam - it is such a drop in the bucket to the amount of waste created by plastics that I was sad to see MOS jump on this ship. Banning straws harms those who rely on them to drink. The world is already set up for able bodied people and I feel like the museum did not consider ability in the banning. I am only the mother of a toddler who struggles to drink milk from an open cup - and without a straw did spill said milk all over himself at the museum. But this is just minor. Imagine if my child was unable to drink from a cup without a straw. Now he is being punished. Think of all the other ways we could reduce plastic, by using compostable silverware and avoiding plastic bottled sodas that are sold at the MOS.”

“Please have the ticket counter people know what the Science Now daily topic is and where the Gordon Science presentation center is located. Thank you.”

“Can you please make a Mugar Omni Theater presentation about Mongooses? They have many interesting facts to learn about, especially their immunity to snake venom.”

“Loved the Museum and saw as much as I could. My favorite exhibits were the Models for Playing, Learning, Dinosaurs and everything Transportation and NASA.”

"I would pay to see a special show of just Music at the Lightning Exhibit. Perhaps 30 Mins. of AC/DC $15.00 each.”

"Under the 120D Section on the wall in Mathematica Exhibit in Puri, India is wrongfully spelled. It is Jagannath Temple and 'Not' Juggernaut. Please correct the 'distortion!'"

"I brought my 3 year old son to the museum today and have to say that I am really disappointed with the quality of our visit. While I understand that construction and repair is a necessary evil, the noise from construction was so disruptive to our visit that neither me nor my toddler could bear to stay in the vicinity. Meaning that over 2/3rds of the museum was essentially off limits to us. In addition, multiple displays that are favorites of my son were not functioning including the butterfly exhibit, and various small displays in and around the museum. While I do understand that this is normal, the museum really should be offering admission at a discounted rate during this time. It is absurd that I paid over $50 to visit a museum and only be able to visit a small portion of it. I’d like to ask for my admission to be refunded as our visit today was disappointing. We live in Boston and have visited the museum before and been really pleased with it, but are really disappointed in today's visit. Please advise."

“We've sent several e-mails to your Museum. We've been consistently ignored. Pretty disappointing considering we have had a membership for almost a decade, never attend, and basically consider our membership a donation to MOS.”

"Exhibit 'World of Maps' - on the image 'Map of a Human Chromosome'
The statement actually said that there are 23 chromosomes in every cell. It should say 23 PAIRS of chromosomes (i.e. 46 in all) [except of course for sperm + egg cells] (otherwise the interactive aspects were excellent.)"

"It would be appreciated if members could receive updates on things like today’s parking garage closure. I drove over an hour to the museum with 2 toddlers. Also the attendants redirecting cars were extremely rude."

"Please use metric and imperial units in all displays, especially for temperature. Your visitors are from many different countries, the majority of which use metric units. So values using Imperial units (especially Fahrenheit) are not understood. Additionally you are trying to encourage a new generation of scientists and engineers. To work internationally they will need to understand both systems. Seeing both systems will start a subliminal absorption and understanding of them. The space exhibit was excellent; however, the use of Fahrenheit severely hampered our understanding. I realize this is a travelling exhibition, please forward my comment to the organizers."

After almost 10 years (she will be one day short) Kate Curtis has decided to leave the Museum and accept an HR/Payroll position with the Swampscott School System. The 5 minute commute and pension were too much for her to turn down. While it’s sad for us, this is an exciting opportunity for Kate, and I know I speak for all of us wishing her the best of luck. Kate’s last day will be September 21st.

With any loss comes opportunity and I’m happy to announce that Sarah Hudson has accepted the position as Payroll Coordinator. This is a great opportunity for Sarah to expand her knowledge and experience within the Accounting department. It will be a loss for Accounts Payable where she has made many improvements in her short time in that role. Please join me in congratulating Sarah on her new position.

With regards to how this will impact the Museum, we will now have two vacant positions, our Cash Accountant position and an Accounts Payable position. We are also in the middle of our new HR/Payroll system implementation that is set to go live January 1st. Needless to say we have few things happening that will most likely impact most if not all of you. We will continue to try provide the best service possible to everyone, but will have to prioritize work accordingly. Our top priority will always be paying our employees, then our vendors, then answering requests from our management team/staff. That being said, there may be times when you may not receive a response as quickly as you have in the past, please be patient. Hopefully all this change will be invisible to most but it is significant enough we wanted to bring it to everyone’s attention. If you have questions please let me know.

Sincerely,
Brian

The Forum Assistant Project Manager will coordinate logistics for national collaborative projects for a number of federally supported grant projects. This position includes monitoring spending by project subawardees, reconciling variances from budget, processing subawardee invoices, and keeping records to support financial decision-making. docs.messageSubject: REPOST: Asbestos Containing Materials  Employee & Building Occupant Notification Letter October 2018
docs.messageBody:
Asbestos Containing Materials  (ACM) Employee & Building Occupant Notification Letter  October 2018


There is a Training/Informational Session open to any Museum employee or volunteer who wishes to attend: 
              Thursday Nov. 15,  1:00pm-2:00pm, in Hornblower 


This mandatory for Museum employees directly affected by the O&M program. If you have previously been required to attend and you did not already receive an invite, please let me know so I can send you the invite.  If you have any questions or concerns regarding ACM, please don’t hesitate to contact me.
 


Background 
As a durable fire retardant material, asbestos was added to various building components such as ceiling treatments, floor tiles, plaster, fiberboard and insulation. These materials are referred to as asbestos containing materials (ACM).  ACM in good condition does not pose a health risk. When ACM becomes damaged, is disturbed or deteriorates, it can release fibers into the air. If inhaled, asbestos fibers may cause serious health problems, including asbestosis, lung cancer, and mesothelioma. The US EPA recommends that ACM be managed in place through periodic inspections and prompt repair when damage is noted.  It must be removed during building demolition/renovation or if significantly damaged.


MOS Asbestos Program
To minimize exposure of building occupants to asbestos fibers, the Museum of Science has conducted asbestos surveys and implemented an operations and maintenance (O&M) program.  This program identifies areas with known or presumed ACM, outlines procedures to maintain ACM and identifies what to do in the event of damage to ACMs.  The O&M program, which includes locations of known ACMs in Section II, can be found on the Hub Safety page.  An asbestos awareness and other related training programs are also available. 

What You Need to Know
•	Prior to conducting renovations or work that may impact building materials such as insulation, ceiling tiles, flooring, etc., please contact the MOS asbestos coordinator, Christina Dillard cdillard@mos.org  ext. 4249, to determine the presence or absence of ACMs.  Avoid impacting or damaging any known or presumed ACMs.

•	Work with the asbestos coordinator to provide contractors with asbestos contractor notification forms and returned a signed copy to the asbestos coordinator.  Make sure contractors have also received a copy of the Contractor Health and Safety Program and return the signed acknowledgement to Christina Dillard.

•	Report damaged ACMs by notifying the asbestos coordinator directly or via ext. 0200.  Do not walk through or otherwise disturb damaged ACM or ACM debris.  If possible, remove any potential sources of air disturbance and isolate the area with signage and barriers.

•	Please contact the the MOS asbestos coordinator, Christina Dillard cdillard@mos.org  ext. 4249 with questions you may have regarding the ACM management program or to obtain further information regarding specific locations.



Christina Dillard | Environmental Health & Safety (EHS) Program Manager 
Museum of Science  | Facilities Dept.  |  One  Science Park  |  Boston, MA 02114-1099
P 617-589-4249 | F 617-589-0101 |M 781-789-1178| cdillard@mos.org  |  www.mos.org

In 2017 the Museum installed level 2 (high speed) electric vehicle charging stations on the fourth floor of the garage with the capability of charging up to four cars at a time. Due to high demand, the Museum also installed three level 1 (low speed) charging stations on the fourth floor and an additional charging station in the basement level of the garage. 

Museum staff, volunteers, interns, contractors and contract parkers are encouraged to utilize both the level 1 and level 2 charging stations. Although vehicles may remain in the level 1 station for the duration of their stay, vehicles must vacate the level 2 stations within 30 minutes completing their charge. ChargePoint will notify an electrical vehicle driver once their vehicle has completed charging. 

Effective on Thursday, November 15th, the Museum will begin charging $5.00 per hour after a vehicle has completed charging and the 30 minute grace period has elapsed. In order to avoid this $5 fee per hour, all EV drivers including Museum staff, volunteers, interns, contractor and contract parkers must move their vehicle within 30 minutes. In addition, we require all Museum staff, volunteers and interns to move their car within the 30 minute grace period.

Thanks!

David

Colleagues,

As you are aware, the Museum of Science is committed to creating a safe environment for all staff, volunteers, interns and visitors. The Safety Committee and Human Resources have revisited our Accident Reporting process and streamlined it down to one form.

All injuries no matter how slight involving staff, interns, and volunteers need to be reported. If you experience an injury while at work (in the building or offsite) please complete the following steps:

  1. Report the injury/incident to Public Safety x0200
  2. Report the injury/incident to your supervisor
  3. Complete the Accident Investigation Form with your supervisor. This form can be found on both the HR and Environmental Health & Safety Hub pages.
  4. Return to Human Resources within 24 hours of the incident or as soon as possible.

It is critical that we properly investigate all injuries and incidents involving full and part-time staff, volunteers, paid and unpaid interns and contractors working on the Museum property or conducting off-site Museum business. Timely and accurate reporting of these incidents assists the Museum in taking steps to remedy hazardous conditions to prevent recurrence.

 

Supervisors, please print out copies of this updated Accident Investigation Form and have them available in your space for your staff.

 

If you have any questions please contact me (x0122) or Christina Dillard (x4249)

docs.messageSubject: Join us at the CS&T stage for the livestream of InSight landing on Mars!
docs.messageBody:
NASA's InSight lander arrives at Mars after a six-month journey THIS AFTERNOON! Join us at the CS&T stage as we watch NASA's livestream, discuss what this lander hopes to discover, and bite our nails during the harrowing seven-minute landing sequence.

The livestream begins at 2:00 PM, and the signal from landing will (hopefully!) arrive at 2:54 PM.

Come watch the population of Mars increase by 1 (robot)!

Accounting and IT are pleased to announce the deployment of several new reports in the SSRS Finance Reporting system.

Project-Source Spread by Month - This report was technically already deployed, but only in draft/testing mode. With help from user-tester extraordinaire Larry Ralph, it has been polished up and is now considered final. For a given fiscal year, this report goes project by project and shows the expenses charged by line item against each of the funding sources used to fund the project. The report may be found in the Project and Grant Budget Reports folder in SSRS.

Project-Source by FY - This report is similar to the preceding one, but instead of showing monthly totals for a single fiscal year, it shows data across all fiscal years since FY15, with one column for each year. It’s good for looking at longer term projects. The report may be found in the Summary by Year Reports folder in SSRS.

Source-Project by FY - This report is identical to the Project-Source by FY, but flips the way the data is organized. It runs through all your funding sources, then shows the activity on each of the projects that that source has funded. The report may be found in the Summary by Year Reports folder in SSRS.

(There is another report, Actuals by FY, in the Summary by Year Reports folder as well. But it’s still in development, so use it with a grain of salt until you officially hear otherwise.)

Note that each of these reports has drill-down capabilities, in case you need to see the transactions behind any of the summarized totals.

You should also note that we’ve completely revamped how to wildcard account number information when telling SSRS what you want to see. This is important if you’ve already been using the system and have grown accustomed to the old underscore wildcarding. The new version is clearer, easier to keep track of, and better at preventing unwanted data from sneaking into your reports.

For further information, including info on drilling down and mastering the new wildcarding scheme, please refer to Accounting’s All About Finance Reports in SSRS document, available on our Hub page.

IT continues to work on developing SSRS reports, and we will keep you posted as more become available.

I am pleased to announced that we have hired a new Manager (Senior Curator) of Living Collections.  Jackie Peeler will begin full-time on 11 December 2018.  She will be here on December 4-5, for the AZA site visit.  Jackie’s most recent position was Director of the Binghamton Zoo in Binghamton, New York.  She has 20+ years of experience working in zoological facilities.  Jackie has worked with a variety of animal species, has experience working with plant collections and is experienced with animal welfare, care and management.  Jackie has participated in the AZA accreditation process and is familiar with AZA standards.  Please join me in welcoming Jackie to the Museum.

The Museum of Science is accredited by the Association of Zoos and Aquariums (AZA).  As part of the accreditation process, every five years the Museum has a site inspection by 2-3 zoo or aquarium professionals.  Our site visit will take place on December 5-6, 2018.  

While the focus of the inspection is related to animal welfare, care and management, the inspectors look at all areas of the Museum.  This is a time for us to highlight all of the good work we are doing with our live animals as well as work in other areas.  The inspectors are free to talk with any staff member they might come across.  If they ask you something and you don’t know the answer tell them you don’t know, don’t make up an answer.  They will not expect you to know how to take care of the animals unless your job is to take care of the animals.
