docs.messageSubject: Join us for Living Laboratory Researcher Small Talks
docs.messageBody:
Hi everyone,
 
Over the next two weeks, the Early Childhood Ed team will be hosting Living Laboratory researchers onsite to chat with our staff and volunteers about the research they do at the museum, and how they use the scientific process to investigate research questions in fields such as psychology, education, and child development.
 
Please join us to learn more about current research of local university partners happening in our very own halls, and/or to learn more about the Living Laboratory program.
 
Following is a schedule of who will be coming when; each researcher will be with us for ½ hour.  Feel free to join for any/all that you would like, invite other interested MOS colleagues, and email me if you would like any more information!
 
Wednesday 12/5 at 9:30 (Discovery Center)
Kelly Cui – Doctoral Student, Boston University Social Learning Lab
The Social Learning Laboratory’s research focuses on children’s use of social and cognitive information when learning about the world. An issue central across children’s development is how they navigate diverse sources of information, such as testimony from teachers, family or peers, or their own inquiry and evidence.  Kelly’s current research with the Living Laboratory explores the factors that children consider when deciding whether someone is a trustworthy source of information.

Thursday 12/6 at 9:30 (Discovery Center)
Leo Rosenstein – Lab Manager, MIT Language Acquisition Lab
The Language Acquisition Lab’s central topic of study is how children learn and acquire their native language(s) – how much of it is biologically determined versus experience-based, how does it change as children mature, and what strategies do children employ in order to extract and use the relevant information in language experiences? Members of the lab are currently studying how children learn the rules of grammar, and how their use of these rules changes as they grow. 

Saturday 12/8 at 9:30 (Classroom A)
Peggy Li – Research Fellow, Harvard University Laboratory for Developmental Studies
The Laboratory for Developmental Studies represents a multidisciplinary group of researchers interested in discovering more about the way infants and young children learn about the world that surrounds them. Dr. Li’s research primarily focuses on the relationship between children’s language and cognitive development, and how they both may rely on and grow from one another. Currently in Living Laboratory, she is investigating the role language plays in the creation of new representational structures and concepts for children.

Saturday 12/8 at 12:30 (Upper Morse)
Amanda Haber – Doctoral Student, Boston University Social Learning Lab
The Social Learning Laboratory’s research focuses on children’s use of social and cognitive information when learning about the world. An issue central across children’s development is how they navigate diverse sources of information, such as testimony from teachers, family or peers, or their own inquiry and evidence.  Amanda’s current Living Laboratory research investigates how children’s exploration of a new concept is influenced by the type of information they receive about it.

Sunday 12/9 at 9:30 (Hornblower)
Rebecca Peretz-Lange – Doctoral Student, Tufts University Cognitive Development Lab
The Cognitive Development Lab’s goal is to better understand how children learn about the physical and social world – about the objects they play with, the people they learn from, and how both interact in their everyday life.  Much of the lab’s research focuses on how children learn about cause and effect.  Rebecca’s current Living Lab research investigates how children reason about other people’s behaviors.

Monday 12/10 at 9:30 (Discovery Center)
Vishakha Agrawal – Lab Manager, Northeastern University Communication Development Lab
The Communication Development Lab investigates perceptual and cognitive development in human infants and young children to gain new insights into the development of multisensory communication skills. Members of the lab research topics such as how children use audio-visual clues to enhance their attention to faces and understanding of language, and how these early experiences affect attentional processing and language development.  

Thursday 12/13 at 12:30 (Classroom A)
Jess Beal-Applin – Doctoral Student, Boston University Developing Minds Lab
The Developing Minds Lab studies how infants and children perceive, understand, and remember “the vast amount of visual information available in the world and carve it up into the meaningful units that are most relevant to us as humans: namely, inanimate objects and animate agents.” Jess’s current work in the Living Laboratory investigates how children’s memory may be influenced by societal factors.

Friday 12/14 at 9:30 (Discovery Center)
Peter Blake – Lab Director, Boston University Social Development and Learning Lab
The Social Development and Learning Lab conducts cognitive and behavioral experiments with children regarding social concepts such as cooperation and competition, ownership and private property, fairness and other social norms, and learning through imitation and communication. Dr. Blake’s current Living Laboratory research investigates children’s perceptions of fairness.

Friday 12/14 at 12:30 (Hornblower)
Sona Kumar – Doctoral Student, Boston University Social Learning Lab
The Social Learning Laboratory’s research focuses on children’s use of social and cognitive information when learning about the world. An issue central across children’s development is how they navigate diverse sources of information, such as testimony from teachers, family or peers, or their own inquiry and evidence. Sona’s research investigates how testimony from an adult may influence children’s perceptions of and interest in a concept.

Sunday 12/16 at 12:30 (Hornblower)
Rebecca Peretz-Lange – Doctoral Student, Tufts University Cognitive Development Lab
The Cognitive Development Lab’s goal is to better understand how children learn about the physical and social world – about the objects they play with, the people they learn from, and how both interact in their everyday life.  Much of the lab’s research focuses on how children learn about cause and effect.  Rebecca’s current Living Lab research investigates how children reason about other people’s behaviors.

Tuesday 12/18 at 9:30 (Discovery Center)
Leo Rosenstein – Lab Manager, MIT Language Acquisition Lab
The Language Acquisition Lab’s central topic of study is how children learn and acquire their native language(s) – how much of it is biologically determined versus experience-based, how does it change as children mature, and what strategies do children employ in order to extract and use the relevant information in language experiences? Members of the lab are currently studying how children learn the rules of grammar, and how their use of these rules changes as they grow. 

Tuesday 12/18 at 12:30 (Lower Morse Conference Room)
Peter Blake – Lab Director, Boston University Social Development and Learning Lab
The Social Development and Learning Lab conducts cognitive and behavioral experiments with children regarding social concepts such as cooperation and competition, ownership and private property, fairness and other social norms, and learning through imitation and communication. Dr. Blake’s current Living Laboratory research investigates children’s perceptions of fairness.

docs.messageSubject: Coming Soon!  Our New HR/Payroll Solution - UltiPro
docs.messageBody:
Dear Colleagues,

The Museum of Science has some great news to share!  You will soon be able to get the HR/Payroll information you need and answers to your own questions FAST.

Our new solution, UltiPro®, will give you anytime, anywhere access to your own personal data and relevant HR, payroll, and benefits information.

The UltiPro portal and its online features will be available to you by Thursday, December 20th.  *See below for upcoming information and support sessions for employees.     

UltiPro is accessible 24-7 from anywhere with an Internet connection.  Initially you’ll have quick, easy access to view and review your personal information.  As we move forward, your pay data will be stored, allowing you to see your pay statement details and (eventually) pay history and year-to-date summaries.  

Future Enhancements will include:

  • Change address and dependent/beneficiary information
  • Change or update information for direct deposits
  • Electronic workflows and approvals
  • Enroll in medical, dental, vision, or retirement plans
  • Print pay history for financial institutions
  • Record life-event changes, such as marital status or new dependents
  • Review pay statement details
  • View or print your W-2s

We’re very excited about rolling out this new solution.  UltiPro will help improve our communications to you as well as provide you with faster, efficient HR and payroll services! 

*Information and Support Sessions

In December, we will hold information and support sessions to help you get acclimated to UltiPro – specifically, we will demonstrate how you will enter time, effective December 20th.  Also, over the past couple of weeks, we have been meeting with department managers to introduce them to UltiPro.  We encourage you to contact them for additional support, particularly, as it pertains to entering and submitting hours worked.  Support sessions will be held during the dates and times below.  You do not have to sign-up, just stop by, as we will be providing handouts and training resources.

docs.messageSubject: Computer Science Education Weekend - this weekend at the Museum!
docs.messageBody:
Join the Museum in celebrating Computer Science Education Weekend, Saturday and Sunday, December 8 & 9. Computer Science Education Week is celebrated nation-wide around the birthday of computing pioneer, Admiral Grace Murray Hopper (December 9, 1906).

We will be marking the occasion with our own roster of fun, educational hands-on activities for visitors of all ages. Computer Science Education Weekend will feature a "passport" of activities for visitors to try, while collecting stamps to return for a prize. Activities include:

Circuitry
Put your creativity to the test by designing, building, and testing circuits out of unconventional materials! (Suit Cabot Lab)

Robotics
Program robots to follow your instructions with KIBO or Sphero Mini Golf (Blue Wing, Level 1)

Programming
Test your coding skills with Pac-Man or use computational thinking skills to navigate a maze. (Blue Wing, Level 1)

Community Alley
Talk to local computer scientists and roboticists as they share their stories and projects. (Blue Wing, Lower Level)

Prototypes
Help us test some Tech Studio exhibit prototypes that could soon have a permanent home inside the museum. (Blue Wing, Level 1)

Thank you for promoting this exciting themed weekend at the Museum. We hope to see you there!

docs.messageSubject: TODAY 12/7: Fenway High School Science Fair
docs.messageBody:
Please join us in welcoming all of Fenway High School today, 12/7, as they host and celebrate their Science Fair at the Museum. About 75 Seniors have been working diligently on their projects since September and they are excited to showcase their findings in the Blue Wing Well. During the exhibition, 9-11 graders will be exploring our Exhibit Halls, seeing an Omni show, and judging the Science Fair projects. Fenway Science Fair at the Museum is a keystone piece of our 25+ year long partnership with Fenway High School and we are happy to be able to host it again this year.

We welcome all members of the Museum community to stop by and view their projects from 9:30am - 11:30am in the Blue Wing Well. Please email Meghan Carter (MCarter@mos.org) or Christina Moscat (CMoscat@mos.org) with any questions.

Paid staff positions will be posted internally for five (5) business days to give internal applicants priority during the recruitment process, in support of the Museum’s Affirmative Action Plan. At this time, the below listings are actively accepting internal applications:

Visitor Services Representative (Shift #212)

The Visitor Services Representative helps guests have the best possible experience at the Museum of Science! The VSR functions as a member of the Museum's sales and guest service force -- selling tickets and memberships and proactively making suggestions to guests at point of purchase to match guest interests to Museum offerings and meet sales goals. In addition, the VSS operates the coat room and Omni Theater front-of-house and controls access to venues including Exhibit Halls, Discovery Center, Butterfly Garden, and Omni Theater.

Deadline for Internal Applicants: 12/13/2018

This position is part-time, 11.25 hrs/wk, with the following schedule: • Friday: 4:15 PM – 9:15 PM • Saturday: 9:30 AM – 4:15 PM

November 1, 2018-November 30, 2018

“Hello,  Are gift certicates (cards) available for puchase?  if so, how may they be used?  That is, admission, gift shop, etc. -  Thanks”
 
“Dear Museum of Science,  My family came home after several weeks of staying in and out of hotels do to the gas line incident here in Lawrence. We were taken back when we found your letter with the four free passes to the Museum of Science.  Your kindness has warmed my heart, truly appreciative of your kind gesture and we will definitely take some time to enjoy the Museum with our kids.  Thank you”

“We attended an event there and enjoyed the evening until we attempted to leave. As visitors to Boston we were unaware that cokes could not be consumed on the street. A person snatched them from my husband’s hands and walked away with them.  All the way my husband is saying that we will drink the coke inside before leaving and asking for them back. They sat them on a table and just said it’s against the law.  I saw them snatch an empty cup from an older lady just outside the door very rudely as well.  If they had stood at the door explaining that cups couldn’t be taken out, we would have gladly complied.  I am sure that you will want to address this situation because rudeness to a guest should never be tolerated.”.

“Hello, I visited the museum. Myself , son and  grandchildren used a library pass  to get in . Even with this it costs $40.00 .this seems like a lot for a family making  45,000.00 with no paid vacation , no retirement  and using Mass health. Yes they too much for no EBT befits  so have to pay . Seems wrong . In  addition you over heat the place so one has to carry costs or pay more .this was my 73 th birthday gift   .Kids wanted some to eat and again the prices are high. Also we had to leave an  information movie as a parent left their kid that had some  problem and  it was play their iPhone with a high volume .You need more floor people so they ask problem kids even if they have learning problems to be respectful. only time I saw a floor person was when they were asking people to leave about 10 minutes  before closing . The bad reviews you get seem to be right on. even the MFA has free coat check and people are not so active  .  your adds should be ' the museum  for rich family's only ' or 'pay more or be left out '  $4.50 for a bottle of water and  butterfly exhibit  are extra costs more and more .We took the train and  walking the unfriendly street to north station . Were you left out of the green way?"

"Your website has no dates for Omni programs . How can I plan ahead ? Poorly designed."		

"It was disappointing when we went to the IMAX theater only to be followed by your employee ticket clerk. Guess they wanted to see something happen in the seats and sat a few rows behind us. Please stop the stalking by your employees. Thank you."	

"I would be very happy if there was a exhibit about rockets."		

"School groups are very loud and disruptive. We did not enjoy the planetarium show we paid to see as a result."

"A couple of months ago I brought my granddaughter to the museum, and she met a gentleman volunteer who was demonstrating the Theremin, a musical instrument I had never before seen. The volunteer, I don't remember his name, was so kind, spending a lot of time enthusiastically talking with my granddaughter about music. He inspired her to take up the piano, and now she is one hundred percent involved in music. Her outlook on life is also much more positive, which I attribute to her love of music. Her encounter at your museum and the caring support she got from your volunteer was so precious! That brief encounter changed her life. We came to the museum two other times but did not see him. Can you please relay to him our gratitude. He's a distinguished, tall, 60-year-old with a beard."

"Visited the Museum.  Had lunch. Ordered a 12 inch sandwich and two sides. Staff cut a 3 inch sandwich and gave us two sides.   This was the cut sandwich.   Not what I ordered. Explained this to the staff member and they said this is what they were told to give when the twelve inch was ordered. What is so hard about sending the proper food that was ordered.   Got a membership and this was not a good first impression of the staff or facility."

"We received our Sparks! newsletter this weekend and my son, age 2, was delighted to see the article about the trains. He was so excited we went to the museum the next day. However, the exhibit is not, contrary to the final paragraph of the story, here ""right now."" It doesn't open until 11/18. I suppose I could have checked that on your website but it didn't occur to me that I would need to do so."

"I'm confused.... your email solicitation invites me to renew membership, and link it, and set up auto renewals for a 10% discount..... and when I complete all the forms, no where is there a renewal option!"

"Grant in the skeleton exhibit taught us so much! What an amazing volunteer. Thank you, Grant!"

"Capitalize on the slime craze! Create a hands on exhibit for the overnights next summer. Teach on polymers + chemical reactions! My husband is a chemist and has explained the process to our kids..."

"Terrible exp! My family (wife and 4 year old) were at the space area of the museum. A very rude staff member came to us yelling while we were trying to take a last picture. They stood in front of my wife with a terrible attitude. 

"At the thanksgiving season, I would like to extend my thankfulness to your staff, Patrick, for his great help to me.  I got a flat tire on October 4th when driving out of the garage from the parking.  It is very cold and dark at that evening and I totally have no experience in dealing with such situation.  I appreciated that Patrick offered me help and eventually was home safely."

"I spent the night at the museum with my daughter. We frequent the museum, particularly the planetarium. We went to the planetarium program in the morning with our troops and I was so delighted to see that our favorite presenter was doing the show! We have seen her do many shows and it is always a treat. As always she did great and I hope to see her do another show when we return."

"On a recent visit, I had an incident with one of your employees and would like to provide feedback by sending an email directly to the appropriate supervisor in customer service or personnel. Thank you. I look forward to hearing from you."

"What happened to the Nano Brothers shows? They were the highlight of our visits, and the reason that we keep renewing our membership. Please bring them back as a weekly feature!"

"Enjoyed a trip to the Museum this weekend. However the exhibit on energy / power generation is hopelessly out of date. One graph from 2007 shows U.S. power generation coming from nearly 50% coal...a statistic that is 11 years out of date. Another sign lists coal energy as the cheapest form when in reality solar, wind, and natural gas are all cheaper than coal, see for example https://www.lazard.com/perspective/levelized-cost-of-energy-and-levelized-cost-of-storage-2018/. The display is highly misleading and must be updated -- especially given the Museum's public commitment to renewable energy. Thanks."

"I was at the museum and I think I noticed an error at the bird exhibit. The sign for Barn Owl says its endangered in connecticut and rhode island but the picture of the states below it has massachusetts and rhode island colored in."

"I was hoping that you can kindly send me a teacher member card.   I have misplaced my card.  I have been a member for years."

"I have been trying to renew a premier5 memberships as a gift with the 20% off Vybet Monday discount."

"There are stickers on the doors that say 'conserve energy' Why is there such a wide gap at the doors? Fix this please!!! The staff must get cold in the lobby."

"1) lack of any environmental messaging was surprising and disappointing.
2) all disposable dishware also surprising and disappointing"

"There used to be footprints on either side of the Boston/Cambridge split in the lobby, you could put them on the upper walkway."

"Dear Museum Staff,
Our yearly 8th Grade field trip to the MOS continues to be one of the experiential and academic highlights for our students. The MOS support is deeply appreciated by the students, parents, and staff at our school."

"I took my 10 yesr old son to the museum todAy when he had a day off from school. We were both excited for him to see “Rocky Mountain Express”  in the Omni Theater. We ended up leaving during the introduction, however, since he found the “sound check” noises, particularly what sounded like a violent car crash, to be terrifying. Target age is listed as grade 3-12, however, this sound was quite traumatic, and should be eliminated. Thank you from a longtime MOS member"

"I was a member for one year.  I am no longer a member.  I am very annoyed that I cannot EASILY unsubscribe from your email. Today I spent and inordinate amount of time going all over your web site looking for unsubscribbel  Under email I found out it was easy to unsubscribbe.  I thought it was a law that all emails must have a means to unsubscribe. I would like this email to go to the board, the webmaster, and the chief administrator.  I find this problem absolutely rude from such a large technologically advanced organization.  I expect no more emails, an at a minimum an unsubcribe link in the next email.  An apology from the museum would show good manners"

"I work  with the Arc of the South Shore. We had a great time at the Musuem on Friday. The staff gave us the discounted passes plus he was very informative. Also the staff at the animal exhibit was very nice and a very good instructor.i was wondering if you have instructors come to schools or organizations.  Thank you so much I oil forward from hearing from y

docs.messageSubject: Planned Network Maintenance Night December 11th, 2018 from 6:00pm to 11:59pm
docs.messageBody:
All,

Please be advised that IIT will be performing a planned network maintenance on the following date and time:

Tuesday December 11th, 2018 from 6:00pm to 11:59pm 

This maintenance is necessary to perform upgrades to our network infrastructure.  We anticipate this scheduled outage will take approximately 4 to 6 hrs. to complete.  During this maintenance window you may experience brief outages where servers, business applications, and or files may not be accessible both internally and externally.  To ensure uptime and stability of our platform, we are performing this upgrade shortly after close of business so we can maximize our efforts to ensure business operations will not be impacted when we open the next day.  
If you have any questions or concerns please contact the Service Desk team at x0130. 

We thank you in advance for your attention and understanding.

The MOScars Academy nominated the finalists. Now you can determine the winners! 

From October 2017 through September 2018, 664 individuals received MOScar Dollars as recognition for acts of exemplary service to our guests and/or colleagues. Another record breaking year, this is the most MOScars we have ever given in our now 11 year history!

The MOScars Academy is a cross divisional team that is chosen new every year to create the ballot. This year the Academy had A LOT of reading to do! Now it is your turn to vote on the following categories:

Best Service to Colleagues
Best Service to Guests
Best Example of Museum Mission & Spirit
Best Example of Volunteer Service & Spirit

Consistent Service Award – New for 2018!

 

*New for 2018*

  • This year the Academy has chosen to do a blind ballot! This means that names have been removed from the first 4 categories. This was a result of the feedback we received from the MOScars survey that was recently circulated to staff. We want to celebrate the special acts of service by these staff members. We will reveal the nominees at the MOScars Award Ceremony on January 10, 2019!
  • The Academy has come up with a new category for 2018, The Consistent Service Award. The staff members in this category have received some of the highest recognition from their peers through the MOScar program. They performed acts of service big and small for a lot of different people. As they read through the MOScars these people showed up over and over because they’re always there when someone needs them. The focus of this category is on the people nominated and all that they’ve done this year so they will be recognized by name.

Click HERE to vote for your favorite MOScar nominees!

Find out who wins at the MOScar Award Ceremony on Thursday, January 10th at 2:30pm in Cahners!

Voting ends Monday, December 14th. Paper ballots are available in the Volunteer Services office. Please only cast your vote once.

 

Thank you!

docs.messageSubject: Internal Job Listing- Education Associate, Live Presntations
docs.messageBody:
Internal Job Postings

Paid staff positions will be posted internally for five (5) business days to give internal applicants priority during the recruitment process, in support of the Museum’s Affirmative Action Plan. All positions accepting internal applications can be found on our Internal Employment Opportunities page.

To apply, simply click on the position title below and complete the online application. If internal staff apply after the position is posted externally, they will not be considered as a candidate because they did not apply during the internal posting period.

At this time, the below listings are actively accepting internal applications:

Education Associate, Live Presentations

The Education Associate I will research, develop and present programs to Museum and community audiences that contain accurate and relevant science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) principles and concepts in a way that both educates and inspires further interest and curiosity for participants. The programs will be based on current STEM topics and support school curriculum standards as appropriate to enhance formal learning experiences. The Education Associate will teach on site and in the community to extend the Museum's reach and relevance to society. The educator will act as a resource for STEM content and continually learn and develop new programs, demonstrations and props, and content including platforms such as podcasts and web based resources to expand the Museum's resources. They will work both on teams and individually, work closely with staff in other departments, and help host presentations/activities with key partnerships with other institutions, organizations and scientists to deliver exemplar programming.

Deadline for Internal Applicants: 12/19/18

This position is full-time, 40 hours/week, Tuesday-Saturday, 9:00am-5:00pm

We have an abundance of leftover SubSpace mailers on the 4th floor. 

Please come take some if you need:
-lots of cool posters
-unique wrapping paper
-colorful pet cage liners
-extremely cheap wallpaper
-and so much more!

Beginning on 7 January 2019,  the following exhibit areas will be closed Living on the Edge, Math Moves and the Virtual Fishtank.   The Lobster Fishing diorama, Aeolian Landscape and the giant lobster from Living on the Edge will be relocated in the Museum but the remainder of the components will either be recycled appropriately or tossed out.  Math Moves will be lightly refurbished and will move to the Living on the Edge location.  This work will be completed by February school vacation week.  The Virtual Fishtank will be going to the McAuliffe-Shepard Discovery Center in Concord New Hampshire.
 
These are the first in a series of exhibit closures and moves that will take place in winter/spring 2019 in preparation for building renovations for the two new exhibits Tech Studio and Adventure that will be opening in 2020.

docs.messageBody:
Internal Job Postings

Paid staff positions will be posted internally for five (5) business days to give internal applicants priority during the recruitment process, in support of the Museum’s Affirmative Action Plan. All positions accepting internal applications can be found on our Internal Employment Opportunities page.

Lead Visitor Services Representative

The Lead Visitor Services Representative plays a leadership role for the Visitor Services department helping to ensure that guests have the best possible experience at the Museum of Science! Functioning as a member of the Museum's sales and guest service force, the Lead VSR sells tickets and memberships and proactively makes suggestions to guests at point of purchase to match guest interests to Museum offerings and meet sales goals. In addition, the Lead VSR conducts school group check in, operates the Thrill Ride 360 simulators, 4-D Theater, coat room, and Omni Theater front-of-house, and controls access to venues including Exhibit Halls, Discovery Center, Butterfly Garden, 4-D Theater, and Omni Theater. As a leader in the department, the Lead assists the departmental management team with duties such as break schedules, cash outs and other revenue controls, sales coaching and training, troubleshooting, and advanced customer service support, and maintains a high degree of proficiency in systems, equipment, and business practices in order to support the Visitor Services team.

docs.messageSubject: GSEs for Trains! All Aboard at Science Park
docs.messageBody:
The Interpretation staff is looking for some help to staff the Trains! exhibit this coming Friday, 12/21. We have posted multiple half-day GSEs so if you are looking for a fun and different way to experience this exhibit, please consider signing up. The description is as follows: 

Help greet visitors in "All Aboard! Trains at Science Park!" Your primary role is to be available in the gallery to provide guest service, answer questions from visitors, and address concerns that may arise. You might also explore the exhibit and help visitors make observations as you feel comfortable. We'll schedule a short 15 min orientation to prep you for your time in there. During the orientation, we will give you a quick overview of the exhibit, including very basic background info and an FAQ tip sheet. We will also review procedures and provide contact information for addressing common problems.

Information Technology is pleased to announce that we are continuing to make improvements to our network infrastructure.  With the support of Museum leadership, we are enhancing security features that we enabled in December of 2017.  Beginning Tuesday evening, January 8th (after the Box Office closes), the Museum will be blocking websites that have been categorized as high risk, suspicious or have inherent security risks in regards to malware and phishing. We are taking these steps to further align the Museum with Payment Card Industry requirements as well as remain compliant with our Human Resource policies on technology usage for our community.  

What Can I Expect When This Takes Effect?
These enhancements should have no impact on your ability to do your job.  In the event you attempt to access a website for work that has been deemed risky due to malware or phishing, you will be blocked from accessing that site.

What Do I Do If I Need To Access A Site That Has Been Blocked?
If you receive a block but have a legitimate need to access the content, or have questions or need assistance, please contact the IT Help Desk at ithelp@mos.org or call x0130.

The last day that Space (located in Nichols gallery) will be open to the public is Sunday, January 1st. Check out this awesome exhibit before it's too late! 
Be sure to check out the rotating ISS Destiny Lab Module experience (if you're not prone to motion sickness).

This exhibit is on loan from the Science Museum of Minnesota.

The Advancement Division is very excited to start planning for Pi Day 2019! In an effort to raise awareness of the Museum’s mission as well as promote our annual day of giving, we are developing a new video series to be shared over email and social media to promote the four areas of STEM, and how the Museum supports each area. And we are reaching out to you because we need your help!

If you have a child between the ages of 9-15 (or know of anyone who does), we would like to invite them to be a part of our video shoot where they’ll be asked to talk about an area of STEM. We will need children/parents to be available on: 

•	Friday, January 11th between 5-8pm or
•	Sunday, January 13th between 9am–12pm or
•	Sunday, January 13th 1–4pm. 

Availability for all time slots is not required, but please indicate your availability on the form. If interested please complete the submission form below or click here. 

Filming will require a commitment of roughly 2- 3 hours during a session. A schedule will be sent to those who are selected to participate. There’s chance your child may not be chosen, simply because we are looking to capture a wide range of kids from diverse backgrounds. 

Please send your submissions no later than January 2nd. Participants will receive an Amazon gift card for $50 and food/drink will be available during shooting.

If you have any questions, please email lstanley@mos.org. 

https://goo.gl/forms/TolnORgp4GDQUoJA2

Hi everyone! WCVB's Chronicle aired a segment last night focused on the concept of "time" featuring our own Eric O’Dea! You can view it here: https://www.wcvb.com/article/its-time-to-change-how-you-look-at-aging/25621815. In the segment focused on aging, Eric discusses humans’ short time on Earth in the segment's larger context of research on health, time theories, and dementia.

docs.messageSubject: Internal Job Posting - Curriculum Program Manager for Computer Science Education
docs.messageBody:
Internal Job Postings

Paid staff positions will be posted internally for five (5) business days to give internal applicants priority during the recruitment process, in support of the Museum’s Affirmative Action Plan. All positions accepting internal applications can be found on our Internal Employment Opportunities page.

To apply, simply click on the position title below and complete the online application. If internal staff apply after the position is posted externally, they will not be considered as a candidate because they did not apply during the internal posting period.

At this time, the below listings are actively accepting internal applications:

Curriculum Manager for Computer Science Education

The role of the Curriculum Program Manager, Computer Science (CS) Education is to assist the Director of CS Education in developing curriculum and programs for the Museum's K-12 Computer Science Education Initiative. The Program Manager applies best practices in educational product development, oversees project timelines, leads curriculum writing, and works with the Director to build partnerships with educators and institutions that are vital to CS program content development, testing, and delivery.

Deadline for Internal Applicants: Friday, December 28

This position is full-time, 40 hours/week, Monday-Friday. This position will also travel 3-4 times per year, 1-4 days at a time.

docs.messageSubject: Internal Job Listing - HVAC Mechanical Systems Technician
docs.messageBody:
Internal Job Postings

Paid staff positions will be posted internally for five (5) business days to give internal applicants priority during the recruitment process, in support of the Museum’s Affirmative Action Plan. All positions accepting internal applications can be found on our Internal Employment Opportunities page.

To apply, simply click on the position title below and complete the online application. If internal staff apply after the position is posted externally, they will not be considered as a candidate because they did not apply during the internal posting period.

At this time, the below listings are actively accepting internal applications:

HVAC Mechanical Systems Technician

The position is responsible for the day-to-day preventative, diagnostic and corrective mechanical maintenance procedures for the building mechanical systems. Scheduling the computer building management system – which includes temperature control, lighting control, building environmental adjustments and air handler functionality - responding to visitor and staff requests, building management system alarms, and completing daily rounds of the critical building infrastructure. Assist with other facility repair and maintenance work in order to keep equipment in proper operation.

Deadline for Internal Applicants: Friday, December 28

This position is full-time, 40 hours/week, requiring one weekend day.

Hello Everyone, The Accounting department is very thrilled to announce that are our staff count is finally back to normal! Please help us welcome the new additions to our team: Lindsay Day, our Cash & Payroll Clerk and Alishia Syrek, our Senior AP Coordinator. Lindsay started about a month ago while Alishia just started this week. We are very happy to have them onboard and wish them a long and successful tenure at the Museum! We also wanted to thank the entire Museum for your understanding during this hectic transition. Having two vacant positions while being in the middle of our new HR/payroll system implementation has been quite challenging to say the least. So thank you for your patience and support while we were handling your requests! Happy Holidays and Cheers to another great year!

The wireless network known as MoS_Function is designated specifically for use for Museum events.  In order to ensure that this service is robust and has capacity available, the network will be password-enabled and only broadcast a signal as necessary for events beginning December 28th, 2018. 

What Can I Expect When This Takes Effect?
This will not impact your regular wireless use, as MoS_Staff (our secure, staff-only wireless) and MoS_Wifi (our open, public wireless) are available Museum-wide 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.

What Do I Do If I Need To Access A New Wireless Network?
If you have been using MoS_Function and are having difficulty switching to MoS_Staff , or have questions or need assistance, please contact the IT Help Desk at ithelp@mos.org or call x0130.

docs.messageSubject: Final Week to See "All Aboard!" Exhibit
docs.messageBody:
This is the final week to visit "All Aboard! Trains at Science Park", located in Stearns (Blue Wing, Level 1)!
Sunday, January 6th is the last day the exhibit will be open to the public. 

This exhibit was developed by the Museum in coordination with the HUB Division of the Northeastern Region (NER) of the National Model Railroad Association (NMRA)(http://hubdiv.org/). This local model train group designed and built the large model train display in the center of the gallery. HUB volunteers have also been present at the Museum almost every day to maintain the display and interact with visitors. 

Make sure you check it out before it's too late!

docs.messageSubject: New Country Style Breakfast In The Riverview Cafe!
docs.messageBody: Missing out on the most important meal of the day? Now you don’t have to! We are excited to announce that we will be launching a new breakfast program in the Riverview café beginning Monday January 7th at 7:30am. We will be offering all the breakfast classics to help start your morning off right. We will have eggs ($1.25), bacon ($1.25), french toast ($1.25) and some delicious rotating chef specials including omelets, burritos and frittatas ($3.50-$4.50) If you are looking for something quick we are also launching some delicious new fresh pastries that will be sure to give you a kick start to your day We will be open from 7:30am-9:30am and a cashier will be at the main lanes for checkout. Monday through Friday so come enjoy a delicious country style breakfast on the Charles with the Wolfgang Puck team.

December 1, 2018-December 31, 2018

“Just wanted to let you know that instructors in the Human Life wing yesterday (Mary for taste testing w/cotton swabs and Jenn for cleaning animal heart and lung) were great!!  They captivated our group of 3-7 year olds.  So instructive, so caring, so compelling.  Great job MoS!”

“I was reading about your Pink Floyd Laser Show but it was really difficult to find out 1; In what country you are located 2: Where in this country you are 3: I still haven't found out where in Boston you are located as the map only shows the intrerior of the museum.”

“For 30 years MOS had the best Mac n cheese in town. Now the new “ recipe” is extremely disappointing. Bring back the best Macy n Christmas in Boston.”

“My son and I had a great day today at the museum. I was especially impressed with an employee named Grant (I think) who was working bone exhibit on the 2nd floor. He spent a lot of time speaking with and teaching my son all about bones. “

“Went into the Mars presentation. Staff talking during the movie....whole presentation.”

“Elizabeth is extraordinary and a very nice valued worker. She made my visit above and beyond.”

“Reinstate the Solar System Model!! I love the planets at Riverside and South Station and would love to go find all of the others around Boston! (in T-Stations and otherwise)”

“We had the most pleasant experience because of an above and beyond customer service rep. named Jasmine. This place will be one to come back to because of her service.”

“Train scene too high and snow too high for kids and adults. S/B separate table--less tunnel also.”

“I signed up for membership almost two weeks now. Yet, I didn't receive membership card or even a letter from Museum of Science. When should I expect to receive them?”

“Bring back the molasses gingerbread cookies in the cafe! Chocolate chip is good, but the variety is nice and that was my favorite one.”

"The hands on exhibit was fun but there should be more items."

"Interesting, fun to learn. More signage of lab hours in main entrance."

"To whom it may concern,  I wanted to reach out in regards to my recent visit to the Museum of Science. I brought my boyfriend to see the Train Exhibit as a Christmas gift as he is a big collector and hobbyist and I had heard it advertised on the radio and saw the billboard for it as well. While we enjoyed visiting the rest of the museum, I have to say I was extremely disappointed in the train exhibit. It is presented as this great learning experience with lots to partake in and see yet was essentially just a small corner of the museum with a large train track in the middle of it. Needless to say my boyfriend was very disappointed in his experience as well. The Museum of Science is held in high regard and its customers pay good money to visit and it would be my thought that if you advertised for a grand exhibit with lots of potential, you would get what you paid for; however, in this instance that was not the case. I just wanted to bring this to someone's attention as I feel I did not get what I paid for and was greatly disappointed and would hope that in the future the museum's advertisements would hold true to their exhibits. Thank you so much for your time. “

"In the minerals exhibit, amber is included as a mineral. Amber is not a mineral. There's a fossils exhibit 5 feet away! (Well, not technically a fossil either w/o any bugs.)"

"I like trains a lot, and I like you to invent some more trains."

"I love the train exhibit. The scenes are very well done and really pretty to look at. The top is so high however that children can't see. A set of steps or bleechers around the perimeter of the room would be great so kids can step up high to admire the top."

"This science lab was a wonderful hands on experience. Thank you!"

"We found the film 'Destination Mars' to be a great disappointment w/ no real explantation of the dementions, boring colors - unhuman. We are used to better."

"I have to say how disappointing it was taking my kids here. They didn’t even like it 95 buck including parking what a rip off"

"Hello,  We recently bought a family membership.  Three of our daughter's are blind.  We are really disappointed!  Very few of the exhibits are truly blind friendly and certainly didn't engage our girls.  We would really like a refund.  We may consider becoming members at a future date if you engage new exhibits that are truly friendly to those who are blind and have special needs.  Thank you."

"I recently went to a Planetarium music show featuring Radiohead. I hadn't been to one in years, so long, in fact, that I asked for tickets to a laser show. My wife and I were wondering and hoping that someday you might have a Coldplay show in the Planetarium."

"The trains exhibit you've been promoting was very disappointing. My mother and I made the trip to the museum specifically for it, only to find it to be a rudimentary display of running trains. The top level train had clearly come undone at some point and the engine was pushing the car. The trains that were running didn't seem to have any connection to Boston or New England (even I have a T commuter rail train I could have lent you) aside from a few structures to represent Boston. There were no displays on how trains work, steam or diesel. There was nothing on the science or engineering behind railroads or important railroad landmarks. The year-round layout at Charles Ro Supply in Malden is far better and equally educational. The only positive note I have is about the gentleman explaining the different scales of model trains to people. You could have done a lot more with the history of model trains. I think for the amount of advertising you did for the exhibit, it was terribly weak and hugely disappointing. You could have at least connected with the NMRA Hub group or the local n-trak organization. Or even the New England Lego users group. I spent a lot of money to come to the museum for a lot of nothing."

"It would be very helpful if you would post holiday hours on website.  I'll call later today to see if you are open Dec 31 and/or Jan 01 and if so, what the hours are."

"We were truly disappointed by the All Aboard! train exhibit.  When I write ""we,"" I refer collectively to our family, including two boys, ages 9 and 12, two middle-aged parents, and two grandparents in their 70's.  We had encouraged our children's grandfather, a model train aficionado, to come to town to see the exhibit with us after seeing a promotional billboard over Route 90.  Our conclusion: the actual exhibit is hardly ""billboard worthy.""  While it nodded to an explanation of perspective and scale, we found little in the exhibit overall that related much to science."

"We came for the train exhibit but it was very lacking would've liked more science behind trains etc... we see more @ free train shows then here very disappointing"

"Jeremy S. smiled at us at 10:15 and was very helpful 4 1/2 hours later... I saw him responding to a group of people in the same manner. He's great!"

"All Aboard
This is a great exhibit for MOS to display. It builds connections with local organization and inter generational interactions. I liked all the 'hidden' details (Waldo, unicorn, reindeer, etc). Would add an ice scullpture to Frog Pond. Liked the snow on the roof and different types of trees. The perspective on the size of trees is well done. Really enjoyed this exhibit."

"My boyfriend loves trains and we had a really great time. Thank you :)"

"The train exhibit would have been amazing if you had an 'I spy' feature for the kids."

"None of the hand sanitizer dispensers worked in the museum!"

"Bought gift membership - we had a wonderful time."

"Love your teenage teachers! Great with little kids!"

"There was not one hand sanitizer station that worked in the entire museum!"

"'Hose threw water' was in Quick as a Wink. Was that in intentional 'threw'? Or was it supposed to be 'through'?"

"This exhibit is great. My 7 yr old son had so much fun looking at the train models & finding surprises. Making models was the best part."

“I visited on 12/31 and wanted to share my feedback about the restaurant experience in the hopes that things can be improved for other guests. The day was busy as you would expect for a vacation/holiday period. Unfortunately, the restaurant was not prepared for the influx of capacity crowds during lunch. There were not enough employees working to provide service for the amount of customers present. It led to long lines of people waiting. We waited in long lines for food, especially at the grill where the four employees I could see could not keep up with the demand. The food was gone as fast as it was prepared. Additionally, there were 6 register stations, but only 2 were staffed. This makes no sense to me. Obviously, the reason to have 6 registers was in anticipation of large crowds, but why then would you not staff them at the busiest times of the busiest days. The result was long lines of people with hungry and impatient children standing in lines holding trays of food that was getting cold. Further, the soda machines were busy, which resulted in the machines running out of ice and various sodas, and also ketchup, napkins etc. ran out. There were no available employees to replace these items as they were depleted.  The end result of all of this lack of staffing and preparation was a poor dining experience for customers. People coming to the museum expect the prices to be high and the quality of the food to suffer due to mass production, but to have to wait and wait as well is too much for families with small children. These concerns can be rectified with more staffing during the busy lunch hours and better preparation for large crowds. Thank you.”

"Can you please send me more information about your policy for admission of MIT students
to the museum of science?
I am currently a graduate student at MIT, and both as an undergraduate earlier, and now as a graduate student I've enjoyed showing the MoS to my visitors with kids to excite them about STEM for the last 9 years.  Yet, I was denied entry yesterday since apparently I no longer look like an undergraduate :)
I verified today with our activities committee (MITAC) and libraries staff assured me that a valid student MIT id is all that is needed (there is no pass like your desk member recommended).
As far as I know we have been contributing to the Museum of Science, both with money coming from my student tuition, and with volunteering and joint projects.  Our department regularly keeps our award ceremonies at the MoS, and I even attended my graduate student friends wedding there (apparently MoS was a special place to them as well).”

Accounting and IT are happy to announce the deployment of several more major reports to the SSRS reporting system: First, the Actuals by FY report in the Summary by Year Reports folder, previously announced as available but still in development, is now considered finished and ready for prime time. Other new reports include two reports under Department Budget Reports:

Department Income and Expense - This is the same as the pdf budget report managers currently get e-mailed each month. We’ll continue to send those out as a final “official” version once the books are closed for the month, but in the meantime, you can now run this yourself if there’s anything you want to check on before the monthly numbers are finalized.

Department Spread by Month - Another budget vs. actual report, but with a separate column for each month. Note that this report shows only your general operating budget (no grants or endowments).

Note that these reports speak Accounting-ese: income is reported as negative (credit) numbers. Don’t worry; you’ll get used to it. And finally, there are two new reports under General Inquiries:

Vendor Inquiry - Shows invoices and credit memos processed by Accounts Payable. Organized by Vendor, then Invoice.

Vendor Inquiry by Check - The same information as above, but clumped by check.

Note that while other SSRS reports have data going back several years, since we just started entering invoices directly into the new Accounting system on 11/1/2017, that’s as far back as the Vendor reports will go. If you have questions about invoices/payments earlier than that, e-mail Accounting. With the deployment of these reports, we have now reproduced most of the functionality you used to enjoy (well, not enjoy, but at least had) with Crystal. There are still a couple of specialized reports we have yet to push out, but what’s now available is a pretty complete manager toolkit for looking at your financial data. As always, check out the All About Finance Reports in SSRS document on Accounting’s Hub page for further info on using this system.

docs.messageSubject: Special Funded Field Trip Opportunity for March!
docs.messageBody:
Hi everyone!

Do you know a High School student or teacher who would love to visit the Museum of Science on a field trip for free? If so, please share with them about "High School Health Month." All March long the Museum will be partnered with CVS Health to offer exhibit hall funding and transportation scholarships for all high schools. 

There will also be special programming for this field trip opportunity, including rotating lung activities in the Hall of Human Life, and a new live presentation called "Fresh Look at Old Habits." You can read more about this opportunity here: 

https://www.mos.org/highschoolhealthmonth

If you have any questions, feel free to contact Joanna and I at: jsnyder@mos.org and cmoscat@mos.org

Best,

Christina

Hello Everyone,

The following policy has been updated in the Employee Handbook:

Religious Accommodation Policy:

The Museum of Science respects the religious beliefs and practices of all staff and will make, on request, an accommodation for such observances when a reasonable accommodation is available that does not create an undue hardship on the Museum’s business.

 

Requesting and Approval of Religious Accommodation

Staff whose religious beliefs or practices conflict with their job, work schedule, or with other aspects of employment, and who seeks a religious accommodation must submit a written request to their immediate manager. The written request must include the type of religious conflict that exists and the staff member’s suggested accommodation. Once the request is made to the manager, the manager will consult with Human Resources for a determination. Once a determination has been made, the manager will inform the staff member of the result.

To view the most updated version of the Employee Handbook please visit the HR Hub page.

docs.messageSubject: REMINDER: Summer Course Registration for Staff
docs.messageBody:
Summer Course Registration for Staff

The Museum’s Summer Courses will go on sale to museum members on Tuesday January 15 at 9am.  If you are a staff member, you will be able to register with Science Central beginning Monday January 14.  

The discounted fee for staff is $255 per half day 1 week course ($510 for a full day).  In order to register please call Science Central on Monday at 617-723-2500 or x7993 from within the museum.

As many of you know, our Summer Course Program is very popular, capacity is limited and many courses sell out quickly.  Because of this, you may only register early a child for whom you are a parent or guardian .  Unfortunately we cannot extend early registration beyond your immediate family. Additionally, you are welcome to register participants for an available course at any time after registration officially opens on January 15. 

To recap:
•	Courses will go on sale early to Museum Staff (Mon Jan 14 )
•	Register by calling Science Central (617-723-2500 or x7993)

REMINDER: Summer Course Registration for Staff
Nancy Ries

January 8

Summer Course Registration for Staff

The Museum’s Summer Courses will go on sale to museum members on Tuesday January 15 at 9am. If you are a staff member, you will be able to register with Science Central beginning Monday January 14. 

The discounted fee for staff is $255 per half day 1 week course ($510 for a full day). In order to register please call Science Central on Monday at 617-723-2500 or x7993 from within the museum.

As many of you know, our Summer Course Program is very popular, capacity is limited and many courses sell out quickly. Because of this, you may only register early a child for whom you are a parent or guardian . Unfortunately we cannot extend early registration beyond your immediate family. Additionally, you are welcome to register participants for an available course at any time after registration officially opens on January 15.

I am very pleased to announce that Brian Therrien has been promoted to the position of Associate Vice President of Finance.  During his over 9 years at the Museum, Brian has provided outstanding oversight and instituted needed improvements in the Museum’s complex annual operating budget process, the production of the monthly financial reporting package, and the annual audit.  He has taken on increasingly important financial leadership roles on cross-divisional teams including for curriculum and exhibit-related projects.  He also has been a key driver in the recent implementation of the new HRIS system and the review and updating of various pay policies.  Brian’s hard work and business savvy, his ability to identify and institute changes in processes and procedures throughout the Museum and his efforts to work with all levels of the organization to deliver insightful perspectives on budgets and projects are relied upon to ensure the best financial results.  Please join me in congratulating Brian on this well-deserved promotion!

docs.messageSubject: Annual Hazardous Waste Training 1/17 and 1/22, 1-2pm in Cahners Theater
docs.messageBody:
Annual Hazardous Waste Management/Minimization Training Sessions have been scheduled for:

Thurs Jan 17 1pm-2pm or 
Tues Jan 22 1pm-2pm 

If you work with Hazardous Materials that may become Hazardous Waste, or you supervise someone that generates Hazardous Waste, you must attend an annual hazardous waste training session. 

Please join us, if you did not receive an invite to this training and you work with Hazardous Materials or if you feel you may benefit from this training to better understand what hazardous waste is and how to properly handle and dispose of it. 

Hazardous Chemicals/Materials may become hazardous waste through use, spills, chemical expiration, abandonment, etc. This session will provide information about how to minimize the generation of hazardous waste and how to properly manage the waste in accordance with state and federal regulations.

Proper management of Universal Waste (i.e. bulbs, batteries) and E-Waste (electronics) will also be covered in these training sessions. 

If you have any questions regarding this training or the MOS Hazardous Waste Program please do not hesitate to contact me.

Best regards,
Christina Dillard

Hi Everyone,

We are very excited to share that the Museum will be marching in the Boston Pride Parade for the first time ever this coming June! We welcome all staff, along with their families, significant others and friends to join in this special day and help represent the spirit of the Museum. All are encouraged to wear their MOS best (t-shirts, red coats, etc.) and we will host a sign-making session closer to the day of the parade to celebrate this special opportunity for us as an institution to support the LGBTQ+ community and its allies.

If you are interested in marching with us, please email the MOS Co-Marshalls James Wetzel and Dani LeBlanc to be added to the participant list. We will continue to send out reminders and more information over the course of the Spring to those who sign up. In the meantime, don’t hesitate to reach out with any questions, and we hope you will join us in spreading  the message that the Museum of Science is an institution for ALL! 

A little more about Boston Pride—
Boston Pride produces events and activities to achieve inclusivity, equality, respect, and awareness in Greater Boston and beyond. Fostering diversity, unity, visibility, and dignity, we educate, communicate, and advocate by building and strengthening community connections. With over 55,000 marchers and 750,000 live spectators in 2018, plus broadcasting on local media channels, joining the Boston Pride Parade is sure to bring visibility to your organization and signal the work you do for equality.

Saturday, June 8, 2019
START: Copley Square (MOS meeting location TBA)
FINISH: Boston City Hall Plaza
12 noon (pending City approval)
Rain or Shine

Best,

James & Dani

What does an organization do with the leftover food after an event? In an effort to support sustainability and reduce food waste, Wolfgang Puck Catering, the exclusive onsite caterer at the Museum of Science, has partnered with Rescuing Leftover Cuisine, a local non-profit food rescue program. When the opportunity exists to donate excess prepared foods, Wolfgang Puck Catering will contribute to homeless shelters, rescue missions, and/or other bona-fide institutions of need. Already this year, catering has provided multiple donations to various shelters throughout Boston. hashtag#sustainability hashtag#science hashtag#catering hashtag#waste hashtag#donations hashtag#museums hashtag#localization hashtag#rescue hashtag#shelter hashtag#organics hashtag#missions hashtag#eventing

This spring Information Technology will be redesigning and refreshing the Museum’s wireless network.  The goal of this effort is twofold: 1) to update our infrastructure to bring us into compliance with Payment Card Industry (PCI) requirements, and 2) to support a greater number of devices and increase application performance throughout the building, for both staff and visitors alike.

This work will span several weeks as IT and our partner vendors work our way through the entire facility installing new equipment.  In order to determine the best place for access points and other equipment such as cables and wiring, a site survey will be required as a first step.  This will also help identify what type of equipment is needed and how it needs to be installed.

IT will be conducting the onsite survey the week of January 28th and we expect it to take 2-3 days to complete.  It will require that we bring contractors and their survey equipment into office and exhibit hall spaces during business hours, when the wireless is in use.  IT plans to survey the offices on floors 4-6 on Monday, and then move to the Gordon Wing, lower floors and exhibit halls on Tuesday and Wednesday.

What Can I Expect When This Takes Effect?
The survey work should have no impact on your ability to do your job.  We anticipate minimal disruption, if any, to normal business activities or the visitor experience.  There will be no disruption of network services during this time.

What Do I Do If I have Concerns?
If you have concerns regarding the survey, or have questions or need assistance, please contact the IT Help Desk at ithelp@mos.org or call x0130.

docs.messageSubject: Community Charter School of Cambridge Partnership 2019
docs.messageBody:
As some of you may know, the Museum of Science has a partnership with the Community Charter School of Cambridge (CCSC) in Cambridge, MA. As a part of this partnership, we host CCSC Seniors as Volunteers at the Museum to help them fill their Senior Internship requirement from January until the end of May.

Starting tomorrow, Wednesday, 1/23, 6 CCSC Students will begin their Museum of Science experience. Three students will be in EHI, one will be in Tech Studio, one will be in HHL, and one will be in Discovery Center. They will volunteer in their departments every Wednesday morning and participate in Personal/Professional Development Workshops in the afternoon led by the School and Youth Programs Team.

Please join us in welcoming our new friends and feel free to say hello if you see them at Coffee Talk or in the Exhibit Halls!

docs.messageSubject: Internal Hob Listing- Public Safety Officer/Shift Leader
docs.messageBody:
Internal Job Postings

Paid staff positions will be posted internally for five (5) business days to give internal applicants priority during the recruitment process, in support of the Museum’s Affirmative Action Plan. All positions accepting internal applications can be found on our Internal Employment Opportunities page.

To apply, simply click on the position title below and complete the online application. If internal staff apply after the position is posted externally, they will not be considered as a candidate because they did not apply during the internal posting period.

At this time, the below listings are actively accepting internal applications:

Public Safety Officer/Shift Leader

The Public Safety Officer/Shift Leader position will take on different responsibilities depending on days and schedule worked. As a Public Safety Officer, They are responsible for maintaining a safe and secure environment by being alert to potential threats through patrols and electronic surveillance, responding to emergency incidents, disturbances, and requests for assistance in accordance with the Crisis Management Plan and department policies and procedures. Responsible for maintaining smooth operation of garage entry and exit process, providing excellent customer service with garage operational issues and taking immediate and effective action to minimize service disruptions to staff, interns, volunteers, contractors, or guests. As a Public Safety Shift Leader, They are responsible for maintaining a safe and secure environment by coordinating the activities of Public Safety Officers on the shift including but not limited to: ensuring staff are properly trained to perform daily shift procedures and operational tasks; responding to emergency incidents and performing critical analysis of the circumstances to determine when to involve the Director of Public Safety or Assistant Manager or Public Safety and take preliminary action to safe guard staff, volunteers, interns, guests, and property prior to the arrival of the Director of Public Safety and/or Crisis Management Team designee; monitoring the Skidata garage system and garage capacity report to coordinate efficient garage entry and exit process; and accounting of garage bank and daily revenue.

Deadline for Internal Applicants: 1/31/19

This position is full-time, 32.5 hours/week, and this individual will be working the following shifts on the following days: • Friday and Saturday, 12:00am- 8:00am (Shift Leader position) • Sunday and Monday, 12:00am - 8am (Public Safety Officer position)

docs.messageSubject: Boston Celtics and JN Philips Recyling Challenge
docs.messageBody:
If you noticed a lot of Boston Celtics fans in the Museum today, that was no coincidence.  The Museum welcomed the Celtics and 7th graders from Argenziano School in Somerville for a morning of design challenges and celebrating recycling.
As part of a school-wide contest, the students recycled 2,691 bottles in just 10 days, a school record! For their efforts, they were rewarded with a field trip to the Museum and the opportunity to meet 2008 world champion for the Boston Celtics, Leon Powe. Together they participated a design challenge led by Engineering Education Associates, Devin Curley and Arga Yunus, using only recycled materials.

Quiet Time
Today, February 7th
10:00am – 10:25am
Planetarium



Practice the art of quieting your mind in the Planetarium! Enjoy peaceful music as you look up at thousands of stars and clear your mind.


Hope to see you there!

Hello friends!

If you don't know, my name is Jeremy and I work in Science Central as the Sunday Info Desk Specialist (among other things). I am also a Master of Divinity candidate at Boston University School of Theology, where I am currently completing my contextual field education at Safe Havens Interfaith Partnership Against Domestic Violence and Elder Abuse. My work there centers on the intersection of spirituality, sexuality, and violence. 

My end goal is to create a resource for faith and ethical leaders that will set necessary guidelines on how to appropriately, compassionately, and in a way that is identity affirming provide spiritual and pastoral care to survivors of sexual and intimate partner violence who are LGBTQ+. This is a significant undertaking that has been met with overwhelming interest and support. To this end, I would like to share a flyer for upcoming listening sessions I will be having with survivors who identify as LGBTQ+ in the hopes that more and more word will get out. The more participants who attend these, the better, as no one person's experience is the same. 

Hopefully these issues haven't impacted you personally, but maybe you attend a place of worship or are involved in a community where someone could benefit from sharing their experiences in a safe and non judgemental way.

Museum friends!

I've been brewing up some fermentation projects this winter, and I'm currently in search of a kombucha SCOBY (Symbiotic Colony of Bacteria and Yeast), also known as a kombucha "mother" or "mushroom". I figured that my fellow science nerds here at MoS might be able to supply me with one such blob of living microbes. I would also be interested in water kefir granules if you've got them! :)

Either way, let me know-- I can supply a vessel to receive said SCOBY, and I'm happy to do a trade with other homemade ferments, tinctures, herb clippings, art, high fives, etc.

Thanks!
Leandra

MOScar of the Month!

 

The MOScars Team would like to highlight and share some of the wonderful deeds from your colleagues and volunteers!

From the dozens of nominations we receive each week, we have selected a MOScar that we believe best exemplifies the spirit of the program across all categories. And the ensuing MOScar of the Month will consist of this email shout-out and, of course, bragging rights.

 

Our January MOScar of the Month is….

 

CONGRATULATIONS Allison Anderson!

Best Service to Colleagues

Recognized by Marta Beyer on January 4, 2019

 

“Starting last year, Allison organized a very complicated tracking system for a Research & Evaluation Department survey that goes out yearly to hundreds of NISE Network participants across the country. The process that she put in place has made this year's work so much more efficient and will be a major help in the future. Allison did an amazing job of pulling together a massive database, various Excel files, and our survey system's capacities. Allison's attention to detail and deep knowledge of how to make all of these aspects work seamlessly with each other has been a tremendous contribution and asset to the evaluation of the NISE Network's Earth and space efforts. Thank you, Allison, for your super work on this behind the scenes process related to sending out surveys!”

  

Take time to write a MOScar today. It only takes a minute but can make someone’s entire day. Remember - no deed is too small!

 

CLICK HERE to recognize someone

The Museum will be celebrating National Engineers Week during the Massachusetts school vacation week again this year! This is a great opportunity to highlight our engineering-focused programming to a building packed with excited visitors. Activities occurring Sunday, February 17th through Saturday, February 23rd include: 
 
- Hoop Glider, Paper Bridge, or Spinning Top engineering activities for groups with children 8 and under in the Discovery Center*  
- Engineering-themed presentations at the Gordon Current Science and Technology Stage 
- Hands-on engineering and technology activities in the Hands-On Lab and throughout the Museum with Exhibit Hall Interpretation staff  
- Extended programming in the Engineering Design Workshop featuring regular Design Challenges and Engineering is Elementary activities 

*Please note the Discovery Center has a limited capacity and may have wait times for entry. 
 
This year we are also hosting volunteers from several of our corporate members. Look for volunteers from AIR Worldwide, New Balance, and others helping with our engineering programming. Special thanks to Volunteer Services and Corporate Relations/Advancement for helping recruit and train our corporate volunteers!

Hi! Annual Giving is trying to collect stories from employees, volunteers, and visitors that show the impact made by the Museum. If you have any stories, please shoot me an email: alexbrown@mos.org. Thanks so much. I look forward to hearing all the stories!
