docs.messageSubject: A New Comment Card Report January 1, 2019-January 31, 2019
docs.messageBody:
Comment Cards January 1, 2019-January 31, 2019

"Hello, and my apologies for the previous interrupted comment. This comment form submits the comment as soon as you press Enter. I'd like to draw your attention to non-scientific wording in the New England Habitats exhibit in the Green Wing of the museum. As you can see in the pictures linked below, the panel for every species says, '[the species] are built for survival'. This is teleological wording that ignores science, misinforms the public, and suggests that the MOS adheres to creationism. Please correct these displays to something like 'how [animals] are adapted to their environment' or 'how [animals] have evolved to adapt to their environment.' Thank you. https://photos.app.goo.gl/ZjUEM2gQCYhwLaoc7"

"My husband and son were there last week and my son left his water bottle next to the photo booth. I was sure it would be at Lost & Found went I went to retrieve it today. I was informed by the gentleman at the Info Booth that all things 'food related' are thrown out at the end of each day. A reusable Nalgene water bottle labeled with the child's name? Really?? Conservation is promoted throughout the building, starting at the front door. This policy of throwing away a child's water bottle without giving his parent any time at all to come for it is in direct opposition to your conservation efforts. I highly recommend you amend this policy."

"My 6yr old son's favorite spot in the museum has always been the hallway of moveable gears and pulleys (lower level, blue wing). He's a beginner reader, so he's noticing words more and today he noticed that several of the machines were missing their labels. I'm sure that it's not a priority, but we would love to see that area freshened up and missing labels re-painted. Thank you very much!"

"I was at the museum today, to view the new trains exhibit. It was fantastic! Trains have been part of my life for over 60 years. It's so encouraging to see that the museum is promoting our great hobby! Unfortunately the average of model railroaders is around 65 so we need all the help we can get!"

"Is the David Bowie Experience only at 7:30 in the evening?  What about those of us who grew up with his music but can no longer drive at night?  I live in Kittery and getting to the Museum for 7:30 and then making it home is a real hardship.  Thank you"

"In the Hall of Human Life, the Do you looked scared link station is not recording data correctly."

"Am I missing it on your webpage or is there no membership opportunity as a singleton?"

"I was at the museum, one show i saw was the polar Express in 4d and i was not happy with it as it was not what i thought it would be for 4d i am not happy about it."

"I do not know why my membership did not auto-renew."

"Hi, I am a basic member and attended the Volcanos Imax today. The movie was very good. When I went to pay for the parking, the machine did not acknowledge my membership card and there for did not get the 2 hour discount. We were not there more than 2 hours but were still charged $13.00 on my credit card."

"After ordering tickets and being told that my membership would be applied at checkout the website proceeded to charge my card. Now I'm on eternal hold to try and get this charge off..."

"I also still haven't received my membership cards (and got the membership sometime before Christmas)"
"Your Wardsboro Panther display reads that the last 'cougar' killed in New England was killed in 1881.  This information might be correct if you had said 'last Eastern cougar' ... 130 years later, a cougar was struck and killed on the Wilbur Cross Pkwy in Connecticut. DNA showed that this animal came from Black Hills, S.D.  
The last 'cougar' killed  part of your display should properly reflect the correct feline on display, an (Eastern) cougar."

"I'm a local MOS lover and have been visiting the museum all my life. Yesterday, I spent the afternoon at MOS with my family. I happened to walk by a staff member who was giving a presentation on the top science stories of 2018. He did a wonderful job and I really enjoyed it! However, what I'd most like to remark upon was what it meant to me to hear him introduce himself with his pronouns in that setting. I am a non-binary person who uses they/them/theirs pronouns. It is often so hard to get even my own family to be respectful of my pronouns and gender identity. To see a MOS staff member in a professional, science-based, and highly visible setting introduce himself with his pronouns really made me feel valid. It made me want to come back even more, and to bring friends who are not always treated with respect for their identities. It was particularly meaningful that this staff member included his pronouns despite their not contradicting the assumptions audience members may have made about him—that is to say, he appeared to be cis-gendered but included pronouns anyway, sending the super duper important message that this is for everyone, not just trans folks. Thank you all so, so much. I hope that you will please let the staff member know how much his words meant to me, and that MOS will continue to be a leader for social justice. Whether you know it or not, we see the large and small ways you seek to support marginalized communities and they mean everything to us. Truly, thank you."

"TWIMC, I apologize for the formatting, but your platform does not allow for me to hit the 'return' button on mobile (as I've now learned twice). I hope, despite this inconvenience, this message is received and taken seriously.  Besides fixing that issue (allowing people to hit 'return/enter' on mobile to improve formatting as well as changing formatting to automatically  create new 'lines' instead of typing them all in a single stream of text. As I attempt to navigate this, I am reminded there is an email I can reply to for more immediate service. Despite the fact I don't require immediate feedback, I'll opt out of this as it seems barely navigable. Please ask a higher-up to try to utilize this. It's ridiculous." 

"Had a great time. Your staff was very helpful & supportive of my disabled parent. It's great that you offer scooters free of charge.

Suggestion - sell petware/clothing in souvenir shop."

"All Aboard:  Best thing I've ever seen!"

"Please put a tip box in the restrooms, like you have @ the coat check. Bathroom staff work very hard and are very friendly and gracious."

"I know this isn't PC, but we will not be taking our family any more to an institution that welcomes this group https://www.facebook.com/theslaughterhousesociety/ according to this article: https://www.boston.com/culture/events/2019/01/14/museum-of-science-drag-king-show-to-planetarium-valentines-day 

"Hi! Please remove me from your mailing lists. I love the MOS, but I don't like to receive mail. 
Thank you!"

"I am very annoyed by my visit to your cafeteria. My wife tried getting a cup for tap water (which is supposed to be free) and they literally gave us the equivalent of a shot glass and wouldn't give us another shot glass or a bigger cup. This is an absolute joke. Just because we dont want to drink soda doesnt mean we should get cups equivalent to a sip of water. You are the museum of science, you should be encouraging people to drink water not soda. The employees not giving us a reasonable cup for tap water really spoiled my trip and we will not be returning to the museum of science because of it, we will just explore nature instead. I don't return to places that treat their custoners so poorly, you should be ashamed."

"Hi, I'd love to be able to access my member card on my phone by logging into the website or a mobile app, so that I don't need to carry the physical card. Any plans to do that?
Shameless plug: I work for a company specializing in building web and mobile apps, would love to help if we can.
Thanks!" 

"Wondering why the 5 person family membership only comes with 4 passes for each thing? We have 5 people in our family ages 7-41, so they all need tickets, but in order for us to go to anything, we have to purchase one additional ticket. It is frustrating to have to pay for another ticket. Wouldn't it make sense to offer a regular 2 person membership and then ""add a person"" option for the membership extras? Or just put 5 tickets each on the 5 person membership? Just curious why you have it set up like that. Thanks"

"the amount of stations are wonderful, I thoroughly liked the chemistry."				

"It was cool and I liked it. :) Awsome!!!!"

"We came to see the trains that came from the cardiac waiting room @ Boston Children's Hospital. We were told that they are not currently on display. We would like to know if they'll be coming back. My son is very disappointed & searching for it."

"Thrill ride Kim was the Best."

"I am a little upset about your renewal policy. I got a renew notice in the mail and I decided to renew on-line. When I completed the renewal it said that my membership was only until 1/31/2020. My current membership ends 3/31/2019. That means my membership is only for 10 months. In the past I have renewed by mail and the new membership has been added at the end of the current membership which would have been 3/31/2020. I guess I will have make sure that I renew during the month my membership expires so I get a full 12 months." 

"We have been a member at museum of science for years and really enjoy Discover Center. However, we had a very unpleasant experience this morning while visiting the space.

docs.messageSubject: Boston's Best Drag Queens HUBWeek Award Nomination!
docs.messageBody:
Hi Everyone,

Our team has continued to collaborate with some of the city's best Drag performers over the past year on a series of Drag shows in the Planetarium. They have been incredibly successful in broadening our audience and fulfilling our mission that ALL are welcome at the Museum. We are also proud to say this type of collaboration is the first of it's kind in the Planetarium field garnering much support and interest from our colleagues, and we are excited to continue to push the boundaries of the dome as a venue and performance medium. 

We are fortunate to have been nominated for a HUBWeek Art Award, for "Provocative Performance Art" and would love our colleagues to take 10 seconds and vote for us! The link to do so is here- https://tinyurl.com/yyqtclzm 

We appreciate the support and thanks in advance!

docs.messageSubject: Internal Job Listing - Lead Visitor Services Representative
docs.messageBody:
Internal Job Postings

Paid staff positions will be posted internally for five (5) business days to give internal applicants priority during the recruitment process, in support of the Museum’s Affirmative Action Plan. All positions accepting internal applications can be found on our Internal Employment Opportunities page.

To apply, simply click on the position title below and complete the online application. If internal staff apply after the position is posted externally, they will not be considered as a candidate because they did not apply during the internal posting period.

At this time, the below listings are actively accepting internal applications:

Lead Visitor Services Representative

The Lead Visitor Services Representative plays a leadership role for the Visitor Services department helping to ensure that guests have the best possible experience at the Museum of Science! Functioning as a member of the Museum's sales and guest service force, the Lead VSR sells tickets and memberships and proactively makes suggestions to guests at point of purchase to match guest interests to Museum offerings and meet sales goals. In addition, the Lead VSR conducts school group check in, operates the Thrill Ride 360 simulators, 4-D Theater, coat room, and Omni Theater front-of-house, and controls access to venues including Exhibit Halls, Discovery Center, Butterfly Garden, 4-D Theater, and Omni Theater. As a leader in the department, the Lead assists the departmental management team with duties such as break schedules, cash outs and other revenue controls, sales coaching and training, troubleshooting, and advanced customer service support, and maintains a high degree of proficiency in systems, equipment, and business practices in order to support the Visitor Services team.

Deadline for Internal Applicants: DATE

This position is full-time, 39 hours/week, with the following schedule: • Monday: 8:45am - 5:30pm • Tuesday: 8:45am - 5:30pm • Friday: 8:45am - 3:45pm • Saturday: 8:45am - 5:15pm • Sunday: 8:45am - 5:15pm

Hi all! Just a general FYI, the Buddies Exploring Science Together (BEST) Program will begin tomorrow and run pretty much every Wednesday and Thursday morning from now through mid-April. In this program, BPS middle school students with Autism Spectrum Disorders will attend field trips at the MoS for several consecutive weeks, supported by MoS educators and by Boston University Occupational Therapy graduate students. 

On Wednesdays, the students will be coming from the Orchard Gardens School. On Thursdays, the students will be coming from the Jackson Mann School. We'll be based in Hornblower, but will be bringing the groups of students to a variety of exhibits/shows throughout the Museum. Please feel free to ask me if you have any questions! This program is heading into its 7th year and has been a huge success in years past. We're very excited to get started with it this year!

-Katie (kslivensky@mos.org; x4248)

Membership has one half-day afternoon GSE available for tomorrow, February 28. This GSE lets you...

[*] enjoy a workstation with an up close and personal view of the Charles River
[*] earn GSE credit
[*] and experience the satisfaction of knowing you've helped the Membership Department and the Museum's members!

If you have the availability, please consider signing up.

docs.messageSubject: Thursday 2/28: Extreme Animal Adaptations High School Science Series
docs.messageBody: School and Youth Programs is hosting the Extreme Animal Adaptations High School Science Series Thursday, 2/28. For this event, up to 300 high school students and their teachers will be at the Museum exploring the theme by engaging in hands-on activities, visiting the Nature’s Superheroes: Life at the Limits exhibit and attending a Keynote Presentation.  The scheduled program is: < b > 11: 00 AM - 11: 45 AM: < /b> Keynote Presentation in Cahners Theater by Harvard University Geobiologist, Jeffery Marlow. He will be presenting about his experiences doing research on microorganisms in extreme environments. All are welcome to join us for the keynote presentation.If you have any questions, please email Hannah Yaeger at HYaeger @mos.org.

Thank you to everyone				for your help,				support,				and participation in National Engineers Week this year!We are proud to say that we engaged 6,				385 visitors in our engineering activities and presentations throughout the museum over National Engineers Week(2 / 17 - 2 / 23),				and saw a total of 7,				630 visitors who participated in engineering activities over the entire school vacation week(2 / 16 - 2 / 24).
\ nSpecial thanks to Discovery Center,				CS & T,				and EHI staff who helped make this possible with their additional engineering programming throughout the week,				as well as to Engineering is Elementary staff who ran their engineering activities				for hundreds of museum visitors in the Engineering Design Workshop on Tuesday and Wednesday afternoons.In addition,				thank you to those who signed up				for GSEs and to Volunteer Services and Corporate Relations / Advancement				for helping recruit and train our corporate volunteers.Thank you everyone!

docs.messageSubject: A New Commnet Card Report has Been Generated-2/1/19-2/28/19
docs.messageBody:
February 2019 Comment Cards

"I just saw the David Bowie Experience and I LOVED it. 
Thank You!"

"Can you suggeste an appropriate movie for a 6  1/2 year old at the planetarium."

"Drag Queen and King shows? Really? What does this have to do with science. THIS IS WHY I WILL NOT BE RENEWING MY FAMILY MEMBERSHIP."

"I am most interested is watching the IMAX movie 'Superpower Dogs' yet the current listing indicates that no theater in New England plans on airing it.  Please consider adding this movie to you future listings."

"Your reset password 'change password' button does not work after receiving the link to reset." 
"There is a broken “Exhibit” link. I noticed this by clickkng on Exhibits from the Valentines via an iPhone.
https://www.mos.org/exhibits/chocolate"

"I am wondering if the women of gastropod will be returning to the mos any time soon? And, can yall have Tracy and Holly from Stuff You Missed in History Class too???  PLEASE."

"How do I change the names on the membership account? Why not possible online? Thanks."

"Hi there. I bought tickets for the David Bowie experience last weekend, which I was super excited for. When I arrived at 7:33, three minutes late, we we're locked out. 
I was never informed that I would be locked out. The lady at the desk said it said so when I purchased my ticket but that information was not included. I saw the event through Facebook and bought them through the link provided there. 
Now you're sold out this weekend and I missed an awesome opportunity due to lack of communication on your part. 
I wanted to let you know that there were many others waiting in line with me for their refund. 
Thank you for your time on the matter. "

"Recently I visited the museum for 3-4 hours. I paid for parking, but did not receive a receipt. At the parking gate my ticket was not recognized (so I had to back up and get in another lane) and I was charged the full day's rate. I'm requesting a refund on that last charge only. I can send documentation by email. Thank you."

"In the Charles River exhibit there is a sign showing how land was filled to increase the size of  Boston and Cambridge , But it doesn’t say where the dirt came from"

"Many years ago when I was a kid I remember two things that are no longer at the museum: a huge steam engine out front and a boat’s bridge that might have been where the discovery center is now. It would be nice to see the boat bridge return and to see something telling about the steam engine. 
Also, it would be nice to see the steam engine in the basement of the blue wing moving"

"Hi,
I'm very interested in how you process and apply information to exhibits in the Planetarium!!
I work in Clinical Pharmacy so I'm curious how those in other scientific fields apply literature and information
Please reach out, I'd Love to discuss more!"

"I am writing to let you know about a disappointing experience I had with two staff members.  
The employees were engaged in a conversation for the entire time we were present, and appeared to be annoyed when people engaged them to ask questions.  While engrossed in their conversation, they also were standing in the way of one of the benches. This experience was so uncharacteristic of my typically positive encounters at the MoS that I wanted to share this feedback."

"Hello,  Please pass this note onto Terry in Live Presentations. I had the pleasure meeting Terry yesterday at the Lightning demonstration and told him of its online video.  A phenomenal show!"	

"Cafe food is going downhill.  Three days straight no fish and chips. Got chicken fingers and fries today because no fish again - horrible- fries were cold, chicken tasted it’s been sitting in grease for a while. What a wasted lunch break, and wasted $, couldn’t eat half of it. Please get better food quality and cooks"		

"Cafeteria VERY dirty unpleasant"

"Thanks for yesterday's visit. My family always enjoys the MoS. Yesterday's hit was 'Superheros' exhibit, esp. the tardigrade and the various deep-diving mammals. The butterflies are always a tonic in the middle of winter. 
I think there is an error in the activity ""Mapping the Coast"" in the ""Making Models"" sections. In this activity, the guest looks through a window at a slow rotating island, and is asked to create map the coastline. There are 4 signs posted on the island, one for each of the cardinal compass directions. After the guest is satisfied with their effort, they lift a flap to view the right answer. 
As a sailor (and driver in Boston), I'm used correlating what I see with what's on the map. It's a good skill to have and I'm glad to see an exhibit showcasing it.
The problem is that the right answer is not presented with North-is-Up orientation.  To see this, look for the single deep narrow bay.  On the model, it occurs in the NW quadrant of the island. On the answer-map, it occurs just south of west, say 255°. It's about 80° off. That's frustrating.
I hope you find the above explanation cogent. If I'm mistaken and there's really no error after all, I'd love to be corrected."

"I visited the MofS today with my family and especially loved the Superpowers Exhibit and the Wild Kratts exhibit, specifically with their common theme of deep ocean ecosystems.  In the future I would love to further explore the process of chemosythesis and the symbiotic relationship that exists within giant tube worms.  Lastly, the Art and Nature exhibit I visited last month was so incredible, and underrated.  Each pull of a drawer was breathtaking, and I’d love to learn more about mordern art in nature collections.  Thanks for your time.  Best wishes!!!"

"Good morning,
Yesterday my family and I had taken a trip to the MOS which we had done many times when our children were younger. When purchasing our tickets to the exhibit hall I had inquired about any benefits for military/veterans. The cashier asked for an ID which mine had started I was retired. I was told there is nothing offered for Veterans only active Military Members. I wouldn’t be writing this today if I hadn’t noticed on your website that you offer FREE admission to the exhibit hall for EBT/WIC recipients for up to 4 family members which I found to be quite disheartening that I served 21 years to our great nation only to be told my service doesn’t qualify me or my family for any type of discount. Not that I expect one but the fact that EBT/WIC admission is completely free made me feel as though I had to express my dismay. Our family has always enjoyed the MOS and we have told many families and friends of the fun we’ve had there, but from this point on I will also be sharing the fact that you off free admission for EBT/WIC and nothing for Veterans and family.
Thank you for your time"

"When I visited information to voice my issues from walking from the Cambridgeside mall. I was told this happens because of Feb break. I get that however, to not post on social media or your own website is inconsiderate. You need to inform guests where to go and how to plan a visit. Plus, if this does happen often then have a relationship with the mall so my membership with parking isn’t a waste. Very annoyed"

"I am trying to give in honor/memory of a deceased relative, but clicking on 'give in honor of someone' on the site https://mos.org/make-a-gift takes me to the monthly giving site."

"We arrived with a toddler planning to park knowing I had w/ membership free parking. Lot was full and we were directed to Galleria lot. Now told parking is not reimbursed @ Galleria. One of the benefits of membership is the free parking which we could not get reimbursed."

"Charles River Exhibit: The section on sewers - when tiles are placed one of the options says rainwater enters sewer system which is incorrect."

"Absolutely above and beyond expectations! From Megan and the girls @ the box office to Patrick in security to the fabulous Marc S. 25 yrs. in customer service and I was blown away! We love you guys."

"The discovery center is always crowded and normally has a wait list. Unfortunately, our experience with the center has always been negative. The wait list is not properly managed and we have had to go home without the experience of the discovery center. The kids eagerly look forward to it and so far they have been disappointed. It would be great and appreciated if you take great care managing the wait list."

"We are members and we love the Museum.  But yesterday, for at least the second time, the parking garage door malfunctioned and nearly injured a small child in a stroller.  PLEASE get this fixed.  I put my leg in the doorway to activate the sensor that is supposed to make the door stop closing and reopen. But the door kept closing.  Other people frantically pushed the ""open"" button in the elevator which also did NOT work. The door nearly crunched the poor girl in the stroller and horrified her mom. (Fortunately, my wife and two children were already safely inside the elevator.)
It's a science museum, so surely someone on staff has the technological wherewithal to fix this door. Again, it has been malfunctioning like this for a long time (months maybe?) as I have experienced this same issue previously. Thank you."

"The new crowd control line barriers in front of cashier in cafeteria 
 very problematic and dangerous . Many with you children can’t keep children close: children grabbing the line/ rope strap. Tripping going around corners.  Absolutely no room to SAFETY maneuver. No room to walk balance trays hold children especially in front of fridges by sandwich station. I saw a child fall bump head on food displayed inside the gudlines. The guideline It’s poorly designed and dangerous 
I tripped over one of the posts as I went through. I tripped over children as children being kids bounced around under the guidelines. It needs to be kid family friendly. The gudlines in front of the cashier in the cafeteria are just another stressful obstacle for parents to have to maneuver .."

"Museum seemed very dusty and couldn't stop sneezing. Displays seem old and out of date."

"Investigation station experiments w/ temperature right sensor isn't working :("

"My family visited today and renewed our membership. The majority of the museum is excellent. However I have to say your Wild Kratts underwater exhibit was a big disappointment. We were there at 9 am and the exhibit didn't open on time, there was a delay while staff searched for someone to turn on the lights. The room is small and enclosed which emphasized how small it was! Why not make it open air? It was also really stark, poor quality (to be frank), and several electronic features were broken. There was none of the ""wow"" factor your other exhibits have, and it felt more like a small scale children's museum exhibit.
My kids were thrilled to go since they are fans of the show, and I feel like many other families were also there specifically for that exhibit. We stayed less than 15 minutes. 
I know we'll get our moneys worth for the membership over the course of a year, because we love the museum of science and there is so much to fill every visit with the permanent exhibits. I'm hoping your other special exhibits this year are higher quality!"

“To whom this may concern,
Myself and my four year old daughter came to the museum today from New Hampshire expecting to have a fantastic, fun day of exploring and learning but instead experienced a less than stellar day. Paying 63 plus dollars to not even be able to experiment with hardly anything in the whole museum was extremely frustrating. The field trip groups that were there today were sooooo out of control that it was impossible to gain access to any of the exhibits. We waited upwards of 40 mins to use the seesaw and swings and never got on anything else. My four year old was filling the shark teeth in the Wild Krafts exhibit when two boys walked over and cranked the handle destroying what she was making and then immediately after she fixed it a teenager walked over grabbing all the “teeth” and throwing them around the room. Not one single teacher or museum staff spoke to anyone. My four year old was floored and asked why would someone do that? The exhibit on the ground floor that you can crawl in under the fish tank was filled with at least 40 children screaming and my daughter got trapped inside and had her head smacked off the ceiling trying to get out. I had to crawl over at least 10 children so I could help get her out. Teachers may not have been able to see inside but they certainly could hear the excessive screaming. I know the behavior of school groups is the responsibility of the school, the teachers, chaperones, etc. but today was so frustrating and it was sad to watch children trying to experiment with parents and have these “other” kids just destroying things. I also tried to have a snack in the atrium area and it was impossible so we decided to finish up and go eat in the car. My daughter had a sip of water from her thermos on a bench near the escalators (thinking this was not in an exhibit) and a museum employee came flying out of a door right up to us and raised his voice saying how there was no food or drink allowed. I said I’m sorry I didn’t realize. They cut me off and said read the signs and went back into the door they came out of. I was clearly in the wrong but there is a way to approach people not doing the right thing especially in front of small children. And there were two other families sitting having snack on the same bench who were not spoken to and we weren’t even eating. I love the Museum of Science and have always wanted my child to grow up going there like I did but after today I am appalled at my experience and feel cheated out of not only a lot of money and time but my daughter learned zero about anything today other than how not to behave in public. Thank you for your time.”

docs.messageSubject: Hodgekinson Room has new AV system
docs.messageBody:
We are happy to announce that the video projection system in Hodge has been upgraded. That means a new projector, new cables, and new controls. The whole system is designed to be automated and completely plug and play. It’s a modern, user-friendly system that should serve us well for many years. 

Upon arrival to Hodgekinson Room the first presenter to use the system will turn on their laptop and insert one of the appropriate cables. When the system senses this connection, the system will turn on the projector and lower the screen. The cable may be unplugged and passed to another user and the system will automatically scale, sync, and project that user’s laptop. It’s that simple. We have posted instructions on the wall, so you don’t need to remember this or feel the need to print these instructions.

For those who would like to learn more about the system or want an opportunity to practice using it, there will be drop-in sessions on Tuesday March 12th from 2 to 4PM and again on Tuesday, March 19th, 2 to 4PM in the Hodgekinson Room.

At this time, the below listings are actively accepting internal applications:

Butterfly Garden Interpreter

The Butterfly Garden Interpreter is primarily concerned with providing a high quality visitor experience through maintaining and practicing high professional standards for visitor services, informal science interpretation and care of the Museum's living collection. She/he greets visitors and engages them in subjects of plant and butterfly biology through interpretations and answering questions. The Butterfly Garden Interpreter monitors visitor activity to ensure plants and butterflies are not touched or removed from the Garden. He/She also ensures all USDA containment procedures are followed. The Butterfly Garden Interpreter assists in the training of volunteers and may on occasion supervise the operation of the garden in the absence of the Curators.

Please be advised that IIT will be performing a planned network maintenance on the following date and time:

Tuesday March 12th, 2019 from 6:00pm to 11:59pm

This maintenance is necessary to perform upgrades to our network infrastructure. We anticipate this scheduled outage will take approximately 4 to 6 hrs. to complete. During this maintenance window you may experience brief outages where servers, business applications, and or files may not be accessible both internally and externally. To ensure uptime and stability of our platform, we are performing this upgrade shortly after close of business so we can maximize our efforts to ensure business operations will not be impacted when we open the next day.

If you have any questions or concerns please contact the Service Desk team at x0130.

We thank you in advance for your attention and understanding.

All pies are welcome! Apple pies, blueberry pies, pecan pies, chocolate cream pies! Mini pies! Pies on a stick! Yes, even pizza pies!
 
Bring your pies to the Hodgkinson Conference Room any time after 2:00 p.m.
Forks and plates will be supplied and pies will be ready for eating at 3:14 sharp!
 
If you’d like to help with decorations and set up, please contact Lori at lsartre@mos.org
 
Spread the word! All are invited!

Hello all,

It's Brain Awareness Week. To celebrate we're having some guest educators from BU and the Brain Aneurysm Foundation join us to talk with our visitors about brain functioning and brain health. They will be outside of HHL on:

3/13 from 11 AM to 2 PM
3/14 from 11 AM to 2 PM
3/16 from 11 AM to 4 PM

There will also be a talk on the CS&T stage on 3/16 at 12:30 PM featuring Dr. Farahnaz Wick as part of the new collaboration between Strategic Projects and the MIT Center for Brains, Minds, and Machines. The talk is titled Seeing with the Mind’s Eye: An Exploration of Visual Attention.

docs.messageSubject: Join our 3rd Annual Pi Day of Giving!
docs.messageBody:
Can you recite Pi? Yes! Apple, cherry, blueberry...we are counting down to our annual Pi Day celebration!

Like last year, the Museum’s education and exhibits teams have put together a robust schedule of math related activities, with drop-ins and live presentations throughout the entire Museum.  The schedule of events can be found here, www.mos.org/public-events/piday2019, and I hope you will all join in on the fun!

We have designated Pi Day to be the Museum’s “Day of Giving”—our opportunity to capitalize on the fun and uniqueness of the day to entice potential supporters to make a gift to the Museum.  This will be the third year that we’ve held a Pi Day of Giving, and our goal this year is to raise at least $80,000.

We’re asking our Museum colleagues for help to make this the best Pi Day yet. You can help by spreading the word.  We want to bring our love of STEM to our social networks and online communities as much as possible.

1.	Visit www.mos.org/piday and take a look at the campaign
2.	Change your social media profile picture and header image to our Pi Day 2019 imagery. You can find pre-sized imagery in our social media toolkit. Download also at www.mos.org/piday 
3.	Interact!  Share, like and comment on the content we post on our Facebook, Instagram and Twitter accounts. Use the hashtag #GivePi or #MOSinsPIre on Instagram or Twitter and you’ll end up on our social media news feed on www.mos.org/piday 

We’re counting on you to be our Pi-bassadors!

Please direct any questions to Lindsay Stanley (lstanley@mos.org) or Michael Grace (mgrace@mos.org).

docs.messageSubject: Thursday, 3/14: Making Math Count High School Science Series
docs.messageBody: School and Youth Programs is hosting the Making Math Count High School Science Series Thursday, 3/14. For this event, up to 300 high school students and their teachers will be at the Museum celebrating Pi Day and exploring applications of math by engaging in hands-on activities and attending a Keynote Presentation. The scheduled program is: 9:30 AM -1:00 PM: Various math-themed activities throughout the Museum (start and end times vary) 11: 00 AM - 11: 45 AM < /b>: Keynote Presentation in Cahners Theater by Lucas Mason-Brown. He is a PhD student in Mathematics at MIT and co-founder of Data for Black Lives (D4BL), which is a group that uses data science to create concrete and measurable change in the lives of Black people. His academic work investigates the mathematical concept of symmetry and the role that it plays in classical and quantum mechanics. Please feel free to join us for the activities or the Keynote Presentation.If you have any questions, please email Meghan Carter at MCarter @mos.org.

\ n < p > Dear Colleagues, < /p>

The Museum of Science is committed to creating a safe environment for all staff, volunteers, interns and visitors. As a part of this effort, the Safety Committee is underway reviewing and making improvements to many of our Safety Programs and Policies. The most recently completed program review was for our “

https://bmos.sharepoint.com/SitePages/Environmental%20Health%20and%20Safety.aspx">Environmental Health and Safety Page under the category Electrical. Please review the revised policy and familiarize yourself with requirements of this program. The direct link to the policy: https://bmos.sharepoint.com/EHSDocs/Extension Cord Use Policy.pdf

The content of the program has not changed, however, clarifications and illustrations were added to better convey the information. The program still applies to all indoor and outdoor extension cords used at the Museum. There is guidance and regulatory requirements provided for selecting and using appropriate extension cords and surge protectors. Ultimately this information is provided to ensure that you have the information necessary to protect yourself, your colleagues and the Museum from improper use that could lead to equipment failure or an electrical fire.

 **It is important to remember extension cords and surge protector strips shall not be used in place of permanent wiring and shall not replace the need for installation of outlets and proper wiring where necessary. When wall outlet availability is insufficient, please complete a Facilities Work Order to request installation of additional wall outlets.**

 Below are some highlights from this program:

  • Extension cords are intended to supply power temporarily.
  • Extension cords are prohibited for use with major appliances. Do not use extension cords permanently to power appliances or equipment such as printers, copiers, fans, coffee makers, microwaves, etc.
  • Don’t run extension cords through walls, ceilings, floors, or windows, over drop down ceilings, or under doors, carpets or rugs, or false floors.
  • Light Duty, ungrounded flat-wire ribbon extension cords are not permitted for use at the Museum.
  • Grounded, medium to heavy-duty, UL-Listed extension cords, 14 gauge or thicker, may be used for temporary use. Do you know what to look for on your cord to ensure you have the right gauge and if it’s rated for outdoor use?
  • Heavy-duty (14 gauge or thicker) multi-plug UL-listed transient voltage surge suppressors may be used to protect sensitive electronic equipment. Not all power strips and adapters offer surge suppression. –do you know what markings to look for to ensure you have the right one?
  • Do not “daisy chain” your cords. Extension cords shall not be connected in a series. Plug extension cords and surge protectors directly into the wall outlet.

 Inspect those cords! Ensure you have the appropriate cords for your temporary power supply needs and help prevent becoming a statistic here at work or at home!

Every year, approximately 2,200 shock-related injuries happen with extension cords and 3,300 home fires originate in extension cords, killing 50 people and injuring about 270 more. 

If you have any questions or concerns regarding this program, please contact me at x4249 or cdillard@mos.org

Thank you in advance for your continued commitment to helping create a safe museum environment.

Sincerely,

Christina Dillard

Christina Dillard | Environmental Health & Safety (EHS) Program Manager

Museum of Science | Facilities Dept. | One Science Park | Boston, MA 02114-1099

P 617-589-4249 | F 617-589-0101 |M 781-789-1178| cdillard@mos.org | www.mos.org

docs.messageSubject: Fun outdoor citizen science activity for this warmer weekend!
docs.messageBody:
We are looking for volunteers to help us inform a new project, an environmental literacy grant, Citizen Science, Civics, and Resilient Communities, from NOAA. In this project, we will be recruiting volunteer citizen scientists, who make observations and collect data in their local community, and then referencing that information in future public forums like the one you have participated in.  We are now calling on you to help us with a developmental step in the process! 
From now until March 26th, we are pilot testing some of our potential citizen science components. We want to know what you, potential citizen scientists, think of certain third party citizen science platforms. This will help us decide which one to use for the final version. Go to this website to get started: https://scistarter.org/noaa

Instructions for pilot testing: 
1.	You will be directed to a SciStarter website that holds instructions on how to use three different apps.
2.	Create a free SciStarter account. 
3.	If using the app, download 1-3 of the platforms listed from Google Play or Apple Store. If using a computer, sign up on the website online. (Note: To use the MyCoast app/website, you need to be near a coastal environment) 
4.	Create a free account for each platform.
5.	Follow the instructions for the specific platform(s) you’ve selected. 
6.	Participate once or more for each platform you’ve used. 
7.	Take a brief post survey about your experience using the platform(s) you used: https://www.surveygizmo.com/s3/4829713/Citizen-Science-Platform-Survey

Thank you for participating in this crucial step in the process! We look forward to hearing your feedback about these platforms.

docs.messageSubject: What do you call a baby axolotl ?
docs.messageBody: Cute!!Or an axo - little ? Or technically - larvae ? Come find out at the Museum 's Health Fair: Our Bodies, Our Future today and tomorrow- March 22 and March 23.  What do axolotls have to do with our bodies?  They can regrow most parts of theirs, a phenomenon that would be amazing to replicate in humans.  Meet the researchers attempting to learn about just that.  Also, find out what happens to your body as it ages, learn about ear size, and much more.  And of course, come and hold a human brain.

If anyone is looking for a fun engineering activity to do with their kids, the Tufts Center for Engineering Education and Outreach currently has opening for all of the there spring and most of their summer workshops!  Offerings range from preschool to grade 8, with both weekend and after school opportunities available.  
Spring opportunities can be found here: http://outreach.tuftsceeo.org/2019-spring-workshops/
Summer opportunities can be found here: http://outreach.tuftsceeo.org/2019-summer-workshops/
For questions feel free to check out the CEEO website, or email jscarborough@mos.org for questions

On Saturday 3/23, at 8:00 PM, the International Space Station will be passing directly above Boston in its orbit around the Earth. Although it will be 250 miles above our heads, it will be clearly visible due to its size and reflective solar panels! From the ground with the unaided eye, the space station will appear as an extremely bright point of light moving from southwest to northeast. It looks like the clouds will clear out in time, so set an alarm for 8:00 and step outside to wave at the six astronauts on board!

P.S. If you miss the 8:00 flyover, you can catch the ISS again at 9:30 after it has completed circling the entire planet.

< p > Dear Colleagues, < /p>

 The Safety Committee has completed its review of another Safety Program, “Youth Workers Safety Policy”.

< p > & nbsp;The revised program is located on the < a href = "https://bmos.sharepoint.com/SitePages/Environmental%20Health%20and%20Safety.aspx">Environmental Health and Safety Page under the category Youth Workers. The direct link to the policy is:  https://bmos.sharepoint.com/EHSDocs/Youth Workers Safety Policy.pdf

 If you employ a teen or have a teen at home about to enter the workforce; take a moment now to review this policy and understand the restrictions and consider the hazards!

In 2015, 403 workers under the age of 24 died from work-related injuries. In 2015, there were 24 deaths to workers under 18 years of age.

 ** Young people often begin their summer jobs with a sense of excitement and a desire to prove themselves, but with little knowledge of critical safety practices. This is where YOU come in to ensure they receive the mentoring necessary to be appropriately cautious and ask good safety questions to protect themselves and others!**

Note, the content of this program has not changed, however, clarifications and minor edits were made to ensure alignment with OSHA and Massachusetts Labor regulations.

Below are a few highlights from this program:

  • You MUST ensure staff under 18 do not do any of the tasks prohibited for their specific age group.
  • You are highly encouraged to implement a mentoring or buddy system for youth workers. Having an experienced worker be a buddy to answer questions, offer safety tips, and provide hands-on training to help the inexperienced worker see how the tasks are completed greatly reduces the likelihood of accidents.
  • Did you know that persons under 16 may NOT work on or use ladders, scaffolds, or their substitutes?

 If you have any questions or concerns regarding this program, please contact me at x4249 or cdillard@mos.org

 Thank you in advance for your continued commitment to helping create a safe museum environment.

Sincerely,

Christina Dillard

 

Christina Dillard | Environmental Health & Safety (EHS) Program Manager

P 617-589-4249 | F 617-589-0101 |M 781-789-1178| cdillard@mos.org

UPDATE: Tuesday PM briefing (Peter Blake) has been canceled. Wednesday PM briefing (Leo Rosenstein) has been moved to Thursday AM in the Discovery Center

Hi all,

Over the coming week, the Early Childhood Development and Education team will be hosting Living Laboratory researchers onsite to chat with our staff and volunteers about the research they do at the museum, and how they use the scientific process to investigate research questions in fields such as psychology, education, and child development.

Please join us to learn more about current research of local university partners happening in our very own halls, and/or to learn more about the Living Laboratory program.

Following is a schedule of who will be coming when; each researcher will be with us for ½ hour. Feel free to join for any/all that you would like, invite other interested MOS colleagues, and email me if you would like any more information!

Monday 4/1 at 9:30 (Discovery Center)
Leo Rosenstein – Lab Manager, MIT Language Acquisition Lab
The Language Acquisition Lab’s central topic of study is how children learn and acquire their native language(s) – how much of it is biologically determined versus experience-based, how does it change as children mature, and what strategies do children employ in order to extract and use the relevant information in language experiences? Members of the lab are currently studying how children learn the rules of grammar, and how their use of these rules changes as they grow.

Tuesday 4/2 at 9:30 (Discovery Center)
Peggy Li – Research Fellow, Harvard University Laboratory for Developmental Studies
The Laboratory for Developmental Studies represents a multidisciplinary group of researchers interested in discovering more about the way infants and young children learn about the world that surrounds them. Dr. Li’s research primarily focuses on the relationship between children’s language and cognitive development, and how they both may rely on and grow from one another. Currently in Living Laboratory, she is investigating the role language plays in the creation of new representational structures and concepts for children.

Tuesday 4/2 at 12:30 (Lower Morse)
Peter Blake – Lab Director, Boston University Social Development and Learning Lab
The Social Development and Learning Lab conducts cognitive and behavioral experiments with children regarding social concepts such as cooperation and competition, ownership and private property, fairness and other social norms, and learning through imitation and communication. Dr. Blake’s current Living Laboratory research investigates children’s perceptions of fairness.

Wednesday 4/3 at 9:30 (Discovery Center)
Jenna Alton – Lab Manager, Boston University Social Learning Lab
The Social Learning Laboratory’s research focuses on children’s use of social and cognitive information when learning about the world. An issue central across children’s development is how they navigate diverse sources of information, such as testimony from teachers, family or peers, or their own inquiry and evidence. Jenna’s current Living Laboratory research investigates how children’s exploration and perception of an activity may be influenced by the type of information they receive from adults.

Wednesday 4/3 at 12:30 (Classroom A)
Leo Rosenstein – Lab Manager, MIT Language Acquisition Lab
The Language Acquisition Lab’s central topic of study is how children learn and acquire their native language(s) – how much of it is biologically determined versus experience-based, how does it change as children mature, and what strategies do children employ in order to extract and use the relevant information in language experiences? Members of the lab are currently studying how children learn the rules of grammar, and how their use of these rules changes as they grow.

Thursday 4/4 at 12:30 (Classroom A)
Vishakha Agrawal – Lab Manager, Northeastern University Communication Development Lab
The Communication Development Lab investigates perceptual and cognitive development in human infants and young children to gain new insights into the development of multisensory communication skills. Members of the lab research topics such as how children use audio-visual clues to enhance their attention to faces and understanding of language, and how these early experiences affect attentional processing and language development.

Friday 4/5 at 9:30 (Discovery Center)
Rebecca Peretz-Lange – Doctoral Student, Tufts University Cognitive Development Lab
The Cognitive Development Lab’s goal is to better understand how children learn about the physical and social world – about the objects they play with, the people they learn from, and how both interact in their everyday life. Much of the lab’s research focuses on how children learn about cause and effect. Rebecca’s current Living Lab research investigates how children reason about other people’s behaviors.

Friday 4/5 at 12:30 (Classroom A)
Olivia Soledad – Research Assistant, Boston University Developing Minds Lab
The Developing Minds Lab studies how infants and children perceive, understand, and remember “the vast amount of visual information available in the world and carve it up into the meaningful units that are most relevant to us as humans: namely, inanimate objects and animate agents.” Olivia’s current work in the Living Laboratory investigates how children’s memory may be influenced by societal factors.

docs.messageSubject: Charles River Clean Up Boat GSEs
docs.messageBody:
Charles River Clean Up Boat GSE’s-New GSE Sign-Up Instructions for This Year!
**Please read all the way through**

It’s Clean Up Boat Season!
Since 2007 the Museum has partnered with the Charles River Clean Up Boat, a registered 501©3, whose primary focus is to keep the Charles River clean of floating trash and debris. This organization has done a great job keeping our river beautiful and has received many accolades for its work. 

Full day GSE’s will pick up and drop off in Brighton at the DCR Nonantum Road Boat Ramp. (Please visit www.cleanupboat.org for directions.) 
NEW GSE SIGN-UP PROCESS THIS YEAR—**It is important to complete these steps in order**  

How do I sign up?
1. Go to website- cleanupboat.org.>Click on ‘Volunteers’>within the first paragraph, click on the word ‘here’ >this will bring you to the volunteer sign up page. 
2. Sign up for an available date, either under the Volunteer 1 or Volunteer 2 fields (please know that the maximum number of Volunteers is now two per day) and then fill in your contact information and select from the drop down that you are a Museum of Science Employee. **Due to overwhelming demand, we are limiting sign ups to one GSE shift per season.
3. You will receive a confirmation email from ‘Signup Genius’ (be sure to check your clutter/junk folders if you don’t see it right away).
4. Next, sign up for the corresponding GSE through our GSE sign up system.  Please note that the GSE dates listed through the Museum GSE offerings may not match as being available on cleanupboat.org. This is due to other volunteers, separate from MOS employees, signing up through the cleanupboat.org website. This is why it is important to sign up on the Clean Up Boat website first.
If you signed up for a shift on cleanupboat.org and notice that there is no corresponding GSE sign up, please let me know.

What if I need to cancel or reschedule my GSE?
1. Cancel your GSE using the Museum GSE cancellation process.
2. Go to cleanupboat.org and back to the Volunteer sign up page. Right above where the list of dates begins, you will see a link titled ‘Already signed up? You can change your sign up.’ and follow the instructions from there. I have found that the easiest thing to do is the 'enter your email' option and it will email you a link. Once cancelled, you will receive a cancellation confirmation email. If you are cancelling your GSE within 3 days of your scheduled date, in addition to canceling on the volunteer page, please contact your Captain directly to let them know.  Captain contact information is located at the top of the volunteer sign up page.

This GSE is fun, rewarding, and on most days a good way to get out and enjoy the weather! Read over the GSE description carefully and be sure to sign up for a day that you know you can commit to.

docs.messageSubject: NanoDays with a Quantum Leap -Saturday, April 6th
docs.messageBody:
Ever wondered about the weird world of quantum mechanics? Spooky action at a distance? Superposition? Quantum computing? Well, dive right in at the 2019 NanoDays with a Quantum Leap celebration!

Join us to explore nano and quantum science with hands-on activities and Guest Researcher presentations. Cheer on your favorite quantum idols at the 2019 National Quantum Matters™ Science Communication Competition Finals. Look inside a replica of an IBM  Q  System One, the world’s first fully-integrated universal quantum computer! For details see: https://www.mos.org/nanodays 
We hope to see you there!

Internal Job Postings

Paid staff positions will be posted internally for five (5) business days to give internal applicants priority during the recruitment process, in support of the Museum’s Affirmative Action Plan. All positions accepting internal applications can be found on our Internal Employment Opportunities page.

To apply, simply click on the position title below and complete the online application. If internal staff apply after the position is posted externally, they will not be considered as a candidate because they did not apply during the internal posting period.

At this time, the below listings are actively accepting internal applications:

Archives Fellow

The Archives fellow will assist the Senior Archivist in the continued expansion of the Archives department, and will help perform care and organization of the collections, which include manuscript, audiovisual, and bound works from the 17th century forward. The fellow will participate in strategic planning and discussion of short- and long-term goals, and be responsible for processing and digitizing materials under the direction of the Senior Archivist. Primarily, the fellow will undertake an independent processing project, but will also assist with research requests, organizing supplies, monitoring storage environments, and other recurring activities. The fellow will expand their personal skills and knowledge by assisting with inventory and rehousing projects, outreach to staff, preservation tasks, data ingest, and digital imaging. As part of the Museum of Science, the fellow will support the institutional commitment to education and safety for visitors, and will participate in training to meet such goals.

Deadline for Internal Applicants: 4/11/19

This position is full-time, 35 hours per week, Monday – Friday, 9:00am-5:00pm starting July 1, 2019.

All,

Please be advised that IIT will be performing a planned network maintenance on the following date and time:

Tuesday April 9th  2019 from 6:00pm to 11:59pm 

This maintenance is necessary to perform upgrades to our network infrastructure.  We anticipate this scheduled outage will take approximately 4 to 6 hrs. to complete.  During this maintenance window you may experience brief outages where servers, business applications, and or files may not be accessible both internally and externally.  To ensure uptime and stability of our platform, we are performing this upgrade shortly after close of business so we can maximize our efforts to ensure business operations will not be impacted when we open the next day.  

If you have any questions or concerns please contact the Service Desk team at x0130.  

We thank you in advance for your attention and understanding.

March 2019 Comment Card Report

"Hello! The museum is great, but why most exhibits show USC units only? You have word 'science' in your name, and language of science is SI units. Also it makes things difficult for all foreign tourists (except those who are from Liberia) as all other countries are metric.
Boston aquarium is a good example of handling this, all their exhibits show units in both systems."		
"Hi. I was just looking at your Omni Theater shows and I’m disappointed that the options listed for schools aren’t available to the public. I’m most interested in seeing the shows available to schools and hope you may consider playing them to the public. The Extreme Weather, South Pacific, and Lewis and Clark are all very intriguing. Is there a way to reserve the theater to see them without being part of a school program?"

"I am looking for something to do with my daughter, who is 10, on Pi Day. I am disappointed that the museum is not offering any special activities after school hours."

"I would simply like you to update your info tag on Mountain Lion exhibit.
I can say with absolute certainty that my brother, Bill and I three days apart spotted in Connecticut a Mountain Lion I want to say in 2017. Bill and friend spotted a  Mountain Lion in Redding area in CT. Three days later, in the Audubon in Fairfield, I spotted a Mountain Lion. Both sightings were reported to Animal control Authorities of both towns.
These sightings came after there was an article in National Geographic a few yrs ago of a Mountain Lion killed on  I-95 in Milford, CT."

"Sean at the Information Desk was the catalyst in finding our lost wallet. He arranged for us to look unencumbered between shows at the Omni. We found the wallet thanks to his efforts. His kind & caring way was appreciated. Thank you Sean"

"The Hall of Human Life wristband for me isn’t working."	

"For an organization that prides itself and brags about reducing its carbon foot print, your recycling in the cafeteria is extremely poor. No plastic or paper recycling at all. I expect more from the Museum of Science."

"I think that the Pi Day Facebook profile picture change call to action should have been a Facebook profile frame instead of a whole image. I think it would have given a lot more exposure and more people would have actually done it.”
"When I signed up for membership at the Museum, the person taking my information incorrectly entered my email.
I have been unable to delete this incorrect email from my email preferences.
Note: I have added my correct email to my email preferences.  Please delete the incorrect email  from the email preferences and from your database.  Thank you."
"Oh my! What a wondrous place. Oh if only I was a child again!"
"Today me and my family visited the planetarium and it was a very experience. We decided to grab a snack from the food area. We got fries from the grill area, we were looking the ketchup and saw the dressing for the salad thinking it was near that. There was a dressing that was red so my 10 year old daughter went to check if it was ketchup, she put her finger on the top to try it. Me and my wife were in the process of explaining to her that she cannot do that and while we were telling her a staff member scolded my daughter about what she had done. They made her feel scared and horrible about what she had done. This was very rude! We were handling it. I am very disappointed about our experience today.”

"Hello Museum of Science, 
I hope your week went well! I recently went to your ""Coldplay Experience Light Show"". I truly enjoyed it and wanted to let you know how inspirational and relaxing it was. After taking a look at your other featured artists, I recognized the variety you had. An idea which occurred to me is that a Queen light show would also be amazing. As the movie Bohemian Rhapsody recently came out and has received raving reviews, this addition could also attract a great crowd. Just think about it. Queen has had a great uproar and it could be a fantastic way to introduce and represent a larger music variety. I know I would thoroughly enjoy this show and many others would too. The vivacious, inspiring and complex music would be a great landscape for some mindbending visual effects. 
Please let me know what you think of this idea! Thank You."

"I attended your free Friday night with my wife and daughter yesterday. I was arriving late to meet them and when I arrived I was able to walk in, unchecked, past the turnstile attendant. I didn’t get a ticket like everyone else. I didn’t get looked at.  While I’m not typically a paranoid person, I didn’t see one single security guard the entire time I was there. There were droves of children and families. But not one security guard. At least not at the entrance/exit. In today’s world the idea that that many children and people could congregate in a public place with little or no oversight is slightly unsettling. Whether it’s an act of violence or an abduction, there was not a single preventative measure of note. 
I thoroughly enjoy and appreciate the program and I love being able to introduce children to the sciences in such an enjoyable way. I would love to see an added measure of security to ensure the safety of everyone there."

"When I log in as a member there is a box on top of the display that says 'Hello,' and my name.  There is no obvious way to logout.  Instead, if I click on this 'Hello,' box there are 2 lines: 'Your Account' and 'Not' followed by my name and 'Logout'.  There really should be three lines: 'Your account"", 'Not', 'logout'  I should not have to logout by saying that I am not me."

"Add a laser tag arena. Laser tag is VERY popular. Do some thing like the butterfly gardens, where you have an entry every 35 min (games last 30 min)"

"Can you please direct this email to the curator of the Hall of Human Life?
The diet recommended in the Hall of Human Life is seriously flawed, as exhibited by the diabetes stations recommending refraining from salmon and the hypertension station encouraging salmon consumption.  Caution about sugar consumption is vague and needs to be more explicit -- it merely references an excess of calories.  And a station on contributing factors to heart disease was absent.
I laud this robust exhibit, but its flaws are a disservice to its many viewers.
With Boston being a center for medical care, what can be done about a notable nutritionist bringing accuracy, completeness, and consistency to the Hall of Human Life?"

"I write this at the risk of seeming a whiner or a lush: I am at the ticketed event for the Washburn challenge this evening and I am really, really bummed that you closed the bar service. I had a hellacious day at work, I rushed to get here and was really looking forward to 5-10 minutes of shaking off the day with a glass of wine before the lecture. (I actually got off the Green Line and got into a Lyft because I knew I’d be late otherwise.) When I got to the bar at 6:50, the catering staff was fairly curt in telling me the bar service was closed. Which is really annoying. I get it that you don’t want to have people lingering but seriously, just one glass of wine? Too much to ask? Fine, I’ll at least grab a snack. Except you already took away the plates so... guess not. 
Better next time on the invitation say the wine and cheese reception ends at 6:45, not 7. Super grumpy. Thanks for listening."
"Hello, I visited the natural history section of your museum and I noticed that you have about 4 passenger pigeon specimens in the bird area, and I would like to inform the museum about an ongoing project that is actually working on 'de-extincting' the passenger pigeons. 
The project is set to begin next year, with wild release in 20 years if successful. I think it may be a good idea to see about creating a poster near a passenger pigeon specimen. This organization is also working on several different projects such as the, Heath Hen, Woolly Mammoth, Black-Footed Ferret, and Horseshoe crab. 
I will leave a link to the passenger pigeon page for reference.  
Also, this technology has been proven to be at least practical, when a species of extinct wild goat was de-extinct in 2003 but only survived for 10 minutes.”

"Good evening, my son is a music composer major at Oberlin Conservatory. All of his peers at Oberlin, Berklee, Manhattan School of Music, etc. are highly creative, talented musicians. Many composers studying at American conservatories have limited opportunities to exhibit their pieces to the public. My proposal is to host a year long laser light show series exhibiting conservatory students'' pieces at the Museum Of Science. 
Please contact me at your earliest convenience, if you are interested in my proposal.
Thank you for your consideration."

"I spent 45 dollars in your cafe yesterday 3/27/19 around 3pm. The entire time sitting at a table workers were converging on us putting chairs up, cleaning up, removing chairs at the table we were sitting at. Basically it was truly an unpleasant experience. Like they were telling us to hurry it up. Then another group of workers dressed in black did the same thing. Took over the area. I mean what are you?  A cafe for visitors or is it your policy to close up shop while you claim to be 'open'?"

"March 29, 2019 was the first time I visited the museum I fell in love with it it was beautiful my son had a great time and went with the Webster a elementary school it was great we had fun I am really actually excited to go again thank you"

"I was here for 4:00pm Omni Show. Since I came early I wanted to take an advantage of no show tickets of 3pm show. Even one lady came out feeling sick, I wasn't allowed to get in to watch the show. The fact is there are empty seats inside the theater and I am not be able to watch the show. The system is not efficient. Can you fix it for future cases?"

"I like how you made eye pictures. It was fun being confused!"

"Our overall experience on our visit was good however the dining area was a mess the process of getting the food was ok the food was hot and came out fast however once we had our food the checking out was a nightmare I do not blame the cashier personnel it was overwhelming the number of people needing to checkout and the three cashiers to do. I would suggest or any busy day investing in extra registers that could be added on a day like yesterday could be a stand alone you can add on or something but yesterday was a mess and makes me sad because everything else was good just management needs to correct this"

Live Presentations Fellow

Deliver educational programming daily/weekly that exemplifies educational excellence and guest service so as to engage and excite our audience in science, technology, engineering and math (STEM) content. In response to feedback from the Museum community, we've made a number of updates to The Hub's home screen. For instance, Message previews show who created the message and when, and updated messages go back to the top of the queue. Search through Messages and Get it Done items using text filters.

Other feedback we received was that some folks want learning resources for changes to The Hub. To that end, we've created video, audio, and text covering changes to Get it Done and Messages. Links to these resources may also be found at the top of the corresponding sections of the home screen.

With Quark and Matrix behind us, we expect the pace of The Hub's evolution to pick up steam. In coming weeks, we plan to begin introducing improvements to the people information in the Organization, Teams, and Staff section, and we'll be formally seeking more of your feedback regarding The Hub's future evolution.

Please keep a lookout for the upcoming feedback opportunity - it's important for us to know what's important to you!

docs.messageSubject: UltiPro Updates - Name, Address, Phone & W-4
docs.messageBody:
Hello Everyone,

We have recently turned new features in UltiPro. You are now able to update your name, address, phone number, and tax information all within UltiPro! This will replace our current process of updating your information via the Hub or email.

Name, Address and Telephone Changes:

  1. Myself Tab > Personal > Name, Address and Telephone
  2. Select the gray “Edit” button in the upper right hand corner of the window
  3. Update your information
  4. Select the green “Save” button in the upper right hand corner of the window
  5. Review your changes, and select the green “Submit” button in the upper right hand corner of the window
  6. An email will be sent to you when action has been taken on your change (approved, denied, etc.)

Important things to note:

  • Address and name changes will be routed to HR for approval. These updates will remain pending until reviewed by HR.
  • If you are submitting a name change, you will need to provide a copy of your new Social Security Card to HR. HR will not approve a name change in the system without this additional documentation.
  • Your primary email must stay your MOS email address, please do not update your primary email address
  • You can future date this change

 

Tax Information Changes:

  1. Myself Tab > Pay > Income Tax
  2. Select “Add/Change Withholding Form (W-4)” from the far right hand side of the page
  3. Select the form you would like to update
  4. Update your information (the full W-4 is linked if you need the worksheet to help you)
  5. Select the gray “Next” button in the upper right hand corner of the window
  6. Check off the disclaimer box, and “Sign & Save”

 

If you have any questions about this process, please contact us at Ultipro@mos.org

docs.messageSubject: Free Tickets for the Annual Run of the Charles -  race down the Charles via a canoe, kayak or paddleboard!
docs.messageBody:
Hello Everyone,

We have 5 free entries for Museum employees for the 37th Annual Run of the Charles hosted by the Charles River Watershed Association. This event is a race down the Charles via a canoe, kayak or paddleboard! Participants will receive a free lunch, free Sam Adams, and a free rental for their canoe or Kayak.

As CRWA's signature event, the Run of the Charles is the largest flat-bottomed boat race in New England and a major event in Greater Boston, it draws 1,500 racers and spectators each year!

For more information on this event, please visit, https://www.crwa.org/staffrun-of-the-charles#runofthecharles.

If you are available on Sunday, April 28th and would like to participate, please contact Aurelia GrantWingate (agrantwingate@mos.org). We will be accepting the first 5 entries for free entry.


This opportunity has been made possible by Boston Duck Tours, a big thank you to them!

Hi Everyone!
Tomorrow the 13th is national citizen science day! To celebrate, we will be testing citizen science platforms at the museum from 11am-2pm. We will be using the app ISeeChange to take pictures for the investigation called "first of the season." We will be directly outside the museum, so if you have time tomorrow make sure to stop by and say hi to David and me! The weather is looking warm!! 

Here is the website for more information on our project: https://scistarter.org/noaa
Learn more about citizen science day here: https://www.citizenscience.org/events/citizen-science-day/

I wanted to let everyone know that the Museum of Science has been accredited by the Association of Zoos and Aquariums (AZA) once again! Our manager of Living Collections, Jackie Peeler and BarB Harvey met with the accreditation committee today to discuss the results of our application and onsite inspection. The committee voted to accredit us for the next five years. Huge thanks to everyone as this is a museum wide accomplishment. Many departments and staff worked to make this happen, it truly takes a village! Special thank you to the Living Collections team for all of their incredibly hard work as they all spent the last year and a half prepping for this. They did a tremendous job! They are well deserving of any congratulations or high fives you want to pass along should you see them.

docs.messageSubject: "The Science Behind Pixar" debuts in Japan
docs.messageBody:
Hi Everyone, 
I am excited to announce that the international copy of our "The Science Behind Pixar" exhibit has officially opened in Tokyo, Japan this weekend at The Roppongi Hills Observation Deck, Tokyo City View! Tokyo is the 10th city to host a copy of the exhibition, which has seen over 1.5 million visitors since opening here at MOS in 2015. This is the first time that the exhibit has been presented in another language, with the graphics printed in Japanese and all of the screen activities, videos, and audio available to visitors in both Japanese and English. The Japanese title of the exhibition is "PIXARのひみつ展 : いのちを生みだすサイエンス" (roughly: The Secrets of Pixar : Creating Worlds with Science). The exhibit will be on display in Tokyo through September 16th, at which point it will continue on to 5 more Japanese cities through Spring of 2021.

A huge Thank You to everyone across MOS that helped us plan and execute this huge undertaking!

Please let me know if you have any questions about the exhibit or its tours, and check out the hashtag #pixarのひみつ展 for some great visitor photos!

Julia Romano Tate
x0287

On the evening of 4/23 starting at 6:00 pm, a series of upgrades will be performed on our active directory domain controller servers in our MOS data center.  These upgrades will be staggered throughout the night to minimize end user impact.  Part of this upgrade will involve migrating some of the services on the wireless side to new servers.  This will enable the Museum to take advantage of new and improved capabilities within our environment and will help us prepare for future IT project improvements to both systems and networks.   This will also allow us to continue to receive support from Microsoft by updating to a newer more stable platform.

What Does This Mean?
Information Technology will be replacing our existing domain controllers, which respond to security authentication requests (logging in, checking permissions, etc.) and is used by IT when granting access to museum resources.  During our outage window, we are working with an outside vendor to address any issues should they arise.  

What Can I Expect When This Takes Effect?
Do not panic! When these upgrades take effect, there is little expected impact on the internal network or network access. There could be some delays in access for short durations of less than a minute as services flip from the old domain controllers to the new servers. On the wireless side, we do expect that when services are migrated, users may need to disconnect and reconnect to the wireless network, as some of the networking options will be changing, and the end devices will need to reconnect to get this updated information.

What Do I Need To Do?
If you need to be on any of our WI-Fi networks during this time frame and have issues with connectivity, please wait a few minutes and then disconnect and try again.  We expect this will clear up any connection issues.

As always, if you have any questions or issues, please contact our service desk, System Support Services, at ithelp@mos.org or call x0130.

Interested in helping tour 2nd graders around the Museum? We would love if you'd sign up for a GSE! Two new Eye Opener GSE dates have been posted: Tuesday, April 30th and Tuesday, May 7th! If neither date works for you, be on the lookout! More Tuesday Eye Opener GSEs will be posted soon.

In this GSE, you'll get partnered up with a experienced volunteer to tour 4-6 2nd grade students from Boston around the Museum exhibit halls, into the Butterfly Garden, and even behind the scenes at the Live Animal Center! It's a lot of fun and you may even get an adorable thank-you letter out of it from your 2nd grade students.

If you have any questions, please feel free to reach out to me at x4248 or kslivensky@mos.org.
