docs.messageSubject: Postponed: Launch of New Work Order System and Customer Service Portal
docs.messageBody:
We are still making changes to our new work order platform.  Based on current status, the launch scheduled for tomorrow evening has been postponed.  The project team continues to work on stabilizing the system over the next week and will revisit the timeline and send an update to staff once we have a new go live date.

This means that staff should continue to use Track-It until the new tool is rolled out to the Museum.
_______________________________________________________________________________________________________________________

The Museum of Science has some great news to share!  We are implementing a new work order and customer service portal that centralizes requests for IT, Facilities, C&W, CRM Systems and Exhibit Maintenance.  This new system, Service Now, will allow us to retire the legacy Track It application and replace it with more flexible and integrated work order environment.

We are planning to roll out the new platform on Wednesday, May 1st.  Please note the following schedule of activities in order to support the launch: 
•  Mid day on Tuesday, April 30th: the current Track-it Work Order System will be taken offline.  Any new request that you need to submit that day can be emailed to ithelp@mos.org and the Service Desk will assure that a ticket is entered for you in the new system
•  Evening of Tuesday, April 30th: all active work orders will be migrated from Track It to the new system
•  Morning of Wednesday, May 1st: the new portal will be available to all staff at https://museumofscience.service-now.com/.  You will sign in with your museum user name and password.  There will be also be updated links from the Hub for easy navigation and access

Service Now is accessible 24x7 from anywhere with an Internet connection and works across operating systems and multiple browsers. 

Below is a short list of the enhancements you can expect with the new service:
•  Better communication and updates for end users
•  Searchable Service Catalog by department
•  Email notifications and updates to tickets and work orders 
•  Ability to trace reoccurring issues and trends
•  Ability to share a request with several departments and add more than one user on a tickets
•  Search feature that will make is much easier for an end user to find what they need from an area

After the rollout, there will be continued growth and improvement in the platform as we get feedback and are able to implement additional functionality.  The platform has many features that we look to implementing in the future including an extensive, searchable Knowledge Base and giving more tools to the technicians, like location updates, to streamline requests and needs for the museum. 

*Information and Support Sessions
There will be 4 user drop in sessions to learn more about Service Now:
•  Thursday, April 25th from 2:30-3:30pm in the Engineers Enclave
•  Friday, April 26th from 2:00-3:00pm in the Engineers Enclave
•  Monday, April 29th from 11:00-12:00pm in the Engineers Enclave
•  Wednesday, May 1st from 11:00-12:00pm in Hodge

If you cannot make one of the four sessions but would still like a training session or if you have any questions or comments, please email SNAdminTeam@mos.org.

We’re very excited about rolling out this customer service platform and look forward to your feedback.

docs.messageSubject: April is Distracted Driver Awareness Month
docs.messageBody:
April is Distracted Driving Awareness Month, and the Safety Committee would like to share some statistics and resources on distracted driving. You can also look at the National Safety Council website for more resources and information:

https://www.nsc.org/pages/ddam/ddam-materials

Every day at least 9 people die and 1,000 more are injured on U.S. roads in distracted driving crashes, caused by cell phones, dashboard touchscreens, voice commands and other in-vehicle technologies that pose a threat to safety, according to the National Safety Council.
Driving with any form of distraction is a choice. Everyone can choose to glance at the screen or respond to a text while sitting at a red light. April is Distracted Driving Awareness Month , making now the perfect time to consider the consequences of distracted driving. However, if you are driving on Museum business, you are prohibited from using your cell phone while driving. 
The official policy from the Museum handbook: Vehicle Use - It is the policy of the Museum that cell phones and pagers are not to be used by staff while operating a motor vehicle.  Using telecommunications devices, even with a hands -free accessory, is a distraction that reduces the driver’s ability to react to hazards.  This applies to personal cell phones used for, or while conducting, Museum business.

Fast Facts about Distracted Driving:
•	5 seconds is the average time your eyes are off the road while texting; traveling at 55 mph, that is equivalent to driving the length of a football field blindfolded.
•	Voice-to-text is even more distracting than holding your phone. You're mentally distracted by composing the message and visually distracted by common autocorrect errors. 
•	Even at stoplights, it is important to remain an attentive driver; a AAA study shows that people are distracted up to 27 seconds after they send a voice text.
•	7% of all drivers at any given time are using their phones while driving, but cognitive neuroscientist, David Strayer, says only about 2.5% of the population is actually capable of multitasking.
•	Drivers who are talking on their cell phone are 4x more likely to crash — drunk drivers share those odds. The odds of crashing if you’re texting while driving is 8x times the normal rate, meaning it doubles the crash likelihood of driving drunk.

So how do we resist the temptation? Here are three ideas to help curb this terrible habit: 
1.	Get your phone out of reach. Turn your phone on silent—or airplane mode—and place it in your glove compartment. If you’re still too tempted, throw it in the trunk before getting behind the wheel. 
2.	Distract yourself—safely. Try listening to interesting radio stations, podcasts or audiobooks. None of these are as attention-absorbing as texting, which takes both your attention and your eyes off the road. 
3.	Use an app to prevent use.  Some wireless providers offer a Drive mode App, which can detect when your car is traveling, stop you from sending texts, and even send an automatic response saying you’re driving and can’t talk right now. 

Please remain safe on the roads and avoid distracted driving.

The Safety Committee

This position is full-time, 30.50 hours a week, with the following schedule: • o Monday: 9:30am - 6:00pm o Friday: 8:45am - 4:30pm o Saturday: 8:45am - 4:30pm o Sunday: 9:30am - 6:00pm

Duck ‘n’ Hover is back! Tech Studio will be hosting our teen engineering event again this year on Saturday May 11th! In this free event, teens in grades 8 through 12 will design and build a wind-powered device that can lift a payload of rubber ducks three stories high. Students will be assigned a team to participate in the engineering challenge. Each team will be led by a near-peer mentor. No previous engineering experience is necessary, and participants will be provided a t-shirt and lunch! Families of teens are welcome to attend the event and watch the timed team trials provided they purchase museum exhibit halls admission (or use a family or library membership). There will also be engineering activities around the building for visitors to participate in, as well as local engineers that will be sharing their work with visitors.

We also encourage educators to join us for the event to cheer their students on and explore educator resources at the museum! Educators will be provided coffee and can explore the Exhibit Halls, as well as enjoy some other fun perks while their students are building. We are happy to provide bus transportation for groups of 40 or more. Additionally, any group for which at least 1 teacher and 10 students attend will be entered in a raffle for 1 free field trip for the 2019-2020 school year (Exhibit Halls Admission fees for 50 people and a scholarship covering the cost of 1 bus). 

If you know of any teens in grades 8-12 who may want to participate, they can sign up at this link: tinyurl.com/ducknhover2019

If you know of any educators/community group leaders who may want to bring a group, please have them email us at designchallenges@mos.og so we can send them a flyer and give them more information.

If you would like to help us out by volunteering to help with either the high school challenge or our family engineering activities at the event, you can sign up at this link: tinyurl.com/ducknhover2019volunteer (GSEs are also posted on the Hub, and the link has more information about what volunteering entails)

If you would like to help us out by being a mentor for a high school team at the event, you can sign up at this link: tinyurl.com/ducknhover2019mentor (GSEs are also posted on the Hub, and the link has more information about what mentoring entails)

Please feel free to email designchallenges@mos.og with any questions!

Dear Colleagues,

 The Safety Committee has completed its review of another Safety Policy and Procedure, “Ladder Safety”.

 The revised program and supporting Ladder Safety references are located on the Environmental Health and Safety Page under the category Ladders. The direct link to the policy is: https://bmos.sharepoint.com/EHSDocs/Ladder Safety Program.pdf The general requirements of this program have not changed, however, clarifications, definitions and minor edits were made to ensure alignment with some recent changes to OSHA regulations.

 Ladder Safety Program Highlights:

  • All Museum employees, who use ladders, are required to receive Ladder Safety Training. Managers/Supervisors: Ladder Safety Training resources are available on the EH&S Hub - updated training slides or I will be conducting a ladder safety training on May 22, 1pm-2pm in Hornblower (please contact me if you would like to attend)
  • Contractors are responsible to provide training to their own employees and are expected to use their own equipment. If a contractor can’t use their own equipment and must use MoS Equipment, a waiver must be signed before use.
  • You are required to inspect the ladder for defects or possible hazards before each use and annually each department must inspect their own ladders.

 Before you use that ladder, please re-review the Ladder Safety Policy and ensure that you:

  • Know how to choose the right ladder for the job -
    • Kind of ladder – Step stool, step ladder, extension, articulating?
    • Size - How high do you need to reach?
    • Duty Rating - How much weight will be on the ladder? (Yes, step stools have duty ratings too)
    • Material -Fiberglass, Aluminum, Wood?
  • Stay off the top- The top of ladders aren’t meant for standing on and there’s absolutely no reason to tempt fate.
  • Remember: persons under 16 may NOT work on or use ladders, scaffolds, or their substitutes.

 ** Don’t be a statistic! ** Ladders are an invaluable tool at work and at home, but more often than not, they are used incorrectly or not at all –opting for furniture climbing. Missing the last step and overreaching are the two most cited causes of ladder accidents, according to a study by the American Ladder Institute (ALI). The third leading cause of unintentional injury-related death is falls. In 2017, 36,338 people died in falls at home and at work, according to Injury Facts.

If you have any questions or concerns regarding this program, please contact me at x4249 or cdillard@mos.org

Thank you in advance for your continued commitment to helping create a safe museum environment.

Sincerely,

Christina Dillard

Christina Dillard | Environmental Health & Safety (EHS) Program Manager

Facilities Dept. | P 617-589-4249 | M 781-789-1178| cdillard@mos.org

docs.messageSubject: Postponed: New Work Order System Launch
docs.messageBody:
We are still making changes to our new work order platform. Based on current status, the launch scheduled for tomorrow evening has been postponed. The project team continues to work on stabilizing the system over the next week and will revisit the timeline and send an update to staff once we have a new go live date.

This means that staff should continue to use Track-It until the new tool is rolled out to the Museum.
_______________________________________________________________________________________________________________________

The Museum of Science has some great news to share! We are implementing a new work order and customer service portal that centralizes requests for IT, Facilities, C&W, CRM Systems and Exhibit Maintenance. This new system, Service Now, will allow us to retire the legacy Track It application and replace it with more flexible and integrated work order environment.

We are planning to roll out the new platform on Wednesday, May 1st. Please note the following schedule of activities in order to support the launch:
• Mid day on Tuesday, April 30th: the current Track-it Work Order System will be taken offline. Any new request that you need to submit that day can be emailed to ithelp@mos.org and the Service Desk will assure that a ticket is entered for you in the new system
• Evening of Tuesday, April 30th: all active work orders will be migrated from Track It to the new system
• Morning of Wednesday, May 1st: the new portal will be available to all staff at https://museumofscience.service-now.com/. You will sign in with your museum user name and password. There will be also be updated links from the Hub for easy navigation and access

Service Now is accessible 24x7 from anywhere with an Internet connection and works across operating systems and multiple browsers.

Below is a short list of the enhancements you can expect with the new service:
• Better communication and updates for end users
• Searchable Service Catalog by department
• Email notifications and updates to tickets and work orders
• Ability to trace reoccurring issues and trends
• Ability to share a request with several departments and add more than one user on a tickets
• Search feature that will make is much easier for an end user to find what they need from an area

After the rollout, there will be continued growth and improvement in the platform as we get feedback and are able to implement additional functionality. The platform has many features that we look to implementing in the future including an extensive, searchable Knowledge Base and giving more tools to the technicians, like location updates, to streamline requests and needs for the museum.

*Information and Support Sessions
There will be 4 user drop in sessions to learn more about Service Now:
• Thursday, April 25th from 2:30-3:30pm in the Engineers Enclave
• Friday, April 26th from 2:00-3:00pm in the Engineers Enclave
• Monday, April 29th from 11:00-12:00pm in the Engineers Enclave
• Wednesday, May 1st from 11:00-12:00pm in Hodge

If you cannot make one of the four sessions but would still like a training session or if you have any questions or comments, please email SNAdminTeam@mos.org.

We’re very excited about rolling out this customer service platform and look forward to your feedback.

docs.messageSubject: FINAL RSVP BY FRI 5/17:  BOSTON PRIDE 2019!
docs.messageBody:
This year, for the first time ever, the Museum will be marching in the Boston Pride Parade!  We invite everyone from the Museum community - with your families, partners, and friends - to come march with us as we represent our institution and celebrate our values that the Museum of Science is a welcoming place for all!

The details so far:
Saturday, June 8 (rain or shine)
Copley Square (exact meeting time and location TBD)
Parade will finish at City Hall Plaza

We’re absolutely thrilled to be participating in this massive, joyful Boston event and we would love to have you alongside us on this special day.  If you’d like to march with us, or have any questions, please send an email to both James Wetzel (jwetzel@mos.org) and me (dleblanc@mos.org) and we’ll get you on our list and make sure to send you reminders and more details as they become available.  

Please also help us spread the word to others who may be interested in marching, particularly to staff or volunteers who aren’t in the Museum as often or who may not access the Hub regularly.  Everyone is welcome.

And in the meantime, mark your calendars for Saturday, June 8 and get ready to show off your best Museum fashion - red coats/aprons, Overnights T-shirts, or any other Museum gear or science flair you want to throw in!  We can’t wait to see you all on this important day!
Everything has been taken.

Restoration work continues within the Museum’s parking garage as we work to repair existing distress and deterioration, control leakage, and extend the useful life of the garage, which is so valuable to our daily operations.  

Already you can begin to see the improvements of the work throughout the 5th floor, sections of the front façade and some of the interior ramps.  

So what can you expect? The loudest and messiest work is expected to continue over the next 3 weeks as we complete the major concrete repairs on the ramps and surrounding areas.  Typically the loudest days are Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday during the demolition and winds down on Thursday and Friday as the concrete repairs are poured and spread. 

Work associated with the protective coatings and exterior façade will continue throughout the summer and we expect to finish these restoration efforts in late July.

As you navigate your way through the garage, please pay particular attention to our Public Safety staff and signage to help you safely and efficiently enter and exit from the garage.

Thank you in advance for your cooperation and understanding as we continue to improve the Museum!!!

Mapping the World Around Us and Making Models will be closing permanently on 24 June 2019 to make way for two new exhibits Adventure and Tech Studio which will open during the summer of 2020.  A few components will be moved to other areas of the Museum, some will go into storage, some will be going to other institutions and others will be permanently retired.

The Energized exhibit will be closing on 29 July 2019.  This area will become the temporary home for Design Challenges while construction takes place on the first floor of the Blue Wing.

April 2019 Comment Card Report

"I am having trouble logging into my account.  It told me my email and/or password was wrong.  So I had a reset email sent to me and it won't let me click on the button to reset.  Nothing happens.
Thanks for your help."

"I went to three websites and it doesn't tell when Cuba ends
It tells you that you must sign up for a time
I don't get it"

"I know the store is Indepnt. but I was appall when I bought stuff, asked for a bag & the staff member said we don't have one but you can BUY ONE for $4 - since when do you have a store with even no paper bags? 
A member for many years - the comment and Idea just very Rude"

"The purpose of me buying a membership is so that I can come into your museum and spend some quality time with my children learning about science, taking in a movie, eating at your food vendors.
I am going to have to reassess this. I planned an evening only to be greeted with a full parking lot and a traffic nightmare. All of your hardwork making the museum better and I felt like I was in line at an over filling MacDonalds with a staff that does not understand they are backing traffic out into the street. On top of the fact that someone was recently killed in that area it was very dangerous. And this was like 7:30 at night. Having work hard all the time I finally had time to see the laser show with my daughter at the late 9:30 show. That did not happen it was a wasted trip gas and time. I don't know what the problem is on a Friday why the parking lot is filled are you renting out spots?
I've also noticed the parking garage is always filled up even when there is not many people there.
Now I see you are having 18+ evenings.
The purpose of your museum is not a hook up place. Is it really being run by people out to promote science or is this some sort of bad joke. I'm not going to subsidize your adults only nights thats not why I buy a membership and spend 400-500 a year between parking tickets and food.
RIDICULOUS IDEA!!! Maybe you should open a night club next."


"Put the show times on the museum phanphlets!"

"We visited the MOS a little while back and noticed that many of the newer exhibits were bilingual. Why just two languages?
In America, we speak English. If you are going to appeal to our foreign visitors, why not add French, and German? Why just Spanish? I asked you this then and no one responded. I would appreciate a response.
Thanks."

"In 1951, the Boston Society of Natural History (BSNH) began its metamorphosis into the Museum of Science (Boston). What happened to the natural history collections that were associated with the BSNH? Where are they now? 
Thank you."

" We LOVE the museum and have recently seen a couple of shows there that I wanted to comment on.
1 - the David Bowie Planetarium show could not have been better! The graphics were astounding and the music was wonderful.
2 - we also went to see the Great Barrier Reef movie at the Omni. While it was interesting, it wasn't exactly new, or shot for a big screen. It was almost out of focus and twenty years old. The science in it was sound of course but completely outdated. It was quote disappointing for such a wonderful museum
Just thought you should know
Thanks"

"Today my mother lost her wallet somewhere in the museum. She went several times to ask if anyone found and returned a wallet throughout the day. The last time she went to ask before leaving the staff member just said no and didn’t look anywhere or ask anyone around them if anyone turned something in. We asked what to do because the parking ticket was also in the wallet.  Once we said that (the parking ticket was inside) they said that’s a problem and decided to look around and needed the draw to get unlocked. The wallet was in there the whole time. To not unlock the drawer before knowing the parking ticket was in there. This was not good customer service, clearly seeing my mother was stressed, they could of looked around instead of being rude and acting like we were bothering them. Very disappointed. Working with the public I know that is not how to act when a customer has a question or needs help. Thank you."

"I'm reaching out in regards to a visit I made recently with my three children; ages 8yo, 4yo, & 3yo.  I renewed our annual membership and expanded it to the five-person package because I had my two youngest with me, in addition to my 8yo, and we all were really disappointed.  I'm reaching out to request a refund for the difference from the five-person membership back down to the two-person membership.  The museum does not really offer much for the younger crowd and they were actually in the way of other museum visitors; while most attractions were visually appealing to them, they just could not understand what the exhibits actually were about.  I was quite shocked because of the charge of any person age 3yo and older.  I assumed there were appropriate attractions and interactions specifically for this age.  We specifically visited to see the Wild Kratts exhibit and we couldn't have been more let down.  It was terrible.  My children, Wild Kratts lovers, were shocked when we walked into the room to see that we had traveled 1.25hrs to see this exhibit.  Because of the ages of my two youngest and lack of facilities for them, we ended up leaving early and plan to return with just my oldest."

"Was reading about this new exhibit at Museum of London. You should try doing something like this.

"My family does not have WIC or EBT.   Its a shame that families have to save up to visit the museum. Rates are  slightly ridiculous for working class families"

"I brought a group of 20 Romanian students to museum - Had water for them but had forgotten cups. In cafeteria, buyin lunch. They would NOT give me the small cups - finally gave 5 - Had to bring each student up to ask - & they didn't speak English No excuse for this discourtesy."

"I'm trying to change my address on the site, but it says 'This address is invalid.'
Please update the address on my account."

"I must say me and my family were a tad bit disappointed with the museum this visit. Thank goodness we had library passes. For the money that is actually charged per person, I would demand my many back. My family and I were expecting more interactive exhibits that would make you leave feeling you learned something, amazed, and that science is exciting.  These exhibits, other than being geared towards extremely young children, were tired and boring."

"I wanted to submit a comment about the Magic Tree House planetarium show. It was really cool and my 4 year old and I have been twice now. It blew my mind the first time I saw it. I do have an issue with the lack of representation of black and brown people in the show though. It feels so incredibly white, both in who is represented and from a cultural perspective (white dominant cultural elements are so prominent). I would think that MOS would at least there be diversity in every show it puts out and that it be working towards inclusivity and racial equity in how it approaches it's programming. I truly hope someone will rise this comment up to those in leadership positions."

" In the human life area we were lucky enough to interact with Alyce who was sharing information on bones. I can't tell you enough how amazing she was, intelligent, knowledgeable, interesting...I could have listened to her so day. So I just wanted to let you know what a gem you have in her!"

"Please have a staff member in the dinosaur area! Especially near the T. Rex, our favorite guy. Today I witnessed *many* parents allowing their children to climb the wall, and one who watched while his child played inside the enclosure. This is my biggest (only) pet peeve about the MOS!"

"Yesterday, my significant other and I traveled over 2 hours from northern New Hampshire with our children to visit the Museum of Science.  My significant other and I remember visiting the museum as children and we couldn’t wait to share this experience with our kids, ages 9 and 10.  
The kids loved the Museum and truly had a ball with the entire experience.  Our youngest especially loved the Lightning! show.  She loved it so much, that when it came time to leave, she decided to purchase a Genius @ Play 8” Plasma Ball from the gift shop to remember the trip.  She used her own money to make this expensive purchase, and carried the box around like it was a trophy.  She couldn’t wait to get it home and set it up in her room.  
After an exhaustive trip back home sitting in several hours of traffic, she raced inside with her prize.  She carefully set it up and was completely devastated to learn that her Plasma Ball didn’t work.
My significant other tried to assist her, checking the power source and troubleshooting various other possible issues, but it was no use.  The Plasma Ball is most certainly broken.  
Of course, I’m not blaming the Museum for the broken toy.  The problem is, it’s not as simple as just packing it back up and returning it to the store.  Without traffic, it would be a significant journey to get back to the Museum to make the return.  Is there another way we can make this right?  It’s heartbreaking to know that the wonderful day we spent at the Museum will be tarnished in her memory by the purchase of this broken Plasma Ball."

"Our visit was incredible. We were running late at lunch so I called and a nice woman was able to move our Omni movie tickets to a later show. When we finally arrived, we found that the elevator from the garage was broken. My son is in a power chair so the elevator is a must. Before I could even come up with a plan to get him into the museum, an employee (sorry I didn't get her name) called on the phone to get some advice. Someone came up and they suggested I go park on the first level. She even went to check to make sure there were spaces (there wasn't when I had driven in). We went to the car and another employee came after us to instruct us to park outside of the museum instead because that would be easier. The level of service was truly above and beyond. Navigating Boston with a wheelchair is almost always a challenge.  I often have to beg, cajole or demand assistance and we always have to wait for help. However, your team made it so much easier and they all did it so pleasantly and almost without any request from us. Thank you!"

"Please make a Tupac Shakur Planetarium show."

"Staff member at discovery center unpleasant and not speaking kindly to my four yr old. We asked to wait (at capacity) they said not worth it we close soon."

"Movie on adaptation of animals made NO mention of global warming - M. of NH movie? Awesome museum of course!!!"

"Dear Museum of Science,
Please can you try to open a Fireman Sam exhibit? It could take about fireman, which are important people on our planet. It is ok if you can't do it."

"My wife and I just bought a premier membership for the Science Museum and took our two small grandchildren, ages 2 and 4.  One main reason for our purchase of the membership was the promise of free parking as advertised on your website.  When we arrived shortly before 10:30am, we were barred from entering the line to the garage and told we could not wait for a space to become available.  I drove around for a half hour before parking at the Galleria.  By the time we were ready to leave the museum, it was pouring rain.   We knew of the rainy forecast but felt the free covered parking would keep us dry.  In addition to all of us getting very wet, I also incurred extra cost to park my car.   Your website led us to believe that with a premier membership, free parking was part of the package.  I am hoping that you will offer me some redress for the inconveniences that I experienced."

"I tried to renew my Teacher partner program card (originally from 2015 but I am in a one-week ASTC membership limbo because I need to receive my local science museum updated card for reciprocal benefits. Your site is not recognizing the domain. Perhaps when I first signed up it was [email] though we haven’t used that domain in years"

"Do you think you could add a small exhibit for animals"

"Yesterday I came to the museum and pots for the exhibit hall tickets and also if they're 40 movie not being able to see all the sections I want I went back home this morning I came to see the Butterfly gardens and they told me I cannot purchase the ticket because I need to get another exhibit hall ticket which to me sounds in efficient it's for customer service purposes and also the fact that the six dollar that I was happy to pay for that and use it into the Museum butterfly gardens and they told me I cannot purchase the ticket because I need to get another exhibit hall ticket which to me sounds in efficient it's for customer service purposes and also the fact that the six dollar that I was happy to pay for that and use it into the museum
This issue could be easily fixed and more revenue produced for the museum if you easily let people purchase additional items within the two or three days after your visit."

"What a great museum! So much to do & so"

"I thought it was great"

"electrity show
Have interpreter for deaf or hearing hard."

I found this necklace yesterday afternoon (5/6), on the 3rd(?) parking level (I think), definitely five rows of cars away from the wall if you stand with your back to the Museum half way down the lot. I left it with the info desk this afternoon (5/7), so check with them if this belongs to you!

docs.messageBody:
Hi Folks,
Just a reminder that if you have an invoice you need to submit to Accounting, you don't need to put a Check Request on top of it. The naked invoice is just fine - slap an account and a signature on it and send it on up. Check Requests only are for those instances where you don't have an invoice for us to process.

docs.messageSubject: Reminder: Natural Science Lunch - Thursday May 23 at 1pm in the ERC
docs.messageBody:
Evolving Minds: Why Learning Counterintuitive Scientific Concepts like 
Natural Selection is So Hard

Deb Kelemen
Boston University

Natural selection is a fundamental mechanism of evolution, the unifying principle of biology. However, even after instruction, it remains a profoundly misunderstood scientific mechanism. The origin of many such misconceptions can be traced to predictably developing, untaught cognitive biases that are observable from early childhood. And yet, prevailing assumptions about young children’s cognitive limitations mean that, in most countries, comprehensive, causally coherent instruction on natural selection is typically delayed until adolescence–long after folk misunderstandings are likely to have entrenched. 

In this talk, I will overview cognitive developmental research on some of the untutored biases that create challenges for students’ acquisition of evolutionary concepts. These include early developing tendencies to view natural phenomena as intentionally designed and as possessing an immutable essence. I will also discuss recent educational studies exploring young children abilities to accurately learn about evolution from mechanistic explanatory storybooks that have been designed to take these cognitive developmental findings into account. Implications for our understanding of the mutability of cognitive biases and our enduring abilities to accurately learn about counterintuitive scientific concepts will be discussed.

Tech Studio would like to thank everyone who helped out with our annual high school engineering event over the weekend, Duck 'n' Hover! Over 150 high schoolers competed in the ultimate design challenge to build a wind-powered device to lift a payload of rubber ducks over 30 feet high in the Blue Wing Well. The winning design carried over 150 ducks! The participants and our Museum visitors had a great time, and got to take home some rubber ducks and duck-themed swag from our registration table. We couldn't have done it without our 27 near-peer mentors and our 45 Museum of Science and corporate volunteers, so thank you!

Thank you also to HHL, EHI, and Discovery Center staff and volunteers who helped us out by doing engineering and duck-themed activities for visitors throughout the day as part of our Duck 'n' Hover passport activity! The visitors really enjoyed being able to participate in engineering activities throughout the building in addition to watching the competition in the Blue Wing.

Thank you all!

In order to control pests we need everyone’s cooperation. Here is how we can use Your help.

We ask that you please always report pest sightings as well as any evidence of pest activity in a timely manner.  (Cockroaches, mice, ants, fruit flies, moths, etc.) 

The Facilities department offers the following options for reporting, choose which ever is best for you. 
  
•	Submit a W.O. with Museum's On line work order (Get It Done/Facilities/Work order) 
•	Write the information as detailed as possible in the sighting book located in the Front desk.
In the event of a present situation that can’t wait, you can reach us at Facilities ext. 0150
Helpful tips that relate to pest prevention: 
•	When reporting, be specific (date, type of pest seen, where, route of travel, your name & ext in case we need more information)
•	Keep your space clean of clutter, food etc.  Treats, food and snacks kept in office should be in covered containers. 
•	Keep the food disposal related items in a centralized location (we suggest the Kitchenettes areas rather than individual trash barrels)
•	Do not eat food in the hallways, stairs, elevators, or exhibit halls. 
•	Keep floor & walls clutter free (suggested clearance of 6 inches off floor and away from walls when possible) 
Need some help cleaning? – Get some assistance from C&W. 
Need ways to store properly – Get some assistance from the Facilities Department
	If you have any questions, suggestions or concerns please let me know. 
Yesenia Lopez
Facilities Department
617-589-0150

docs.messageSubject: Exclusive Staff and Volunteer Preview for BODY WORLDS & The Cycle of Life, Friday, June 14, 2019
docs.messageBody:
Exclusive Staff and Volunteer Preview for BODY WORLDS & The Cycle of Life
Friday, June 14, 2019
We are happy to announce that starting Tuesday, May 28, 2019 at 11:00am tickets will be available for the Staff/Volunteer/Intern Preview of BODY WORLDS & The Cycle of Life. Bring up to 4 guests for a sneak peek at the exhibit before we open it to the general public! 

Staff/Volunteer/Intern Preview Details: 
When: Friday, June 14, 2019 
Timed Tickets Required: 12:30pm – 6:00pm (entry times every 10 minutes with last entry at 5:00pm) 
Where: Nichols Gallery (Red Wing Entry) 
Additional Information: We estimate it will take most visitors 1 hour to 1.5 hours to walk through the exhibit. For your convenience, Audio Tours will be available at the exhibition entry free of charge on a first come first served basis! 

The normal exhibit policies and procedures will apply: 
•Food and beverages will be prohibited inside the exhibit. 
•Flash photography will not be allowed in the exhibit. 
•There are no bathrooms within the exhibit, please plan accordingly. 
•Guests will not be allowed to re-enter the exhibit. 
•There will be no exchanges or late arrivals permitted. 
•Bags and strollers will be permitted if they do not disrupt the flow of traffic. Large strollers will not be permitted and will be directed to stroller parking. Individuals with large bags will be directed to the lockers in the lobby.
•All members of your party will need a timed ticket, including yourself, to enter the exhibit. 

Ticket Process:
Due to the popularity of the exhibit, we are asking all Staff, Volunteers and Interns to obtain their timed tickets for the preview at the Box Office via the Yellow Line on a first come first served basis. Each staff member, volunteer and intern will receive one ticket for themselves and up to 4 additional tickets for their guests. Tickets will be available at the Box Office starting Tuesday, May 28 at 11:00am through the day of the event on a space available basis, however, we expect this to be a popular event and highly suggest getting your tickets in advance. 

•You must obtain timed tickets for entry to the preview and all guests must be accompanied by a staff member, volunteer, or intern to enter the exhibit. 
•You must have your ID badge to obtain your tickets at the Box Office. 
•Tickets cannot be held at the Box Office. 
•Each staff member, volunteer and/or intern must be present to obtain their own tickets with a valid Museum issued ID badge. 
•Please arrive to the Box Office no earlier than 11:00am to get your tickets. Please be mindful of visitors in the queue, as they will receive priority service. 
•Please contact Amy Germaine ext. 0377 or Wendy Tatarouns ext. 0213 with questions regarding the preview.

The Safety Committee has completed its review of the Safety Policy for, “Respiratory Protective Equipment”.

The revised program is located on the Environmental Health and Safety Page under the category Respiratory Protective Equipment . The direct link to the policy is:  https://bmos.sharepoint.com/EHSDocs/Respiratory%20Protective%20Equipment%20Program.pdf

The content of this program has had limited change;  clarifications and minor edits were made to ensure the health and safety of Museum staff in compliance with the OSHA Respiratory Protection standard, 29 CFR 1910.134.

  • If you are enrolled in or manage staff enrolled in the Respiratory Protection Program please ensure that you are familiar with the requirements of this policy.
  • If you have any questions or concerns related to respiratory hazards in the course of your work, please review this program, speak with your supervisor and or contact the Respiratory Program Administrator/EH&S Program Manager

Below are a few highlights from this program:

  • To determine the need for respiratory protection, a job hazard assessment performed with your supervisor and the Respiratory Program Administrator is required to identify and evaluate the respiratory hazard(s) in the workplace. If air contaminants exceed permissible exposure limits and engineering or administrative controls are inadequate to eliminate or reduce exposure, selection and use of a respirator in compliance with this program will commence.
  • Before staff may be required to use any respirator with a negative or positive pressure tight-fitting facepiece, they must complete a medical evaluation, be fit tested and trained.
  • Only filtering face piece, disposable, dust mask type respirators are allowed for voluntary use; The Form Appendix D to 29 CFR 1910.134 (Mandatory) Information for Employees Using Respirators When Not Required (Voluntary Use) must be completed and on file with Human Resources and the Respiratory Program Administrator/EH&S Program Manager prior to use. If your staff is voluntarily using dust masks and you are unsure if they have completed an Appendix D form, please have them do so now.

If you have any questions or concerns regarding this program or any of our safety programs, please contact the Environmental Health & Safety (EH&S) Program Manager, Christina Dillard at x4249 or cdillard@mos.org

Thank you in advance for your continued commitment to helping create a safe museum environment.

Sincerely,

The MOS Safety Committee

docs.messageSubject: Complimentary Passes for Body Worlds & The Cycle of Life
docs.messageBody:
As of today, June 3, 2019, all Staff, Interns and eligible Volunteers can pick up their complimentary passes for Body Worlds & The Cycle of Life in the Human Resources & Volunteer Services offices on the 6th floor. 

In order to enter the Body Worlds exhibit, guests must also have Exhibit Halls admission. Because of this, staff, volunteers and interns will be receiving Body Worlds and Exhibit Hall complimentary passes. 

Individuals are eligible for the following amount of passes:

• All Full-Time Regular MOS Staff receive 4 Body Worlds and 4 Exhibit Hall passes
• All Part-Time Regular MOS Staff receive 2 Body Worlds and 2 Exhibit Hall passes
• All Full-Time and Part-Time Temporary and Casual MOS Staff receive 2 Body Worlds and 2 Exhibit Hall passes
• All active MOS Volunteers who have served 70 hours in the past 12 months will receive 2 Body Worlds and 2 Exhibit Hall passes
• All MOS Interns receive 2 Body Worlds and 2 Exhibit Hall passes
• Trustees and Overseers receive 2 Body Worlds and 2 Exhibit Hall passes (these passes will be mailed)

There are multiple ways to redeem your passes for timed tickets:

1. By visiting the Box Office
2. Calling Science Central at 617-723-2500
3. “Purchasing” tickets through the Museum’s online store
a. To get started, Log In or Create a New Account on www.mos.org
b. Under “Explore,” select “Exhibits” and then select “Body Worlds & the Cycle of Life”
c. Select a date and time and the amount of passes you wish to redeem for that specific date and time. Click “Add to Cart” 
d. Under “Gift Passes” (located at the top of the cart) enter in the 12 digit gift code found on the Body Worlds pass (you must include the dashes)
e. Press “Import Another Pass” and enter the 12 digit gift code found on the Exhibit Hall pass. Press Continue once you’ve entered all gift codes
f. After applying the gift code, select the number of free passes to use from the blue bar below your item
g. If you scroll to the bottom of the page, your “Total to Pay” balance should be $0.00
i. If you’re having issues with your online purchase, please call Science Central 617-723-2500

It is also especially important that you communicate to your guests that the Body Worlds passes expire on Friday, December 20, 2019.

• Passes must be exchanged for a timed ticket when space is available.
• The Museum provides one set of passes per eligible employee or volunteer; if you hold more than one employee or volunteer role with the Museum, eligibility for passes will be based on your primary position.
• Staff and volunteers may use their Museum badge to view the exhibit at any time on a space available basis. Please try to avoid peak periods of business when visiting the exhibit.
• You can collect the passes between 8:30am-5:00pm Monday-Friday. If you are unable to come in during that time, we will provide your manager a release form so that they can collect the passes on your behalf. 
• Audio guides, subject to availability, will be free to all staff, volunteers and interns by showing their Museum badge. Regular rates apply to guests using the staff/volunteer/intern gifted passes. 
• Lost or misplaced passes will not be replaced.

The Body Worlds & The Cycle of Life passes will be available in the
Human Resources office on the 6th floor Monday - Friday 8:30am-5:00pm.
If you have any questions concerning the free passes, please contact
Aurelia GrantWingate x0121, agrantwingate@mos.org

docs.messageSubject: Upcoming Out of Band Network Maintenance 6/10 6pm and 6/12 6pm
docs.messageBody:
Next week upgrades will be applied to our network infrastructure over two separate maintenance windows. These upgrades will be staggered through their respective evenings to minimize end user impact:
•	On Monday, June 10th, IT will perform upgrades to the wireless switches in preparation for this summer’s full wireless refresh. This work is necessary for the new wireless equipment we will be installing
•	On Wednesday, June 12th, IT will perform upgrades to the network core to patch vulnerabilities and get on the most stable current release. This upgrade will improve functionality on the switches and the security of our infrastructure

What Does This Mean?
For the wireless switch upgrades on the 10th, Information Technology will be upgrading the firmware on seven switches within the Museum. During the upgrade process, wireless access may be unavailable for the following areas: the Gordon Wing, 3rd floor offices and ERC, Box Office and Blue wing, and the Engineer’s Enclave. This work will take place after hours to minimize impact and will not have a Museum-wide scope. 

The network core upgrades on the 12th will affect network access periodically as updates are applied and devices are rebooted. We will have staff on site checking connections and validating our entire infrastructure post-install. 

What Can I Expect When This Takes Effect?
On the 10th, portions of the Museum will have briefly interrupted wireless network access, but the impact should be minimal. 

On the 12th, network and file services may be briefly unavailable. We will be staggering the install to minimize impact.

What Do I Need To Do?
If you need to be on any of our Wi-Fi networks after hours on the 10th, affected areas may be unavailable briefly. If you need to use the Internet, your hardwired connection will not be impacted at all. 

On the 12th, we will not be starting until after the box office has closed, and will be doing everything we can to minimize the impact so you will not be required to do anything.

As always, if you have any questions or issues, please contact our service desk, System Support Services, at ithelp@mos.org or call x0130.

May 2019 Comment Card Report

"I would like to give a big shout out to Kellie, who works in the Wild Kratt's Ocean Adventure. I work at the preschool nearby and often visit this exhibit with Kellie as the museum educator. My classroom (10 children aged 18-24 months) decided to visit the exhibit during school vacation  week  (April 15-19). We usually have three teachers, but were short on this day. When we entered the exhibit, we could see that it was crowded and would have to keep an extra eye on the children. Two minutes into their play, 2 children needed immediate diaper changes. Given that we were short a teacher, my co-teacher and I asked Kellie if she could by any chance help us make sure none of the other children ran away. Given how many other children and adults were in the room, Kellie agreed and helped us. We were extremely grateful to have the extra eyes. She is always happy to see our children!"

"I attended the Laser Floyd show on 4/20/19 with a friend and we both were left with dismay.  I think of the MOS as a world class museum and thought who could put on a laser show better than a science museum? The lasers were flat and had no continuity with many repeating patterns. It was comparable to having someone with a laser pen do squiggly lines  across a surface or playing with a Spirograph. They were not in synch with the music and didn't take me deeper with the music, it didn't add to the experience. It also didn't use up the roof of the planetarium and was focused only in one section. There were times that it showed potential and then strayed. It was very disappointing and my friend who attended with me felt the same.
The imaging behind the lasers was great and the sound was incredible. I just wish the lasers held up to enhancing the experience and helping create a feeling of a journey much like the music does. The ambience of lighting and the mood it can create are a big part of the concert experience and the MOS has a wonderful opportunity to create something out of this world. It would be perfect in such a place as the planetarium!
Thank you for allowing me to comment on my experience and I look forward to visiting the museum as it is always a pleasure."

"We came with 11 patients in wheelchairs and Camden Ballard was amazing! So helpful!!"

"1. Nobody knew about raffle advertised in my e-mail.
2. Mac 'n cheese was not hot by the time I got through the line to pay. Had to ask for my receipt.
3. Food & Nutrition author's bare belly peeking out was distracting (11:30 A.M. presentation)
4. A hook on the back of the bathroom door would have been nice. Had to put my coat, etc. on the bathrm floor."

“My daughter was in today with her school. She was in the gift shop and accidentally dropped a small snow globe and it broke. The cashier told my daughter that she had to pay for the snow globe and extra because it broke! It was a $2.00 snow globe, my daughter gave the cashier a $10.00 bill and received no change or receipt? I would like to know A. Why did she have to pay extra for something that broke and  B. Why wouldn’t she have received any kind of receipt? She’s in the 4th grade. I am just wondering if this is common at the MOS? I am very disappointed that you do not hire responsible staff that deal with children on a regular basis.”

“I was wondering if you happen to have any promotional items and or a t-shirt you can send my way, I would love to show my support both near and far.”

"Every time I visit the area, I always make sure your place is a must stop on my itinerary. I am proud to continue to support such a wonderful business like you. I am always very satisfied with the services I am receiving from you. Thank you for always making my experience a great one. I highly recommend you to others to enjoy as well. You always leave me wanting to visit again time after time with family and friends. I am so glad I discovered your place, and never doubting my choice to make that first stop.”

“I was disappointed to see Bodyworlds featured in my regular MOS mailing this morning. 
I understand that the museum needs money but, the discretion the MOS uses in renting our the variable space values dollars over science. E.g.: the NE Patriot's shameless victory lap with token science was a bit galling. Though I suppose a Raytheon exhibit is also a plug but, at least that's science. I also understand that anatomy is science but, when I see ads for Bodyworlds, I can only think of loved ones who have died and those corpses are not there for science but, to be taped at not by or for anatomists.”
Thank you, still love the MOS"

"Hello I am emailing you because of an issue we had during lunch. We ate at the food court and it was $47.66 for four drinks a salad 2 chicken fingers and fries and a slice of pizza. I am the one that had the pizza from pucks and it was terrible. It was on a giant piece of focaccia bread from what I could tell. It tasted like it was from a freezer and it was 8$ I would have been better off going to a pizza shop down the road for that price highway robbery. I don't like being rude so I did not go and complain to the person working but something needs to be done for these prices it was roughly a $250 day and we love the museum and plan on coming back for body worlds but I can't see spending a fortune on food when  parking and the gift shop and ticket prices are already pushing the budget. I'm sure that's good for the museum but for us it's a deterrent from wanting to come back on our family outings. Again biggest complaint is the prices for things and that awful pizza. Thank you"

“Impossible Triangle in the Optical Illusions--Put orange stripes on the carpet from wall to box so people know they're walking in the middle of something."		

"Hi. You are all doing a great job. Love you."		 

"Your website team probably knows this, but just in case, please forward this to them.
At the moment, your website is not working properly in MS Edge.  It works well in Chrome, but there are lots of errors on Edge.  If you need further details (version info, etc.) just contact me."

"Can you adopt a model recycling program, including composting, bottles/cans, some plastics, & trash?"

"I wanted to write regarding my visit to the museum today.  We attended specifically for the Wild Kratts under the sea exhibit.  Because of how expensive the tickets were, we purchased a membership, to try and take advantage of the museum this summer.  When we walked into the exhibit, we were VERY disappointed.  The room was TINY, and geared towards really young children.  My daughter had been extremely excited for this, and instead of being excited, she started to cry.  We walked around the small room, and then walked right out the door.  My daughter actually thanked me for getting her out of there..  She now is telling me that she never wants to go back, and to be honest with you, I don't blame her.  I too, have no desire to come back.  At the very expensive price we just paid for the membership, I am insanely disappointed, and not sure how to handle this.. Please help."
			
"Hi.  My only slightly negative experiences were the attendant at the gate would not let my students get a stamp.  I did not get a sufficient explanation why.   Also, the electricity demonstration was much below the level of understanding of the AP Physics students that I brought.  I can understand this because you had to accommodate students that were in grade school.  I don’t know how this can be fixed, but I just wanted to let you know.  We love the MOS"

"Was very disappointed at the treatment from the cafe in the red wing. I was going to pay for my food, and was screamed at by a worker to go a certain way to the cashier. Which was weird because there was no one in line. I proceeded to sit down and eat when another staff member came over and started being rude about how I grabbed food from the display. Which in the first place had NO SIGN. They yelled at me to give it back which caught me off guard as I had no intentions of eating it at this point. I won't be back to this museum as the staff is nothing but rude."

"This is fun!"

"Please forward this message to the Board of Trustees as well as Management.
I have been a member off and on for decades and I appreciate the work you do.
I am sad and upset to see that you are scheduling ""Body Worlds.""  I am sure you are fully aware of the many controversies of obtaining bodies for this purpose.  The statement that they have been ""legally obtained"" is not an excuse for profiting and exhibiting a person's body for commercial purposes.
Every human being is sacred and their bodies need to be honored not plastcized and put on display for ""educational purposes.""  We have adequate textbooks and medical cadavers for this purpose that are found in educational materials already.
I am ashamed of the group who approved this and I respectfully request that you withdraw this  exhibit. Until it is withdrawn, I will do all I can to influence everyone I can to NOT attend at the Museum of Science while disrepected bodies are being exhibited."

"As MOS members we are very disappointed to learn that the MOS is associating itself with the questionable ethics of Dr Gunther von Hagens. It is clear from many news reports including NPR that the bodies in the Body Worlds exhibit may be on display without the consent those individuals. The company behind Body Worlds has a murky history with documentation of the cadavers used. It is troubling that MOS could not resist this sideshow-like display which may include exploiting cadavers of unwilling participants. We understand that the dissections are truly amazing. However it is troubling MOS chose not to be an example of ethics in science and instead is taking a deep dive with this display."

"I would like to say thanks for the Museum of Science. Museum of Science provided free tickets for all my 4th graders English Program. It was the first and only field trip they had this academic year. During visit, they had so much fun while learned electricity, human body, math, and nutrition.
I am sure that it was a learning experience that they will remember forever!"

"Please bring back Mirror Maze"

"For Red Sox weekend, will you have the demonstration of Bernoulli & ball flight, it was cool in the Science of Sports exhibit. Would love to see it again on Red Sox weekend. There was a plastic golf, baseball football & a tennis model that was put into a jet of air & we got to try it out for ourselves."

"I am disappointed that there is almost nothing on climate change! These children lives will be profoundly influenced by climate change - yet nothing! Not science - just entertainment. Do you get funding from the fossil fuel industry?"

"Just a note to let you know how disappointed I am that you are not making the Red Sox weekend schedule available on line or on the phone. For a 2 day, 8 hr per day event, I think it's a bit unreasonable to keep the schedule a secret and asking us (yes I am a member) to come in in person to find out about the schedule of programs. Kind of unrealistic to expect us to block out the entire weekend to attend an event/program or two in which we are interested -especially when there is apparently a brochure which will be available in person. Not very welcoming or accommodating a system. I have been checking the website for several weeks looking for the schedule, without success."
Made me proud.

docs.messageSubject: Living with "Wild" Neighbors - MOS Safety Committee Tip Series for Natl Safety Month
docs.messageBody:
Happy National Safety Month from your MOS Safety Committee! With help from our colleagues we are going to offer some Spring/Summer Safety Tips over the next few weeks, to help remind you that safety doesn’t stop at the door of the Museum!

Our first article reminds us how to safely live with our “wild” neighbors.

What happens when you put nearly 6 million people on 5 million acres with native wildlife? As the people move in, the animals learn to adapt, but their adaptations aren’t always so cute or appreciated by humans. Bunny Watson of the Live Animal Care Center put together a very informative Tip Sheet (https://bmos.sharepoint.com/EHSDocs/Living with wildlife in Massachusetts.pdf) that will help you avoid conflict with your wildlife neighbors.

 Here are a few highlights of how to be a good neighbor!

  • If you leave it out … they will come. Store food securely!
  • Winter is for the birds! Take your bird feeder down in the Spring and Summer.
  • Limited access isn’t enough – seal those gaps! If you want to stop unwanted guests, identify access points into your home and seal them tight.
  • Good Fences make good neighbors! Use fencing around your vegetable garden or it will be a buffet.
  • If you have wildlife that is being a nuisance DO NOT relocate it yourself. It is illegal to move wildlife to a different area.

To Learn More please click here! And please don’t take matters into your own hands. Let the experts help!

If there's a concern about wildlife on the Museum property, please do not attempt to interact with the animal. Note the location and contact the live animal center x0333.

Please, do NOT feed any wildlife seen on the property. Be sure that any food is cleaned up and if trash barrels are full please notify C&W. Keeping the area clean will reduce wild visitors.

Thank you for your continued commitment this month and every month for helping create a safe museum environment.

Sincerely,

The MOS Safety Committee

Museum Partners –

I am writing to share the bittersweet news that Maggie Andrews will be leaving the Museum as of Wednesday, June 26th. She has accepted a position as the Events Senior Manager with The MBA Tour, a company that connects top business schools with prospective MBA candidates through international events and conferences. Maggie looks forward to traveling internationally with the team, and implementing new technologies as a part of their overall event strategy.  

In the past year and a half, Maggie has been an asset in the planning and execution of significant Museum events such as Chairman’s Circle featuring Author Dan Brown, Celebration of Seafood with WPC Chef Eric Klein, and Discoverer’s Science Uncorked at City Winery. These few events and countless others are testaments to her ingenuity, professionalism and creative spirit; all responsible for producing many beautiful memories for our donors, members and staff. 

I can personally attest that the standards for recognition events at the Museum of Science have been elevated because of Maggie’s commitment to outstanding hospitality, knowledge of the latest culinary trends, and eye for design. Her ability to multitask the most complex event details and handle interactions with vendors and guests with poise and sincere care should be applauded and is a learning opportunity for us all.

Please join me in saying “Bon Voyage” to our dear friend and colleague. Maggie, you will be sorely missed! 

Best regards,
Jason

docs.messageSubject: Bike Safety Tips for National Safety Month - Be Safe! from your MOS Safety Committee
docs.messageBody:
Happy National Safety Month from your MOS Safety Committee! This week we have more safety tips to help us recognize June as National Safety Month.

This week’s safety tips have been shared with us by Megan Gregory from our Research and Evaluation Team (Thank you for this great information Megan!) Her passion for bicycle safety should help us all be safer when traveling on our roadways as a true bicycle enthusiast or as an occasional weekend rider on your local bike path.

Bicycle safety starts with Proper Maintenance .

  • Get at least one professional tune-up each year, but make sure that your tires are inflated and in good condition, and that your brakes are effective before every ride.
  • Remember the ABCs of checking your bike!

A - Check your air pressure!

B - Squeeze your brakes and ensure they work, and that they work well!

C - Clean you chain regularly, and especially after bad weather.

 Be Seen -  Use Reflectors and Lights

  • Make sure that you have reflector strips on your pedals, or wear a reflective ankle cuff on your left leg. Drivers usually have a better time recognizing bicycles at night when there is illuminated movement (reflectors on your pedals/ankles, reflectors in your wheel spokes that rotate, etc.) in addition to static lights mounted to your frame and handlebars.
  • Invest in good-quality bike lights. Rechargeable ones tend to cost more, but they tend to be brighter. Furthermore, it may be easier to keep a charging cord at work than it is to buy batteries on a regular basis.

Be Heard -  Use Bells and a Loud Voice

  • Have a bell on your bike to alert pedestrians, cars, and other cyclists of your presence. Use your bell and vocal communication – ring your bell and then say, “Passing on your left!” when passing a pedestrian on the bike path, for example.
  • When on bike paths, give other users as much space and forewarning as possible when passing them. It is important to share these resources gracefully!

Protect Your Head

  • Replace your helmet every 2-3 years, and immediately after any crash in which you hit your head, or if you drop it onto hard ground from a height of four feet or more. Helmets are quite delicate, and any impact that can cause the foam to deform will severely degrade its safety.

Be Smart

  • If you ride on the sidewalk to get to the Museum parking garage and employee bike cage, always give pedestrians the right of way. If you find this frustrating because it’s harder to balance or it feels annoying to have to slow down to a walking pace, then it may be better to simply hop off your bike and walk it into the garage or until you are in an area where you are able to ride it comfortably and safely. Even though you’re allowed to ride on most sidewalks in Boston, cyclists still must give pedestrians priority on sidewalks.

Be Smarter – Know your Rights!

  • MassBike lists your rights and responsibilities as a cyclist on their website here: https://www.massbike.org/laws They describe things in everyday language, and link to the legalese content as well.
  • Bike Safe Boston is a bicycling safety blog written by a lawyer who works with cyclists when they need legal representation. Another good resource to check for bike safety, and for what to do if you are ever in a crash https://bikesafeboston.com/

 

Thank you for your continued commitment this month and every month for helping create a safer museum environment and for taking those good safety habits “home” with you!

 Sincerely,

The MOS Safety Committee

docs.messageSubject: Sweet cat looking for forever home
docs.messageBody:
We are looking for a forever home for our sweet 2 year old cat Bellatrix (aka Bella).  We adopted her 4 months ago to keep our other cat company after his sister passed away, but unfortunately they do not get along as we had hoped.  

Bella is a Scottish Fold with an impressive pedigree who was retired from having litters when we adopted her.  She has an incredibly sweet disposition, likes to play with things that roll, and is a very vocal conversationalist.  She likes to be around people and can be an aggressive snuggler.  Bella is mostly white, with some brown and black spots here and there.  She may not do well with other animals in the house, although the previous owner had no problem with having other cats and dogs around her (just our cat apparently).  She is 100% an indoor cat and would do fine in a house or apartment.

We're sad that we can't keep her and just want her to go to a loving home.  Please contact me at sheilman@mos.org or x0105 if you are interested.

She is up to date on all of her shots.  She will come with a litter box, a few toys, and a cat carrier.

Former MOS Staff member Steven Marchio, has reached out to the Museum on behalf of his new employer iMentor to seek out any MOS Staff Members interested in becoming mentors!

iMentor is seeking Mentors for Amplify Scholars, who are Knowledge is Power Program (KIPP) alumni selected from an incredible group of applicants to receive supplemental scholarship support, training, and mentoring all with the purpose of empowering them on their journey forward as leaders. As a Mentor for an Amplify Scholar, you are joining a unique network of KIPP students and mentors.  

Mentors are asked to talk with their mentees two to three times a month, via a phone call, video chat, or email – acting as a thought partner, cheerleader, guide, and connector as they navigate through college and internships each summer. Amplify Scholars and their mentors are provided discussion prompts and guidance each month to frame conversations and also receive one on one support from our Amplify program manager. We also ask mentors to meet at least once a semester with their mentee.  We have one student who is attending Tufts University and another attending Wellesley University.

As the program is four years, we ask that mentors commit to staying with their mentee until graduation. Every Amplify Mentor is positioned to greatly impact a student’s life. Each Amplify Scholar is a trailblazer – joining them on this journey is truly a once in a lifetime opportunity. We hope you will consider joining the iMentor Amplify family!  For more information, please reach out to MOS alum Steven Marchio at smarchio@imentor.org

docs.messageSubject: Prevent Distracted Driving- MOS Safety Committee Celebrates National Safety Month
docs.messageBody:
This week, we recognize June as National Safety Month with tips from our MOS Safety Committee Member, Mike Adams. Thanks Mike for this valuable information.  

View or print this email on the EH&S Hub

IT’S FINALLY SUMMER AND NOTHING SAYS SUMMER FUN, LIKE A ROAD TRIP!

Whether you’re heading to the beach, going camping, or visiting the world’s largest rubber band ball in Florida (it stands over 6 feet tall  and weighs over 9,000 lbs.!)


We want you to stay safe on the roads.

Driving with any form of distraction is a CHOICE! 

While you are planning your summer travels, it’s the perfect time to consider the consequences of choosing distracted driving.

 FACTS THAT YOU SHOULD KNOW:

  • 4.6 seconds is the average time your eyes are off the road while texting; traveling at 55 mph, that is equivalent to driving the length of a football field blindfolded.
  • Voice-to-text is even more distracting than holding your phone. You're mentally distracted by composing the message and visually distracted by common autocorrect errors.
  • Even at stoplights, it is important to remain an attentive driver; a AAA study shows that people are distracted up to 27 seconds after they send a voice text.
  • 7% of all drivers at any given time are using their phones while driving, but cognitive neuroscientist, David Strayer, says only about 2.5% of the population is actually capable of multitasking.
  • Drivers who are talking on their cell phone are 4x more likely to crash — drunk  drivers share those odds. The odds of crashing if you’re texting while driving is 8x times the normal rate, meaning it doubles the crash likelihood of driving drunk.

THREE IDEAS TO HELP CURB THIS TERRIBLE HABIT:

  • Get your phone out of reach. Turn your phone on silent—or airplane mode— and place it in your glove compartment. If you’re still  too tempted, throw it in the trunk before getting behind the wheel.
  • Distract yourself—safely.Try listening to interesting radio stations, podcasts or audiobooks. None of these are as attention-absorbing as texting, which takes both your attention and your eyes off the road.
  • Use an app to prevent use.  Some wireless providers offer a Drive mode App, which can detect when your car is traveling, stop you from sending texts, and even send an automatic response saying you’re driving and can’t talk right now.

 Please Drive Safely this Summer and Every Day!

Thank you for your continued commitment this month and every month for helping create a safer museum environment and for taking those good safety habits “home” with you!

 Sincerely,

The MOS Safety Committee

The National Safety Council website has lots of resources and information: https://www.nsc.org/pages/ddam/ddam-materials

 https://www.nsc.org/pages/nsm-public-materials

Fiscal Year 2018-19 ends on Sunday (!), which means we’re gearing up to close out the year and brace ourselves for The Audit. In preparation for all that, we ask that you observe the following deadlines, which are pretty much the same as in prior years: • All purchase order/contract paperwork for FY19* is due to Business Services no later than Friday, July 5th. • All invoices, travel vouchers, and check requests for FY19* are due to Accounting no later than Wednesday, July 17th. • If you’ve bought something or had services performed recently and the vendor hasn’t billed you yet, please hound them into billing you ASAP.  Annoying persistence on your part would be greatly appreciated (by us, though probably not the vendor). • Similarly, if you have an ongoing service or project where someone bills you monthly, please make sure we have received all 12 months’ worth of bills. • If there’s paperwork you know will be coming in but probably won’t make it before the deadlines, give us a heads-up so it doesn’t catch us by surprise after we think we’re all done. • Please get all personal reimbursement check requests and travel vouchers up to us ASAP.  Note that reimbursement for expenses incurred more than 60 days ago will be paid at Accounting’s discretion. * - What counts as FY19?   For any given invoice • If the stuff was received / the services were performed before June 30, it’s FY19 and should hit FY19’s budget. • Anything received after June 30 is FY20 and must hit your FY20 budget.  (That’s not us being mean; it’s a nation-wide accounting rule.) • However, if you can prove something was shipped before 6/30 (even if you got it after), it may count as FY19 depending on the vendor’s "FOB terms".  Consult Accounting. • If it’s not obvious from the invoice what year something belongs in, but you yourself do know, please make a note on the face of the invoice to help the AP folks put it in the right year. • Note that receipt/performance date is the only thing that matters.  What year the expense was originally budgeted in is irrelevant. Plan ahead • If you’re going on vacation at any time over the next few weeks, before you leave please make sure: – all Accounting-related paperwork needing your signature has been signed and submitted, and – you have made arrangements for someone else to handle any paperwork that hits your inbox during your absence. • If you (or anyone else in your department’s processing of Accounting stuff) are taking the Early Out package, please make sure all paperwork is taken care of before the exodus, and that any unavoidable loose ends are safely in the hands of Someone Who’s Staying. • If you’re one of those departments that occasionally sends up large numbers of check requests at once (e.g. stipends, etc.), please give us plenty of advance warning if you expect to submit one of those batches in July or August. Understand that July and especially August are real crunch times for Accounting.  If you’ve got anything non-Audit-related you need us to deal with than can reasonably wait until September, we’d truly appreciate you holding off on it until then. Thank you, Stan

I just received an email from my vet today about grain-free pet foods. It also mentioned that this advisory includes cats too:

As pet owners, all of us want to do what is best for our pets.  Nutrition is one of the few things that we actually have control over when it comes to their health.  Picking a food is an overwhelming landscape full of countless opinions, and savvy marketing that not only comes in the form of a commercial, but spills down to the way ingredients are listed on the label of a bag of pet food.  We want to help you navigate nutrition in general, and offer you the best science out there.

Currently, if your pet was on a listed food in the press release and is doing well, the best recommendation is to slowly transition them off over the course of a week.  We are recommending Royal Canin as they have outstanding standards for their nutrition, have a long history of safety and don't spend resources on marketing.  There are other options that you are welcome to use, but we wanted to provide at least an easy answer in the short term and we will provide you with the resources to make a choice that is best for you and your pet below.  

If you have concerns about your pet's heart health, switching foods is the most important treatment and best starting point.  If you have concerns, we are happy to help on the medical side of things and can coordinate special appointments over the next few days to listen and make sure that their hearts sound normal.  There are other ways to try and be sure that hearts are healthy such as electrocardiograms, cardiac stress blood tests and the gold standard of an echocardiogram with a cardiologist.  
 
Here are some links from our trusted local friends at Tufts Petfoodology below to help navigate this new information from the FDA and how to move forward and continue to do the best that you can for your pet:
 
First thoughts about this concept of a heart disease being linked to grain free foods coming out:
https://vetnutrition.tufts.edu/2018/06/a-broken-heart-risk-of-heart-disease-in-boutique-or-grain-free-diets-and-exotic-ingredients/
 
An update on that article above:
https://vetnutrition.tufts.edu/2018/11/dcm-update/
 
How to read between the lines on the ingredient list of a pet food:
https://vetnutrition.tufts.edu/2019/03/stop-reading-your-pet-food-ingredient-list/
 
What to look for when picking a pet food:
https://vetnutrition.tufts.edu/2019/05/pna-pet-food-manufacturer-survey/
 
The FDA news release:
http://link.vetstreetpro.com/u/nrd.php?p=IhG23yRiAR_1781709_142_-2_2&ems_l=58&l=nzzvyM44CCCcljgcmuB4gtosgrdBkzkxotgxE4tkCydkBktzy4ljgdotBkyzomgzoutdvuzktzogrdrotqdhkzCkktdikxzgotdjokzydgtjdigtotkdjorgzkjdigxjousEuvgznE&s=an6gaL8oGHUBOxxdlWbxPxhnDXI
