June 2019-Comment Cards

"Thought you should know that my family is coming down to Boston this weekend and we were looking at what to do. My son loves science, thought, of course we would go to the Museum of Science until...got stopped in my tracks by your cadaver exhibit. I remember well hearing about the awful ways the bodies were ill-begotten....some may well be executed Chinese political prisoners. All too awful for words. Cadavers coming from China should, period, never ever be an exhibit in any museum. For that matter, human cadavers should never be an exhibit, but especially with unknown sources and no clear paper-trail. So, needless to say, we will not be visiting and will encourage others to do the same. A shame really."

"I have noticed that on your billboard on I-90 and on your website, the Life Cycle exhibit that is returning depicts bodies with white skin. The exhibit aims to realistically show us what’s under our skin, but that skin is quite clearly white. You have an opportunity to scientifically approach the reality of black skin and of people of color. I am disappointed at this lost opportunity to educate given the scale and popularity of the exhibit. Choices matter. I have been a Premier 8 member for many years, and I’d like my commitment to science to be reflected in balanced scientific inquiry, and the thoughtful consideration of the existence, and impact of implicit bias in our daily lives."

"Our family has been long time members of the MoS.  I am writing to share a concern about the Body Worlds exhibit.  I appreciate the educational aspect. However, Gunther von Hagens has faced significant controversy over how he sources the bodies.  Although he claims to have certificates from where he sourced them, common sense tells you that if you follow the chain of custody all the way back to the person it is highly likely that these people were political prisoners."

"Greetings! I recently came across National Geographic's Planet or Plastic? exhibit, which is currently in the beginning stages of seeking hosts and putting its tour schedule together. I think the Museum would be an excellent place to bring the exhibit. You have a clear and vested interest in ecological matters and would be able to easily tie it in with ongoing exhibitions throughout the Green Wing. Additionally, a facility that literally sits on the water is the perfect location to highlight this particular issue. 
I don't know what the logistics and funding would look like, obviously, but if it is feasible for you, I would really recommend considering adding this to your rotating schedule.”

"I used to live in Boston, 2011-2012. I took the small child I cared for there many times. Came back to visit and bring my 6 yr old. Prices have increased a lot, but I didn’t t go to one single exhibit or wing that didn’t have multiple things broken. The place was so run down and completely disappointing. I will NEVER recommend this attraction to anyone!"

"I felt compelled to write only because as a frequent visitor, I was unhappy with the rudeness of one of your staff members today. We go about weekly, but definitely twice per month and usually have very pleasant interactions. Today, that wasn't the case when We went for lunch. We eat there about 60% of the time we visit.. My Kids love eating the dino nuggets lol. This is where the trouble began. I got the nuggets with fries and a drink And a personal plain cheese pizza. The total came to 16 something.. Which I thought was high but I may have miscalculated. I asked if she billed everything separately because I had seen a sign stating there was a value meal. They didn't answer and repeated the total. I just paid.. Not that serious. then I'm trying to find a seat when a line of school children passed by bumping me and knocking my pizza and half the fries to the floor. I tried to pick up the pizza but I had my 4 year old and the tray and 2 bags... There was chaos. I asked the very same staff member if I could grab another one pointing to the pizza on the floor and they said no. That I need to be careful. I'm so disappointed in that answer. We ended up just leaving with the nuggets and salvaged fries and went to the playground instead. I just hope that the staff member was just having a bad day and isn't always so unhelpful and insensitive."

"I am disappointed that i was not able to find anything substantive about climate change in your museum.  The most important science issue that young people need to know about is climate change and how it will soon influence everything in their lives.  Perhaps you are not serious about teaching science to these kids and merely wish to entertain them.  Or perhaps you don't wish to annoy supporters in the fossil fuel industry.  Either way, i  expected  better."

"Although the discovery area is great, the visiting exhibits for young children were especially good this past winter!  We like the Dora one better than the Wild Kratz one, but having something special (that changes) that is age appropriate for young children really solves a pain point for Boston area residents who are looking for an overall experience that is friendly for adults and young children."

"Our family has been long time members of the MoS.  I am writing to share a concern about the Body Worlds exhibit.  I appreciate the educational aspect. However, Gunther von Hagens has faced significant controversy over how he sources the bodies.  Although he claims to have certificates from where he sourced them, common sense tells you that if you follow the chain of custody all the way back to the person it is highly likely that these people were political prisoners.

"Please bring back Mirror Maze"

"Love birds world, however shadow puppets no longer lit properly in new location - cannot make out shapes of birds - have low vision need more contrast thanks."	

"The ropes in front of the cafeteria cashiers are hard to use."

"I am disappointed that there is almost NOTHING on climate change! These children lives will be profoundly influenced by climate change - yet NOTHING! Not science - just entertainment. Do you get funding from the fossil fuel industry?"

"For Red Sox weekend, will you have the demonstration of Bernoulli & ball flight, it was cool in the Science of Sports exhibit. Would love to see it again on Red Sox weekend. There was a plastic golf, baseball football & a tennis model that was put into a jet of air & we got to try it out for ourselves."

"A fan of the Omni Theater and laser shows, I'm merely throwing out a suggestion: Early Genesis laser show. (Early Genesis = 1970-1975, The Gabriel Years, or a mix of Prog bands: i.e. Genesis, Yes, Pink Floyd, ELP, etc. ). I know you've had success with the Pink Floyd laser shows so, I thought I'd throw it out there.
I know I'd go!
Thanks for listening!" 

"Hi, I'm trying to see your web address for the Body Worlds and I can't see anything at https://mos.org/exhibits/body-worlds from 3 different browsers on my Apple computer. What gives?"

"I didn't appreciate the imagery + wording used at the end of Body Worlds to describe obesity. It felt very fat-shaming in a really regressive way."

"I was disappointed on a recent visit to the Suit/Cabot lab.  I visited the museum last Tuesday midday.  When I got to the lab with my kids, there was only one staff member who clearly did not want to be there.  They stood in the middle of the room, greeted us, but did not engage with the kids at all. Further, I was one adult with multiple kids, and I think it was clear I could have used help in explaining things to multiple kids of different ages. In the past, staff have engaged with my kids and explained things to them.  Other times, staff have even gone so far as to help my almost 4 year old daughter use a pippette  and look through the microscope.  
I was extremely disappointed.  I hope they were just having an off day."

docs.messageSubject: Upgrade of Tessitura TEST to v15 Tomorrow 7/16
docs.messageBody:
Information Technology will commence upgrading our Tessitura TEST environment tomorrow at 11am.  

Our goal is to upgrade to v15.1.  This process requires we move to v15 first, and then upgrade to v15.1.  Depending in the time it takes to perform both upgrades, we will assess the feasibility of doing this for QA and Live.  Please be advised that this process may take several hours, and we will need to test and verify v15 before moving to v15.1.

IT will send an email once TEST is upgraded along with the decision regarding v15.1.

Please feel free to reach out to Amy Gallant at agallant@mos.org or x0131 with any questions.

Over the course of July and August, Information Technology will be completely replacing our wireless network.  The goal of this project is to provide Museum employees, partners and visitors easy, anywhere, anytime access to wireless network resources and have a reliable connection wherever they are in the building. It will be a brand-new experience for wireless at the Museum!

This upgrade is necessary to improve performance and expand wireless coverage Museum-wide. It also enables us to achieve and maintain Payment Card Industry (PCI) security standards and requirements that are necessary to process credit card transactions, as throughout this process we will be replacing end-of-life, legacy equipment.

What Does This Mean?
Existing equipment will be replaced in phases by brand new wireless access points, starting with the Boston side of the building (Red & Green wing) and working our way through the Museum to the Cambridge side (Blue wing, Engineers Enclave & Gordon Wing). This staggered implementation schedule will help ensure that installation is as minimally disruptive as possible. Prior to beginning installation in any area of the building, we will be discussing the process with affected parties.

We will have a vendor on site performing access point installation, running new cables and mounting equipment. Old equipment will be removed as the new devices are installed and our new wireless networks go live.

What Can I Expect When This Takes Effect?
Cabling and access point installation will officially start the week of July 29th. We will have our cabling vendor in prior to business opening to complete access point installation in public-facing areas of the building (i.e. Box Office, Omni, Planetarium, Butterfly Garden, etc.) and continuing throughout the day in office spaces. Each phase of implementation will be validated upon completion prior to moving onto the next section of the building. 

New wireless networks will replace our existing MoS network names as we create new networks for our unique use cases. Staff credentials to join the wireless will remain the same (your Active Directory credentials).  

For a brief period of time, until the installation is complete, there will be dual wireless network presences with our legacy network and new wireless, but this will not impact your ability to connect or travel throughout the museum with mobile devices.

What Do I Need To Do?
Staff are not required to do anything during implementation.  Once we do the final cut over, staff will need to rejoin the new wireless network once per device. 

As always, if you have any questions or issues, please reach out to me or contact our service desk, System Support Services, at ithelp@mos.org or call x0130.

From: Allison Curtis <acurtis@mos.org> 
Sent: Monday, July 8, 2019 1:28 PM
To: everyone@mos.org
Subject: Service Now Go Live Happening July 17th

Hello all, 

We are implementing a new customer service portal that centralizes requests for IT, Facilities, C&W, CRM Systems and Exhibit Maintenance (Please note that event request for Ex.Main will still be on the Hub’s Need Sheet.)  This new system, Service Now, will allow us to retire the legacy Track It application and replace it with more flexible and integrated work order environment.  

We will be going live on Wed. July 17th.   

The time line for this roll out will be: 
On Tuesday, July 16th, the current Track-it Work Order System will be taken offline.  Any new request that you need to submit that day can be emailed to ithelp@mos.org and the Service Desk will assure that a ticket is entered for you in the new system.  All active work orders will also be migrated to the new system.  
The new portal will be available to you starting the morning of Wednesday, July 17th at https://museumofscience.service-now.com/.    Please do not put tickets into the new system until the 17th.
You will sign in with your museum user name and password.  The links on the Hub will also be updated for easy navigation and access.

Service Now is accessible 24-7 from anywhere with an Internet connection and works across all operating systems and multiple browsers. 

After the roll-out, there will be continued growth and improvement in the platform as we get feedback and are able to implement additional functionality.  The platform has many features that we look to implementing in the future including an extensive, searchable Knowledge Base and giving more tools to the technicians, like location updates, to streamline requests and needs for the museum. 

*Information and Support Sessions
There will be 3 user drop in sessions to learn more about Service Now. 

DATE	TIME	LOCATION
Thursday, July 11th 	1pm-2pm 	Engineers Enclave
Monday, July 15th 	11am-12pm  	Engineers Enclave
Wednesday, July 17th 	1pm- 2pm   	Hodge

If you cannot make one of the three sessions but would still like a training session or if you have any questions or comments, please email SNAdminTeam@mos.org.

We’re very excited about rolling out this customer service platform and look forward to your feedback. 


Allison Curtis, PMP
IIT Ops and Project Manager
Museum of Science
1 Science Park 
Boston, MA 02114
acurtis@mos.org

docs.messageSubject: Help the Forum team track the heat this weekend!
docs.messageBody:
Hi all,
 
As I am sure you’ve been hearing, it’s supposed to be very hot this weekend!  The Forum team is launching a citizen science project on extreme heat in collaboration with the City of Boston, the City of Cambridge and the Town of Brookline.  You can read some of the details here: https://www.mapc.org/planning101/wicked-hot-boston-documenting-extreme-heat-in-the-greater-boston-area/?fbclid=IwAR0-MZqUYzGWY3ahRyR2xTwPqWU_KMJEn31alEUipMjSqh9_mUlnaDXWi_w and here: http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/citizen-science-salon/2019/06/28/wicked-hot-boston-how-can-you-help-beat-extreme-heat/.   
 
There are two ways you can help us this weekend:

1. Over the next few weeks, we’ll be going out into neighborhoods around these communities and mapping heat islands with special thermometers mounted on cars to find out where the hottest spots are located.  While we’re not quite at the point where we’ll be doing this with the general public yet, we are going to do some pilot testing on Saturday, and would love folks to join us!  The protocol involves driving around areas for an hour at 6 AM, 3 PM, and 7 PM.  You don’t have a car or a license to participate.  We’ve created a number of GSE’s for this Saturday 7/20 for various parts of the day because we’ll need help navigating and taking photos and observations while we’re traveling around, and would love for you to join us.  We’ll give you a brief training and then you’ll head out with us to test out our sensors and routes.  So please sign up on the Hub or just reach out if you’d like to help us and we’ll follow up with more details!
 
2. Also, we’re hoping people can also go out and take pictures and make observations of how you’re all  experiencing the heatwave using an app called ISeeChange from wherever you are!.  For information on that, please go to our SciStarter project portal here: https://scistarter.org/noaa, register for an account, and start sharing your observations on ISeeChange!  This is something that everyone can do, so please spread the word to friends and family no matter where they might be.
 
Thanks – if you have questions, please email me, Katie Baur, or Sara Benson and we’d love to answer them.  Stay cool this weekend!

David

Summary After performing a year-end analysis of benefits costs versus salaries, we are changing the benefit rates in the payroll system for FY20. New Rates The new rates are: • Executive Rate: 16% (unchanged) • Full-time: 24% (was 25%) • Part-time: 23% (was 19%) • 430(B) Only: 11.5% (was 9%) Budget Impact We will NOT be changing the approved FY20 department budgets to reflect the new rates – too complicated to do this late in the budget-loading process. As the year goes on, we will be mindful of instances where the new rates cause a department to go over budget through no fault of its own. This should only happen in departments that are part-time-heavy – most departments should, if anything, experience slight budget savings from the change. Grant Impact We will be updating the official GPC budget template to reflect the new rates, though this may take a while thanks to Audit. For anyone with a grant proposal already in the works, Christa and Lindsay will fix the budgets by hand. If you start a new proposal before the template is updated, let me or Lindsay know and we will fix your copy of the template and send it back to you. Because of this change in rates, please discard all old blank templates you may have saved on your computer or network share. Once it’s updated, the official one on the Hub GPC page will be the only valid version.

The Education Associate I will research, develop and present programs to Museum and community audiences that contain accurate and relevant science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) principles and concepts in a way that both educates and inspires further interest and curiosity for participants. The programs will be based on current STEM topics and support school curriculum standards as appropriate to enhance formal learning experiences. docs.messageSubject: Last Day to Pick Up Member Cards
docs.messageBody:
[Update] Today is the last day for all benefits eligible staff to pick up their new Museum of Science member cards from the Membership office space (Blue Wing, Lower Level, along the ramp to the garage). 

Card for non-benefits eligible staff have not been printed in this batch, as HR is still working on compiling the list of non-benefits eligible staff that qualify for memberships. (Non-benefits eligible staff must work at least 95 hours and consistently for 6 months to receive a membership.) 

Cards are sorted alphabetically by first name. We ask that you please initial next to applicable names on the sign out sheet when you pick up your card and/or cards for anyone else in your department. 

Any cards that are not picked up by Today (Wednesday, July 31) will be mailed Thursday, August 1. 

On behalf of the Membership Department, thank you for all that you do for the Museum!

docs.messageSubject: Help needed! Panelists for College Intern Panel on August 1st
docs.messageBody:
Hi all! My name is Emily Carlson and I’m a Workforce Development Program Intern with School & Youth Programs. We are planning to host a College Panel where panelists share their college experiences and answer questions from around 20 Summer Youth Interns. The panel is informal and is a fun way for the high school Summer Youth Interns to find out information about not only the college application process, but also the transition from high school to college life. 

The College Panels are taking place on:
•	Wednesday, July 31st, from 11:30 AM – 12:30 PM (all spots full!)
•	Thursday, August 1st, from 3:30 PM – 4:30 PM (need panelists!)

We need at lease two more people to participate on the panel on Thursday, August 1st! If you are interested in participating, please fill out this Google Form (https://tinyurl.com/MOSCollegePanel2019) with your availability and information. 

If you have any questions, please do not hesitate to email myself or Meghan Carter ( (617) 589-0310 | mcarter@mos.org)!

Best,
Emily Carlson (ecarlson@mos.org)

The wireless installation is underway and we’ve made significant progress in getting the new equipment and cabling installed in the Red Wing. We have been starting every day well before open to make sure the bulk of the work is done with minimal impact to staff and guests. We are live in the Planetarium, soon to complete all levels of the Omni Theater and should finish the Red Wing installation this week. 

What Does This Mean?
If you’re in range of one of our new access points, you’ll be able to connect to the new wireless networks:
•	Staff@MoS – staff access to wireless network & Internet, login information has not changed. 
•	Public@MoS – guest access to the Internet, splash screen to connect. Same as our existing public with a slightly new look.
As the installation progresses there will be updates on coverage zones for everyone, while we work directly with the people in the areas in which we’re currently working.

What Do I Need To Do?
Almost nothing. Once you’ve joined the new SSIDs your devices will automatically switch to what’s available as you move through the building. While the install is underway there will be a dual presence of both our legacy wireless networks and our new wireless networks, but this should not impact your ability to connect to or use either.

As always, if you have any questions or issues, please contact our service desk, System Support Services, at ithelp@mos.org or call x0130.

Thanks,
Rae

Fundraising Events Associate Director

The Associate Director assists the Fundraising Events team in creating, developing, implementing and executing all revenue-generating events within the Advancement Division, to include but not limited to the gala, the Boston Marathon, dinners, third party and cause marketing opportunities. This position will report to the Director of Fundraising Events and assist with the sponsorships, as well as the Fundraising Events & Hosts Committees in helping to empower those members to serve as ambassadors for all events. These activities often serve as focal points for future donors' early perception of the Museum and will be crucial as Advancement works to grow its donor base. This position will support the Director of Fundraising Events in increasing revenue and growing events as well as work in close collaboration with other departments in the Museum.

Deadline for Internal Applicants: 8/14/19

In preparation for major renovation work on the first floor of the Blue Wing, a number of exhibits have been moved or given away.  The Bison diorama has been moved to Museum Then and Now.  The Fog Tornado was moved to the second floor of the Blue Wing near the restrooms.  Several components and exhibit cases have gone to other organizations.

Update: As of 10am 8/13, we have 4 Thinkpad T530s left and 2 mac minis.  We also have some Free 19 to 20" LCDs left.

On Tuesday Aug 13th-- IT is having a yardsale of older equipment that is in good shape.  If you have questions prior, please email me otherwise everything will be ready on Tuesday morning.  Anytime after 8am is ok on Tuesday.  I am in a new office near the kitchen on the 3rd floor in IT.

There will be some PC laptops for sale as well as a some Mac computers.  Everything is in working condition but for laptops, battery life is not guaranteed.   The desktops for sale also do not come with peripherals.  The price ranges are from $75 to $125 depending on specs.  You can pay either by cash or check payable to Museum of Science.  All purchases must leave the museum property.   

If you are looking for a PC desktop, let me know. 

We also have a few older 17" to 20" LCDs that can be taken home.  If you are interested in an LCD, please let me know.

All,

Please be advised that IIT will be performing a planned network maintenance on the following date and time:

Tuesday August 13th  2019 from 6:00pm to 11:59pm
 
This maintenance is necessary to perform upgrades to our network infrastructure.  We anticipate this scheduled outage will take approximately 4 to 6 hrs. to complete.  During this maintenance window you may experience brief outages where servers, business applications, and or files may not be accessible both internally and externally.  To ensure uptime and stability of our platform, we are performing this upgrade shortly after close of business so we can maximize our 
efforts to ensure business operations will not be impacted when we open the next day.  

If you have any questions or concerns please contact the Service Desk team at x0130.  

We thank you in advance for your attention and understanding.

The wireless installation is complete in the Red Wing! We have begun moving onto the next closet that covers the basement and first floor of the Green Wing, including the Café. 

What Does This Mean?
We will be working in these areas either early in the morning prior to opening with our vendor, pulling new cables and mounting access points for our new wireless network. A lot of the work will be in the hallways and along the cable pathway to get wiring in place from our network closet to the wireless access point locations. Some of the work will be in office spaces and exhibits to mount them to ceilings and walls as necessary. We will be working to make sure we are out of public facing spaces before Museum open and minimize disruption to your everyday work life. We also have detailed floor plans of access point locations if you need further clarification on installation areas. Once the access point is mounted, any cabling materials will be cleared out and we will move onto the next location. 

What Is the Timeline?
•	Week of 8/12: Continuing installation through corridor, loading dock, café, and Green Wing.
•	Week of 8/19: Continuing if necessary, otherwise starting work in the next closet (2nd floor, Boston Side).

What Do I Need To Do?
Basically nothing. But if you have a scheduling issue and there is a day it would be highly inconvenient for our cabling team to be in your area, please let us know so we can work around your schedule. We will be coordinating with each department to minimize disruption and schedule access.

Our service desk team will be available to help users join the new wireless networks, and as you move through the Museum your connection should not be interrupted as both networks will be available until the installation is completed for the entire building.

As always, if you have any questions or issues, please contact our service desk, System Support Services, at ithelp@mos.org or call x0130.

docs.messageBody:
Internal Job Postings

Paid staff positions will be posted internally for five (5) business days to give internal applicants priority during the recruitment process, in support of the Museum’s Affirmative Action Plan. At this time, the below listings are actively accepting internal applications:

Advancement Database Associate

The Advancement Database Associate is a vital part of the Advancement Office and the Data Management Services Team. The primary responsibility of this position is to ensure that Advancement constituent records conform to the Museum's data standards and are up-to-date in regards to the fundraising pipeline. To that end, this position oversees the timely and accurate processing of the office contact reports, visits, stage movements, and other donor interactions, reviews new records, audits changes to existing records, and monitors and corrects data errors via daily exception reports in the Tessitura database. Additionally, this position is responsible for pulling regular and ad-hoc communication lists, reports for development officers, auditing central CRM data, and helping the office hold itself accountable with standard KPI's. The Advancement Database Associate acts as a lead for Advancement department Coordinator positions in regards to CRM entry, accountability, and problem solving. This position reports directly to the Manager, Data Management Services but also has daily and frequent contact with Advancement's 40+ staff.

Deadline for Internal Applicants: 8/16/19

Hello Everyone,

The cross divisional MOScars Team is looking to recruit new members! The MOScars Team is made up of enthusiastic Museum employees, responsible and interested in providing a long standing Reward and Recognition program for our wonderful staff.

Team member responsibilities are:

  • Attend a monthly meeting regarding the MOScars Program. These meetings aim to discuss the program, and how we can move our recognition program forward.
  • Work as a team to creatively plan, prepare, and execute the MOScars event held in January. This event is a show that includes planning entertainment, special rewards, food, and gifts. This planning requires additional meetings in the fall/winter.

Right now we are seeking members from the following divisions:

  • Advancement
  • Marketing & External Affairs
  • Exhibits Development & Conservation
  • Education & Enrichment Programs
  • Finance & System Services

(If your division is no listed we already have a team member J)

Deadline for Internal Applicants: August 26, 2019

This position is on call, with shifts during day, night and weekends.

The wireless project is speeding along all things considered, we’ve got a lot of ground covered so far: Red Wing complete, Green Wing (exhibits & basement) complete, and 3rd floor complete as of this morning (45% of our installation is complete). We are very close to finishing the Boston side of the Museum!

What Does This Mean?
We will be working in these areas either early in the morning prior to opening with our vendor, pulling new cables and mounting access points for our new wireless network. A lot of the work will be in the hallways and along the cable pathway to get wiring in place from our network closet to the wireless access point locations. Some of the work will be in office spaces and exhibits to mount them to ceilings and walls as necessary. We will be working to make sure we are out of public facing spaces before Museum open and minimize disruption to your everyday work life. We also have detailed floor plans of access point locations if you need further clarification on installation areas. Once the access point is mounted, any cabling materials will be cleared out and we will move onto the next location. 
 
What Is the Timeline?
•	Start roughing in the 4th floor cabling today (8/20).
•	Work on Body Worlds (2nd floor) tomorrow (8/21).
•	Complete 2nd and 4th floor AP installation Thursday-Friday.
•	We may start on 6th floor this week, depending on how quickly we can progress through some of the trickier office spaces.
 
What Do I Need To Do?
Basically nothing. But if you have a scheduling issue and there is a day it would be highly inconvenient for our cabling team to be in your area, please let us know so we can work around your schedule. We will be coordinating with each department to minimize disruption and schedule access.
 
Our service desk team will be available to help users join the new wireless networks (Staff@MoS, Public@MoS, etc.), and as you move through the Museum your connection should not be interrupted as both networks will be available until the installation is completed for the entire building.
 
As always, if you have any questions or issues, please contact our service desk, System Support Services, at ithelp@mos.org or call x0130.
 
Thanks,
Rae

docs.messageSubject: Internal Job Listing: Education Associate I, Early Childhood Education
docs.messageBody:
Internal Job Postings

Paid staff positions will be posted internally for five (5) business days to give internal applicants priority during the recruitment process, in support of the Museum’s Affirmative Action Plan. All positions accepting internal applications can be found on our Internal Employment Opportunities page.

At this time, the below listings are actively accepting internal applications:

Education Associate I, Early Childhood Education

The Early Childhood Education group oversees the operations of the Discovery Center (an intensely staffed discovery space), as well as drop-in programs in designated exhibit hall venues, in order to introduce the museum's youngest constituents to STEM content and support the development of science and engineering process skills in early childhood. Our activities engage families, preschool and early elementary school students and teachers, and general museum audiences in hands-on, inquiry based activities that span the STEM disciplines (e.g., biology, chemistry, engineering design, math, and psychology). The Early Childhood Education Associate will facilitate programs in a variety of formats (e.g., one-on-few interpretations, workshop-style programs and stage-based presentations), with a focus on the early development of STEM process skills. The Early Childhood Education Associate will help maintain materials and spaces, and assist with the ongoing professional development for part-time staff and volunteers - developing and delivering briefings and trainings, and developing innovative experiences for the museum's early childhood audiences.

Deadline for Internal Applicants: August 27, 2019

This position is full-time, 40 hours/week, either Sunday-Thursday or Tuesday-Saturday (1 weekend day required).

docs.messageSubject: Touch a Moon Rock TODAY with Jerry DeSilva
docs.messageBody:
Here's your chance to touch a piece of the moon!

Today only at 2:30, our Afternoon Report "To the Moon and Back", will feature a touchable lunar meteorite. Come see the show, or stop by at 2:50 to see the meteorite up close!

This opportunity comes to us via Jerry DeSilva, Dartmouth anthropology professor and friend of the museum. He will also be giving a talk at 1:45 about Little Foot, a human ancestor fossil from over 2 million years ago that has helped shape our understanding of human evolution.

Internal Job Postings

Paid staff positions will be posted internally for five (5) business days to give internal applicants priority during the recruitment process, in support of the Museum’s Affirmative Action Plan. All positions accepting internal applications can be found on our Internal Employment Opportunities page.

Welcome Representative

The Guest Welcome Representative helps Museum of Science visitors begin their visits smoothly and efficiently, greeting guests upon arrival, assisting visitors as they navigate the ticketing and admission process, supporting guests in taking advantage of self-service ticketing options, and providing visit planning and Museum information.

Deadline for Internal Applicants: August 28, 2019

This position is part-time, 4 hrs/week, Sundays from 11:00am-3:00pm.

Want to be a part of an exciting community event in Roxbury?  The Museum of Science is beginning an amazing relationship with the Dimock Center in Roxbury MA and we need you to kick it off right!  

Dimock is a community pillar that has been nationally recognized for providing integrated, high-quality healthcare and human services in an urban community.  The Museum is dedicated to fostering a relationship with them and we are starting by volunteering to help with their Road to Wellness fundraiser.  This is a 5K Walk/Run and festival on the morning of Saturday Sept 7.  

We are looking for museum staff to sign up for a GSE and join our volunteer team- we'll help with set-up, registration, course support, and cheerleading! We start at 6:45 am- you can either take public transportation or meet at the Museum to carpool over.  They take over all of Roxbury, so parking will be limited.  If you don't normally work Saturdays, you can still participate with your manager's permission.

This is a high energy event in an amazing community- Come be a part of it!!

If you have any questions please call or email me at x0105 or sheilman@mos.org

Member cards for all non-benefits eligible staff are now ready for pick up in the Membership office space (Blue Wing, Lower Level, along the ramp to the garage).

Non-benefits eligible staff must work at least 95 hours and consistently for 6 months in order to receive a membership. 

Any cards that are not picked up by Tuesday, August 27 will be mailed Wednesday, August 28. 

On behalf of the Membership Department, thank you for all that you do for the Museum!

docs.messageSubject: Reminder - MOScars Team - Recruiting New Members!
docs.messageBody:
Hello Everyone,

The cross divisional MOScars Team is looking to recruit new members! The MOScars Team is made up of enthusiastic Museum employees, responsible and interested in providing a long standing Reward and Recognition program for our wonderful staff.

Team member responsibilities are:

  • Attend a monthly meeting regarding the MOScars Program. These meetings aim to discuss the program, and how we can move our recognition program forward.
  • Work as a team to creatively plan, prepare, and execute the MOScars event held in January. This event is a show that includes planning entertainment, special rewards, food, and gifts. This planning requires additional meetings in the fall/winter.

Right now we are seeking members from the following divisions:

  • Advancement
  • Marketing & External Affairs
  • Exhibits Development & Conservation
  • Education & Enrichment Programs
  • Finance & System Services

(If your division is no listed we already have a team member J)

If you are interested and excited about joining the MOScars Team, please check with your supervisor to see that you would be able to make this time commitment. Then email us at moscars@mos.org.

 

Thank you in advance for your interest! We will be reaching out to new team members in late August.

 

*Please note, we will not be able to take all entries as we need 1 person per division.*

Traveling Programs is looking for some foam play mat material for whacking PVC pipes and making cool sounds.  Does anybody have any of this material they could donate, perhaps from when their kids were younger?  I need probably 1 - 2 square feet.  This is the sort of thing we want (I could order it from here but it comes in larger quantities than I need): https://www.rubberflooringinc.com/interlocking-tile/foam/rainbow-play-mats.html

docs.messageSubject: Are you ready for SAFETY DAY Sept. 25 10AM-1PM
docs.messageBody:
ARE YOU READY for  Safety Day? Wed Sept 25 from 10:00 AM to 1:00 PM in the Engineers Enclave

You are invited to:

  • Browse the safety tables – learn something new from your colleagues,
  • Have some coffee/tea and a snack,  or
  • Compete for the Golden Safety Goggles!

The Safety Committee will have 5 Safety Stations to challenge YOUR TEAM’s safety knowledge– You will be scored on accuracy, speed and creativity.

Stations Include: (1) Injury Prevention is our No. 1 Intention! (2) It’s a Match (3) Safe Selfies (4) Mystery Box (5) Safety First! – It’s Personal

Form your Teams of  2-4 people and come show us just how SAFE you can be!

Will your Team take home the Golden Safety Goggles or the Band-Aids for boo-boos?

Sign your team up now!! https://www.signupgenius.com/go/60b0f4caaa62da3f94-safety

Earn BONUS POINTS:

  • CREATE a fun team name
  • RECRUIT multi-department teammates
  • WEAR themed or matching outfits

You don’t have to compete to ENJOY Safety Day!  ….

Stop by anytime between 10am-1pm to LEARN About:

  • Yard Safety – taking care not to harm yourself or the delicate ecosystem around you
  • Keeping our lakes and streams clean and safe
  • Bicycle Safety – Learn and Spin the wheel of chance for a Free Blue Bikes Membership
  • And so much More … handouts, posters, brochures on Keeping you Safe in the yard, at home and abroad.


Look forward to seeing you there,

Safety Committee

 

FY2020 Safety Committee Members – Representing YOU and Keeping the Museum Safer!

Public Safety -Ryan Campbell, Human Resources- Lorah Broderick/Hayley Ienello, Facilities-Jena Boehm, EH&S Program Manager -Christina Dillard, Traveling Programs/Live Presentations-Mike Adams, Exhibits Project Mgmt. & Production-Greg Murray, Exhibit Maintenance-Mathew Leclerc, IIT -Allie Curtis, Event & Conference Services-Lisa Cigna, Living Collections-Jackie Peeler, and Planetarium-Heather Fairweather  

Learn More about the Museum’s Safety Program at: https://bmos.sharepoint.com/SitePages/Environmental%20Health%20and%20Safety.aspx

docs.messageSubject: Help us test a new forum on Substance Use Disorder - 1/2 Day GSEs Posted!
docs.messageBody:
1/2 Day GSE's Available!

Have you been hearing about forums and haven't had a chance to attend? Are you interested in learning more about substance use disorder? Do you want to experience being a part of a fun and educational focus group led by our very own R&E team? 

Join us on Wed. Sept. 11 from 1 - 4pm to test out a brand new forum we are creating in collaboration with Tufts Clinical and Translational Science Institute! The focus of the forum is to build a community of resilience around substance use disorder. You do not need to know anything about the topic to participate. We only need folks who are willing to have an engaging, facilitated discussion in small groups and who don't mind giving us constructive feedback at the end.

Sign up here! https://bmos.sharepoint.com/sites/hr-service-signups/SitePages/App.aspx?r=0&gseScheduleID=5564

Please email ehostetler@mos.org if you have any questions.

Emily Hostetler
Forum Education Associate II

docs.messageSubject: You're Invited: Teen Research Project Shareout!
docs.messageBody:
The Living Laboratory team has been supporting a program this summer called the Teen Science Research and Communication Program (TSRCP), which engages teen staff in science research and communication training. Over the course of the summer, the teens have been running child development research in the Discovery Center, demoing completed research with families, developing materials to be shared with the museum and academic communities, and learning about best practices in science communication.

The teens will be sharing out on some of their projects today, Wednesday August 28th, and you are invited to come explore their work! Program participants will be in Engineers Enclave between 2:30 and 4 PM presenting the research posters they have developed, and demoing child development research studies that they interpret with families. The event is drop in, and we will have snacks while they last ☺

Feel free to stop by at any time, and share with anyone you think may be interested!

Thanks, Rachel

docs.messageSubject: Updates for Discovery Center, Engineering Design Workshop and Astronomy After Hours program times and location
docs.messageBody:
Updates for Discovery Center, Engineering Design Workshop and Astronomy After Hours Program times and locations as of September 1, 2019.
 
Please note that the following programs will have a new schedule or location.

Discovery Center will be open 10am – 4:45pm daily.  We will continue to adjust the programming schedule to best meet the needs of the Friday evening audiences including an additional shift of Engineering Design Workshop beginning December.

Engineering Design Workshop, as of September 4, will be relocated to the Blue Wing Lower Level with regularly scheduled programming.

Astronomy After Hours will be offered from 8pm – 10pm on Friday evenings in September and October, 2019.  Hands-on activities will be available in the Engineering Enclave and (weather permitting) telescope viewing on the front plaza. Please note that the Gilliland Observatory on the garage rooftop will be closed on these evenings.

The wireless installation for the entire Boston side of the Museum has been completed. The Red & Green Wings, and Pavilion are all 100% on the new wireless network; as are all office spaces and event spaces basement level through the 6th floor.  The new wireless networks are up and running and you should be able to join with your regular network credentials.

This morning we officially hit 72% completion for the entire Museum! We have started installation in the Blue Wing and are 1/3 of the way through the exhibit spaces. The Box Office and 4D theater are live on the new network, and the entire 1st floor of the Blue Wing is complete as well.  

We will be moving along to the area served out of the Engineer’s Enclave network closet and then eventually the Gordon Wing once the work in the Blue Wing is complete. We are in the home stretch, and will be continuing cabling work over the upcoming Museum closure.

Thank you everyone for your patience and cooperation during this project.

-Rae

Blue Bikes Raffle!

  

The Wellness Team is raffling off 5 annual Blue Bikes memberships!

 Blue Bikes are great to use for commuting, recreation, or exercising on your lunch break! An annual membership provides your first 30 minutes free and unlimited rides. For more information on how Blue Bikes work please visit, https://www.thehubway.com/.

 

To enter the raffle CLICK HERE!

 

Raffle will remain open until Friday, September 13th. Winners will be contacted by Hayley Ienello.

Rules: Only 1 entry per employee. Winners will be given a code for their free membership. Free membership is good for 365 days from sign up update. Annual membership starts when official enrollment is placed with Blue Bikes.

 

Don’t forget – All Museum staff are entitled to a discounted annual membership rate. If you are interested in this benefit please reach out to Hayley Ienello.

*Did you know the Museum has their very own group of bike enthusiasts? This group is led by Ryan Auster, Peter Ford, and Megan Gregory. If you would like to be added to their “email list of MOSers sorta interested in bike-things” please reach out to Ryan Auster.

docs.messageSubject: Come get your groove on! GSE's available at the Innovators Body Rock on September 5
docs.messageBody:
Don't miss your chance to attend Body Rock while earning GSE credit!
 
Participate in our silent rave (which will involve wearing headphones while dancing to music that only you can hear!) Our goal is to pique interest in this activity by planting a small group of dancers. 

Please note that no one will be required to rock til they drop! You are encouraged to take breaks as necessary and explore the space.

As the evening progresses, you may be asked to demo other activities throughout the event.

This GSE will take place on the Pavilion on September 5, 6:00-9:30 p.m.
Event details can be viewed at http://give.mos.org/bodyrock

Saturday is Polymer Day! Come by the CS&T Stage at 11:00 to hear from researchers at UMass Amhert's Polymer Engineering Lab, and try out some hands-on materials activities!

At 3:30 Saturday, we have another speaker in our Body Worlds lecture series. Dr. Stephanie Maddox from McLean Hospital will be talking about how our experiences physically change our bodies and brains.

I'm writing this letter to the entire staff at the Museum of Science to inform everyone my last day of work is 8/30/19. While I am happy to get leisure time with my family. I willd deeply miss my work and colleagues.

During my 25 years at the Museum.I progressed in my professional and personal life.I I thank each one of you for your support, guidance and assistance. The friendship and associations I made here will remain forever.

I wish you all and this Museum a bright future and thank each one of you once again.


It will be a pleasure to be in touch.



Goodbye

Steve
