Curriculum Coordinator, Engineering is Elementary

Cross functionally collaborates with the Engineering and Computer Science Product Development teams to support day-to-day editorial and production processes, and assist operationally with logistics such as conferences. Tasks include but are not limited to: communicating regularly and effectively with cross-functional teams; tracking user reach outs, and maintaining inventories of materials and supplies by sourcing and tracking both; collaborating with teams to ensure appropriate materials are allocated for and shipped to pilot sites.

Deadline for Internal Applicants: September 6, 2019

This position is grant-funded, full-time, 40 hours/week, Monday-Friday.

docs.messageSubject: Planned Out of Band Network Maintenance on Staff Appreciation Day 9-3-19
docs.messageBody:
All,

Please be advised that IIT will be performing a planned out of band network maintenance on the following date and time:

Tuesday September 3rd , 2019 from 5am to 8:00pm 

This maintenance is necessary to perform upgrades to our network infrastructure.  We anticipate this scheduled outage will take approximately 6 to 8 hrs. to complete.  During this maintenance window you may experience brief outages where servers, business applications, and or files may not be accessible both internally and externally.  To ensure uptime and stability of our platform, we are performing this upgrade shortly after close of business so we can maximize our efforts to ensure business operations will not be impacted when we open the next day.  

If you have any questions or concerns please contact the SD team at x0130.  

We thank you in advance for your attention and understanding.

docs.messageSubject: shelves from the Educator Resource Center
docs.messageBody: We are removing 2 wooden bookshelves and one metal bookshelf - please get in touch with Meredith Mahoney x3171.

August 2019 Comment Card Report

"1. Interesting talk on climate change but words too big for kids.
2. suggest a speaker instead of the telephones. too many germs & need volume control so 2 kids can listen at once"

"I was a member 10 years ago when my daughter was young, was always fun. After a 10 year hiatus I decided to take my 11 year old nephew to the museum for his first time. I have to say I am shocked to see such open unused floor and wall space especially on the 1st level, and 2nd- level where the optical illusions are. It's very disappointing! My nephew is 11, he was bored. Most if not all the hands on exhibits are geared towards ages 8 and under. With todays tech and leaps in science, you really need more current exhibits. how bout future tech?  I must say that todays visit(8-2-19)has seriously deterred me and my family from going to the museum of science for a long long time. Also,If youre going to have reduced amount of exhibits, you should lower exhibit hall pricing to compensate for the lack thereof."

"We had the best time at Astronomy After Hours tonight! We enjoyed being able to use many different types of telescopes and seeing some planets! Steve and Kaylen were so helpful with the telescopes and sharing their passions for the stars! Ted was so full of information and we loved learning from him!! This was our first time at this event and we will definitely be back!!"

"We had a wonderful experience, especially because of the time and consideration that Janet Nova took to help our visit. We had four guests with us (for a total of eight people), and she went through the time and effort to calculate out for us how much we would actually save by becoming members at the premiere 8 level. She was patient and definitely helped start our day off on a great foot! Thank you for such amazing attention."

"I just got home from the telescope program at the museum and had to write a review right away! This program was amazing and we learned so much!! Kayla taught us constellations while we waited in line and was so nice and welcoming. Steve greeted us as friends and John showed us Saturn. This program is so well done and it was a perfect night for us. Thank you!!"

"In the early fifties, when I lived In Milford, i sent an object to the Museum which I thought might be a meteorite. It was not, but I was asked if the Museum could keep it for an exhibit on meteorites and things that were mistaken for meteorites.
I was wondering if you still have any record in your database of this item. I’m visiting the Museum next week with my son and his family (museum members) and it would be a treat if I and my grandchildren could actually see this item after nearly seventy years.  
Please let me know what you find. Thank you."

"Why after watching the server make Mac and cheese with elbow noodles in a big pan why does he tell me I can’t have the elbow noodles with red sauce instead of the cheese sauce? His reason is “we only use the noodles for the Mac and cheese “ What!? 
Food service - if it’s available, and asked for, you should serve it.
Being a member for many years and not happy the last two times we bought food, we’ll be bringing our own food from now on
Horrible customer service!"

"Cafe needs to be able to offer other roll options other than the wheat one that comes with grilled items. I don’t eat the wheat roll and when asked for chicken sandwich on something other than wheat I was given the chicken on a plate and charged for a sandwich . What?! Cafe needs to be a bit more flexible"

"1. No gluten free products in any of food area. I shouldn't be restricted to buying only a salad, or bag of chips or banana.
2. We got Dippin' Dots outside the Riverview Cafe. When we finished, there was no where to put our plastic cups and plastic spoons except in the trash - no re-cycling bins.
3. There is only one gender-neutral bathroom, and its in the museum, and when thats closed there is none."

"I am such a big fan of the planetarium music experiences! I have been to a couple and I cannot wait to come back to watch more! I would like to suggest the band OneRepublic that would be great for this experience - I would like more information on who to contact to make this happen! Thank you so much."

"Vegan food options would be greatly appreciated!"	

"We were at the museum yesterday, and ate lunch at the cafeteria. We were surprised at how noisy it was, and I happen to have a dB Meter on my phone. When I used the meter, it was approximately 95 dB each time, which for a customer in the short time that they are there is not a problem, but this may be a problem for your employees. It is my understanding that prolonged exposure to 90 or more decibels is an OSHA violation"

"I was a science explorer in the 1950's and now live in Colorado. I am sitting at the computer listening to a great horned owl calling from a tree somewhere close by and remembering Spooky. I wanted to tell you how much the program meant to me in the past and now.
When I logged onto your website to find out where to write to you, the picture on the homepage reminded me of the transparent woman. I remember that the opening of the exhibit was delayed while the descriptive recording was remade. The original had such a heavy German accent that it was deemed too difficult for us New Englanders to understand.
Our whole family bought stars to help open the planetarium. I hope the list is still in existence somewhere.
Thank you again!"

"Good Morning:  I was watching your Body of Work commercials and realized how gender oriented they were.  The female body is taking a selfie and the male is batting a baseball. Please share with the marketing staff that this is inappropriate in this day and age.  I am a female athlete, a doctor and scientist.  Selfies are not the focus of me.  We can do better than this, especially with an ad for an esteemed museum where young children can be influenced, especially young girls. Especially young girls that we are trying to encourage to be part of STEM studies and careers.  Please consider revising the ads.  Thank you very much for your time."

"In the Human Body exhibit, there was some excessively heteronormative language. In one part it says “the fathers sperm and the mother’s egg.” There is no reason to included that gendered language. You could just say “sperm and egg.” As someone in a queer family I don’t like that because some people use “they” and that might not make them comfortable. It also erases families like mine. 

"I renewed our membership a couple of weeks ago. We went to the museum for the first time since 2017.
I have to say I found it really disturbing to see you were selling alcoholic beverages in the cafe. 
This I thought, was a family oriented place. I really do not believe alcohol serves any purpose in this environment. I truly hope you will rethink this action. We live in a society that is plagued with addiction. We need to be able to visit places where we are not reminded of the pain of this addiction.
Thanks so much for your attention to this matter."

"None of the phone options make sense...
When you call, here are the options, and none of them are for tickets:
For membership line press 1
For school and groups reservations press 2
For recorded information press 3
For events and conference services department (not tickets) press 4
For public safety press 5
Now do you see why calling on the phone makes me feel like an idiot? 
Someone needs to redo your phone system."

"Hi there. We just brought our family through the planetarium for the magic tree house show and were very excited to have our kids learn about space in such an immersive environment. Unfortunately we were very disappointed in the lack of diversity reflected in the show. 
Every single human represented in that show was white, and in a story reflecting the diversity of space and our planet this lack of representation of human diversity was shocking and unfortunate. 
I hope the museum considers adopting another show that better reflects the diversity of our planet so the many types of people walking in the door get to see themselves represented in this important story." 

"Why are you charging $1.60 for a cheesestick and not have a sign for the price? Nice place though."
"The food in your cafe is beyond horrible. Shame on you foe the quality and the dirty conditions."

"As a past member I have enjoyed all the great experiences the facility has to offer. In recently came down to update and pay for my membership and I brought two guests who are pre-med students to seen the Body Worlds exhibit with me, I had seen the exhibit when it came to the museum about 11 or 12 years ago multiple times. When I came last week I must say that we were a bit disappointed with the amount of pieces in the exhibit. I know things on tours change but it was nothing that compared to the previous exhibit. There were many bodies that I spoke to the students about that were not onsite. I do enjoy coming to the site and supporting the museum with my visits and membership but if I had known it was a smaller show i am not sure what i would have done paying extra for the exhibit. Thank you for your time, it is appreciated." 
"super-fun, immediately engaging but very chaotic (children running room to room ""doing things"" without knowing/learning).  I know it's supposed to be ""cool-er than school"".  Lastly, we were there for THREE hours and of the 3 floors/6 wings, we covered 2.  To think the museum requires 3 DAYS to complete, the price is quite off-putting. Also many seemingly interesting exhibits for which one would have to pay extra?!" 
"I am a French Paris science teacher (middle-school and high school) and I had this summer the opportunity to visit your great museum. I visited Boston with my husband and my 3 kids and we visited the Museum of Science. We used the Boston city pass to get into the museum. We didn't understand the museum closed at 5:PM and nobody told us at the entrance access we will only have 1 hour of visit. The museum is awesome and very interesting. We were very disappointed to visit it only one hour.
When we went out, I came to see the cashier and the welcome desk to ask if it was possible to return the day after with free tickets as we visited only one hour. The cashier said to me that they could not do something for us because we had City Pass. It was a pity for us.
Nevertheless, the museum gave me ideas for my French students especially the yellow giant height gauge which shows the difference between angstroem and feet (I can send you a picture of my daughter next to the gauge).
I would like to buy the same gauge as yours for my highschool but in meter/micrometer/nanometer.
Coul you give me the name of your supplier of this gauge ?"

"Why must one purchase a ticket for the Exhibit Halls if they just want to see Body Worlds?  Tickets are expensive enough for a temporary exhibit, let alone having to pay for the permanent Exhibit Halls when you don't want to explore them, or worse, when you've just seen them and a new temporary exhibit comes and you want to see that as well.  You know when Boston museums are too expensive when someone from California tells you that it's cheaper to do things in California than it is in Massachusetts."

"The Body Works Exhibit is, in my opinion, hideous & unethical. Also, the 3 year old I care for is very frightened of the ads o the T. I may not renew my membership over this"

"We had a wonderful time at the Museum today taking in the Body Works Exhibit and the Great Bear Rainforest Show, and at the end of the day we became members. 
I noted with great interest the display in the gift shop talking about the disgraceful accumulation of plastic waste in the oceans and elsewhere. Upon entering the cafeteria I was surprised to see that the only soda, etc. containers were single use plastic. I know that plastic containers are ""recyclable"" but to the best of my knowledge there is no market for them, so the only choices are to bury them in the earth or toss them in the waterways.
My question is, could the plastic bottles be replaced with aluminum containers which could then be truly recycled and help us to protect the environment? 
Thanks for your consideration"

"EBT card, entry free had best time at the Planetarium. Thank you for helping my son ""expend his mind."" Very generous. He is an exceptional learner, had a great time!"

"From time I put Premier Membership 2 in my cart and checked you on Charity Navigator to see whether I wanted to donate a larger gift to your organization, it took all of the 20 minutes you allowed. Had I had maybe five more minutes, I would not have had to start all over again.  Now I will just order the membership but you make it hard to do a gift membership as I have to start all over again."

"Hi!  My family and I took the lovely member cruise this morning and I wanted to give you some feedback about it since I overheard an MOS employee talking about how this morning was the best attended despite many marketing attempts.
I happened to see it in the email that went out on Thursday but that was the first time I saw it. Then when I went online to get the tickets it was very difficult to find it (the link sent you to a page but then you had to sign into your MOS account and wouldn’t return you to the ticketing page directly, so it was a lot of fumbling around on the website). 
My aunt also came with us - but I bought her ticket - shes an MOS member too and loves things like this and said she had never heard of it.
We were both really surprised that there had been a lot of attempts to make members aware of it.  We had a great time so I just wanted to let you know that the marketing attempts may not have 'landed'  like you expected, and may not be a reflection of the actual interest in the program.
I love your programming and thought the feedback may be helpful!"

"New member ( premier) and did not receive 2 hours of free parking which I thought was a benefit!
Please help"

"Hello!I am emailing you because i have 2 boys whom are both science fanatics! Both of them are straight A student's and in Gifted classes! They both study very hard.They are always making something whether it be slime or a stress ball or a volcano it is never a dull moment in our house!My kitchen,front porch and their bedroom stays in a mess lol but I wouldn't trade it for anything. Anyways the reason I am writing is because i was wondering if you could possibly send them a fan pack from your museum with a science kit or t-shirt or hat or stickers or all of the above? We encourage our boys to be whatever they want to be and always put their studies first! We are super proud of them! Thank you so much for your time and we look forward to hearing/receiving some things from you guys !Have a beautiful blessed day!"

"It is my understanding that neither you, nor anyone else, has informed consent agreements from the donors that can be linked to the bodies and body parts on display in 'Body Worlds' (https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=5637687).  The explanation I have seen is that this is to protect the anonymity and confidentiality of the donors, but it makes it impossible to independently confirm that such informed consent exists.  I also understand the bodies come from Dr. Gunther von Hagens, who also sources bodies from China, a known violator of human rights, and who has sourced bodies from a Russian convicted of illegally trafficking in bodies and body parts, although von Hagens claims none of the 'Body Worlds' bodies come from these tainted sources - a claim which cannot be verified given the lack of documentation (https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=5637687).  I also understand (from the 'FAQs' on your exhibition website) that you rely on others to vet the obvious, serious ethical concerns raised ('a distinguished committee of theologians, ethicists, academics and medical luminaries.... California Science Center.... the City of Heidelberg, Germany').  Am I correct in my understanding?"

"Visitor leaving the observatory at Astronomy After Hours: "'My son wanted a drone. Now he wants a telescope instead.'"

"I do NOT like the automatic hand stamper. It presses too firmly. I have slim hands - all bones - OUCH! Possibly rolled my skin over bone pinching me."

"Hi! I wanted to express my sadness today at the museum. We drove about 1.5 hours (back and forth) to visit and watched 4D Splash and Bubbles. However, the experience was nothing like it was before. There were barely any bubbles, music, no splash, except for some very uncomfortable lower leg puffs. This is very different from all the others we have seen so far. I think there was some machine malfunctioning going on. 
Will someone address this issue?"

July 2019 Comment Card Report

"Please remove our names from your mailing lists, both electronic and paper. Thank you"

"It would be great to have the Lewis and Clark Expedition film open to the public instead of only schools.   I am a former educator and would love to see it and  take my grandchildren to see it some time."

"Your cafe really needs some attention.  The floors are sticky, the tables are not clean.  The chairs are a mess (I got a splinter when pulling the chair into the table).  School cafes are cleaner that your facility.  Whole place needs to be refreshed"

"Hi there, I just wanted to note that it's really difficult to determine how long the temporary exhibits run when viewing information on the mobile site. (Possibly the desktop version too, but I've only viewed on mobile). The only way I could determine the run for the Body Worlds exhibit was to try to book tickets as far in advance as possible until it wouldn't allow me to. It would be much more convenient if the site just listed run dates alongside temporary exhibit information so patrons can plan their visit accordingly. It would help on the train ads, too but those are what they are at this point. Still effective since it lead me to investigate! Thank you"

"I joined as a member today. I took my family to see Great Barrier Reef today 2 pm show. We were disappointed in the show. First, we thought we'd see more information about the fish and other creatures along the reef, a la David Attenborough. Instead, it was a travelogue for the eco-tourism place and too much about the lady who blogs. Most of the movie was looking at her, on a boat, or taking pictures under water. We wanted to see what she took for pictures, not her taking them. No information about how she learned to free dive so well. Or info on the fish. What were we looking at?  And some of the video looked liked stock video.  Speaking of video, the movie was out of focus, there was an awful echo in the voices, and the movie did not fit the screen. I so disappointed in the quality of this show, not up to MoS standards. My grandchildren even noticed the poor quality. I wasted four passes on this movie, Please do better."

"We renewed our membership.  However, we did not have a chance to use the 4 free planetarium passes before they expired.  Is there anyway to get these 4 passes credited to our account to use this coming year?"

"The Restrooms and the food court is very dirty, _not_ well taken care of."

"Climate change show - presenter was very animated but content was awfully 'lecture-y' - suggest using Sammy Sosa steroid analogy _first_ - get audience to see data and then attribute his rise in home runs to steroids. THEN use similar data to get them to predict climate change. End was good, but took a _long_ time to get there."

"I do not want the electronic passes to expire because I would like to use them. I come here a lot with my family, therefore it makes more sense."

"I don't want the electronic passes to expire because I want to use them regularly. I also have food allergies and would like that the food services are more allergen friendly. (allergy safe towards peanuts, tree nuts, soy, shellfish, fish, sesame, milk, eggs)"

"(1) Electronic passes should not expire
(2) Top 8 allergen free food bar. I am anaphylactic to peanuts, tree nuts + soy you need to address top 8 allergens thank you"

"The electronic passes. I Don't like it that they expire. We need a food alergy freindly section in the food cort please."

"One of the issues I have with many of your exhibits is that when you look at them closely, your shadow blocks the exhibit."

"Mary, in visitor services was EXTREMELY helpful, pleasant, and a pleasure to work with. She embodies exactly who should be a visitor services representative. Thank you!!!"

"Dear Scot, My granddaughter Samantha and I thoroughly enjoyed the member overnight. Could not have been better. Please let Julie and all the overnight staff know she and they did a great job. Samantha is only 8 and generally goes to bed at 8:00 PM; staying up to midnight might be difficult, so we decided to scientifically count her yawns, but she was so excited, entertained and enthralled, it turned out to be a zero yawn overnighter!
Thank you again."

"You are an institute of science. Stop insisting or allowing your employees to announce their pronouns during shows. This is a huge insult to science."

"Thanks for the Climate Talk. Please suggest that visitors call their US Representatives + Senators + endorse HR763, a carbon fee + dividend act. Maybe even make an exhibit about political solutions?"

"You are a science museum but are negatively impacting the environment by selling water in plastic bottles."

"I see that it was done in the past. It's very disappointing that the event was discontinued."

"I was trying to get a ticket, but suddenly the price changed from $34 to $37 when the time is not the day of the exhibition. I would like to know how your system works with the cut down time to get advanced tickets discount. Thanks!"

"When will your ads of skinned corpses (Body Worlds) no longer be in places where hundreds of thousands of people are exposed to them everyday? Words cannot begin to describe how insensitive and inappropriate these ads are. They can be triggering to victims of violent, morbid events. You could have advertised just as effectively with DRAWINGS of skinned corpses, instead of photos. 
How did you all get permission to post these photos? Aren’t their laws governing the types of images people may post as advertisements so that way respectable people aren’t forced to look at insensitive things like this? (And, btw, the fact people donated their corpses doesn’t make this any less shameful... not when people— including children!— are exposed to your morbid advertisements on a daily basis.)"

"I am writing to express my disappointment in your pricing system for the Body Worlds exhibit. As a family of three who relies on an EBT card to visit MOS, to discover that not only would we have to pay separate admission for this exhibit, but that the “discount” would amount to $15 per person, I was absolutely dismayed that the MOS, which should be a place for all children regardless of socioeconomic status, would be so exclusionary. At $45, there is no way that I as a single mother, can afford this. Just paying for the parking garage is a stretch for me and many other families in our situation. You have cut off access to an exhibit that my children were looking forward to seeing. To exclude those who can’t even afford regular admission smacks nothing short of discrimination. Shame on MOS."

"I have to express disappointment with your pricing for the Body Worlds exhibit for EBT recipients. I understand to a point that you have to charge for this exhibit, but at $15 per person for a family of three it is completely impossible. Single mothers like myself come here as a treat. Even though we don’t pay for general admission, just the parking cost alone makes this museum a once in a blue moon experience. I urge anyone associated with the policy to reconsider as it promotes exclusion to those who are of a certain socioeconomic class. MOS should be ashamed of themselves for allowing such thoughtless discrimination."

"Your cafe needs attention.  The place was a mess.  No clean tables, food left behind on them, food spilled all over the floors (accident waiting to happen).  Walls look like they have never been cleaned, food stains on them - gross!  Your salad bar needs to be checked for freshness - lettuce i got was brown on the edges.  The line to pay was very confusing, People cutting in front of others.  Set up cue line like Disney - they are able to user thousands of guests with no issues and they are bigger than this place"

"We had a wonderful time in the Discovery Center with Kelle! Our son took an immediate liking to her and she was so kind & patient playing with him! Thanks, Kelle!"

"Beyonce experience - I've been to 6+ Planetarium music shows, and this by far was the most underwhelming one yet. By far. (low quality, not syncronized, too bright, boring!) So sad!"

"We saw the Beyonce Experience today and it was terrible, wildly disappointing. The screen was not calibrated, the music and images were out of sync, images did not fit the vibe of music. It felt like I watched a high school project. Beyonce would be disappointed!!"

"First, I wanted to commend you on providing so much mobility equipment for visitor use. Using a mobility scooter allowed me to see much more than I could have. Thank you!
I did want to give two suggestions:
1) providing a chair near the info desk to sit in while people wait for scooters etc. would be a great help.
2) In the Bodyworlds exhibit, there are two sets of closed doors to navigate, and they aren't automatic. I tried to open them from the scooter, but had great difficulty until another visitor came to my aid. Please consider this aspect of accessibility for exhibits with closed doors in them."

"Visited  as a Senior with my 12 year old grandson yesterday to experience together the heavily promoted Body Worlds exhibit.
His ticket cost was $37 and mine $33.
We were told these prices included a second exhibit which we not able to decline.  Both of us enjoyed the exhibit, we could not locate the second event, which was not the reason for our attending.
We were given after payment of $70 cash:
Exhibit Halls Package Adult (Vch) for $22.00 and Package Senior (Vch) for $18.00
BODY WORLDS:  The Cycle of Life
 [2] Add-on Adult at $15.00 each
I am wondering why your banner - blitz all over the city did no show the distinction.
The day before we two experienced [1] The Codzilla speed boat ride with my grandsons father. And the day before, my grandson and I visited the Aquarium. 
I am not seeking a refund, just ticket sellers better equipped at explaining the pricing structure."

"There is nothing on the website that states what is and/or isn't allowed to be brought in to the museum." 
"Astronomy After Hours
I learned so much
The Best
Please always stay open"

"Activities, especially tardigrades under a microscope are wonderful - especially since we were somewhat stranded because of the rainstorm (Astronomy After Hours)"

"When you resume discounted memberships for people with academic appointments I’ll consider rejoining."

"The bathrooms in the concourse were in terrible state when we arrived at 7:30 pm so I reported it to the Info Desk. At 9:30 when we were leaving, the bathroom floors had been mopped but the wasted baskets were still overflowing with papertowels and the toilet paper was still on the floor."

"When I pulled up to the parking garage ticket dispenser (on the right side), I somehow hit my car against a cement post or something when pulling away from the ticket machine! I was not even that close to the machine when I pulled up. Is this a problem for others besides me? I am not a careless driver, so I think somehow the ticketing machine is not spatially set up properly! As a result, my car was dented & scratched along the side. I'm very upset that this happened & think something should be done about this."

"I am visiting from Uganda and I enjoyed the Musuem of Science ,I wish there was a way I could volunteer for the two months I am down here,back at home we do not have a museum of science. I am 15 years old and I very passionate about science that's for sure.
I do biology and chemistry,I dropped physics because it just was not the same as when I used to live back in England where I felt like physics was daily life.
Thank you Musuem of Science.”

"My family (me, my husband, our 19-year-old daughter & her boyfriend, and our four-year-old son) recently went to the MOS for a day, traveling from RI. The entire visit was stunning and exciting, but I am writing to praise a particular member of your staff. At the live animal presentation, a person named Sara(h) came out to teach us about snakes and common rats. Her enthusiasm was contagious and she handled her animals and her audience well. She also led with her pronouns (“My name is Sara and my pronouns are she/her/hers”). As a gender-nonconforming person myself and as an educator who trains on anti-bias work, I wanted to be sure that Sara and the MOS know that her introduction made me feel more welcome and was an unexpected and lovely moment during our visit. Please pass on our thanks - for her thoughtfulness and her impeccable rat-handling."

"Faulty Bee Display
The Bee display in the Human Body exhibit is a death trap for Bees. They are DYING Horrible Dealths! Please FIX ASAP"
"Thank you for a wonderful experience! Your volunteers are OUTSTANDING. One suggestion: caption the lightning demo for ESL folks - they do this at the opera."

"Could you make an exhibit about basketball? I think there might be science in it, but I don't know what."

"Please pass this on to Nicole in the human life exhibit. I just wanted to let you know what a great job she did with sharing information on the organs. It was amazing! She was very engaging and intelligent. It was the highlight of my trip to the museum. Thank you."

"Jordan at the ticket counter was wonderful! Very attentive flagged that membership was more economical after I placed my order - not pushy but knowledgeable & patient"

"I tried multiple times to buy a guest membership. Website kept insisting that it was a "duplicate email". I literally created the email 2 weeks ago. Nobody has touched your site with this email. 
Sorry I will simply buy elsewhere. Your web people really need to fix this."

Voltmeters! Toy boats! Plastic syringes! Pipettes! On Friday Sept 13 from 10am-1230pm come pick up supplies, books, equipment, etc. for your department! Any questions please talk to Meredith Mahoney x3171.

Membership has one half-day afternoon GSEs available for tomorrow, Thursday, September 5. This GSE lets you listen to your headphones while you work, earn GSE credit, and experience the satisfaction of knowing you've helped the Membership Department and the Museum's members! If you have the availability, please consider signing up.

If anyone is looking for a fun GSE this Friday 9/6 from 4:30-8:30 is the first College Friday event and we need help directing students.


https://bmos.sharepoint.com/sites/hr-service-jobs/SitePages/App.aspx?r=1215
The State will be testing elevators on Sept. 5-6 so you may not have access to elevators while they are being tested.

We’re finally in the home stretch of this project! 

This week we will complete the wireless installation for the Blue Wing, having finished the exhibit spaces out of the Box Office closet on Tuesday during the Museum closure. We have been working on the area served out of the Engineer’s Enclave all week and should wrap that up by the week’s end. This covers Science Central, the Enclave, the Butterfly Garden, Behind the Scenes, and the parking garage. 

We are now at 87% completion for the wireless installation, and will be starting cabling work in the Gordon Wing on Monday, September 9th, 2019. Once we hit the Gordon Wing we will have less than 10 access points to install!

Thank you everyone for your patience and cooperation during this project, it is very much appreciated.

-Rae

“Public Speaking for People Who Don’t Like Public Speaking”

September 10th, 1-2:30 in the ERC.

I will be leading an informal 90-minute public speaking workshop for anyone who wants to get more comfortable speaking in front of a crowd, or who just wants to brush up on their presentation techniques. We'll go over best practices used in Live Presentations and review some universal tips for every kind of audience engagement.

The 5 essential vocal tools
Where do you put your hands!
How to channel your nervous energy
How to quickly organize your thoughts
The science behind creating a powerful first impression.

This is a fast-paced, highly interactive workshop where you will get a chance to put all you learn into practice right away. 

Email me at dmarino@mos.org if you are able to make it, or if you have any questions!

If you can't make this one but are still interested we may have another one based on interest.

I wanted to take a moment to update everyone on some resource adjustments that are happening within the Information Technology department for the next few months. These changes are needed to successfully complete cross departmental priority projects, in particular the Tessitura v15 upgrade and MOS Website Refresh.

With these goals in mind, Information Technology has realigned team members to complete these efforts as well as continue to address day to day operations. Primary web developers (Jackie McGraw and Henry Saniuk) are now dedicated to these projects, and an additional resource (James Baker) has been redeployed to address regular maintenance and enhancement requests.  This means that promotional requests for both the current website and the Hub are impacted to some degree, as James will be handling both.  Museum staff should be aware that ongoing activities such as these will be triaged and prioritized, and we will strive to meet timelines to the best of our ability, but turnaround times may be extended.

I want to thank you all in advance for your patience while we are in this resource intensive project phase, as we will do our best to continue to provide the high level of service the Museum has come to expect.

docs.messageSubject: Auction for Patroits and Bruins tickets
docs.messageBody:
Hi everyone,

My brother (Robert Young) is currently running an auction for Patriots and Bruins tickets (both games are in October) as a fundraiser for the Scots’ Charitable Society Scholarship fund.  

What is the Scots’ Charitable Society?
Founded in 1657, The Scots’ Charitable Society is the oldest charitable organization still existing in the Western Hemisphere.  
Scots’ Society aims to provide relief to Scots individuals and/or families in need.
The Society also awards undergraduate scholarships to the Scottish-American community.
Scots’ Charitable seeks to promote Scottish and Celtic heritage through education, participation in highland games, parades and other cultural events throughout the Greater Boston area.

AUCTION ITEMS AVAILABLE - 

NEW ENGLAND PATRIOT TICKETS
A pair of New England Patriots tickets for the game on Sunday, October 27th against the Browns.
Seats are in section 106 row 5 seats 5 and 6
Current bid as of 9/9 is at $175.00

BOSTON BRUINS TICKETS
A pair of Boston Bruins tickets for the game on Thursday, October 17th against the Tampa Bay Lightning
Seats are in Loge 13 row 10 seats 7 and 8
Current bid as of 9/9 is at $150.00

To place a bid for either of these tickets, please email my brother directly at robjyg@msn.com, or email me and I can relay your bid to him.  (Please included in your email that you are a staff person from the Museum of Science.)   He will email updates on the bidding as the auction comes to a close.  
Auction closes at midnight on Sunday, September 15th.

Today we have achieved 100% completion of the wireless installation at the Museum. All legacy equipment has been deactivated (all legacy networks are gone), building inspections are scheduled, and we are completely live on the new wireless network. The most common networks you will see are:

•	Staff@MoS – regular staff wireless access, use your network credentials. Still requires VPN for most internal resources.
•	Public@MoS – guest wireless, web traffic ONLY. Join via splash screen.
•	Events@MoS – wireless network for Museum functions only, password protected.

This project would not have been possible without the much appreciated assistance of Archives, Collections, Event & Conference Services, Exhibit Maintenance, Facilities, Omni, Planetarium, Public Safety, Visitor Services, and Wolfgang Puck. Your guidance, information sharing, and cooperation have been key components in getting our new wireless equipment installed as quickly and efficiently as possible. Everyone who made time to work with us and our vendors really helped move the project along, enabling us to achieve a successful outcome. And everyone in the rest of IT for working with schedule adjustments and helping re-allocate resources as needed while wireless work took priority, thank you for your support.

A huge thank you to Carousel and Connectivity Point, our project vendors, for their tireless efforts and dedication to a successful project completion. We would not have been able to complete this work without their expertise. And finally, thank you to everyone for your patience and cooperation during this project, it has been very much appreciated. 

Enjoy the new wireless experience at the Museum!

-Rae

docs.messageSubject: The Museum Lights Tower Orange Sept. 12 for National Hunger Action Day
docs.messageBody:
As part of our participation in the Greater Boston Foodbank’s Hunger to Health Collaboratory, the Museum is lighting its tower orange tonight to mark Hunger Action Day.
 
The Hunger to Health Collaboratory is an initiative of cross sector leaders dedicated to reducing the health consequences of hunger.  Together, we are contributing our organizational expertise to accelerate the impact of sustainable initiatives to address the systemic injustices associated with food insecurity.
 
In Massachusetts, 1 in 11 people is food insecure.  The number rises to 1 in 9 nationally. 
 
Many families and individuals do not have reliable access to affordable healthy food, leading to preventable negative health consequences. According to a study released by The Greater Boston Food Bank and Children’s HealthWatch in 2018, the avoidable health care cost of hunger in Massachusetts is $2.4 billion. 
 
As a member of the Hunger to Health Collaboratory, we are part of a diverse group of industry leaders working to address the systemic injustices associated with food insecurity.
 
In November, the Museum of Science will host The Hunger to Health Summit where leaders from across the country will convene to discuss the various actions that we can take to raise awareness and take collective action to reduce food insecurity. 
 
For more information about this initiative, please contact Susan Heilman or more information online, visit: https://www.gbfb.org/what-we-do/hunger-to-health-collaboratory/

docs.messageSubject: Boston Climate Strike Community Chalk Day Friday Sept. 20 8am-10am. On the plaza
docs.messageBody:
Join us for a Community Chalk Day to Support the Boston Climate Strike!

The Boston Climate Strike Rally is happening this Friday September 20th in Government Center. 
Colleagues from our youth and community outreach teams will be attending the Climate Strike rally, on behalf of the Museum, to support Boston youth in making their voices heard in this important global movement to protect our future.  

The Museum is proud to be able to stand beside young people around the world participating in this historic movement and want to extend the opportunity for all of us here at the Museum to share our support to climate strikers around the world by participating in the Climate Strike Community Chalk Day.
 
Join fellow colleagues in writing your message of support for climate action, on the front plaza sidewalk, Friday morning between 8:00am – 10:00am. 

This is purely an optional activity for Museum staff members to join the conversation and show your support for climate action! Participants are encouraged to spend some time getting creative! 

All we ask is that you please use respectful language and consider messages that empower our visitors, schools groups and other guests to positive actions in supporting climate action. 

SUGGESTED MESSAGES
Below are some suggested lines you can use—but this is your time to get creative! 

Sept 20th Climate Strike - Boston City Hall
This is an emergency. ACT LIKE IT! Sept 20th Climate Strike. 
Climate Justice NOW. Sept 20th Climate Strike.
There is no Planet B!
The Seas are Rising and So Are We!

Climate strikes were started by school students organizing through the #FridaysForFuture platform. This Global Climate Strike mobilization is a joint response by a broad coalition of groups, NGOs, unions and social movements across the world to young people’s call to action. 

This global movement started and continues through the power of young people.  Let’s help amplify their voices by driving the message that there is no denying the science, there is no planet B! 

We hope all those who are interested are able to join us!  Any questions, contact Carrie Nash.

Good morning,

As previously communicated, the Museum received a donation from Dell EMC for a new storage device.  This has enabled the Museum to improve how we manage, store, and backup much of our unstructured content. 
 
What Does This Mean?
Information Technology will use the new device to replace our existing Zeus file server.  Over the past few months, we have been working with users on unencrypting files and folders that prevented us from transitioning over to this device last summer.   We are happy to report that we will finalize the migration of all Zeus shared folders and home directories on October 7th  starting at 6pm. 
 
What Can I Expect When This Takes Effect?
Do not panic! We will be retaining all file and folder permissions and will be retaining the existing “Zeus” naming convention in order to maintain how users currently connect to shared resources.
 
For PC/Windows users, this will not introduce any changes to the way you connect to your Zeus shares.  However, Mac users that do not currently connect to Zeus via the SMB connection (i.e CIFS) will need to be remapped before or on the morning of 10/8/19 in order to access the shares.  Our service desk will be ready to help with this change and you should contact us immediately for assistance.
 
What Do I Need To Do?
In order to prepare for the final migration of data to the new device we ask that users close out of all shared museum file directories and personal work drives when leaving at night leading up to October 7th so that we can continue to copy files over daily.  On the night of October 7th all files and folders on Zeus need to be closed before 6pm so that IT can work with Dell EMC and maximize our final migration window.  If files and folders are not closed out, IT will close them to ensure that the data is properly migrated to the new device.  To avoid losing changes to files please close out of all files and folders promptly before 6pm.

Please note that staff should not store non-work related items (music, personal photos, videos, etc.) on Zeus shared museum file directories and home directories, in keeping with the Museum’s Technology Resource Policy. This will help us keep up with the demand for storage needs and retain a longer backup retention policy for museum related work needs.  In the future, if you need additional storage capacity for your home directory, you can call the service desk or submit a request online.
 
As always, if you have any questions or issues, please contact our service desk, System Support Services, at ithelp@mos.org or call x0130.

Angela

So far this year we have received 520 recognitions! Let’s keep it going! MOScar-worthy moments happen every day. Take a couple minutes to submit any last-minute MOScar Recognitions to be considered for this year’s ceremony.

Feel free to reach out with any questions!
The MOScars Project Team

Internal Job Postings

The Visitor Services Support Associates are indispensable team members who are fully cross trained to be part of both the Museum's proactive sales team for tickets, memberships and other priorities as well as part of the operations team providing welcoming guest service while conducting admission and/or operational duties in several key, high profile areas of the Museum including the Exhibit Halls entry, Mugar Omni Theater, 4D Theater, Butterfly Garden, Discovery Center, Thrill Ride 360 simulators, school group check in and logistics, and special exhibits. As many of you know, the Advancement Department is launching the Museum’s first annual Sci-K Fun Run! This untimed, dog- and stroller-friendly 5-k along the Esplanade will start and end at Fiedler Field (next to the Hatch Shell) on Sunday, October 6. 

We are offering all Museum employees a discount on tickets! Regular priced tickets are $35, but for our colleagues we’re reducing the price to only $10 for each staff member or $32 for a team of 4 ! We would love to see some friendly museum staff faces out on the course, and hope you’ll join us for a morning of running, fun, and food! Register now at www.mos.org/sci-k and use the promo code STAFF2019 for individuals and STAFFTEAM for teams to claim your discount today!

Everyone is encouraged to dress up in their favorite Science costume and run/walk, then check out our science activities from the education department, a temporary tattoo station, an “astronaut” photoshoot, donuts, and much more! Plus, we will have a finish line swag, an award ceremony for the best costumes and highest fundraisers. The event will be a fun day for families and kids of all ages.

docs.messageBody:
Safety Day is TODAY!!!

Wed Sept 25 from 10:00 AM to 1:00 PM in the Engineers Enclave

 

Drop in anytime to:

    • Browse the safety tables – So MUCH to Learn from our colleagues!

Safety Committee

docs.messageSubject: Thurs. 9/26: A Look Inside High School Science Series
docs.messageBody: Another school year brings another exciting season of our High School Science Series Program! School and Youth Programs will be hosting the A Look Inside High School Science Series tomorrow, Thursday, September 26, 2019. There will be about 300 MA high school students and teachers exploring anatomy and physiology by visiting the BODY WORLDS & The Cycle of Life exhibit, engaging in hands-on activities, and attending a Keynote Presentation at 11 AM in Cahners Theater. The Keynote will be lead by Dr. Fallon Durant and her baby Axolotls. Dr. Fallon Durant is a postdoctoral researcher at Harvard University in the laboratory of Dr. Jessica Whited studying regeneration in axolotls. She hopes to use this research to help develop therapeutics for humans that will help patients prevent scar formation. Fallon received her Ph.D. from Tufts University studying the biophysics of planarian regeneration. Want to get a close look at a baby Axolotl? Dr. Fallon Durant and the "axo-littles" will be in the Blue Wing Well from 9:30 AM - 10:30 AM. Want to learn even more? Join us for the 11 AM Keynote! Please contact Meghan Carter at MCarter@mos.org or X0310 with any questions.

There is a pile of materials that the Hall of Human Life is looking to re-home available in Lower Morse.  Any of these materials are free to be taken on a first come, first serve basis until Wednesday, October 2nd at closing.  Please feel free to stop by and acquire anything that may be of use to you before it's gone!  Available items will be within the marked area.  For any questions, call the HHL extension at 3143.

October is National Cyber Security Awareness Month!  We hear about identity theft and data breaches happening in the news, and how it affects both institutions and individuals on an everyday basis. National Cyber Security Awareness Month was founded to help everyone stay protected wherever and however you connect because education is the key to prevention. The theme for the month this year is, ‘Own IT. Secure IT. Protect IT.’ because keeping the digital world secure requires all of us to be proactive and diligent.

To that end, Information Technology will be leading an informal campaign to help raise the Museum's awareness about the importance of cybersecurity both at work and at home.  Each week, a member of the IT staff will share tips and tools that we can all use to protect the Museum's data as well as personal information.  These will be available both on the Hub and via email.

We all can play a role in building a more secure cyber world!

docs.messageSubject: PEST CONTROL - How you can help!
docs.messageBody:
We need you; 

We ask that you please always report pest sightings as well as any evidence of pest activity as soon as possible  (Cockroaches, mice, ants, fruit flies, fly, moths, etc.) 

The Facilities department offers the following options for reporting, choose whichever work best for you. 
  
•	Submit a Facilities Service ticket via the Hub or https://museumofscience.service-now.com
•	Write, as detail as possible, in any of our sighting logbooks (Front desk/Facilities office) 
•	Send an email to Facilities@mos.org

If you spot a pest, please contact us. Pests like, cockroaches and mice are hide-and-seek champions; the one you see is a likely an indication of more nearby that you don’t see. Ignoring the problem doesn’t make them go away.

In the event of a present situation that can’t wait (i.e. a smell indicative of decay or caught in/on a trap), you can reach us at Facilities ext. 0150.

•	When reporting, be specific. Please include the date, type of pest, location, route of travel. 
            Include your name & ext in case we need more information. 
•	Keep your space clean of clutter, food etc. Treats, food and snacks should be in tightly sealed containers. 
•	Keep the food disposal related items in a centralized location. 
            Kitchenettes or designate a trash barrel for food sources within your space.       
•	Avoid eating on route to other areas.  
•	Keep floors & walls clutter-free (suggested clearance of 6 inches off the floor and keep storage away from          walls when possible) 

If questions or concerns please let us know. 

Thank you all for your help.

September 2019 Comment Cards

“Please offer vegan options in the cafe. Grilled tofu in the salad bar or sandwiches with grilled veggies and tofu. Hummus wraps with veggies. Lots of options!"

"I visited the Museum of Science again yesterday as part of Brandeis University's Orientation for First-Year students. I was primarily interested in seeing how the museum is presenting the science of climate change. I asked at the entrance where I would find the section on climate science. But I was told that there was none. That I might find information about climate change sprinkled into the basic science sections, but there was no single room or section devoted to climate science. I was told that on normal days presenters would talk about extreme weather and meteorological questions as part of their presentations, but presentations are not part of the evening program. 
This came as a shock to me, given the seriousness of the climate crisis, and the urgent need for young people to be educated about the science, the problems, and the solutions. I would like to know what the museum leadership is planning to do to address this dangerous vacuum. Is a major exhibit about climate science in the works? If not, why not? I would assume that MathWorks, your main sponsor, is sympathetic to such a project? Given how many young people are getting involved in climate activism, providing them with a solid basis of the scientific facts seems paramount."

"Starbucks shouldn’t be cleaning their machines 3 hrs before they close, it’s not the customers fault they don’t manage their time efficiently."

"I'd like to know when our membership expires but I can't find it on the website.  Can you help?  Thank-you."

"We are hoping the IMAX movie, "Superpower Dogs" is coming to the MoS.  We saw it in LA and it's absolutely fabulous.  We really hope you consider bringing it to Boston!"

"Change your air filters in planetarium. You have a mold problem! Fix it soon or it will get a lot worse."

"A science museum without gyroscopes for sale is like an art museum without postcards of artwork."

"Hi. We used to use one of your sites to learn forces using the website:  http://legacy.mos.org/etf/force.html.  Apparently it is a retired website.  Do you have another website that can be used?"
"We thoroughly enjoyed our visit, as always"

"My 4 yr old grandson entrusted his dinosaur Penny to Papa- who lost it?? Is there a way I could purchase another Thanks so much for all you do there ??"

"You should provide paper cups in the cafe for water, instead of plastic. Protect the earth!"

"You keep sending me notices to complete application, and the link that you provide does not worked. I took a screen shot and mailed it to you and my email came back as NO REPLY. If you are only interested in one way communication I am requesting to withdraw my application."

"I took my grandson to the museum yesterday. Before leaving for the day, I stopped by Starbucks to get a coffee. I have never had such bad service in my life.  Two staff members behind the counter, one could not see me the other was eating food out of the container their own food, if looks could kill I would be dead now. Gave them my order a latte and an ice cream, paid for the order they then waited on two to three no problem, thinking the other person was making my coffee.  The staff member goes back to eating their food. Asked them where my latte was, they said they never waited on me. I went to get my sales slip to show them. Again another look to kill.  I am so upset I will NEVER go back to the museum. Please take this up with the Starbucks manager so this doesn't happen to another customer. MS has lost my business because of this."

"I wanted to share a wonderful experience that happened last night. Three of my friends and myself went to the museum of science in Boston to see the moon through telescopes. One of my friends has muscular dystrophy and cannot move any limb so he is completely wheelchair bound. 
We came to where the telescopes were set up and noticed that there were long lines at each on that was already set up on the grass and on the sidewalk. We were doubting if he was going to be able to participate until one of the workers who introduced himself as Steve came over and said that he was going to take care of us. 
Steve walked away briskly into the building and within 10 minutes he was back with a telescope that he was setting up to specifically accommodate my friend Nick in his wheelchair. Steve was very patient and enthusiastic about helping us which we couldn’t thank him enough. All four of us, but most importantly Nick, got to enjoy and see the moon crystal clear through the telescope. 
I’m sending this email to put spotlight on Steve and let him know how much we appreciated his extra effort to help and accommodate Nick without us even asking. He made the experience that much more memorable. Steve is a wonderful and kind person and I hope he will be recognized for his thoughtful actions."

"Very interesting. Friendly informative staff in Hands-on Lab." 

"My 4 yr old grandson and I visited the museum this morning, and eventually had a great visit, as we usually do. Because his family has a membership I take him several times a year. 
We arrived and wanted to get a bite to eat before beginning exhibits. We proceeded to the cafe area where I could get coffee (I thought)---several groups of school children were purchasing lunches in the cafeteria, and many then went to the Starbucks area for drinks, I guess. Very bad timing on our part, as we ended up behind about 20 students.....with 1 person at the cashier---I was not able to get to her for an hour. During that time, we went to the other area and got something for my grandchild and sat there. We returned and I had to wait for 15 minutes behind about 7 children. 
Believe it or not, I love children and was in education until retirement.....I do want to suggest that  if there are families visiting there should be a way to accommodate them separately from the school groups. And I felt very sorry for the the cashier, working alone with that very long line of middle schoolers."

"I hate to send you this but I’ve never seen a dining area so filthy and unprofessionally maintained. All of the tables had food, rappers or both on them along with the floors. The cleanest table we found was next to this broom also next to another mess covering the chairs and floor. Also right next to the fountain machines was a cleaning bucket with water and soap splashed everywhere.. I honestly don’t understand how such a high ranked museum can look like this. The thing that bothered me the most was seeing your staff lounging around while the dining area wasn’t busy at all. This pretty much ruined my experience as I’ve longed to come here for years and I’m honestly upset for making a donation to this facility. If I had known it looked like this no money would have been spent."

"You guys should consider doing a light show for Tool. In particular the albums Lateralus, or their newest release, Fear Inoculum. Tool has a pretty decent following and I bet you’d get great turnout."

"Dear Sirs
We are family of 6 (4 kids age 3 – 11 ), visiting Boston, my kids really would like to come to the children museum but we can’t afford the admission, our younger is a disabled kid and we are burdened with a lot of medical expenses including overseas treatment (see receipt attached) , we have a card of free access to national parks, I wonder if you are able to give us 6 complimentary tickets or $ 1 for ticket, we are coming from NJ and won’t be able to make it on Friday. 
Your generosity would be appreciated. "


"Three comments from the same group:
1. Robert was very kind to our grandchildren while proving cooked food.

2. Robert was cooking at the grill and went out of his way to give my granddaughters their meal on the membership appreciation day.

3. Robert went above + beyond serving my family with a kind smile + great attitude! We truly appreciated the delicious dino nuggets. Robert made my girls' night at member appreciation!"

"Two comments from the same group:
1. The person that attend the Grill was disrespectful with my family members which was very polite with our request. We are on vacation and it was a really bad experience.

2. The person that attend the Grill is being really disrespectful with all the clients."

"Loved the Body Worlds Exhibit
could you tell me the name/composer of the music in the Fetus Room - Loved It - very soothing!"

"I have been coming to the Lightning Show for almost 40 years Terry was the most engaging, theatrical, and informative presenter I have seen. Well done!"

"Destination Mars: New Frontier felt cliche and needs more specific info. Part with woman narrator was unnecessary and a filler. Liked food/music."

docs.messageSubject: National Cyber Security Awareness Month: #BeCyberSmart at Home!
docs.messageBody:
Cyber security starts at home. Help make your home a safe digital haven by protecting networks, devices, and online lives with these tips:
•	Keep a Clean Machine: having the latest security software, web browser, and operating system is the best defense against viruses, malware, and other online threats. Remember, mobile phones and tablets need updating too! Browsing on your mobile device? Make sure it’s not running suspicious apps or using permissions you didn’t realize you approved.
•	Lock Down Your Login: usernames and passwords are not enough to protect key accounts like email, bank, and social media. Improve account security by enabling strong authentication tools such as biometrics or unique one-time codes.
•	Share with Care: Your personal information is like money, be smart about where you’re sharing it, who you’re sharing it with, and how it’s being used. Cybercriminals love it when you overshare on social media—they can learn all about you! Make it harder by avoiding posting real names, places you frequent, and home, school, and work locations! Watch this video for more tips on reevaluating your digital privacy: https://habitu8.wistia.com/medias/axab9pmatu 
•	Back It Up: Protect your valuable work, music, photos, and other digital information by making an electronic copy and storing it safely.
•	Be Smart about Smart Devices: The Internet of Things – all of those appliances and devices that connect to the Internet and each other on your home network-- is growing exponentially on a daily basis, this is both a good and bad thing. Good in terms of convenience and accessibility, but at the same time those “benefits” can come with some seriously costly drawbacks and vulnerabilities by creating a multitude of opportunities for cybercriminals. That’s why it’s important to have a defense plan for securing smart home devices. Here’s more tips to make your smart home more secure: https://us.norton.com/internetsecurity-iot-smart-home-security-core.html#tips

Bottom line: if you have a connected home or device, it needs protection!

docs.messageSubject: National Cyber Security Awareness Month: #BeCyberSmart and avoid hackers and phishers!
docs.messageBody:
Make it harder for cybercriminals to access your information at home and in the workplace by keeping it secure! 

•	P@s$w0rds_d0n't_hav3_2_b_th!s_Complic@teD! Seriously, who can even remember that? Make your password a passphrase, keep it fun and friendly (e.g., CorgisAreTheBestDogsEver!), something you and only you can remember. Remember strong and long passphrases are not always enough, step up your game with multi-factor authentication and keep all your private bits…private. Learn what makes a strong password at https://habitu8.wistia.com/medias/r3b9dqonba 
•	Play Hard to Get with Strangers: if you’re unsure of who an email is from—even if the details appear accurate—do not respond, and do not click on any links or attachments. Cybercriminals cast wide nets with phishing tactics, hoping to drag in victims with financial rewards or threats. Don’t engage! And when in doubt, throw it out: delete any suspicious messages!
•	Tips for Spotting a Phish: 1) They offer a reward, threaten you, or claim to need help. 2) They ask for personal information. 3) They want you to download a file or click on a link. 4) Their emails and URLs look like something you’ve seen before, but are just.not.quite.right. For more info on how to stay safe online, check this out: https://staysafeonline.org/stay-safe-online/online-safety-basics/spam-and-phishing/ 

Bottom line: cautious habits and good judgement are the final defense against cybercriminals!  If you are ever unsure about an email you receive, you can reach out to the Service Desk (x0130) for assistance.

Hi all - 
 
We are trying out some new material for our upcoming substance use disorder forum and would like your help!
 
There is one section of our forum that we have changed and we would appreciate your feedback on how it works, if anything doesn’t make sense, and if we need to include more information to help you have dynamic discussions. The section we are redeveloping is our “stakeholder value mapping” section where forum participants learn about various people who have been affected by substance use disorder in different ways, and consider what they would value most in a community that is becoming more resilient to substance use disorder. You don’t need to know anything about the topic to participate, you just have to come ready to discuss the information provided to you! After the discussion, our research & evaluation team will ask for feedback about how we can make the materials better.
 
There are two opportunities to join us:
Wednesday (tomorrow), Oct. 16th from 9:00am – 9:45am in Hornblower OR Thursday, Oct. 17th from 12:00pm – 12:45pm in Hornblower
Feel free to bring your coffee/breakfast/lunch!
 
Thank you, and please let us know if you have any questions. All are welcome to join.
Emily

docs.messageSubject: National Cyber Security Awareness Month: #BeCyberSmart and secure your connections to the Internet!
docs.messageBody:
Be aware of how you’re connecting at home, at work, and everywhere in between: if you connect, you must protect. 

•	Outsmart Cyberthreats with Updates: any device that connects to the Internet is vulnerable to various risks. The best defense is to keep your device’s security software, web browser, and operating systems up to date.
•	Do Not Share Personal Data on Unsecure Websites:  Look for the padlock icon in the address bar to assure the data you share with that site is encrypted.
•	Public Wi-Fi is Not Secure: Limit what you do on public Wifi and avoid logging into key accounts like email and financial services. Be careful what you access on “free” wireless networks at shopping centers, hotels, and public events. Coffee at Starbucks is not worth the risks of exposing your personal or company data on unsecure networks. 
•	If You Collect It, Protect It: Any data the Museum collects, including guest and employee information, must be safely stored and protected. Limit access to only the employees who require that information to perform the core duties of their job. 
•	Practice Vigilance Every Day: Lock your computer when you leave for meetings, go to lunch, or are away from your desk for extended periods of time. Keep your smart phone lock screen enabled with a secure code or biometrics. Log out of any accounts you access via the Internet every time you’re done using them.

Bottom line:  be aware of how and when you transmit personal or company data and take the necessary steps to protect yourself.

docs.messageSubject: Exhibit Moves Starting 10/28 for All Aboard! Trains at Science Park 2019
docs.messageBody:
If you haven't heard, "All Aboard! Trains at Science Park" is rolling back into the Museum this year, but in an exciting new location - Blue Wing, Level 2 in Investigate and part of gallery adjacent to the Lighthouse! We are currently chugging along with the development and planning process, and the exhibit is on track to open Nov. 23.

To prepare the space for our model train club partner and the Exhibits team to install graphics, components, and four model train displays, we will be phasing the closure of the Investigate and Lighthouse galleries starting Oct. 28. As these sections close, a few components will be going into storage temporarily, but many will be relocated around the building where appropriate to keep as many exhibits available to visitors as possible. 
Please note the following closures - each space will be blocked off with versaguards and pipe and drape. Once a space is closed, it will remain closed until All Aboard opens to the public:

-Already closed: The Investigate "living room", as it's been being used for prototyping over the last few weeks
-Oct. 28: The "garage" area of Investigate will close for prep work
-Nov. 4: The "kitchen" area of Investigate will close for prep work
-Nov. 12: The gallery space behind the Lighthouse will close for prep work (the Lighthouse will stay on display and accessible to visitors)
-Nov. 18 - Nov. 22: All Aboard exhibition install
-Nov. 23: All Aboard public opening

For details in layout form, please see the image attached to this message.

All Aboard's last day open to the public will be Tuesday, Jan. 7. Starting Jan. 8, Investigate and the Lighthouse gallery space will be temporary closed once more for a couple weeks as we remove All Aboard and re-install exhibit components.

If you have any questions (or have a good train pun to share), please reach out to me (gfo@mos.org, x4456) or Julia Tate (jtate@mos.org, x0287).

9:00am-5:00pm, Monday-Friday

National Cybersecurity Awareness Month 2019 is about taking proactive steps to enhance cybersecurity at home and in the workplace. The lines between our work and daily lives are becoming increasingly blurred, and it is more important than ever to be certain that smart cybersecurity practices carry over between the two. When you are on the job your organization’s online security is a shared responsibility. It’s not just the job of IT staff to ensure online safety at work. Creating a culture of cybersecurity includes ALL employees knowing how to protect themselves and the organization and understanding the cyber risks as the business grows or adds new technologies or functions. Everyone must do their part to keep themselves and the Museum safe! 

This month we covered topics on protecting your digital identity at home and in the workplace: 
•	OWN IT - Understand your digital profile. Understand the devices and applications you use every day to help keep you and your information safe and secure. Stay safe while traveling, shopping, and using social media or smart devices.
•	SECURE IT - Secure your digital profile. Protect against cyber threats by learning about security features available on the equipment and software you use. Make sure to set up strong passwords, multi-factor authentication, and be vigilant against phishing attempts.
•	PROTECT IT - Maintain your digital profile. Be familiar with and routinely check privacy settings to help protect your privacy and limit cybercrimes. Think before you act online (at home or in the workplace) and protect your personal information.

For more information about connecting with confidence visit: https://niccs.us-cert.gov/national-cybersecurity-awareness-month-2019.

Stay cyber safe & have a Happy Halloween,
Rae

docs.messageSubject: Asbestos Containing Materials - Employee & Building Occupant Notification Letter 2019
docs.messageBody:
Asbestos Containing Materials

Employee & Building Occupant Notification Letter

November 2019

 Background

As a durable fire retardant material, asbestos was added to various building components such as ceiling treatments, floor tiles, plaster, fiberboard and insulation. These materials are referred to as asbestos containing materials (ACM).  ACM in good condition does not pose a health risk. When ACM becomes damaged, is disturbed or deteriorates, it can release fibers into the air. If inhaled, asbestos fibers may cause serious health problems, including asbestosis, lung cancer, and mesothelioma. The US EPA recommends that ACM be managed in place through periodic inspections and prompt repair when damage is noted.  It must be removed during building demolition/renovation or if significantly damaged.

 MOS Asbestos Program

To minimize exposure of building occupants to asbestos fibers, the Museum of Science has conducted asbestos surveys and implemented an operations and maintenance (O&M) program.  This program identifies areas with known or presumed ACM, outlines procedures to maintain ACM and identifies what to do in the event of damage to ACMs.  The O&M program, which includes locations of known ACMs in Section II, can be found on the Hub Safety page.  An asbestos awareness and other related training programs are also available.

 What You Need to Know

  • Prior to conducting renovations or work that may impact building materials such as insulation, ceiling tiles, flooring, etc., please contact the MOS asbestos coordinator, Christina Dillard cdillard@mos.org 4249, to determine the presence or absence of ACMs.  Avoid impacting or damaging any known or presumed ACMs.
  • Work with the asbestos coordinator to provide contractors with asbestos contractor notification forms and returned a signed copy to the asbestos coordinator.  Make sure contractors have also received a copy of the Contractor Health and Safety Program and return the signed acknowledgement to Christina Dillard.
  • Report damaged ACMs immediately by notifying the asbestos coordinator directly or via x0200. Do not walk through or otherwise disturb damaged ACM or ACM debris.  If possible, remove any potential sources of air disturbance and isolate the area with signage and barriers.
  • Please contact the asbestos coordinator with questions you may have regarding the ACM management program or to obtain further information regarding specific locations.

Training Sessions

On Wednesday Nov. 6, 11:00am - 12:00pm  and  Thursday Nov. 21,  11:00am - 12:00pm, training sessions will be held in Hornblower for Museum employees directly affected by the O&M program. If you have previously been required to attend and you did not already receive an invite, please let me know so I can send you the invite.

These training sessions are open to any Museum employee or volunteer who wishes to attend (just let me know so I can send you an invite) or if you have any questions or concerns please don’t hesitate to contact me.
