October 2019 Comment Cards

"I was very disappointed with my visit. Half of the second floor in the blue wing was closed and on top of that, a handful of the interactive activities did not work. I paid nearly 30 dollars for half the experience that was advertised."

"Could not get the ticket on the web site"

"It would be have been nice to know there is a parking garage  attached to your facility.    
Nothing I saw was available via info on your website ?"

"My family visited MOS on October 9 and we had a superb experience when we bought our tickets from Camden.  He engaged my oldest son with talk of Star Wars.  He and both my sons shared their favorite characters and movies.  My sons were so happy to find another Star Wars fan upon arrival!  Camden was very friendly!"

"I'd like to be able to go to your website, click on one of the Omni movies and have it tell me my options of day and time for the next month or two.  That should not be difficult for someone setting up the website to do.  Not everyone who is interested in seeing one of the Omni movies has one particular date in mind that they are planning to go to the MOS.  It often depends on what days and times the movie is being shown.  Based on that information, I would then look at my calendar and figure out a good date to go.  Please make your website more user friendly!"

"My 8-digit wristband number does not allow me to review the data I shared with you. Why is that? Each time I enter it, the next screen shows the data as eight zeroes. I definitely did participate in at least one station (and reviewed my data afterwards while I was visiting the museum)."

"I am still very angry about how I was treated yesterday by your staff. My wife and I are members of the Science Museum and we live in Belmont. We were taking our 7-year-old granddaughter to the Museum, but when we arrived to park in your garage, as we usually do,  your staff member told us the parking garage was full and offered no assistance. We asked where we could park, and they told us the closest parking was at CambridgeSide Galleria, and gestured generally in that direction. BUT, the only turn that I could make was a ""right turn only.' I let my wife and granddaughter exit the car and they went into the Museum.  I headed off to park the car, but upon turning right onto Monsignor Obrien Highway , I discovered no obvious way of getting to CambridgeSide Galleria. Also, there were no places to pull over, so I could not tap in a search for the car's GPS. I didn't want to go to the I-93 tunnel to the Airport, so I went left, hoping it would loop back, but I ended up being forced onto the Tobin Bridge and into Revere. Finally I found a place to pull over long enough to use the GPS and 35 minutes later (and after many traffic lights and confusing turns) I got to CambridgeSide Galleria. 
All of this could have been avoided IF your staff had maps to give people OR if you hired a traffic police office to allow your Members to take a left to go back towards Cambridgeside OR if you used valet parking when there is high demand.
Merely telling people to park elsewhere is not a good answer.
I am still angry with the Museum about the situation."

"Dear Boston Museum of Science,
I love all your exhibits, especially the one about space! My school came on Friday the 4th of October and I noticed that in a section of the space exhibit about firsts in space, you did not put the first woman in space. I’m in girl scouts and my troop studied the first female in space Valentina Tereshkova for an event called ""World Thinking Day."" Valentina was from a small town in Russia and she married the first person in space. I think that it is important to show women’s accomplishments as well as men’s. It would be deeply appreciated if you included the first woman in space in the space exhibit and include women in more parts of the museum. I hope that all of your exhibits keep getting better and better."

"Miriam - she was amazing! She sat with us and explained in detail the best places to visit in the museum."

"I purchased a Family membership again this year and was hoping to exchange my IMAX passes for the planetarium (Laser show) passes. As we don't see any value in the IMAX passes, I called trying to exchange them for laser show passes and were told that it is against your policy. From our perspective, we don't see the difference in value as passes for both facilities are essentially just renting chairs and don't cost the MOS any more money.  If this policy can not be changed this time around, can you change it for the next time around? Being given the flexibility to choose or exchange passes will weigh heavily on our decision to renew our membership next year.  Thank you"

“I find the use of ‘my pronouns’ by the 2 pm demonstrator of the Electricity show on Oct 13 very offensive and triggering. By saying ‘my pronouns’...I feel that this is no longer a safe space. Please refrain.”

“Truly an amazing museum. I could spend days there. In the gift shop, the Starry Sky Galaxy should be removed. It’s a disappointment. Does not work that well.”

“I am very frustrated trying to purchase tickets.  I have tried twice now, and it kicks me out before I have a chance to find all the programs I want to attend.   It is not a straight forward process and the time allotted before your purchases are wiped out is not enough time to make decisions regarding times and shows.  If you could increase the time to more than 5 minutes, it surely would help those of us trying to purchase our tickets ahead of time!!”

“My 8-digit wristband number does not allow me to review the data I shared with you. Why is that? Each time I enter it, the next screen shows the data as eight zeroes. I definitely did participate in at least one station (and reviewed my data afterwards while I was visiting the museum).”

A grandmother stopped by the info desk with a comment about the Body Worlds exhibit. She had taken her grandchildren to see it. We asked her if the kids liked the exhibit. They preferred to go back to the main museum because there was a lack of interactive components and was therefore not that interesting

“Learn how to spell ‘Pittsburgh’ if you want to be wicked smahrt”

“Very shocked that you are not giving teacher's free pass or discount w/ appropriate ID. For a museum of science it's outrageous! Not a member and will certainly not become one!”

"I have applied for several volunteer positions (posted as being open) since August and have gotten nowhere.
This is very disappointing.
It is no way to treat potential volunteers, especially ones who might be considering making sizeable donations or bequests."

"In the math section of your museum, I was looking at the wall about famous mathematicians, but didn't see Alan Turing. He in for many people one of the great mathematicians of the XXth century
Did I miss him, is this an omission, or is this intentional?"

"Hi  I am looking to buy a wall chart about 3' x 3' For The Athol Bird & Nature Club, Geology Division.   The chart is Geological Time Table    with colors like the geological maps.      Do you have any and what is there price ?"

"I think this place is very cool I love it."

Teacher called and told the representative that she thought it was ridiculous that schools have to pay for Body Worlds audio tours. They are paying over $1000 for a field trip, and she thinks the audio tours should be free.

"The AAH (Astronomy After Hours) program is very interesting with many knowledge. Please run in winter!"

“What is your reason for focusing STEM month on girls and ignoring boys?  Boys underperform girls at almost every level of schooling.”

“I like everything but the food is too expensive and the store”

“Hi, I tried to renew our membership online last night and it would not go through, no matter what we did! so I called and spoke with a person and she renewed our membership. she entered my email address just so I could receive the confirmation and the receipt. I didn't receive anything. When I tried to update my account information online, tonight the email address for our membership/account is a kiosk ....email address! and I still could not update my email address no matter how many times I went through editing the address. This is very surprising to see MOS website could not operate a simple task of updating an account! Please advice!”

“Terrible! Day old bread with my grilled cheese that was sitting out so ling it was like a brick when I bit into it, Bathroom by cafe was disgusting! Urine all over the floor. Didn't look like it was cleaned all day. Gross.”

"I just wanted to email to highlight one of your employees who really helped me out the other day. His name was Jeremy - and I called around 3:30 on Friday 10/18. I called to find out whether MOS had a discount for people in the Big Brother Big Sister Program. I was hoping to go with my little brother that evening. It turns out they do not. Jeremy then took the initiative to try to get me and my little brother free tickets to the museum immediately so I could use them that night. He went on hold multiple times trying to coordinate this and ultimately had the tickets emailed to me. I really appreciated the effort, and we had a great time. It was also super helpful because I could not have afforded to pay for two regular price tickets. Can someone please forward this to Jeremy and also his supervisor just to note that he does excellent work!” 

“I like everything but the stuff in the store are too expensive.”

As of this morning axolotls have made their debut in the Hall of Human Life! They've been doing a lot of exploring in their new digs, especially the wild types in the right-hand tank. They've been actively stirring up their sand which is giving a cloudy appearance to the water. (aka they're already establishing themselves as the troublemakers) We wanted to let everyone know this is completely normal and will eventually resolve itself. As the axolotls continue to get used to their new surroundings, the lighting will be kept dim to help them feel comfortable as they settle in. They are nocturnal by nature, so keeping darker areas in the tank will hopefully encourage more activity during the day. If you haven't checked out our new amphibious co-workers, I highly recommend swinging through HHL and introducing yourself. And for those of you who are not well versed on proper axolotl etiquette: red wiggler worms are their preferred house warming gift.

Angela

The School & Youth Programs Team is hosting the Space Exploration: Past, Present, and Future High School Science Series today, 11/14 where we will be celebrating the 50th anniversary of the Moon Landing by taking a closer look at the technology and science that helped us get there! Space is available in our unique 11:30 AM Keynote Presentation in the Planetarium, led by Sands Fish, a Designer at MIT's Space Initiative, who will tell us more about the team of over 50 graduate students, faculty, and staff actively prototyping the future of space missions and space tourism. If you'd like to join for the Keynote, please arrive to the Planetarium no later than 11:25 AM. We look forward to seeing you there!

docs.messageSubject: Internal Job Listing: Exhibit Maintenance Audio-Visual Technician
docs.messageBody:
Internal Job Postings

Paid staff positions will be posted internally for five (5) business days to give internal applicants priority during the recruitment process, in support of the Museum’s Affirmative Action Plan. All positions accepting internal applications can be found on our Internal Employment Opportunities page.

To apply, simply click on the position title below and complete the online application. If internal staff apply after the position is posted externally, they will not be considered as a candidate because they did not apply during the internal posting period.

At this time, the below listings are actively accepting internal applications:

Exhibit Maintenance Audio-Visual Technician

Responsible for the maintenance, repair and upkeep Audio Visual equipment, related wiring and lighting throughout the Museum for exhibits. Perform daily rounds of exhibit areas and exhibit components to ensure they are working properly and provide on the spot repairs when damage is found and report all existing or potential problems. Instruct other technicians in the operation and repair of audio-visual equipment. Install and maintain lighting and related lighting fixtures in both permanent and temporary exhibit galleries. Assist other technicians in the performance of their duties, including inspection rounds, exhibit installations, lighting, and other tasks as needed.

Deadline for Internal Applicants: November 20, 2019

This position is full-time, 40 hours/week, Sunday-Thursday from 8:00am -5:00pm, including most holidays and overtime as required.

Hello friends,

The Astronomy After Hours and Planetarium teams are trying to find homes for some old telescopes from our collection.

The following are available for museum program use only:

2 x Criterion 6” Newtonian reflectors with tripod and motor drive.
1 Criterion 8” Newtonian (tube only)
1 Meade 8” Newtonian with tripod and motor drive
1 Meade SSC-12 EMC 12” Schmidt-Cassegrain telescope (tube only)
1 completely unknown 8” reflector + tripod!

The attached photos give you a pretty good idea of the condition. None is in the first flush of youth. The Criterion scopes date from the 60s, the Meade Newtonian from the 80s and the Meade SCT from the early 90s. I have no idea about the other reflector, but as you can see from the photo, it is a vintage instrument!

If you have any interest in any of these scopes for your program, please contact Steve Adams (x0342) before Friday November 22.

Come help the membership department get membership cards to our new and renewing members. A couple of GSEs have been posted for this week but if those times don't work for you let us know, we are flexible.

Bring headphones if you like and if the weather is clear enjoy a great view of the Charles River.

Gang-

Education is looking for a 5-8 foot high faux fir tree to use in December. If you have one in pretty good condition that you are no longer using, could you donate it - permanently?

Thanks,
Sue Stoessel (call me at x0349 if you can schlepp it to MOS and we'll come pick up from your car!)

docs.messageSubject: Internal Job Listing: Director, Prospect Strategy & Research
docs.messageBody:
Internal Job Postings

Paid staff positions will be posted internally for five (5) business days to give internal applicants priority during the recruitment process, in support of the Museum’s Affirmative Action Plan. All positions accepting internal applications can be found on our Internal Employment Opportunities page.

To apply, simply click on the position title below and complete the online application. If internal staff apply after the position is posted externally, they will not be considered as a candidate because they did not apply during the internal posting period.

At this time, the below listings are actively accepting internal applications:

Director, Prospect Strategy & Research

The Director, Prospect Strategy and Research serves a critical role by leading the ongoing effort to grow, evaluate, and prioritize our pool of current and potential donors. This role uses best practices and evolving tools in prospect research to create and implement plans that accurately identity new prospect donors, update existing information, and recognize/manage the inclination and capacity to give to the Museum. By using this data, the Director manages the flow of prospects as well guide prospect assignments, fundraising metrics, with the overall goal to improve development effectiveness. The Director reports directly to the AVP for Advancement Operations and work closely with the Associate Vice President of Leadership and Planned Giving and the Associate Vice President of Corporate, Foundation, and Government Relations. The Director also works closely with all development officers on prospect strategy, data used for prospect development, as well as Museum Leadership to develop effective solutions to fundraising priorities.

Deadline for Internal Applicants: Wednesday, November 27, 2019

This position is full-time, 40 hours/week, Monday-Friday

Greetings, science educators!
 
Coffee Talk is coming back for the new year, and while it will feature the same educator-to-educator facetime and professional development opportunities it always has, we hope to get your feedback on changes to the format that will make it accessible for as many of you as possible! 
 
Join us at the Science Live Stage on Wednesday, December 4th from 9:00-9:30 AM to meet the team who will be bringing you Coffee Talk, hear a little bit about how to weigh in, and share any announcements you have for the upcoming vacation week.

If you don’t know what Coffee Talk is and want to know more, feel free to email coffeetalk@mos.org for more information!

Hey All,

Marketing is planning to do a fun social media post for Ugly Holiday Sweater Day and we need your help! 

If you have an ugly holiday sweater (bonus points for science or sci-fi related in someway) and are free for a quick photoshoot on 12/5, email me (nguzzo@mos.org).

Thanks!

Have you heard the buzz.... about the Museum's new Green Team? If you can commit to being a team member let me know by Nov 26th!

You should also let me know if you would rather help support our environmental ideas and initiatives and/or be called upon to be part of a subteam to make a "Green Project" a big SUCCESS.

We are seeking individuals with enthusiasm and dedication for environmental sustainability initiatives, creativity, great communication skills, and “get it done” attitudes for our new Green Team!

  • Are you passionate about Environmental Sustainability?
  • Do you have an ability to engage and energize others about Green Team initiatives? 
  • Can you commit a few hours per month to attend meetings and work on projects to promote environmental sustainability?
  • Are you ready to have fun at work while making a real difference?

 If you answered yes to these questions, The Museum’s new Green Team may be perfect for you!

 If you are interested, please review the Green Team Charter, consider your time allowances and discuss this opportunity with your supervisor. We’d really like to get right to work on some endeavors to make some effective, sustainable changes. Please let me know by Nov 26th if you can make this commitment to be a Green Team Member.

 Team member selections will be made to ensure that we effectively represent a broad and balanced representation of The Museum at all levels.

There are so many opportunities for great work to be done here; sub-teams and enthusiasts will undoubtedly be needed, so even if you can’t make a commitment at this time, but want to fulfill a supportive role helping us carry out our mission, let me know so that we can call upon you when the need arises.

 Best,

Christina Dillard

Environmental Health & Safety (EHS) Program Manager

When former astronaut Scott Kelly came to the Museum in October to receive the Washburn Award, many of us were lucky enough to spend some time with him and ask him some questions.  
Below are two photos, but feel free to browse them all at: https://flic.kr/s/aHsmJ1158X 
You're welcome to post or share wherever you like.

You may have noticed that Investigate and the Lighthouse (Blue Wing Level 2) have received a winter makeover during the last few days. Our 2nd-annual All Aboard! Trains at Science Park exhibit has arrived and transformed these spaces into the Museum of Science Station featuring four model train layouts in three different scales (HO, O, and G), and a spectacular custom MOS model by model maker John Goodson. The layouts featured have been created in collaboration with the HUB division of the Northeast Region of the National Model Railroad Association, members of which have become MOS volunteers and will be on-site throughout the duration of the display. The exhibit will be open from today, November 23, through January 7, 2020. 

The All Aboard! experience is completed with other trains-themed offerings throughout the building including the Thomas & Friends exhibit in the Art & Science gallery, the Thomas 4-D movie, the Rocky Mountain Express OMNI film, and the return of the trains-themed Cliff store. 

Come check it out! Thank you to all that have helped and please let myself or Grace Fo know if you have any questions.

Do you know a woman who is looking to transition careers or return to work after a prolonged absence?  The Museum of Science is partnering with reacHIRE to offer a free Return to Work bootcamp at the Museum on Saturday December 7.  

Our goal is to empower more women to return-to-work by giving them the tools and resources that they need to be successful. Come hear from an inspiring panel of reacHIRE alumnae who will share their stories, advice and tips from their return-to-work experience. Get prepared for your journey by participating in breakout stations that will equip you with practical return-to-work preparation and tools as well as 1:1 career consulting!

Please feel free to spread the word: https://mos-reachire-back-to-work.eventbrite.com/?aff=MOS 
Any questions, email sheilman@mos.org

November 2019 Comment Cards
 
"I am a member and the cafeteria has been bugging me for a while and after my experience today I had to say something.
I have celiac disease and none of your food is labeled for any allergies. The staff don't know either.  So I made a salad of just veggies and no dressing and I still had issues when I got home.  Likely the handling of utensils just isn't working to avoid cross contamination. This isn't the first time this has happened.  We paid 20 bucks for food that made me sick.
I also will mention how filthy the cafeteria was and how bad it smelled.
My son loves the cafe but I had to tell him in the future we can't eat there because I get sick Every time.  With all the food allergies and the Massachusetts food allergy law how are you managing this issue so badly?  I encourage you to review this soon.  It could help a lot of visitors."

"I read a troubling article about pressure on employees to upsell. I hope you value all your visitors and our opinions, and that you find ethical ways to keep the museum a healthy financial institution and encourage us all to recognize on a daily basis the humanity of those we work with, for, and among. 

"LOVED the 'Drake' show at the Charles Hayden Planetarium! I'm class of 2016 and couldn't believe I'd never stopped by the museum before. I came to visit my little brother whose still on campus and it was really a great show. 
Are there any plans to do a Frank Ocean planetarium show? Because I'd legit fly back to Boston to see it haha. 
Some feedback -- I think the selection of songs was great, but there should have been a DJ mix versus where the show highlighted verse and chorus/bridge instead of playing the full 3-5 minute song. The show felt kind of short because we only got through 5 songs since the full versions were played. Would waay rather hear more of a spread!
And the 30 minutes really flew by. Would rather the show be an hour (or at leaaaasssst 45 minutes) and would absolutely pay for an increased ticket!! 
Would've been cool to see the lasers in use. 
Overall though, really cool show and idea! It was so much fun bopping along to the songs while being totally transfixed in the animations. The artists did a great job."

"I loved the Museum and the Body World exhibit. One minor concern was that in the Body World film about Alzheimer's, 'loose' was used twice instead of 'lose'. I realize from the credits that the filmmaker and crew may not have been English as first language speakers and you may not be able to fix the grammar but it is very jarring, especially when at the museum with a learning child."

"Good morning-  my wife and I just attended our 3rd MOS 'Experience' in the planetarium. On Friday we went to the opening night of the Drake Experience with our friends after having gone to Rihanna and Beyonce. While we're huge Drake fans, we left feeling slightly underwhelmed by the whole thing. In fact, one of our friends fell asleep briefly during the performance. I'm not sure if this is the right space to voice this type of feedback but I do have some specific notes that may be helpful. If possible I'd love to talk to someone in this department to exchange some ideas. Thanks!"

"Enjoyed the exhibit. You showed consequences of smoking and cancer. Would be interesting to see a body that has had drug abuse."

"I'm a MOS member and often bring my 3.5 year old to the museum. I'm writing because the new Thomas exhibit leaves a lot to be desired. We visited the exhibit in Springfield this summer and were enchanted by the experience which had plenty of room and trains to play with. We have now been disappointed twice at the MOS by the exact same exhibit. Each time we've visited there have not been enough trains, too many children, and absolutely no crowd control by the MOS. We are now not coming to the MOS because the Thomas exhibit is a huge draw for my son, but is very stressful because of the number of children and the lack of space and available activities. It leads to my son being overwhelmed and both of us being quite cranky by the end. It is unreasonable to expect that a bunch of 2-5 year olds are going to be rational, sharing tiny people. This is compounded, in my experience, by lack of parental attention--parents seem to just sit on the benches and let the children go. I'm surprised that the MOS is just letting this exhibit, essentially, run by itself.
Here's my suggestion: much like the Discovery Center, I think you should have museum employees in the room, a cap on how many people can participate at any time, and more trains! Some guidance for caregivers to help set behavior expectations with the children would be great too.
Thanks for considering this feedback."

"Nice Exhibits
-Inconsistancy I found:
The ivory-billed woodpecker sighting in AK in 2005 was a _false sighting_ - what the people saw was actually a pileated woodpecker"

"As a longtime supporter of the museum, I was very upset to hear about the recent 'upsell' practices.  This is NOT how the museum should operate and I'm appalled.”

"Suit/Cabot lab was awesome! Very interactive for 2 kids and 2 adults. Both employee/engineer women were very helpful, knowledgeable, and friendly. Thanks for a great experience."

"it would be great to have two evenings per week where only adults have/get permission to the exhibit hall"

"I would like to know Y the Steam Engine in the Basment of the Blue wing does not have a deminstration Everything seams to Be there for it to work"

"It would be nice to have gates at the staircase inside the discovery center (both top and bottom of stairs). It would keep the young kids safer and parents can be more at ease. It would also prevent young kids from throwing balls and items down the steps."

"Had an amazing time at the Museum of Science - Anime Boston Weekend yesterday. I met some awesome people and your employee Megan (the one dressed as Pikachu) was a lifesaver. She helped me figure out where to go in the museum and how the event was run along with giving me a lot of information. She was very warm, inviting and patient. I've been to the museum several times over the years but not enough that I would remember where everything was by heart. Plus, this is the very first time I went on my own. Every other time was with a tour or a group of some kind, so it meant a lot to have someone greet you like that. I saw a lot of truly wonderful things. I even entered a contest too! (Didn't win, came darn close though lol.) Honestly, it was a lot of fun and I've always loved the museum. Seriously can't wait to go back again sometime!"

"I am very disappointed to read in the Boston Globe about how badly the MOS treats its front office staff.  I have had many contacts with the ticket office and found them to be very helpful.  After my membership expires, I will continue to visit the museum but only pay for the exact items I need for that visit.
You have no idea how bad this looks.”  

"Nice place! :)
Enjoying my visit :)"

"It was great to see the energy and recycling exhibits.
I also like the compostable french fry container at the grill. But I saw no composting bin, nor paper recycling bin.
Those would be great."

"I just renewed my membership. We should have been told this before we renewed."

"Pink Floyd - Great show..enjoyed it! Bring back Led Zeppelin!"

"Wonderful! Body World!! One misspelling - prostate gland (almost end of exh.) 'because of IT'S proximity to the rectum...' WRONG please correct Thx!"

"I loved the new body exhibit in the red wing. There was a video streaming about how Alzheimer's affects the brain.  There was an alarming misspelling in the video, however. in a few places, the text had spelled the word 'lose' as 'loose'."

"We were at the museum yesterday and had a wonderful time. The only problem we had was with parking. We had all of our tickets validated and we paid for the at the kiosk ($5) but then we were also charged an additional amount when we checked out. It added a lot of cost to our field trip."

“This experience was absolutely amazing. The video is only one of many
I do not know her name, The guide/teacher was great. I was so enchanted by the butterflies, I couldn't pay attention to what she was saying! You can hear her on the video.
I can't thank you enough."

"Caught an animal show about camouflage given by Lisa on the afternoon of the 15th. It was a great show, very well put together. Lisa was able to answer a slew of questions as we hung around after the show.  Later in the Hall of Human Life we had an engaging interactive about bones with the volunteer Grant. It was thorough, analytical, and enjoyable."

"I would be interested if you could show 'Extreme Weather' again in the future. I missed it first time out i heard great things about it and it must be great if it's only being shown to schools and the such.......i would love to hear from you ......"

"It would be great if the museum would house a permanent copy of ""Apollo 11 (2019)"" in IMAX format. The documentary consists of restored film from NASA and the National Archives. 
"We love coming here, but I noticed in the Natural Mysteries Room there are a couple drawers mixed up. The echinodrem and the turtle drawer are swapped on the top big drawer and the items are swapped in the small drawers below."

"Any chance of getting a traveling TITANIC Exhibit to come to the Boston Museum of Science? I know they had one in Portland, Maine in 2016. Please add my email if you do plan to sponsor such an exhibit. Thank You"

"I came to see the museum and the employee at the Ticket area was very rude and condescending to me when I Present my retired military identification... Very unprofessional! Is this how your organization responds to the men and women that were willing to lay down their life for the country. Very disrespectful!  This is the birth place of the revolution!  You have got to do better!"

"I visited the MOS on Friday, 11/22. There was an issue with my transaction at the box office with my tickets. William came to the rescue and handled the situation professionally, pleasantly and efficiently. We were about to walk out until he came over and fixed the problem!!!"

" I sent the email below to the information@mos.org address. I received a response from Kelly later that day that my email was being forwarded to the web team. I just wanted to check in to see if there is any update regarding this issue. It would be a real shame to lose functional access to such a great website. I tried to email the information@mos.org address again, but my email would not go through.
Original Email:
I wanted to contact you about an activity on your website that I have used for years. The original link is: https://legacy.mos.org/quest/et/. However, when you go to that link, it states that the page has been retired. I can view it on the Wayback Machine, but the interactive simulation feature of the activity no longer works. This activity is one of my favorites of our entire ancient Egypt unit, and students really love it, too. Is there another way to access it with its full functionality?"

"Hello, I would like to reflect and submit some suggestions about the show at the planetarium dubbed 'The Drake Experience'. The ticket price was great, but you certainly only got $10 worth of an experience which should not be called 'The Drake Experience'. VITAL tracks from his discography through his illustrious career were left out (Marvin’s Room and Ice Melts being only 2 of the many). The visuals were entertaining to an extent however I felt as though the exhibit needed to adhere to the taste of the viewers in terms of the visual experience. It didn’t really go with the music, and there were many missed opportunities that myself and many others highlighted upon leaving. I also wouldn’t recommend following Find Your Love with Hotline Bling. That’s just a mess. If you have a job opening please forward me the info, you need my playlist. I could bring some much needed zest to the party."

Mike and the Store Team

Hi museum friends!

As some of you may know, Exhibit Innovation Projects is currently leading a grant-funded program in which teen staff build their science research, education and communication skills through the lens of Living Laboratory research. Under mentorship from Boston University and MOS mentors, these teens have been developing child development research studies to be run with families visiting the museum.

One of the studies the teens are developing is related to children’s judgments of others’ sharing behaviors. To be able to run this study, the teens are looking for children between the ages of 5 and 8 years who would be willing to be actors in a short video, in which they would model playing a game that would be shown to other child participants who come to the museum. Children would be asked to sit in front of a machine that dispenses Skittles into bowls, and pull a specific lever to dispense the candies in a certain way (that is either advantageous or disadvantageous to themselves).

If you have or know of any children who would be interested in being videotaped for this study, please email rfyler@mos.org. The total time needed to film would be about 20 minutes, and we are happy to work with whatever schedule is best for you (including weekends). All child actors would be compensated with a small gift for contributing to this research project!

Thanks for your consideration, Rachel

School & Youth Programs is hosting all of Fenway High School for their Senior Science Fair at the Museum tomorrow, Friday, 12/6. While the 9-11th graders will be exploring the exhibit halls, the Seniors will be presenting their projects in the Blue Wing Well from 9:30 AM - 11:30 AM. Some of the Seniors are former and current youth volunteers, interns, and staff. We invite you to stop by to view the projects, ask questions, and offer words of encouragement as the Seniors complete a major milestone in their path to graduation. If you have any questions regarding this event please feel free to reach out to Meghan Carter (mcarter@mos.org) or Christina Moscat (CMoscat@mos.org).

I'm posting this for a friend who recently moved to Cambridge and has had to downsize their furniture to fit into a smaller apartment.  Let me know if you're interested and I can give you more info and connect you  (sheilman@mos.org)

1. Queen size sleeper sofa, dark red, $300 obo
2. Queen size storage bed frame with 8 huge drawers, gray, $400 obo
3. Dining room set, table and 4 chairs, $200 obo

- - - - - - -
QUEEN SIZE SLEEPER SOFA, RED, $300 obo

This sofa extends into a queen size bed. Dark burgundy red with big soft back cushions and plush fabric. The seat cushions are pleasantly firm and slightly springy. No stains, bare spots, rips, or runs in the fabric. The mechanism that slides the bed in and out works perfectly. I bought this new for over $800.

The mattress is like new; I rarely used it, and when I did, I protected it with a mattress pad and memory foam topper. I’m including the queen-size, 3" thick, memory foam mattress topper with the sofa. It makes the thin mattress much more comfortable.
- - - - - - -

QUEEN SIZE BED STORAGE BED FRAME, GRAY, $400 obo
Platform bed frame with 8 built-in drawers, excellent condition. Mattress not included. This platform bed is upholstered in gray fabric with a suede-like feel. I bought this new for $1500 from.  The generously sized drawers give the bed frame an amazing storage capacity. They are built into 2 fully assembled boxes that hook side by side to form the bed platform. Also includes a headboard. So the bed comes in 3 pieces for relatively easy transport and storage.
- - - - - - -
DINING TABLE AND CHAIRS, $200
Dining set made from dark hardwood with 4 cushioned ladder-back chairs. I bought this new for $650.  A cool thing about this table is that it has a hidden drawer at one end where you can store placemats, utensils, a secret stash, or whatever you like.

The Engineering Design Workshop will be hosting Computer Science Education Weekend (CSEdWeekend) again this year! We celebrate CSEdWeekend each year to honor Admiral Grace Hopper's birthday (December 9th) and to cap off Computer Science Education Week, a national initiative put on by code.org. This is a great opportunity to bring in local computer scientists and roboticists to display their interactive and innovative work in our Community Alley, and to highlight our computer science-focused programming to a building packed with excited visitors. During this time the Engineering Design Workshop will be closed to focus on our Community Alley and computer science activities. 

Activities occurring Saturday, December 14th and Sunday, December 15th include: 
-Squishy Circuits, Suit/Cabot Lab, Red Wing, Lower Level (10:00 a.m. – 12:00 p.m.)
-Fun with Mazes ‘n’ Microbits, Green Wing, Level 2 (10:00 a.m. – 12:30 p.m.)
-Building Circuits, Suit/Cabot Lab, Red Wing, Lower Level (2:00 – 4:00 p.m.)
-Set It Up, Natural Mysteries, Lower Level (10:30 a.m. – 12:30 p.m.)
-Grip with Code, Hall of Human Life, Green Wing, Level 2 (11:00 a.m. – 3:00 p.m.)
-Fruit Loops Programming Maze, Green Wing, Level 2 (2:00 – 4:00 p.m.)
-Engineering Design Workshop Prototypes, Behind the Scenes, Blue Wing, Level 1
-KIBO, Blue Wing, Lower Level 
-Dash, Blue Wing, Level 1
-Local Roboticists and Computer Scientists, Blue Wing, Lower Level
-The Music, Perception, and Robotics Lab at WPI, CS&T Stage, Saturday only (12:30 p.m.)
-Boston Dynamics, Blue Wing, Lower Level, Sunday only (10:00 a.m. – 1:00 p.m.)
-The New England Robotics Validation and Experimentation (NERVE) Center, CS&T Stage, Sunday only (12:30 p.m.)

There are also volunteer opportunities! If you would like to help out during the weekend, shifts are available both days from 9:30 a.m.-1:00 p.m. and from 12:30 p.m.-4:00 p.m. Shifts include free lunch and free t-shirt, and you can help with activity facilitation, wayfinding, registration, swag giveaway, etc. If you are interested in volunteering, please sign up here: tinyurl.com/csed2019volunteer

GSEs are also available, so feel free to sign up on BOTH the Google form and the GSE page if you'd like a GSE. Hope to see you there!

docs.messageSubject: Collecting Donations to Support Survivors of Partner Abuse
docs.messageBody:
Hello dear Museum folks,

This year the MOS marched in the Pride Parade for the 1st time! Yay! Another way of supporting LGBQ/T+ communities is by donating to organizations that provide support to survivors of partner abuse that is specifically catered to these identities. As a member of the board of directors at The Network/ La Red, I am proud to be raising money for one of the nations ONLY 24/7 hotline and service that is oriented towards caring for and supporting LGBQ/T+ survivors. Every dollar and share is a HUGE support, and through Friday each dollar is matched up to $30,000! If you feel compelled to support, I will be extremely grateful.



https://interland3.donorperfect.net/weblink/weblink.aspx?name=E147294&id=14&cfifid=20
If you're interested in seeing The Nutcracker this holiday season, the Boston Ballet has extended a 20% off discount for certain December dates by using code BAG2019.

docs.messageSubject: Weekly Logistics Meetings to Resume on Wed., Jan. 8, 2020
docs.messageBody: Today's weekly logistics meeting was the last for this holiday season. We will resume meeting every Wednesday beginning again on January 8th, 10 AM, in Hodge. Happy holidays!

docs.messageSubject: High School Science Series: Video Game Technology and Development
docs.messageBody:
Have you ever wondered how video games are made? And how does someone get into that for a career? Do you want to play video games at work?! Join us for our High School Science Series this morning to learn more!

From 10-12, visit 20 Northeastern undergraduate students as they present the first half of their year-long capstone game development projects out on the Exhibit Halls, Blue Wing, Level 1. They'll be play-testing them for anyone who comes by and would love to chat about their process, answer any of your questions, and take feedback as they move into their second semester of the project!

Then at 11am, join us in Cahners Theater for a panel on video game development, with three indie developer panelists: Chaima Jemmali (Northeastern University), Réjon Taylor-Foster (Maximum Crash), and Chris Hart (Boston Unity Group). If you could, please use the back entrance to Cahners by the stairs, as we'll be filing in 250 high schoolers through the main entrance. The panel will conclude around 11:45. Hope to see you there!

docs.messageSubject: Education & Exhibits - Cookie Contest & Food Drive
docs.messageBody:
For many of us the holidays are a time for giving, eating, and celebration. This event is one way for us to do all three, while getting to know our colleagues across the Education and Exhibits Divisions and beyond. You can bake cookies, eat cookies and vote for your favorites with donations of canned and dried goods to the Greater Boston Food Bank. Donation boxes are available in the center of the Gordon Wing near the stairs. See below for the most needed items.

What: Holiday Cookie Contest 2019!
When: Tuesday, December 17th 2:00pm – 4:00pm
Where: The entire Gordon Wing!

Beginning at 2:00pm, unveil your cookies, explore the Gordon Wing and try other’s cookies (Don’t forget Traveling Programs and School & Youth Programs up near the Enclave). Vote by leaving a donation in the donation box at each pod using donation items you bring that day. Each donation item is one vote. Vote as many times as you wish. Whoever collects the most donations wins! Prizes include bragging rights and a spectacular holiday trophy.

**If you forget to bring a donation item on the 17th, feel free to snag a few items that have already been donated so that you can cast your votes. Donations have been accumulating these last couple of weeks in the boxes at the entrance to the Gordon Wing.

Greater Boston Food Bank Donation Guidelines:
MOST DESIRED NON-PERISHABLE (CANNED OR DRIED):
•	Protein: Tuna fish, chicken, salmon, beans, peanut butter, low-sodium soups & stews, nuts
•	Vegetables: Low-sodium vegetables, tomato products, spaghetti sauce
•	Fruit: Dried fruit, applesauce, any canned fruit in its own juice
•	Whole Grains: Crackers, oatmeal, whole grain rice, pasta, low sugar/high fiber cereal (Cheerios, Raisin Bran, etc.)
•	Dairy: Dried, evaporated, and boxed shelf stable milk
GENERAL GUIDELINES:
•	We accept all non-perishable (not frozen or refrigerated), sealed, unexpired food.
•	We also accept unopened toiletries (shampoo, soap, shaving cream, etc.) – these should be kept separate from any food donations.
•	We prefer non-glass containers for the safety of our volunteers.
•	We cannot accept baby food or pet food from a food drive.

docs.messageSubject: Trains and Polar Express on Chronicle
docs.messageBody: For anyone who missed it, the Museum was featured on Chronicle last night, highlighting our exhibit, All Aboard! Trains at Science Park, and the Polar Express 4D! Mike Horvath, Robin Doty, and a few of the volunteers from the HUB Division are featured, so be sure to check it out here: https://www.wcvb.com/article/all-aboard-these-model-trains/30213581

Last week, the organizational team behind the revival of Coffee Talk gave a brief presentation at the Science Live Stage. We discussed the history of Coffee Talk as an informal professional development opportunity to spend some face-time with people from all over the building and to share knowledge that can help us all become better science ambassadors.
 
Whether or not you have ever attended Coffee Talk in the past, we hope that you can give us 5 to 10 minutes of your time to take the survey here https://tinyurl.com/vjwuuv9 on or before Tuesday, December 17th.
 
The 14 total questions have to do with your past experience, including attending and presenting at Coffee Talk, as well as your interest in future topics and formats. There are three pages total, though your middle page will depend on your response to a question about whether you have presented at Coffee Talk in the past.
 
Even and perhaps especially if you have never been to Coffee Talk, your input is welcome! Our hope is to grow and widen the scope of this professional development opportunity to include as many of our staff as possible. Your response is fully anonymous and does not require signing in. The more answers you can give us, the better armed we will be to set up Coffee Talk 2.0 for the new year!
 
Please take the survey linked above by Tuesday, December 17th to weigh in on what Coffee Talk looks like in 2020!
 
Thank you so much,
Team Coffee Talk
Arga Yunus, Engineering Design Workshop
Eric O'Dea, Live Presentations
Lindsey Kolenda, Discovery Center
Meghan Carter, School and Youth Programs
Nicole Merullo, Hall of Human Life
Rachel Fyler, Exhibit Innovation Projects
Sarah Weiner, Live Presentations
Steve Adams, Exhibit Hall Interpretation

Change in Coat Room Availability

Starting this winter, the Coat Room will be open for selected holiday weekends, school vacation weeks, and upon advance request for special events. And, as always, we are happy to assist guests with items that do not fit in the lockers – please direct them to the Information Desk for assistance. Please let me know if you have any questions. 

Wendy x0213

docs.messageSubject: Deck The Halls 2.0:   The Best Way to Spread Holiday Cheer is Decorating Loud This Time of Year!
docs.messageBody:
Advancement’s holiday competition is back!  Tomorrow, Thursday the 19th, each Advancement team will have 2 hours to decorate their area of the 4th floor.  We then invite you—our Museum colleagues—to see what we’ve created and vote for your favorite.

docs.messageSubject: Computer Science Education Weekend - Thank You!
docs.messageBody: Thank you to the 60 volunteers who helped the Engineering Design Workshop team put on Computer Science Education Weekend (CSEdWeekend) last weekend! We hosted 15 local computer science and robotics companies in our Community Alley and on the CS&T stage, and with your help managed to run 12 different programming, robotics, and circuitry activities around the building. We heard from so many visitors how much fun they had trying out all the different activities and visiting Community Alley, and we couldn't have done it without you all. Thank you again!

Check out our half-day Job Fair Representative GSEs in 2020! Meet job and internship seekers in our community and share your experiences as a Museum of Science employee.
January 22: Veteran Networking Event at Northeastern University February 14: Tufts Spring Career Fair February 28: MassArt Internship & Job Fair April 7: Lesley University Career & Internship Fair
See the GSE schedule for all details. More events to follow.
Please contact Katie Cooper at kacooper@mos.org or x0436 if you have any questions. Thank you!

Say goodbye to 2019 by helping membership send out memberships cards. 

GSEs have been posted for Monday and Tuesday. Timing is flexible so please contact me if you have any questions.

As we approach the end of the calendar year, the Advancement division is seeking your help in pushing out our final campaign of the year! All funds raised through this campaign, #ScienceMatters, will support the Museum’s Forums and National Collaborations program, which creates opportunities for everyone to learn, discuss, and participate in conversations around emerging science topics. Everyone has a voice to share, and all should feel empowered to participate in these conversations. A gift to this campaign today will help us continue these important discussions and ensure we are prepared for what the future holds. 

Please share and invite others to join our facebook fundraising campaign, which can be found here: https://www.facebook.com/donate/538244106763828/?fundraiser_source=external_url

You can also give by visiting www.mos.org/sciencematters, or by texting “GIVEMOS” to 4141. 

Thank you in advance for your help in making this campaign a success!

Last chance to come see this year's "All Aboard! Trains at Science Park" exhibit before it leaves the station next Tuesday, January 7. 
The exhibit will be packed and loaded out on Wednesday and Thursday, January 8th and 9th. Investigate and the Lighthouse exhibits will reopen on Saturday, January 18th. 

Please let myself or Grace Fo know if you have any questions. 
Julia (x0287)

Item For Sale!

Log Holder with Canvas Tote-brand new-never opened-(well only opened for someone to view the size) --$15.00

Call me at ext. 0377 or email me at agermaine@mos.org

December 2019 Comment Cards

"The Drake Experience?  Considering that he's under investigation for Child Molestation and a host of related charges, isn't this a bad offering for the Museum?
Please reconsider this."

"two emails from a member account:
1. The Mugar Omni Theatre is the reason I join but I almost can't stand to watch the films because the introduction is so unbearable. It's silly and undignified, unworthy of the majestic films. A silly tittering woman's voice with a silly little laugh and a little cough - the only explanation I can find is that this particular woman donated a million dollars to the museum? and if she has to explain who Leonard Nimoy is, maybe it's time to retire him!
Honestly, it's so annoying it's unbearable especially when going to two in a row which my friend and I like to do. Please please please, if you are renovating the theatre, please renovate the intro as well!
If you don't believe me, try sitting through it ten times in a row, you will be out of your mind . . .

2. Please, since you are updating the Omni theater, could you please also update the introduction?  Most of the sounds are nice, but the final crash is really disturbing, and for this sound to then be followed by 'now sit back, relax,...' is not at all relaxing."

"Please, would you mind having a stool or boost in the bathrooms so kids can reach the water when they're washing their hands? Thank you!"

"Please keep Leonard Nimoy's voice in the renovated theater!!!"

"The purpose of this email is to inform your organization of the concerning experience I had. I attempted to take two friends to see the Polar Express 4D experience.  I purchased tickets online, with no issue, receiving mobile tickets.  The ticket stated: Bring this confirmation directly to the entrance; displayed on your mobile device or printed at home.
The three of us, one a child, took a bus and three trains to get to the museum.  Upon arrival we were told that we needed to purchase an additional $90 worth of tickets to gain entry to the museum, just to see the show.  The time was 7pm, and with the museum closing soon, it seemed like nothing short of a scam.
Not only did this experience waste 3 hours of my time in transit, the customer service experience was quite poor.  When I asked the box office attendant why I was able to purchase tickets online without notification of needing to spend additional money to gain entry, the reply was, 'I don't know, I didn't design the website.'
The box office attendant refunded my money for the 4D experience, and commented that this ticketing issue 'happens all the time'.  It is incredibly concerning that MoS- a museum of science and technology- would have such a poorly designed web store algorithm, to the point that customers are not made aware of the additional ticketing requirements until arriving to the facility.
I grew up going to the MoS.  I credit my childhood experiences at the MoS with guiding me into a career in science.  It is appalling that an organization I am so fond of would knowingly treat it's customers in a dishonest manner, in an attempt to make money."

“I had opportunity to see the Body World exhibit yesterday. What I found very disturbing (and I realize the exhibit was not created by MOS) was the initial part that showed faces aging over time. All of the faces portrayed were those of white/light-skinned people. As an older white man, I find this extremely troubling and cannot imagine what it would be like for children, youth, and adults of color to be confronted with this. I wish this had been different as it had a negative impact on me as I started the exhibit which had many impressive aspects. I would hope that MOS program staff would attend to who gets included/portrayed (and how) and who is excluded in any exhibits there.”

 “Hi, Please please please consider bringing back the Fleetwood Mac Experience show to the Planetarium please please I wasn't able to see it when it was out please bring it back I would appreciate it so much. Even if it's for one or two weeks. Please bring it back soon.
Thank you”

“PLEASE DO AN OASIS PLANETARIUM MUSIC SHOW!!!!!!!!”

“Hello,
I visited Body Worlds & The Cycle of Life.
I was learning so much there that I almost missed my train home. 
I am a former physics instructor, and I'd like to mention two things that concern me about the exhibit.
They both involve the concepts of force and pressure.
First, the section of the exhibit section that shows how to properly lift with one's legs seems to say that pressure is measured in pounds. That is not correct. Pressure can be measured in pounds per square inch, newtons per square meter, and other ways. But pressure is not measured in pounds; force is measured in pounds.
Second, the section on blood pressure seems to say that blood pressure is a force. That is not correct.
Pressure is force per unit area, but it is not just force.
As you probably know, many Americans think that they can have their own truth.
When considering the difference between force and pressure (at least), they are wrong.
I realize that you probably cannot change the exhibit before it ends in January.
I hope, however, that you will find this information helpful and that you will pass it on to anyone who will host Body Worlds in the future.
Thank you”

“Not obvious how to apply my free membership Omni passes.  Got to checkout and did not see.”

“I am hereby notifying you that when our membership comes around again for renewal we do not wish to renew.
I am completely horrified at the Body World Exhibit.  There are no words.  It strikes me as disrespectful and ghoulish.  Don't tell me 'it's educational'.  It is being presented as 'entertainment' and a revenue generator.  I, for one, am not entertained.  So my money next year will be spent on a membership to the Museum of Fine Arts.
Thank you.”

 “Hello,
I just wanted to write a note and say that we are not renewing our membership this year because we have tried to go at least 15 times during the last 2 years, during which w were premier members, and the garage was full EVERY time. We couldn't park anywhere else close enough to walk over in inclement weather, so the membership was really a waste of money. Not to mention the wasted drive there each time. 
There should be parking spots reserved for members and a spot should be available for purchase online. 
We'll miss you.”

“I recently purchased a membership for my boyfriend who started going to the museum while waiting for me at work in Boston. We live in Rhode Island. He was obsessed with going to Body Worlds and I know there is so much more to see!
We did attend Body Worlds. While on a break getting coffee at ""Starbucks"" cafe I bought a pack of little crackers labeled $1.60 approx. I was billed $3.something on my debit card!
I complained on Twitter - Dec. 2nd- but, absolutely no reply there. (If you have a Twitter acct., I feel you really should monitor it.) I copied the Attorney General.
So, I had to slog out this email instead. 
Please do not allow this to happen to others. PLEASE MAKE MORE CLEAR that you vending machine is there for the purpose of ripping people OFF. What about a pack of .25 cent crackers makes them $3.00 there?? It's not Martha's Vineyard. 
Please find a way to answer me and return my money.”

"I would like to see a new membership level that includes everything with premier 8, but with more tickets included for Butterfly garden/4D theater and/or temp exhibit tickets."

"I was visiting the museum on 12/17/19 and at the Thomas train exhibit at around 11am. An employee (or volunteer?) named Steve spent over an hour with my 3 year old daughter! The patience, kindness, and attention he showed was incredible as he played and read to her. As a museum member, that was our best experience so far and it all because of the time Steve spent interacting with my child!"

"The GIFT Shop is a 'huge' disappointment! It looks like a toy store. Really will a baby know where the pink or blue stuffed whatever came from the MOS> Where are all the informative Books & Materials for those over 12 years old?
No Reply needed just action please"

"I'm writing with a comment about the Discovery Center. We often feel like there's a problem with the algorithm that governs how many people enter. We applaud the idea of limiting access over time so it doesn't get too crowded. The day we were there however, we were told it was too crowded but that we could go in after about 15 minutes; once we got in, we found there were no more than 25 people in the area, on both floors combined, and we could see through the door that families were still being turned away. We told one of the volunteers, who went outside to tell the person monitoring the area to let more people in, but it feels like there's a flaw in the system. There's so much space in there; families shouldn't be turned away until there are at least 50-75 people in there. That's especially the case because being families who are turned away are usually going to go into the main exhibit area, and it's not an easy process for families with small children to hoof it to the main exhibit area and find something to do and then turn around and hoof it back to the Discovery Center -- and that's if they receive the notification text, which itself sometimes doesn't work, as we've found (by asking if it was our turn after our estimated wait time had elapsed, only to find out that we'd been sent a text that we never received)."


“Last I was there was during the BiCentennial I am a fan of Star Wars , just today I'd seen an article showing a Naboo Starfighter on display, but it was from 2005, my loss would there be any way of knowing what happened to that exhibit?”

"I loved the microscopic water bears and looking at the microscope. I LOVED the colored pencil close-up. SO COOL & FUN! (Hands on Lab)"	

"Hi I think the museum is awesome! the new body worlds is SUPER COOL! :)	

"Your Membership web site needs some serious work:
1) The account can only be linked to a single member on the membership, despite have 2 members on the card.  
2) Resetting the password only prompts ONCE for a new password, and doesn't ask you to verify or retype it in any way.  And it's obscured, with no way to see cleartext.  How am I to know if I typed the new password in correctly?  
3) There are multiple email addresses associated with the account.  I can set preferences for them, but I can't delete any of them?  Why can't I manage my email addresses?
4) While I can edit the info for [my individual record], I can't edit or change any associated person on the membership.  Why not?
Having a background in web development, I know this is basic stuff that I would expect handled in this day and age.  And as an institute promoting STEM, I would think you'd want a less frustrating experience for your members."

"please put agates on display like Molly of Denali"

“Goodmorning,
 This email is regarding the disappointment we had in your David Bowie Laser show. I thought it may have been just me and I hadn't seen a show in a couple of years but after people were walking out, it made it clear that it wasn't what most thought was going to be lasers, lights, LIVE laser made images. The other unfortunate part was this was the person I brought, First time. He'd like to go to the museum, can you honor our tickets to allow him a good experience? “


“Can you purchase tickets for the laser shows at the door or at the museum it self? Before the show starts can you buy tickets?”

"As a member of the MOS for 8 years, I am utterly dissapointed and disgusted with the process/procedure for the wait list to enter the Discovery Center. Staff member says they wait 15 mins for a family to arrive, and then would text the next family. At #20 on the list, how long would that take us to enter? 5 hrs? 3 hrs? There are many better solutions!
P.S. The wait has never seemed this impossible before!”

"In the bird section there is a wrong ID. It says red-winger warbler when the birds are red-winged blackbirds. also the last nuimber of each column is cut off o the ID sheets."

"A visitor stopped me (staff in red coat) to say they're big train enthusiasts and they really liked this year's All Aboard. Much better than last year's. Family (of 4) came to MOS for this."

"I would like to share my experience with the vending machine I chanced to use towards the evening. The vending machine 'accepts' dimes and quarters but doesn't give any credit towards them. Cancelling the transaction doesn't return the money either since the machine wanted me to make a purchase first. I had to insert more paper currency to pay for my snacks. On completion of the transaction the machine returns the balance in coins excluding the amount that I had put through the coin slot earlier.
I've been deprived of some cash by the machine and intend to get it back. I would like your help in this matter by providing the manufacturer's contact number and make of the machine as well as the business that has installed it there. These can usually be found near the payment terminal on the machine or the glass in front of the snacks. It's the snacks vending machine between the two beverage machines right next to the riverside café in the red wing. I'm informed that complaints of this nature are taken seriously in the industry. I earnestly request your assistance in this matter."

"1. DoD has started a Digital Engineering Strategy (DES) that uses models to prototype systems before construction. This might be something to try in your engineering workshop.
2. You might want to contact STEM From Dance, a NYC program that uses dance to intriduce girls to STEM This would make for an interesting presentation
3. The Mathematica history did not include lt. Wronski. He is a minor mathematician but he did develop the Wronskian, that is used for differential equations
4. The brain teasers of the Winter 2020 Bent of Tau Beta Pi has a problem to develop a formula to calculate the sun's angle at noon for all the days of the year. This might be an interesting addition to the Mathematica exhibit"

docs.messageBody:
Internal Job Postings

At this time, the below listings are actively accepting internal applications:

Director, Theaters and Attractions

The Director of Theaters and Attractions will oversee the Museum's digital IMAX giant screen dome theater (the Mugar Omni Theater), the 4-D Theater, Thrill Ride 360 (a venue consisting of two MaxFlight motion simulators), and is responsible for current and future revenue generating ancillary amenities and attractions. This position blends content selection and scheduling, industry advocacy, venue oversight, technical systems expertise, and business analysis and strategy in the direction of key museum venues serving 400,000 to 500,000 visitors per year and generating $2 million + in annual revenue.

Deadline for Internal Applicants: Wednesday, January 8, 2020

This role normally works Monday – Friday but also requires schedule flexibility with availability for occasional evening and weekend work and availability during the Museum's busy school vacation and holiday periods.

Help the forum team test out their new forum!

We are working with local community partners to create a new forum all about how to readapt and use space in Boston, including what kind of housing people want to be built in their community. 

Join us and have a conversation with other museum staff members on various space use and housing options that could transform our neighborhoods.

docs.messageSubject: "Thomas & Friends: Explore the Rails" Closes Next Week
docs.messageBody:
This week will be our last week hosting Thomas & Friends (in the Blue Wing, Level 2 gallery near the Butterfly Garden). 

Sunday, January 12 will be the last day that the exhibit will be open to the public, and the deinstall will begin promptly on Monday, January 13.

Thank you to all those who made the exhibit possible, and kept everything running smoothly through a hectic holiday season!

Please remember if you need to request to have your department use the Blue Wing exhibit hall from July 1, 2020 - June 30, 2021 in the evenings ONLY. Please remit your requests to nyang@mos.org by Wednesday, January 8th. 

TO: Museum Management Team and Museum Event Planners
FROM: Sheryl White Vincent, Director, Event and Conference Services
Re: July 2020 – June 2021 Space Sharing
Date: Thursday, November 21, 2019
Please forward this to staff in your department that plan(s) events using the Blue Wing exhibit halls.
Why so far ahead?

Revenue generating departments such as Event & Conference Services, the catering division of our in-house food service vendor Wolfgang Puck, and Overnights must make revenue projections for the next fiscal year budget based on what they have to sell, namely the Blue Wing. Other departments such as Advancement and Lectures & Special Programs also need to budget and plan for the upcoming year. Departments that do not plan and schedule as far out can find themselves with out a Blue Wing date for their upcoming event. While everyone tries to be flexible, it becomes difficult once commitments are made to budgets and contracts. This group is aware that dates do change for exhibit openings and thus space sharing negotiations do happen through out the year to accommodate event schedules.

Next Steps
Each department that requires the use of the Blue Wing (including Cahners Theater or CS&T) during non-public hours between July 1, 2019 and June 30, 2020 must identify their needs NOW.
We are striving to identify the MUST have needs now, meaning if you “think” you might need a date, but you are really not sure, please don’t ask for it. The calendar will be open for those additional requests moving forward, so holding a date for just in case is not necessary.

If you cannot target an exact date, please communicate the day of the week and the month of your activity or event. Activities such as exhibit installations, construction and large set-ups must be scheduled as well.
This information is due to Nora Yang (mailto:nyang@mos.org) by 5pm on January 8th. Thereafter, the Space Sharing Task Force will meet to review requests for the Blue Wing. It is the intention of this group to allocate Blue Wing dates by January 31st

docs.messageSubject: Annual Hazardous Waste Trainings on 1/22 or 1/30 1-2pm in Cahners Theater
docs.messageBody:
Annual Hazardous Waste Management/Minimization Training Sessions have been scheduled for:

Wed Jan 22 1pm-2pm or

Thu Jan 30 1pm-2pm

If you work with Hazardous Materials that may become Hazardous Waste, or you supervise someone that generates Hazardous Waste, you must attend an annual hazardous waste training session. If you are not required to attend, but would like to better understand what hazardous waste is and how to properly handle and dispose of it then please attend. Email me at cdillard@mos.org with your date of choice to be added.

Hazardous Materials may become hazardous waste through use, spills, chemical expiration, abandonment, etc. This session will provide information about how to minimize the generation of hazardous waste and how to properly manage the waste in accordance with state and federal regulations.

Proper management of Universal Waste (i.e. bulbs, batteries) and E-Waste (electronics) will also be covered in these training sessions.

If you have any questions regarding this training or the MOS Hazardous Waste Program please do not hesitate to contact me.

Best regards,

Christina Dillard | Environmental Health & Safety (EHS) Program Manager

Museum of Science  | Facilities Dept.  |  One  Science Park  |  Boston, MA 02114-1099

P 617-589-4249 | F 617-589-0101 |M 781-789-1178| cdillard@mos.org  |  www.mos.org

For those who travel by air, please be aware that beginning October 1, 2020, travelers who are 18 years of age and older will need a REAL ID or another acceptable form of identification in order to fly. 

Standard drivers’ licenses will no longer be accepted by TSA at airport security checkpoints.  

REAL IDs are generally marked by a star on the top of the card. Between now and the effective date of the new regulations, it is encouraged that you check your IDs and obtain a REAL ID if you don’t already have one.

To obtain a REAL ID, please keep in mind that it requires documentation beyond what is required for most standard drivers’ licenses. Prepare to collect and present several documents to DMV officials that prove your residency and identification.

REAL ID compliance varies greatly from state to state. Travelers should seek information directly from the TSA at www.tsa.gov/real-id or their local DMV.

docs.messageSubject: New Website - Content Freeze Starting February 15
docs.messageBody:
Hi everyone,
 
As you know, the Web Dev and Marketing teams have been working behind the scenes to bring you the first phase of a brand new www.mos.org, during the week of March 2, 2020.
 
In going with the new launch, we wanted to let you know about some upcoming milestones:
 
January 31 – Final day for submission for routine page updates, changes, vanity url creation, & new pages on the website until March 2.

What this means: If you know you will need new web pages or changes to existing web pages between now and March 6, please submit them before Friday, January 31.  If you submit them between Feb 1 and Feb 14, we can’t guarantee, your changes will be made.
 
February 1 through Feb 14 – Web Dev team will be busy getting all those last minute changes & updates on the site as well putting the finishing touches on the new pages.

What this means: If you submitted your web requests before January 31, you will see them on the website.
 
February 15 through the week of March 2 – There will be no updates to www.mos.org.  During this time, we will be migrating the old website into the new website.  Because of this activity, we will not be able to make updates to anything on the current www.mos.org.

What this means: We will not be making any changes to the website or posting any new items.
 
Week of March 2 – New website will be live!*

What this means: You will see a new homepage this week and some other fancy new designs.
 
*Please note: not all pages will look “new” on this date.  We are working on a schedule for the remaining pages to be converted to the new designs.
 
This only effects www.mos.org.  It does not affect the Hub, wifi, or other computer/software business needs. 
 
Should you have any questions or concerns, please do not hesitate to reach out to Michelle Briand and Kim Cho if you have any questions.

During this maintenance window you may experience brief outages where servers, business applications, and or files may not be accessible both internally and externally.  To ensure uptime and stability of our platform, we are performing this upgrade shortly after close of business so we can maximize our efforts to ensure business operations will not be impacted when we open the next day.  

If you have any questions or concerns please contact the Service Desk team at x0130.

docs.messageSubject: Summer Courses On-Sale Date for Staff
docs.messageBody:
The Museum’s Summer Courses will go on sale to museum members on Thursday January 23 at 9am. If you are a staff member, you will be able to register with Science Central beginning Wednesday January 22. 

The discounted fee for staff is $255 per half day 1 week course ($510 for a full day). In order to register please call Science Central on Wednesday at 617-723-2500 or x7993 from within the museum.

As many of you know, our Summer Course Program is very popular, capacity is limited and many courses sell out quickly. Because of this, you may only register early a child for whom you are a parent or guardian . Unfortunately we cannot extend early registration beyond your immediate family. Additionally, you are welcome to register participants for an available course at any time after registration officially opens on January 23. 

To recap:
• Courses will go on sale early to Museum Staff (Wed Jan 23 )
• Register by calling Science Central (617-723-2500 or x7993)
• Fee is $255 for a half day $510 for a full day
• Early registration is for immediate family members ONLY (ie. children for whom you are a parent or guardian)
• Once courses officially go on sale staff may register based on availability. To receive the discount you must order by phone. 

Please visit the Summer Courses Web Page for more information: www.mos.org/courses

We are revamping the Lyman Library collection to be more reflective of the work happening across the building. I’ve begun weeding older titles in order to make room for new texts that better match our initiatives, both within and beyond our walls.

School and Youth Programs is hosting the High School Science Series: The Road to Carbon Neutrality, today, Thursday January 23, 2020. Please contact Hannah Yaeger at hyaeger@mos.org or X4242 with any questions.

docs.messageSubject: Emergency Out of Band Network Maintenance Window Tonight 1/23/20 @ 6:30pm
docs.messageBody:
Information Technology needs to perform emergency maintenance in our data center tonight beginning at 6:30pm, shortly after the box office closes.  During this time we will be shutting down several servers while we work with an outside vendor to address an issue we are having with our production virtual environment.  

What Does This Mean?
Information Technology will be turning off impacted machines after we get the okay from the box office that they are closed for the night.  During our outage window, we are working with an outside vendor to address any issues should they arise and access to server and system resources may be limited.  
 
What Can I Expect When This Takes Effect?
Do not panic!  All file access to Zeus and email (hosted in the cloud with Microsoft) will still be available during this maintenance window.  Our main website, www.mos.org, will also be up (with appropriate messaging for visitors).    

What Do I Need To Do?
Information Technology will be contacting impacted end users to let them know to close out of system applications that could be impacted by this maintenance.  As always, if you have any questions or issues, please contact our service desk, System Support Services, at ithelp@mos.org or call x0130.  You can also submit a request online.

docs.messageSubject: Emergency Out of Band Network Maintenance Window Tonight 1/27/20 @ 8:30pm
docs.messageBody:
Good afternoon,

Information Technology needs to perform emergency maintenance in our data center tonight beginning at 8:30pm to patch a bug in our redundant firewall devices.  During this time we will be performing a code upgrade with an outside vendor to address an issue we are having with our network connectivity.  

What Does This Mean?
Information Technology will be taking down the network tonight at 8:30pm for a minimum 4 hour window.  During our outage window, we are working with an outside vendor to address any issues should they arise and access to server, system, and network resources will be limited and intermittent (This includes Zeus and Tessitura).  VPN into the building will also be impacted while our firewalls are updated one at a time.
 
What Can I Expect When This Takes Effect?
Do not panic!  Email (hosted in the cloud with Microsoft) will still be available during this maintenance window to external users.  Our main website, www.mos.org, will also be up (with appropriate messaging for visitors).    

What Do I Need To Do?
Information Technology would like all users to close out of all system applications and files before leaving for the night.   At the close of our maintenance window we will send an update to staff. As always, if you have any questions or issues, please contact our service desk, System Support Services, at ithelp@mos.org or call x0130.  You can also submit a request online.

Regards,

Angela

Our post tasks have finished successfully, and all systems and network resources should be back up at this time.  If you have any questions or issues tomorrow, please contact our service desk, System Support Services, at ithelp@mos.org  or call x0130.

Angela

A Retirement Planner from Fidelity Investments, Derek Cunningham, will be coming to the Museum on Wednesday, February 5th to deliver financial wellness presentations at 10AM and 3PM in the Engineer's Enclave. He will also hold individual meetings with any staff who are interested.

If you are interested in having a personal financial consultation with Derek, please email me to schedule your appointment.

10:00 AM Presentation Topics include:
•	Museum of Science 403(b) Plan Basics
•	Principles of Budgeting and Saving
•	The Fundamentals of Investing
•	Asset Allocation and Investment Strategies

3:00PM Presentation Topics include:
•	Social Security and Medicare Basics
•	Principles of Financial Planning
•	Principles of Income Planning

To get to the Engineer’s Enclave, go down the concourse towards the garage and then take the elevator or stairs to the 2nd level landing. You will need to use your Museum badge to the left of the glass reception door in order to gain access, and the Engineer’s Enclave is straight ahead.

Please note that effective 1/1/2020, the IRS mileage rate has been decreased to 57½ cents per mile.  Travel you undertake for the Museum in 2020 will be reimbursed at that rate.
 
(If you have any as yet unsubmitted Travel Vouchers or Petty Cash slips for travel you did in 2019, those will be reimbursed at the old 58 cent rate that applied at that time.)
