Internal Job Postings

Paid staff positions will be posted internally for five (5) business days to give internal applicants priority during the recruitment process, in support of the Museum’s Affirmative Action Plan. All positions accepting internal applications can be found on our Internal Employment Opportunities page.

To apply, simply click on the position title below and complete the online application. If internal staff apply after the position is posted externally, they will not be considered as a candidate because they did not apply during the internal posting period.

At this time, the below listings are actively accepting internal applications:

Senior Network Engineer

The Senior Network Engineer is responsible for the design, installation, configuration, and maintenance of the voice data and network infrastructure. Primary responsibilities include network architecture and security, monitoring and intrusion prevention, capacity planning, disaster recovery planning and monitoring of all network performance activities. This position routinely configures and maintains physical and logical network components, and works closely with other team members and departments but also works independently in solving technical integration issues, outages and security risks. Respect for the importance and confidentiality of the information encountered is essential to the success of this position.

Deadline for Internal Applicants: 2/6/20

This position is full-time, 40 hours/week, Monday-Friday.

docs.messageSubject: Please submit your web requests by EOD, Friday, Jan 31
docs.messageBody:
Hi everyone,

As you know, the Web Dev and Marketing teams have been working behind the scenes to bring you the first phase of a brand new www.mos.org, during the week of March 2, 2020.

In going with the new launch, we wanted to let you know about some upcoming milestones:

January 31 – Final day for submission for routine page updates, changes, vanity url creation, & new pages on the website until March 2.

What this means: If you know you will need new web pages or changes to existing web pages between now and March 6, please submit them before Friday, January 31. If you submit them between Feb 1 and Feb 14, we can’t guarantee, your changes will be made.

February 1 through Feb 14 – Web Dev team will be busy getting all those last minute changes & updates on the site as well putting the finishing touches on the new pages.

What this means: If you submitted your web requests before January 31, you will see them on the website.

February 15 through the week of March 2 – There will be no updates to www.mos.org. During this time, we will be migrating the old website into the new website. Because of this activity, we will not be able to make updates to anything on the current www.mos.org.

What this means: We will not be making any changes to the website or posting any new items.

Week of March 2 – New website will be live!*

What this means: You will see a new homepage this week and some other fancy new designs.

*Please note: not all pages will look “new” on this date. We are working on a schedule for the remaining pages to be converted to the new designs.

This only effects www.mos.org. It does not affect the Hub, wifi, or other computer/software business needs.

Should you have any questions or concerns, please do not hesitate to reach out to Michelle Briand and Kim Cho if you have any questions.

Our next Electronic waste pickup is scheduled for Tuesday Febraury 11, 2020.  If you have any equipment that needs to be disposed of, please let me know via email. 

Thanks, 
Yessie

docs.messageSubject: Welcome to Tim Ritchie, the Museum’s New President!
docs.messageBody: On February 3, Tim Ritchie will officially start his tenure as our new Museum president. You may have had the chance to meet him during his visits to the Museum over the last six weeks but if not, you will. Tim is eager to get to know you all and learn more about your role and contribution in making our Museum the best it can be. As we near his official arrival, I wanted to share with you some clips of an interview with Tim that we captured when he visited in December. We asked him about his background, how he sees the role of science centers overall, what he’s looking forward to most about being at the Museum of Science, and of course what his favorite sports team is. I invite you to have a look at these as a way to get to know Tim and to learn about what drives him in leading our institution. You can find all the videos here on our website. I also wanted to remind you of our all staff welcoming for Tim from 3:00pm – 5:00pm on Tuesday February 4th. In order to ensure we all have an opportunity to attend this important event, the Museum will close at 2:45pm that day. The event will start with an all-staff meeting in Cahners Theater at 3:00pm followed by a reception in the Blue Wing. I invite you all to join me in welcoming Tim to the Museum of Science! Wayne Bouchard

•	What: Natural Science Lunch with Nicole Merullo, Ed Associate in the Hall of Human Life
•	When & Where:  February 6th , 1-2 in the ERC 
•	Topic of Interest: Primates are human's closest relatives, but most of us know very little about who they are and how they live. The field of Primatology attracts researchers from all different corners of biology to answer questions about behavior, ecology, evolution and taxonomy of non-human primates. In particular, studying primates helps us learn about ourselves and our impact on the environment.

docs.messageSubject: Coleslaw's Corner & Other Adult Programs GSEs!
docs.messageBody: We have had a GSE spot for this Thursday's Coleslaw's Corner open up. If you have the availability, please consider signing up. You won't want to miss this all-new drag performance in the dome of the Planetarium. Fusing together elements of theater, live music, poetry, cutting-edge video projection, and more, this truly one-of-a-kind drag experience invites you to join Coleslaw's journey as she travels through microcosms in search of wisdom. We also have GSE spots open for other upcoming Adult Programs events: On March 5, Dutch ReBelle returns to the Planetarium for a unique live performance. ReBelle earned national attention early on with electrifying performances at SXSW, A3C and the Brooklyn Hip-Hop festival. Publications like XXL noted ReBelle “spearheading her way into blogs because of her poetic style…lyrical bravado…and fiery talent.” On March 10, CLTX Gaming, the NBA 2K League affiliate of the Boston Celtics will present eGaming: CLTX Gaming Fan-fest, an exclusive event that fans of sports egaming fans will have the chance to play a special league-build of NBA 2K not accessible anywhere else except for the immersive world of the Planetarium! On March 12, we will be hosting a ReelAbilities Film Festival Preview Screening of Picture of His Life with an immersive viewing in the Planetarium to celebrate the festival's upcoming lineup. Plus many other chances to help throughout the rest of our winter/spring 2020 season!

docs.messageSubject: UltiPro Update - Employee Directory & Org Chart
docs.messageBody:
We have recently turned on two new features in UltiPro! You are now able to access an Employee Directory and a Museum wide Organizational Chart. These features pull information straight from UltiPro, and is a real time reflection of what is in the system.

1. Employee Directory: Allows you to search for staff members in a variety of ways. You will then be able to access someone’s job title, phone number, extension, and email with one search. UltiPro also lets you customize how you would like to see staff information on the Employee Directory page.

 

2. Organization Chart: The organization chart in UltiPro shows all employees in the Museum by supervisor. The graphic will start with your position. You are able to zoom out to see where you fall within the institution or use the search feature to find a specific supervisor or employee.

How to Access and Use The Employee Directory:

  1. Log into UltiPro
  2. Select the “Menu” icon in the top left corner of the page
  3. Select “Employee Directory” under “My Company”
  4. Search for the employee you are looking for (you can adjust the filters, by adjusting the “Find By”)

How to Access and Use The Organization Chart:

  1. Log into UltiPro
  2. Select the “Menu” icon in the top left of the page
  3. Select “Organization Chart” under “My Company”
  4. This will bring you to your position within the organization
  5. Use your scroll on your mouse to zoom out – click a supervisor to drill down on their reports
  6. If you would like to search for a specific staff member or supervisor, use the search box

If you have any questions on how to access these new features, please email ultipro@mos.org or call Lorah Broderick x0122

Join us for an afternoon Coffee Talk tomorrow, Wednesday, February 5th from 3:30-4:00 PM in Hornblower to hear from Ryan Auster and Alex Lussenhop in Research and Evaluation about the museum’s COVES initiative.

The Museum of Science has been collecting public visitor demographics and experience data since 2009, but since 2016, we’ve had the ability to compare our results with other museums through the Collaboration for Ongoing Visitor Experience Studies (COVES). Today, over 30 museums across North America collect and compare visitor experience and demographic data. During this Coffee Talk, Ryan and Alex will share Museum of Science data from FY19 and share how we fit in to the bigger picture.

docs.messageSubject: Internal Youth Job: Research and Science Communication Assistant
docs.messageBody:
Internal Job Postings

Paid staff positions will be posted internally for five (5) business days to give internal applicants priority during the recruitment process, in support of the Museum’s Affirmative Action Plan. All positions accepting internal applications can be found on our Internal Employment Opportunities page.

To apply, simply click on the position title below and complete the online application. If internal staff apply after the position is posted externally, they will not be considered as a candidate because they did not apply during the internal posting period.

At this time, the below listings are actively accepting internal applications:

Research and Science Communication Assistant

The Research and Science Communication Assistant (RSCA) will work closely with small teams of peers, under collaborative mentorship from Boston University researchers and Museum of Science staff, to engage families in learning about current research topics as part of their museum visit. The RSCA will complete training in experimental psychology research methods, science education strategies and science communication practices, with a focus on the science of child development. The Research and Science Communication Assistant will develop skills related to designing and conducting a child development research study, including those needed to develop and execute a research protocol, analyze data, and present research findings for both public and professional audiences. They will gain practical experience through direct interaction with the public, including recruiting museum visitors to participate in studies, collecting data, and talking with families about study questions, methods and implications. The RSCA will also engage museum visitors in learning about research topics by facilitating small group activities for families, as well as developing and prototyping educational products such as hands-on activities and caregiver handouts for use in the Museum.

Deadline for Internal Applicants:February 11, 2020

This position is grant-funded, part-time. 3 days per week, 21 hours/week total, from mid-June to September 2020 1 day per week, 7 hours/week total, from September to mid-June 2021

With Dogs: A Science Tail opening on Sunday, this is a good time to remind everyone of the Museum’s Service Animal Policy. Please let me know if you have any questions.

Only service animals, as defined by the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA)(42 USC §12101 et. seq.), are allowed in the Museum building. This means no pets, emotional support animals or therapy animals are allowed. Any individual can request a reasonable accommodation to any museum policy. 
 
Under the ADA, places of public accommodation are only permitted to ask the following questions of an individual seeking admission with a service animal:
1) “Is this a service animal required because of a disability?”
2) “What work or task has this animal been trained to perform?”
 
The Museum has determined that these questions can only be asked by public safety staff in public areas of the building, and by visitors services staff at gated entry points (EH gates, Omni, Planetarium, Discovery Center). Once a visitor has entered a paid area of the museum, a person with a service animal should not be asked about it. This is to avoid well-meaning staff and volunteers from approaching the same visitor multiple times during their visit. If a volunteer, staff person or visitor sees a service animal behaving inappropriately anywhere in the museum, they should contact public safety immediately.
 
Definitions/additional information
 
The ADA defines service animals as dogs or miniature horses, individually trained to provide assistance to a person with a disability. The service that the animal provides must be directly related to the person’s disability.
 
There are requirements that a service animal handler must follow:
1) The animal must be leashed, tethered or harnessed, unless these devices interfere with the animal’s work, or the individual’s disability prevents them from using these devices.
2) The animal must be under the handler’s control at all times.
3) The animal must be housebroken.
If a service animal is out of control or disruptive, the handler can be asked to remove the animal, but must be offered the opportunity to return without the animal. 
 
MGL Ch. 129 §39F extends all of the rights that the ADA confers on service animal handlers to individuals TRAINING service animals in Massachusetts. This means that people coming in to train service dogs cannot be refused. The dogs can be very young, but are still expected to be under control and housebroken.

docs.messageSubject: Guests bringing animals to the Museum
docs.messageBody:
To ensure that the Museum is complying with accessibility standards regarding service animals, providing a welcoming experience for our guests who are accompanied by service animals, and minimizing the number of times that guests may be asked about their service animals the Museum has set the following procedures:
 
Only trained staff at access control points (entry to exhibit halls, Discovery Center, Omni Theater, and Planetarium) may ask if an animal is a service animal.
 
If any staff or volunteers see a guest with an animal they strongly suspect is NOT a service animal, they should NOT approach the guest. Instead, they should alert Public Safety with a location and a description.
 
If any staff or volunteers see an animal behaving inappropriately or creating problems for other visitors, they should alert Public Safety with a location and a description.
 
Please remember that:
Service dogs come in all sizes and many breeds.
Service dogs perform many different services for their owners, many of which are not obvious.
Service animals may even be miniature horses.
Service animals DO NOT need to have identifying vests or tags
You MAY NOT ask what the guest’s disability is.
You MAY NOT ask for proof that an animal is a service animal.
Service animals in training are treated as service animals under Massachusetts laws.

If you would like further information about service animals, contact Nora Nagle, x3102

Activities occurring Sunday, February 16th through Saturday, February 22nd include:

- Hoop Glider, Paper Bridge, or Spinning Top engineering activities in the Discovery Center

January 2020 Comment Cards

"had a Chicken caesar pesto wrap today for lunch - thought it was a caesar salad wrap but it was all chicken no lettuce at all.  Way toooo much chicken"

"I am very disappointed in the anti-customer nature of your vending machines, which essentially have stolen my money, and I'm sure the money of many other visitors.  At the vending machine near the trash bins next to the dining area behind the cafe, I put a dollar in without looking at the prices, assuming my $1.25 would be enough to get something.  I was wrong, as the cheapest item was $1.55.
My first complaint is that items being priced at $1.55 is ridiculous.  Not only is that way too expensive for the items on offer, it also brings in the need for small coin change where there should not be.  Just price it at $1.50 if you feel the need to price gouge, don't add the extra nickel just because you can.
My second complaint is what happened after I realized my dollar wouldn't be enough.  I hit the cancel button on the machine, expecting to get my dollar back, or at least coins worth the same amount.  But instead, I was greeted with the lovely message ""No change given unless purchase made"".  I tried a number of different buttons trying to cancel it and get my money back, but nothing worked.  Essentially, this vending machine held my money ransom to try and force me into a purchase I literally could not afford to make.  I don't care about losing one dollar, it won't make me go hungry.  But this needs to be changed."

"There is an exhibit piece on the lower level that is a disc of fluid, you are encouraged to spin it to observe eddies and fluid dynamics. It is beautiful. I would like to know what the fluid is inside it."

"Megan & Sarah were two presenters today (top science/space stories of 2019, Electricity Theater). They did an excellent job and are always a pleasure to watch. I've seen them several times & always look fwd to it."

"Sarah who presented top 10 space stories and Meghan who presented top 10 science stories were both fantastic. My whole family has enjoyed their science talks each time we've come in the past few years. They speak clearly and specifically, obviously well versed in their areas, on top pf good stage presence."

"The lockers are unnecessarily expensive :("

"I received a phone call from a guest today who wished me to relay their concerns about their visit to the appropriate parties.  They first wanted to note that our staff had been very kind and welcoming for most of their visit.  However, their experience with the Discovery Center line did not match the rest of their day.  They said that they approached the Discovery Center agent around 3:30pm.  That staff member was chatting with a friend when they approached.  They asked if the Discovery Center was indeed full.  They felt the response of 'It’s at capacity according to the sign' was delivered in a curt manner and were dismayed when the agent returned directly to their conversation with the friend."

"There were no times on the door of the educator library so now I have to come back because I was lacking that info you needed to provide. Closing at 3:30 is hard for teachers availability."

"I visited the museum yesterday with my 2 year old daughter and Anna in the Discovery Center was ABSOLUTELY FANTASTIC with the kids. She engaged my toddler in learning about bones. I am so excited we decided to join the museum as a family this year! Just had to relay our awesome experience :)"

"I spent $140 on a membership & $25+ on a show and you also try to squeeze money from me for a coat check?!! Really !?? I am extremely unlikely to renew my membership."

"My family and I visited the museum. We had tickets to see the body world exhibit and then tickets to visit the science museum after. However, soon after entering the body world exhibit (approximately 5 - 10 minutes), my son fainted and we had to leave the exhibit and the nice staff there called the medic asking for water and an ice pack. Unfortunately, the medic was not much help and did not bring either of those two items requested. The only help that was offered to us was the call to the medic. My niece and I ended up walking through the body world exhibit very quickly while my son and my fiancé stayed outside to rest after the episode. We ended up leaving the museum right after the quick walk through and did not visit the science museum. I was not going to comment on the incident because I am not much of a complainer. However, I was quite disappointed in the medic and the overall lack of help that we were given. I thought that maybe by sharing our visit that this issue could be addressed so that another family that is in the same situation receives much better care and compassion than we received. Thank you for listening."

"Recently I visit with my family the Museum of Science MA. The museum needs a good renovation. Most of the collections are old and if you compare with other museums of science around the world it`s poor. Plus the price of the tickets is too expensive for those old collections. Thank you and a Happy New Year!"

"Need Signs going into the Parking area is a nightmare there is no or little signage & people fight to turn in. You need a traffic light too"

"We came to see the exhibit, and the parking garage was closed at 12:05 pm. The public safety staff just said ""It's closed"" 3 times when I asked ""why"" and ""for how long."" It cost me over an hour of my very precious 3 hour visit. So rude!"

"Please place signs in museum for easier navigation. The bod exhibit is extremely difficult to find"

"Aloha, I was excited to hear a 'plug' for MoS on NPR!  My wife is an International Bachelorette high school math teacher.  Dinner time discussions with our three children bring out many great ideas, which is why I am contacting you today.  My background in architecture coupled with my work as a bicycle instructor led me 6 years ago to become the USA agent for a German bike company solely for children.  Over these years of working with many schools within the USA to bring cycling to the youngest riders, focused on the 2 to 8 year olds,  I discovered how cycling can explain many scientific principles.  These include motion, momentum, energy in to energy out, how we eat, and on and on ever expanding like a DNA molecule.  All the while, the bike, especially the running bike  by KOKUA LIKEaBIKE, is a great tool for this discussion and experimentation.  I don't have a direct 'ask' beyond wanting to start a discussion with a science based learning center such as MoS about how we might work together to bring a FUN, HEALTHY, LEARNING activity for children and parents of young children.  The closest example I have experience with is yearly balance bike rodeo at the Honolulu Museum of Art. I really hope that we could have a conversation.  With sincere aloha."

"Please start serving chicken and waffles in the cafe. Thank you!"

"This comment does not pertain to a museum visit, but rather to an email exchange with Jeremy at the MoS.  I had tickets for Saturday evening's planetarium shows when my date became ill at the last minute. I wrote to the Info email address asking whether the tickets could be used at a future date. I received a reply from Jeremy within minutes.  He asked when I would like to attend the shows and reissued the tickets. It was all very fast and professional.  It's not very often that one has such a high-quality experience with customer service in this world.  Kudos to both Jeremy and the MoS!"	

"awesome museum but one of the skulls didnt have a name next to the [illegible] in exhibit w/ the polar bear I think"

" A member wanted to let us know that they are canceling one step renewal because of the Globe article. Their comment was that they were dismayed to hear that we aggressively market one-step renewals and other items."


"British Steve in the Science Lab is absolutely amazing. filled w/ knowledge and helped our crew of 8 test conductivity, density, etc
The BEST!!"

"The Hands-On Lab is the highlight of our visit every time we come!"

" What do you think about providing an electronic membership card, for apple and android smartphones - Apple wallet, for instance? It would be better for the environment, and also more convenient than carrying a card around. There might even be a cost savings if you did not have to pay for the cards to be made and mailed. 
Thanks for considering!"

"I visited the museum yesterday with my family and we had a wonderful time! We went to the Lightning show (I believe it was @ 2pm), and I would like to offer a suggestion. At the beginning, there was a 'zap the kids' part. And, unfortunately, one of the kids reacted badly to it and had a hard time recovering. My suggestion is instead to 'zap the parents'. I realize it's probably great to get the kids involved, but I can tell you -- if my kids saw their Dad get zapped on stage, it would be hilarious for them! I think it would also be less variable, doing that with adults instead of kids. Thank you for your consideration!"

"At a recent visit, I interacted with your 'Hall of Human Life' exhibit.  This exhibit solicits a significant amount of data from visitors, some of it deeply personal, and I was wondering:
1.  What is your data retention policy - how long do you maintain the data?
2.  For what purposes is the data utilized?  Is it part of ongoing research and, if so, which research?  Is there an IRB involved?
As you no doubt know, de-identified data can often be easily de-anonymized, and I am thus looking for more information on how you protect your visitors' personal data."

"We came to the museum today and were surprised at how dirty the exhibits for kids to participate in were. The exhibit about the river where the fish tanks are.
There are activities for kids to build bridges and one with floating weights. The water had a terrible odor, was yellow with things floating inside. It is obvious the water has not been changed in a long time. If kids or anyone is playing with stagnant water it needs to be changed daily otherwise people are going to get sick.
I was very disappointed in the poor upkeep and lack of basic sanitation."

"We have visited many times. This time we were very disappointed. There were a few area closed for new attractions coming. As I understand I also feel that for the price and having a few areas closed was quite a turn off. Also the water in the Charles River exhibit was very disgusting. It was very clouded with lots of floaters. The smell from the water was horrible. Also one was yellow. I feel like this is a health hazard in a way. I refused to let my daughter play in it."

" We visited MOS and choose to get our grandchildren to the Planetarium, hoping they will learn more about the stars and planets. Instead, 70% of the show was about learning Chinese and how great the China is. Why I agree that the Chinese culture is rich and old, this was not the right place to advertise it and cultural propaganda! Moreover, it was misleading to promise a show about stars and serve the kids something else. I would like to have cost of the tickets refunded or have issued new tickets   (for 6 of us) for other shows, except Planetarium (at least until the show will be about planets and stars). "

"A member called today at 10:20. She wanted to see if any spaces had become available for a couple of courses that she tried to sign up for at 9am. Those courses were full. The member was in tears. She wanted us to share that She felt that it was unfair that spaces could become full when a member so clearly tried to sign up at the start of sign-ups. She also wanted to let us know that she may be calling to get a refund for a course that she was able to book and that she may wish to ask for a refund of her membership."

"I noted that in your mineral exhibit you have a beryl from Royalston, Ma. This is a particulary valuable specimen which should be protected and not accessable easily."

"I just renewed my membership with the idea that I would be able to enjoy my two extra Omni pass tickets. When I look on the web site where it shows what passes I have, it shows that the extra passes were added to my last year's total. Seeing how my last year's membership expires on 3/31/2020 and the fact that the Omni theater is not reopening until Spring 2020 which I assume could be after 3/31 it looks like I will not be able to use the extra passes. I would have assumed that the extra passes would have been put on next year's membership. Thank you."

"Why isn't the coatroom open? It is winter! I expected this service to be available especially after paying for a family membership."

"We are big fans of the museum and have been members for the past few years.  We visited the Bodies section and my almost 5-year-old son was very intrigued by the exhibit of the big sneezing nose - there are 2 yellow balls representing pollen that you put into the nostrils of a giant nose, then you press a button and the nose sneezes them out.  Unfortunately, last night he tried to simulate what he saw by putting a small toy part into his nose and trying to sneeze it out.  The toy part got stuck and we had to go to urgent care for a doctor to take it out.  It was traumatic for him (he had to be put in a straight jacket-like contraption because he was struggling so much) and horrible for me to watch.  I hope the museum will reconsider this exhibit - perhaps put a warning sign to not attempt this on yourself (I never even thought of warning him because he's never shown any interest in putting foreign objects up his orifices) or adjust the exhibit somehow.  It just does not seem like a good idea for an exhibit to suggest kids put things into noses..."

"When does the dog exhibit end?  I've had this problem before with your website.  It's great to know when an exhibit opens, but if I can't go then or am going on vacation, etc., I'd like to be able to know when the exhibit ends so that i can make plans."

"I have a 7th grader who is very interested in the Science on Screen summer program that is offered to grades 3-5 this summer (July 3-7th). Is there any chance that Science on Screen can be offered for middle school kids during this week this summer? It would be a fantastic experience for middle schoolers interested in creating stop motion."

"I wanted to reach out after spending an awesome day at the museum with you all. Overall, we had a great experience. The students were really invested in the exhibits, and everyone at the museum was super friendly!
I did want to reach out regarding one of the demos in the Exciting Energy show. One of the demos shown involved the demonstrator with a bullwhip. She explained the purpose of this as showing a transfer of energy into sound, or a 'sonic boom'. While I think the intent of this was to show a different example of energy transfer, I think the impact of this demo failed to recognize the historical significance and context of a bullwhip. Yes, bullwhips are used to herd cattle, but they were also used as instruments of torture and enslavement for hundreds of years. Several students exited the show discussing connections they had to history class in terms of slavery, and some students were quite disturbed by this. Given the fact that you welcome students of African American descent on a daily basis, I would encourage you to consider a different demo for this show. If bullwhips are the only instrument available that produces this, it seems that it is not really that relevant to be sharing with students anyways. 
I look forward to hearing how you will address this concern."

Colleagues,

I wanted to fill you in on an action our team has taken in response to a comment we received last week regarding a demonstration in which a bullwhip was used to describe the transfer of energy and the “sonic boom”. The comment suggested that the demonstration could be a triggering action for some, and we couldn’t agree more. We have unanimously decided to stop the use of that demonstration in any of our education programs onsite or in the community.

The gift of comment cards and constructive dialogue, as demonstrated by this comment, tells us that even with our best intentions we can always learn from our community on how we can grow our offerings to be consistent with our values and our complete commitment to being a welcoming community space to all.

Our decision to remove that demonstration active immediately was taken in direct alignment with our values that all are welcome and our programs, facilities, exhibits all need to reflect that value.

Each of us interacts with school groups, each of us cares about making sure that all are welcome here at the museum so I wanted to share this action taken to ensure that you all know our commitment to that value. It’s important to hear from our visitors in all of their comments but in instances such as this, it is equally important to hear about the action taken to resolve it.

I welcome any further conversation. Please feel free to drop by or email me.

docs.messageSubject: "Building Our Museum" - New Temporary Exhibit Opening This Weekend!
docs.messageBody:
In light of all of the exciting transformation and construction happening around the Museum of Science, we will be featuring an internally-developed temporary exhibit that showcases large-scale images from our archives! 
The exhibit, titled "Building Our Museum: The Making of Science Park", will be on display in the "Blue Wing, Level 2" gallery (internally called the Art & Science Gallery, and where Thomas & Friends was most recently on display). 
It will open this Saturday, February 15, and will close Sunday, May 10.

The images in the exhibit highlight some iconic elements of the Museum, including the installation of the original and current T. rex in the Blue Wing, the original construction of the OMNI and Planetarium, and some incredible aerial shots of Science Park over the past several decades (and shown here is an image of the Blue Wing!)

This exhibit aims to not only call attention to past construction around the Museum, but also highlight some of the current construction projects and future plans, encouraging visitors to imagine what they might want our our building to look like. In addition to the incredible images from our building's history, we're incorporating a couple low-tech interactive elements: a magnetic-wall interactive where visitors can create their own MOS-layout with various components, and Imagination Playground's Blue Blocks (you may have come across these at other museums and schools). This exhibit came together extremely quickly, and we're excited to be able to learn more about how visitors might use this space and these low-tech interactive elements.


If you have any questions, please feel free to reach out to me at x4456 or gfo@mos.org

docs.messageSubject: Natural Science Lunch with Lee McIntyre 3/5 @ 1 PM in ERC
docs.messageBody: Upcoming Natural Science Lunch with Lee McIntyre, BU Professor of History & Philosophy of Science.  Dr. McIntyre's books include The Scientific Attitude: Defending Science from Denial, Fraud and Pseudoscience, and Post Truth: How we arrived in a post-truth era, when "alternative facts" replace actual facts, and feelings have more weight than evidence. Save the date for this intriguing presentation and conversation about science communication in our current cultural climate.

docs.messageSubject: What’s your favorite Museum of Science memory?
docs.messageBody:
As part of our annual Pi Day of Giving, we are launching the campaign with a digital memory wall. 

Most people first came to the Museum of Science as children. You may be one of them. And for some children, perhaps even you, the Museum impacted their lives and careers! For everyone who comes here, though, the Museum tends to create memorable moments. 

We encourage you to read others’ favorite memories and hopes for the future, and then share yours. Visit www.mos.org/memories for more information!

Greetings all,

By now, hopefully you have all seen the boxes for the 13th Annual Boston Bruins PJ Drive done in collaboration with Cradles to Crayons.  There is one box in the Gordon Wing by the bathrooms and one in the 5th floor mail room.  The drive runs until March 15.  To find out more info about the drive: https://www.cradlestocrayons.org/boston/bruins-pj-drive/ 

Why pajamas??  Pajamas have always been one of my favorite items to donate to charity and they are highly sought after by charitable groups.  Having a pair of pajamas gives a feeling of comfort and home even if they are living in a shelter.  Changing into pajamas is a demarcation for when night has arrived and it signals that it is time to sleep.  Pajamas can be fun and allow children to express themselves in ways that their clothes may not.

What kind??  Winter, summer, spring, fall.  Any season!  Boys, girls, gender neutral.  Size Newborn - Adult M.  Don't forget the big kids too.

Where to get them??  This time of year, winter pajamas are on sale!  You can go to Walmart, Target, Kohls, etc (or online like me!) and get Pjs for kids at $5 or less!  

Let's fill up those boxes!!!

Join Lee McIntyre, Author & Research Fellow @ BU, for a Natural Science Lunch in the ERC.  Open to all MoS employees.
""It is incredible but true that in an era when facts have never been more available, science denial is on the rise. But is this due to a lack of scientific evidence, or because science deniers embrace a number of myths about scientific reasoning? In this talk I will discuss what I believe to be really distinctive about science -- which is not its logic or its method, but the attitude of its practitioners -- and show how this can be used to fight back against science deniers. Research has shown that push back against science deniers can be effective, with face to face encounters perhaps the most effective of all. In addition to discussing this research, I will share some details of my own recent visit to the Flat Earth International Conference, where I tried out some of these techniques in person."

Wicked High Tides forum on Sea Level Rise needs one more table facilitator for the night! 

More about the GSE: 
Keep the conversation surrounding a current socio-scientific topic going by facilitating a table at this forum at the museum!

Each table will be made up of 8-10 members of the general public, and experts will be on hand throughout the night to help out with any content-specific questions. The GSE's job is to guide their table through discussions (making sure each person is given a fair opportunity to participate) using a facilitator guide and deliberation materials. The facilitator is a neutral party in the discussion.

The forum is 3/3/2020 from 6:30-9pm with some prep time before. 

Contact kbaur@mos.org or sbenson@mos.org with any questions

With the opening of Dogs! A Science Tail, we've been seeing far more furry friends onsite than typical, and wanted to share some of the FAQs we've received so far.  

If you have any additional questions, please reach out to one of the following, and we can help answer your question or direct you to the right person to help answer your question: 

Grace Fo 
Nora Nagle
Sharon Horrigan
Jackie Peeler


Q1.
Why am I seeing more dogs in the building, garage, exhibit halls?

A.
We see service animals in the Museum almost every day. During the Dogs! A Science Tail exhibit, we have invited select organizations and individuals to partner with us to provide live education and interpretation. We are doing this in order to further the educational goals of the Museum during the run of the Dogs.

Q2. 
How are dogs being selected to participate in programs for the Dogs! exhibit?

A. 
The Dogs! A Science Tail ancillary education programming extends the learning goals of the exhibition with live dog presentations, demonstrations and educators that bring to life the exhibition themes and stories. The Museum of Science is proud to welcome community organizations such as Canine Companions for Independence, American Kennel Club, and Urban Hound along with other professionals trainers and owners. In the live demonstration area, Dog Park, Museum visitors will be invited to drop-in and have the opportunity to ask questions of trainers as well as watch demonstrations by service dogs, rescue dogs and more! Invited community members volunteer their time to help educate our visitors through conversations and demonstrations of their dogs’ amazing senses, training, and abilities. Participating dogs have suitable socialization and training to prepare them for community settings and active in breed, agility or obedience competitions and/or a service or therapy dog.  

Q3.
Does this conflict with our service animal policy?

A. 
No. These guest presenters and their animals must travel through the building in order to get to the presentation space in Nichols. They will be accompanied by Museum staff for the entire time that they are in the building. Only service animals are allowed in areas of the building (like the cafe or exhibit halls) without a Museum staff escort.

Q4.
What if I see a dog in the building that does not seem like a service dog, and is not accompanied by a staff member?

A. 
Please remember that:
-Service dogs come in all sizes and many breeds.
-Service dogs perform many different services for their owners, many of which are not obvious.
-Service animals DO NOT need to have identifying vests or tags.
-Service animals in training are treated as service animals under Massachusetts laws. 

Q5.
What if the dog that I see is misbehaving?

A.
Contact public safety at x0200 if you see a dog behaving inappropriately (eliminating, bothering other guests, destroying property of the Museum or of other guests, growling, behaving aggressively, etc.). Please give a description and location.
 
Q6.
Why does the Museum only allow service animals? 

A.
The Museum is following the Americans with Disabilities Act. This law requires all public places to allow trained services dogs, which are trained to do work or perform a task to assist a person with a disability, into their facilities. Other animals, like therapy dogs or emotional support animals are not covered by this law. The Museum does not allow other animals into the building in order to protect visitors, the Museum’s own live animals, Museum staff, volunteers, and property. 
 
Q7.
What is the difference between Service Animals, Therapy Animals and Emotional Support Animals?

A.
Please see the table attached.

docs.messageSubject: 2/27: Biotech & the Genetic Revolution High School Science Series
docs.messageBody: School and Youth Programs will be hosting the Biotech & the Genetic Revolution High School Science Series tomorrow, Thursday, February 27, 2020. There will be about 300 MA high school students and teachers exploring the powers and pitfalls of biotechnology. Want to learn more? Join us for the Keynote and/or Hands-on Activities! Hands-on Activities Blue Wing, Level 1, 10 AM - 12 PM BioBuilder Showcase- Local high school students will be showcasing their latest BioBuider projects. Only until 11 AM! Gingko BioWorks and BioBits- Use science tools and cell-free technology to learn the central dogma of molecular biology BosLab- Create your own fluorescent necklace and discover the impact of green fluorescent protein (GFP) on biology Building with Biology: Tech Tokens and Graffiti Wall- Decide which biotechnologies you would invest in and answer the question "How might synthetic biology change our lives?" Keynote Presentation Cahners Theater, 11 AM - 11:45 AM The Keynote will be lead by Dr. Natalie Kuldell. Dr. Kuldell is a member of the Biological Engineering faculty at MIT and leads BioBuilder, a nonprofit organization that inspires the next generation of innovators with authentic science and engineering. Please contact Meghan Carter at MCarter@mos.org or X0310 with any questions.

docs.messageSubject: New Dog Titles in the ERC
docs.messageBody:
Hi Everyone

In connection with the new exhibit “Dogs – A Science Tail,” I’ve added more canine texts to the library collection. You can find these titles and more using our Online Catalog: http://library.mos.org/
(While in the building, this link currently works only on desktops, not wireless devices - we're looking into the problem.)

I’m still working to provide museum staff with greater access to digital content. In the meantime, please feel free to utilize two existing avenues for online resources:

Gale Database Resources
https://www.galepages.com/mlin_b_musmsci
Museum staff have access to a variety of online databases (many provide full-text articles) via the MA Library Databases Network. Scroll down the page and check out which portals might work for. Be sure to look at Gale in Context: Science (toward the bottom right of the page).

Inter Library Loans
If you need an article or text, perhaps from a more obscure reference, we can usually obtain it for you via our ILL subscription. Just send an email to library@mos.org, with as much bibliographic details as you can provide, and typically I can turn around your request within a week.

As always, please let me know if you have ideas for other books that you’d like to see on our shelves.

Jeff Mehigan | Librarian, Educator Resource Center
Pronouns: he, him, his
William and Charlotte Bloomberg Science Education Center
Museum of Science | 1 Science Park | Boston, MA 02114
jmehigan@mos.org  / 617.589.0174
Please note my schedule is Wednesday, Thursday, and Saturday
